DOC.HEAD: Jurors In Salcido Trial Listen To His Taped Confession
DOC.TEXT: Ramon Salcido said in a statement played for jurors Thursday that anger and drugs sparked the rage that led him to kill seven people. ``I don't feel like I wanted to kill nobody ... I wanna have some beers, you know, and forget everything else. But wife's made me feel that (way) when she start, when she left me at home with my kids and take off,'' Ramon Salcido said in the two-hour tape that jurors followed with the help of a transcript. Salcido, 29, is being tried in San Mateo Superior Court for the murder of his wife, Angela, two of his daughters, his mother-in-law and her two daughters and a co-worker at the Grand Cru winery. He also faces three counts of attempted murder for attacks on a third daughter, another co-worker and the co-worker's wife. Salcido was arrested in his native Mexico four days after the April 14, 1989, slayings in Sonoma County. The trial was moved here because of extensive pre-trial publicity. In the taped statement Salcido made while being returned to California, he said he was angry with his wife because she had married him while pregnant with another man's child. He said he was angry at his mother-in-law for not telling him about the child's parentage and angry at his supervisor because he thought the man tried to have him fired. Defense attorney Marteen Miller concedes his client committed the crimes, but claims Salcido was not capable of planning the murders and therefore should not be convicted of first-degree murder or face the death penalty. Salcido had been an alcoholic since age 18 and had consumed three grams of cocaine and three bottles of champagne in the hours before the slayings, Miller claims. Prosecutor Peter Bumerts said the tape supports his contention the slayings were premeditated. ``Anybody that says `I decided to go kill my children because I was mad at my wife,' and then goes to a place where he will not be seen is not mentally impaired,'' Bumerts said. Near the end of the statement, when asked if he wants to add anything more, Salcido said the drug dealers who supplied him are partly responsible, claiming he would not have committed the attacks sober. Several times, Salcido expressed remorse, said he was scared and that he felt as though he were someone else. ``I'm ready to receive anything and everything you guys to do,'' he said. ``I don't feel like, I wanted to try not being guilty when I know, I know that I'm guilty.''

DOC.HEAD: GED Test Developer Dies
DOC.TEXT: Cornelius P. Turner, developer of the General Educational Development tests that permit non-graduates to win certificates equivalent to a high school diploma, is dead at 83. Turner died of blood poisoning at Alexandria Hospital on Wednesday. He lived in Alexandria. As a Navy lieutenant from 1943 to 1945, Turner directed a program that developed high-school diploma equivalency tests for use by members of the armed services during World War II. After the war, he held a number of positions that helped expand use of the tests until all U.S. states and Canadian provinces adopted them. About 700,000 people a year take the tests. He taught mathematics and history at Leicester, Mass. and served as superintendent of schools there before World War II. Turner is survived by a son and two grandchildren. His wife of 53 years, Mary, died in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: President Fujimori To Ease Restrictions on Foreign Investment in Peru
DOC.TEXT: President Alberto Fujimori, whose country is starved for foreign capital, says he will ease restrictions on foreign investment in Peru's petroleum, fishing, mining and tourism industries. Fujimori said Wednesday that he would promote ``legislation to speed up negotiations with foreign investors and eliminate laws that limit the potential profitability of these investments.'' Foreign corporations will soon be able to repatriate profits from their Peruvian operations, Fujimori told a luncheon given by the American Chamber of Commerce in Lima. Upon taking office on July 28, Fujimori began a series of measures to curb hyperinflation and open Peru's economy to world markets. The measures have included drastic rises in the costs of government services and the end of most price controls and subsidies. Fujimori also slashed import tariffs, forcing Peru's traditionally highly protected industries to compete with foreign products. The measures sent prices soaring 397 percent in August, but prices in September are expected to rise less than 5 percent. The austerity plan has left Peru's economy virtually paralyzed. Many factories are closed and thousands of small businesses are expected to go bankrupt. At Wednesday's lunch, Fujimori assured businessmen they were safe from ``the risk of of expropriation, illegal change of ownership or conversion into national currency'' of foreign profits in Peru. Fujimori's predecessor, Alan Garcia, threatened to nationalize various foreign concerns in Peru. These included the mines of Southern Peru Copper Corporation, the largest U.S. company operating in Peru. Fujimori said the results of his austerity measures were ``encouraging.'' He said Peru needed ``fiscal and monetary discipline to create a climate of confidence'' for foreign investment. ``President George Bush has said prosperity in Latin America depends on trade, not aid,'' Fujimori said. ``We agree on that one.'' Fujimori's Prime Minister, Juan Hurtado Miller, is in Washington this week for talks with the International Monetary Fund. Peru cut relations with the IMF in 1987, after unilaterally limiting payments on its $20 billion foreign debt the year before. Hurtado hopes to come home with fresh loans if the IMF approves of Peru's austerity measures. IMF officials have indicated they will.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: George Clinton of the funk group Parliament Funkadelic drove across the state line to get married rather than wait three days for a license in Michigan. The 49-year-old funk king and Stephanie Lynn Goshorn, 34, both from Brooklyn, Mich., walked into the Lucas County Courthouse with little fanfare Tuesday but didn't leave unnoticed. Connie Krall, the deputy clerk who wrote the license, said her co-workers recognized Clinton. ``I'd never heard of him,'' Ms. Krall said. ``But when I saw his hair, I thought he was going to be outrageous, like Little Richard, but he wasn't. He was very courteous and he never played up his celebrity status.'' Michigan has a three-day waiting period for a marriage license. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Lucille Ball's daughter, Lucie Arnaz, plans to produce a musical about her father, Cuban bandleader and TV star Desi Arnaz. ``My father wrote a book years ago about coming to this country and his band and all that and was always talking about turning it into a musical, and finally he said, `What the hell. I'll never make it. You try,''' she said in the Sept. 30 issue of Parade magazine. Her father died in 1986. Her husband, actor and writer Laurence Luckinbill, wrote a script for ``Desi: The Musical'' and the couple hope to produce it within the next couple of months. Arnaz, 39, is back on television in ``Sons and Daughters,'' in which she plays a single mother raising an adopted daughter. Her last TV effort, ``The Lucie Arnaz Show,'' flopped five years ago. From 1968 to 1974, she played the daughter of her real-life mother in ``Here's Lucy.'' --- LONDON (AP) - British hat designer David Shilling has been recruited by the United Nations to assist Ecuador in strengthening its hat-making industry. The U.N. International Trade Center said Wednesday that Shilling will visit Ecuador in October to advise artisans on the fashion requirements of Western markets. Shilling's creations are usually standouts in the hat parade at the Ascot races attended by Queen Elizabeth II. His designs are on display at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Azabu in Tokyo and the Museum of Decorative Arts in Paris. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Three years after Paramount Pictures bought the rights to his award-winning play ``Fences,'' August Wilson says production has been stalled by his insistence on a black director. The playwright said he is seeking a director ``who would approach my work with the same amount of passion and measure of respect with which I approach it and who shares the same cultural sensibilities of the characters.'' ``The last time I looked, all those directors were black,'' he wrote in the October issue of Spin magazine. Wilson, who won a Tony and a Pulitzer for the drama in 1987, said he rejected a respected white director ``not on the basis of race but on the basis of culture.'' Wilson said this week that Paramount agreed in March to hire a black director and recently began suggesting names. ``I consider their agreement a small victory,'' he said in a statement. ``I will consider their actually hiring a black director a greater victory.'' --- SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. (AP) - A film crew has begun shooting scenes from ``Billy Bathgate,'' starring Dustin Hoffman as Depression-era gangster Dutch Schultz, at Saratoga's famed racecourse. A crew of more than 100, plus 500 locally recruited extras, filmed racing and crowd scenes Wednesday at the thoroughbred track. The Disney film, based on the 1989 best-selling novel by E.L. Doctorow, is about a New York City boy who joins Schultz's gang in 1935. Loren Dean plays Billy Bathgate, and Nicole Kidman, girlfriend of Tom Cruise, plays Drew Preston, Schultz' moll. The film is due out next year. About 1,000 extras will be used during the film's three-week stay in Saratoga Springs. Most of the filming will take place in New York City and North Carolina. Linda Toohey, executive vice president of the Saratoga County Chamber of Commerce, said she drove around Saratoga County last spring with a member of the film production staff to take snapshots of potential locations. A location she would not disclose was the one selected for a scene in which Billy and Drew go skinny-dipping. For that, the filmmakers needed water deep enough for a stuntwoman to make a dive off a 20-foot cliff, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Activists Renew Dialogue After Gulf Crisis Rift
DOC.TEXT: Israeli peace activists have renewed dialogue with Palestinian leaders following disagreements over the PLO's position in the Persian Gulf crisis. After a two-hour meeting, the leftist ``Peace Now'' movement and Palestinians headed by activist Faisal Husseini agreed late Wednesday to resume talks on the occupied territories and other issues. ``We want to keep up our meetings even if is against the emotion in the street right now,'' Husseini told an assembly of 100 Israelis. ``The going will be tough,'' Yitzhak Galnoor, a Peace Now activist. ``But once all the dust settles we see that three years of an uprising cannot be ignored, we still have the same problem to solve.'' During the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip at least 996 Palestinians have been killed and 52 Israelis and foreigners have died. Quarrels among the peace groups began when the Palestine Liberation Organization sided with Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein following the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Husseini said the PLO objects to war and to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. But he also said Palestinians were angrier with the United States than they were supportive of Iraq. ``American forces are there for their own interests, the price of oil. But they are completely neglecting our case,'' he said. Husseini was unable to persuade Israelis at the meeting to issue a joint statement urging the United States to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis peacefully and then turn to the Palestinian issue. Another Palestinian activist, Ghassan Khatib, asserted ``there were some mistakes made by Palestinians and the PLO (about the gulf crisis) and we should acknowledge that.'' ``We feared from the start we were going to be losers,'' Khatib added, noting the gulf problems have overshadowed the Palestinian issues. Both sides agreed to continue their meetings. Leaders of Peace Now resolved to press on trying to persuade Israelis that the government should end its diplomatic boycott of the PLO. ``We're going to have to get back to this issue. There is no other solution but to talk to the Palestinians, the PLO,'' said Galia Golan, a professor of political science at Jerusalem's Hebrew University.

DOC.HEAD: Automatic Budget Cuts: Fewer Maps for Troops, Grounded Space Shuttles
DOC.TEXT: There will be fewer maps for troops in the Middle East. A million children won't be vaccinated against polio, measles and diphtheria. There may not be enough government lawyers to argue before the Supreme Court. Airline flights will be reduced and most space shuttles won't fly at all. All this, and more, is predicted if there is no budget agreement and the president orders automatic spending cuts Monday, the first day of the government's 1991 fiscal year. For 2.4 million federal employees with mortgage payments and mouths to feed, the impact could range from a few days off without pay to the devastation that faces Jeannette Gordon. She could be laid off 255 days out of a work year of 260. Most agencies of the government expect to be forced to trim expenses by 32.4 percent. They'll do it by cutting services to the taxpayer, suspending programs, furloughing employees, putting off that needed paint job or turning out the lights at night. The Gramm-Rudman law doesn't much care. It requires whatever it takes to slim down federal spending by $100 billion or so in fiscal 1991. Most federal employees can be laid off for 22 days with a simple notice; after that the rules get more complicated. The prospect facing Mrs. Gordon, who works for perhaps the smallest agency in government, is unique. ``We don't have contracts we can cut and we don't have employees to lay off,'' says Mrs. Gordon, one of two people who run the Susquehanna River Basin Commission. ``My budget for 1991 is $211,000; our 32.4 percent is $68,364,'' she says. What remains goes into office expenses and the salary of Commissioner Warner Depuy, who won't be furloughed because he is a presidential appointee. ``That,'' she says with a sigh, ``doesn't leave anything to hire me.'' Ironically, Mrs. Gordon used to work at the Office of Management and Budget, which tells the president what kind of a cut to order. `I worked at OMB for 17 years,'' she says. ``I was always on the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue. I never knewit worked like that.'' The way it works is this. To save money: -There would be fewer maps produced by the Defense Mapping Agency, which has worked overtime to make 20 million maps for Operation Desert Shield since the Middle East crisis began. The agency's 8,000 employees are on notice they might be furloughed. -Meat counters would be emptier as 7,344 federal meat and poultry inspectors shave weeks off their annual duties. A sequester, which is what the cutback in funds is called, ``would result in the absence of inspection services and the shutting down of meat and poultry slaughter and processing plants for about 140 days,'' the House Appropriations Committee predicts. -NASA would have to cancel the space station and drop or postpone all 21 shuttle flights scheduled in 1991 and 1992, according to the committee. But the agency says it has enough money left over to launch the first shuttle in the new fiscal year, on Oct. 6. -Commercial airplanes would not be able to fly at night because the National Weather Service will close 250 stations from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. Pilots need up-to-date weather information. The Federal Aviation Administration would start cutbacks with 20 percent fewer flights the first three days because controllers will be furloughed two days each in every two-week pay period. Many important government activities are immune to cutbacks. The Postal Service, which gets its money from the business it conducts, is not affected. Social Security benefits, federal retirement and disability payments, veterans' compensation and pensions, state unemployment and many low-income entitlement programs are untouched. The affairs of state won't suffer. The State Department plans to exempt people whose jobs deal with crisis spots, but cut back on travel and overtime. The White House will furlough people one day a week on different days. A joke making the rounds is that presidential dog Millie will have to give back one of her pups. The Justice Department said furloughs during the first two weeks of the new fiscal year would range from one day per Drug Enforcement Administration employee to nine days at the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission. Layoffs will hobble prosecutions of savings and loan fraud and make it difficult to operate the nation's overcrowded federal prisons, officials say. The furloughs ``hit us at the worst possible time,'' said Deputy Solicitor General John Roberts, whose lawyers are scheduled to argue 10 of the 20 cases scheduled to be heard before the Supreme Court in the first two weeks of October. ``The arguments will be 20 percent shorter,'' Roberts quipped. Checks written to farmers under various commodity programs, including price support loans and direct payments, will be reduced by the percentage of the sequester. About $84 million in federal grants to states for foster care, adoption and child protective services would be eliminated, straining state child welfare systems. Biomedical research would be cut by $3.5 billion and 30,000 drug abusers would not get treatment. The government has pulled its Perils of Pauline act nearly every year in recent times, threatening to run out of money, but Congress always comes to the rescue. Sequestration has been required only twice before: in the current fiscal year, which ends Sunday, and in 1986. The General Accounting Office checked five departments to see how they were affected by the 1990 cutback and found few dire effects. Although many agencies will hold staff meetings on Friday to finalize their plans, the likelihood is that no one will know the extent of the required cuts, if any, until Sunday. ``If there is no action before Friday,'' said Laura Kopelson of GAO, ``our instructions are to be watching the news on Monday morning.''

DOC.HEAD: Sandstorms a Threat as Seasons Change
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt ^By RICHARD PYLE
DOC.TEXT: As the change of season cools the sun-scorched Saudi desert and fills the sky with clouds, U.S. military planners have a new weather worry - sandstorms. A ``sarrayat,'' Arabic for `the night comer', could occur at critical moments for ground forces, whose tactics are heavily geared toward fighting under cover of darkness. The night sandstorms are brief but violent and are sometimes accompanied by lightning and thunder. Even in daylight, strategists must reckon with seasonal storms called ``shamal,'' the Arabic word for north, which pick up sand and turn the sky yellow for hours or an entire day. A U.S. Navy captain said recently that his ship had turned from the official gray to a subtle shade of brown after a few weeks in the Persian Gulf. American troops have learned to protect their vehicles and aircraft from the incessant dust and sand - using such modifications as pantyhose for filters. But they have not yet experienced the fury of the sustained desert winds that sometimes reduce visibility to near zero and cause even the hardiest Bedouins and their camels to hunker down. ``We're not overly concerned, just aware that there's a possibility of dust storms,'' said 1st Lt. Todd Fasking, an Air Force meteorologist. ``The percent of time that they occur is really very small, but if a storm comes at absolutely the worst time, the percentage doesn't matter.'' Saudi experts say the desert storms this time of year are less severe than those of the ``Khamseen,'' or 50 days, from late May through early July, when the Indian Ocean monsoons generate a low-pressure system over the desert. American strategists have not forgotten the 1980 Iranian hostage rescue attempt that ended in disaster when the helicopters suddenly became caught in a sandstorm that one pilot later described as ``like flying in a bowl of milk.'' And history suggests that the northern Saudi region, where more than 150,000 U.S. troops are deployed, may be overdue for bad weather. Jaber Jum Ah, a consultant on desert weather for Aramco, the Saudi-owned oil company, said severe storm seasons come every six or seven years. he last one was in 1983, he said. They usually occur between Oct. 10 and Nov. 10, he said. The worst season in modern times was 1925, the year of the ``sinkings'' - so-called because hundreds of small craft were swamped and lost in a gulf storm that lasted about half an hour. ``The gulf is not so deep, and the seas can run as much as 15 feet - not serious for big ships but very dangerous for small ones,'' Jum Ah said. While the storms may arise suddenly, meteorologists say threatening weather patterns can be predicted and monitored. Fasking said winter frontal systems develop in Saudi Arabia much as they do in United States, generally moving from west to east, and can be observed by satellite. ``We can see a front coming and track it,'' Fasking said. ``With the satellite we can see suspended sand as it kicks up out of northern Saudi Arabia into central Saudi.'' He said advisories are issued when winds reach velocities that could jeopardize visibility for air operations.

DOC.HEAD: Filipino Jobseekers Undeterred by Threat of War in Persian Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Filipinos are fleeing the Persian Gulf area, but thousands more are still flocking to the Middle East, searching for jobs to escape poverty and hopelessness in this troubled island nation. Over the last year, an average of 15,000 Filipinos a month left for jobs in the gulf, and that figure still holds true despite the crisis precipitated by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, according to the state-run Philippine Overseas Employment Agency. Chartered jets which recently flew hundreds of exhausted and penniless refugees home from camps in Jordan have been returning to the Middle East packed with new job-seekers. ``If you remain in our country, you will never prosper,'' said Letty Solis, whose mechanic husband Leopoldo is still looking for work after returning from Kuwait last month. Statistics show why Filipinos leave families behind to work in the gulf. The unemployment rate here stands at more than 8 percent and is expected to increase as thousands of workers return from Kuwait and Iraq. Before the crisis, an estimated 90,000 Filipinos were working in Kuwait and Iraq. About 16,500 have returned to the Philippines. ``The mimimum pay you get here is not enough to buy the basics for yourself, much less your family,'' said Miguel Ramos, 35, an unemployed electrician who has just been hired by a firm in Saudi Arabia. A job here for Ramos would pay about $88 a month. He expects to make more than four times that in the gulf. Ramos acknowledged, ``It's a gamble. I know it's risky but I'd rather take it. Besides, things are so unstable in our country anyway that it doesn't make any difference where you are. If you are used to hardships then it doesn't matter if there's war.'' President Corazon Aquino's government has promised to help workers who fled Kuwait and Iraq find other jobs abroad. But of the 16,500 workers who have come home since the invasion, fewer than 100 have found new jobs overseas through government efforts. For most, conditions are desperate. Many of those who left Kuwait lost most of their savings when banks wre closed and the Kuwaiti dinar declared invalid. Gulf labor laws make it nearly impossible for refugees from Kuwait to land jobs in Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates or other gulf countries without first returning to the Philippines. Every day, the semiprivate Overseas Workers' Welfare Adminstration headquarters teems with returnees inquiring about jobs abroad and applying for $120 in emergency displacement loans which returning workers are authorized to obtain. That would feed an average-sized Filipino family of five for two weeks. Many must borrow money or move in with friends and relatives after years of relative comfort and prosperity abroad. ``I will still go back there if things normalize,'' said Mars Ariola, who worked in Kuwait as a truck driver for five years. ``If I cannot get into the Middle East, then I will try Europe or any other country.'' Except for banning travel to Kuwait, Iraq and parts of Saudi Arabia, the government has done nothing to prevent thousands of its citizens from working in the Persian Gulf despite fears that the region may explode into full-scale war. Filipinos working in the Middle East send home about $1.3 billion a year, a major source of foreign exchange. Remittances from Kuwait and Iraq accounted for about 5 percent of the foreign exchange, official figures show. ``We have to consider the need for them to earn and also for the country to get revenues from the foreign exchange earnings of our workers,'' presidential spokesman Adolf Azcuna said. ``We just hope that the workers will be deployed to areas far from trouble.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudis To Adopt Forceful Diplomatic Posture
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis is forcing Saudi Arabia, which traditionally has relied on quiet diplomacy, to take aggressive steps - even against Arab states once considered allies. Jordan and Yemen have already experienced the newfound Saudi punitive power. Indications are that the Palestine Liberation Organization, or at least its leader Yasser Arafat, will be next. Sudan, another recipient of Saudi financial aid that has not broken with Iraq over its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, could soon see its relations with Riyadh sour. ``There will be a settlement of accounts when this is over,'' a Saudi diplomatic official said Wednesday. ``We have to stand up for principle. It is no more Mr. Nice Guy. . . . There is no longer the fear of offending Arabs.'' As Saudi Arabia deliberately strains relations with some traditional Arab allies, it is moving quickly to improve its position on the world stage, re-establishing ties with Moscow and Beijing. Senior Saudi officials believe the crisis has dashed any hopes for Arab unity and created an atmosphere in which Arab states will seek to bolster their standing outside the region. ``The bubble of pan-Arabism is burst,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Now maybe all of us can be more honest.'' The international rush to help defend Saudi Arabia from Iraq has persuaded Saudi officials they can take on fellow Arab states over disputes they might have glossed over in the past. ``The whole world has underwritten the security of the gulf region,'' a Saudi prince said Monday. In the past, Saudi Arabia shied away from a forceful public role in Arab policy debates, choosing quiet diplomacy and use of its huge foreign aid budget to sway friends. Now, angered by King Hussein's refusal to break with Baghdad and by the Jordanian monarch's criticism of the Saudis for opening their country to foreign troops, the Saudi government has come out swinging. Prince Bandar Bin Sultan, the Saudi ambassador to the United States, wrote an open letter to Hussein attacking the king. He ended, ``I no longer can feel that you are the same man I knew.'' Choosing Bandar to deliver the message was a sign of the Saudis' new interest in aggressive diplomacy. ``The playing field was American public opinion,'' the Saudi official said. ``King Hussein was trying to go over our head and over the head of George Bush. So we chose our spokesman who was most eloquent in dealing with American matters. '' Bandar's public denouncement came after a series of jolts in Saudi-Jordanian relations. Saudi Arabia first cut off Jordan's oil supplies, saying Amman's bills were overdue, then expelled most Jordanian diplomats for alleged espionage. ``None of this convinced . . . (Hussein) to change course and we lost patience,'' another Saudi official said. He said Jordan has received little, if any Saudi aid since the invasion. ``Right now our line is, `The check is in the mail.' Soon he'll find out we forgot to put a stamp on it.'' With Yemen, which initially opposed slapping santions on Iraq, Saudi Arabia ended its open border policy and then expelled most Yemeni diplomats for alleged espionage. Yemen sided with the Saudis when the U.N. Security Council voted Tuesday to impose an air embargo against Iraq. The Saudi diplomatic official said Riyadh viewed those votes as encouraging but was not yet ready to forgive Yemen. ``Our actions might have had something to do with the vote but there was a lot of American pressure, too,'' one of the officials said. The Saudis are far more reluctant to criticize Arafat, but say privately that he is unwelcome in their country and could face sharp cutbacks in aid. One idea under consideration is to give direct aid to Palestinian housing and other social services projects, but little or nothing to the PLO chief directly. The Saudi officials said they have been satisfied with their handling of the gulf crisis to date but it was too soon to grade diplomatic efforts. ``We have to be aggressive now - it is a matter of life and death,'' the diplomatic official said. ``But we can't say what will happen in the future. We are all learning a lesson right now.''

DOC.HEAD: Census Figures Show Rich-Poor Gap Widening, Lawmaker Says
DOC.TEXT: New Census Bureau figures show that the gap between the rich and the poor is widening, says the chairman of the congressional Joint Economic Committee. ``Those at the top of the scale are receiving an ever-larger share of the pie,'' Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., said Wednesday after the bureau released its annual report on income and poverty. ``Meanwhile, families in the middle and at the bottom are barely keeping ahead of inflation,'' Hamilton said. ``The gap between the rich and the poor is widening when it should be shrinking.'' Robert Greenstein, executive director of a liberal research group, the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, said the 12.8 percent poverty rate reported by the bureau is a bad sign. ``With the economy running out of steam and a new recession threatening, the poverty rate is likely to start rising again,'' Greenstein said. ``That means an already high poverty rate is likely to climb higher and if the recession is a deep one it could reach poverty levels not seen for a quarter of a century.'' Both liberals and conservatives continued to clamor for a change in the way the Census Bureau figures out who is poor. For the third year in a row, the bureau said the decline in the poverty rate between 1988 and 1989 was so small that it was not statistically significant. The 1988 rate was 13 percent. The bureau said 31.5 million Americans were below the poverty level last year. For a family of four, that level is an annual income of $12,675. In 1988, 31.7 million were below it. ``It is time to update our official poverty measure to provide a more accurate reflection of today's economic needs,'' Hamilton said. A Joint Economic Committee study last year suggested that the poverty thresholds might increase as much as 50 percent if they took into account such things as the increasing share of income that is now paid for housing. On the other hand, Kate O'Beirne, deputy director for domestic policy studies at the conservative Heritage Foundation, said, ``Owing to the method they use, the Census Bureau dramatically overstates the number of people in poverty.'' The problem, she said, is that the bureau counts only money as income and does not include such things as food stamps and Medicaid and Medicare benefits. In an appendix to its report, the Census Bureau said that with the addition of these and other non-cash items, the poverty rate would be as low as 10.4 percent. Both Daniel Weinberg, chief of the Housing and Household Economic Statistics division of the bureau, and Greenstein said that adopting such an alternative method would not affect the trend of poverty rates. The bureau reported that median household income in 1989 was $28,910, up 1.3 percent from 1988 after adjusting for rising living costs. Household income had been unchanged in the previous two years. The bureau said the wealthiest one-fifth of households received 46.8 percent of the income. While this was no higher than in 1988, it was significantly higher than the percentages of 44.2 percent in 1979 and 43 percent in 1969. Those on the lower rungs of the economic ladder received somewhat lower shares of the aggregate income. ``There seems little doubt that the income distribution has become somewhat less equal over the past 20 years,'' the bureau said. It said the reasons for this are not clear.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force C-17's Cost Hits Estimated $400 Million
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force is estimating that the cost of its C-17 transport has risen to $400 million per plane and fears the aircraft's manufacturer, McDonnell Douglas, may go bankrupt by year's end, a House committee chairman says. In a letter released Wednesday, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., cited the company's cost overruns and excessive work hours as evidence of a ``management collapse'' in the program to build 120 of the wide-body planes. Dingell based his assessment on internal Pentagon documents, reports from McDonnell Douglas and an inquiry conducted by the staff of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations. Dingell is chairman of both the full committee and the subcommittee. An unidentified Air Force official who had been working with the company told the panel's staff that ``in his opinion, McDonnell Douglas management was committing corporate suicide,'' Dingell said. The official said the options left to the Air Force were to either suspend or significantly cut progress payments on the C-17 program, but a financial analysis of the company concluded that if the payments were cut, McDonnell Douglas might go bankrupt. ``Regardless of the progress payments issue, the Air Force believes that McDonnell Douglas may go bankrupt by the end of the year,'' Dingell said in the letter. He also cited internal Pentagon reports that estimated the C-17's cost at more than $400 million per plane. Air Force officials testified to Congress last June that the plane, which will replace the current C-141 aircraft, will cost an estimated $249 million. Richard Hill, a McDonnell Douglas spokesman in Long Beach, Calif., said the company has estimated that when the C-17 program is completed the cost will be below the ceiling levels in the government contract. Hill acknowledged past reports of schedule problems and delays but said that since November 1989, the company ``has met every milestone set. In the past few months, the landing gear was placed on the airplane. It's going to fly in June. The progress is there.'' Hill declined to comment on the bankruptcy issue. McDonnell Douglas, in an internal report dated April 1990, estimated a cost overrun of $836 million on the C-17 contract. In the last month, however, the contractor spent $118 million to complete work that was estimated at $47 million. Overhead expenses of $51 million in the internal report far exceeded the cost of $15 million, while administrative expenses of $9 million were about three times the projected cost of $3 million. Dingell, in his letter to Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, bristled at the number of hours it took to produce work that McDonnell Douglas' own industrial engineers said should take only one. For example, he said, 25.8 assembly hours were spent on the aircraft when one was determined to be sufficient. ``We found an appalling picture in factory labor performance,'' Dingell said. Problems with the program were raised in June when the Air Force decided to take away the approval it had previously granted to McDonnell Douglas on its purchasing system for the C-17. The decision meant the company must get Air Force approval for purchases in excess of $100,000. The Air Force told Congress that the action would not delay the program. Nevertheless, concerns about the program prompted the Senate, in adopting a $289 billion defense authorization bill last month, to defer buying two planes in fiscal 1991 because of development and testing delays. The House, in a $283 billion defense bill approved last week, cut President Bush's request for about $700 million for the two planes to about $500 million. But the House also restricted spending any money in the fiscal year beginning next Monday until Defense Secretary Dick Cheney certifies the successful completion of the first flight of the production aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Senate OKs Parental Notification for Teen Abortions; Final Vote Delayed
DOC.TEXT: Intense political differences over abortion derailed a bill in the Senate that would extend a 20-year-old law providing federal aid to clinics that offer family planning services to the poor. The Senate adopted provisions sought by both opponents of abortion and advocates of abortion rights in two days of debate, but then pushed the bill aside Wednesday when a vote to limit debate failed. ``I don't think a bill (on family planning services) is going to clear Congress after this,'' said Doug Johnson, legislative director of the anti-abortion National Right To Life Committee. The bill would renew the family planning programs funded under Title X of the Public Health Service Act. Its authorization actually expired five years ago, and the services have been continued each year through passage of catchall spending bills, but advocates sought reauthorization with increases in federal support. The Senate on Tuesday approved, 62-36, an amendment that would nullify Bush administration regulations prohibiting family planning clinics that receive federal money from offering any information or counseling involving abortion. Legal challenges to those regulations are before the Supreme Court. On Wednesday, the Senate accepted an amendment requiring the notification of the parents of any girl under age 18 who seeks an abortion from an organization receiving federal family-planning money. The measure, sponsored by Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo., an abortion opponent, was passed on a unanimous voice vote. But the key vote came earlier when the Senate rejected, 54-43, a motion to table, or kill, the amendment. The family planning organizations are prohibited from using federal money for abortions, but Armstrong said more than 30 perform abortions at the same clinic that provides federally supported family planning services. ``In almost every jurisdiction you have to have the permission of your parent ... to give blood,'' he said. ``But there is a surgical procedure for which that is not required, and it is abortion.'' When backers sought a vote to set a time to end debate - a move needed to bring the overall bill to a direct vote - they failed by 10 votes to get the required 60 votes. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., the bill's sponsor, said the action means the Senate turns ``our back on millions of teen-agers.'' But Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, suggested Democrats had only pushed the bill to force President Bush's veto and said the services would again be funded regardless of the bill's outcome. ``Nobody is going to be denied those funds,'' Hatch said. In the House, meanwhile, a similar measure was approved by the Energy and Commerce Committee without any of the controversial Senate provisions on abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Gifford: Schools, Universities Need Technology Chief
DOC.TEXT: Bernard Gifford is a product of a government push 30 years ago to create more nuclear scientists, so he is convinced that Congress can propel his idea to put technology specialists in each school district. Gifford, vice president of education marketing for Apple Computer Inc., addressed more than 70 members of Congress on Wednesday. ``I believe the time has come for universities and school districts to create a new job, that of chief technology officer, on the same par as an academic dean or superintendent of instruction,'' he said. Gifford said such a the technology officer would be ``far more than just a person in charge of computers,'' but also one who understands the use of technology and have visions of ``where we're headed.'' ``My argument is we will not understand how to use the technology or how to implement it unless we create people at a high enough level ... whose obligation it is to add intelligence to the technology,'' he said. Gifford said there are only about a few million computers in use in the nation's schools for the 44 million students in public and private primary and secondary schools. Rapid advancement of technology makes it difficult for schools to keep their equipment up to date and many of the teachers are not adequately trained to use the sophisticated technology. Asked about the cost of his idea, Gifford acknowledged the tight budget problems but stressed said Congress ``is in a unique position to champion the development.'' ``The federal government in the past has stimulated the creation of a generation of specialists in Eastern European languages, molecular biology and nuclear science when there was a great need for those professions,'' he said. ``Just as the government encouraged a generation to pursue those scholarly pursuits, I hope similar incentives will be available for those educators who want to guide schools and colleges into the Information Age,'' he said. When the government pushed in the 1960s for more nuclear scientists, Gifford said he received a fellowship that paid his way through graduate school and gave him a $4,000 yearly stipend. ``All I had to do was major in biophysics,'' said Gifford, a Brooklyn native who has worked as a teacher, a deputy commissioner of education for New York City public schools and dean of the School of Education at the University of California at Berkeley.

DOC.HEAD: NAACP Campaigning to Keep Soap Opera `Generations' on the Air
DOC.TEXT: Blacks are breaking down the ``iron curtain'' that once barred them from important jobs in the television and movie industries, but more progress is needed, the NAACP said in joining a campaign to keep the multiracial daytime drama, ``Generations,'' on the air. The 17-month-old soap opera, which employs many blacks in front of and behind the cameras, is being dropped by some stations nationwide and needs public support, NAACP officials said at a news conference Wednesday. ``Generations'' co-star Jonelle Allen, who received a congressional citation for her work from Rep. Mervyn Dymally, D-Calif., urged viewers to contact their local NBC-affiliated stations and ``Let it be known that you love `Generations.''' Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, was too ill to attend the news conference but sent a message that was read by an aide, Bill Pollard. ``While it is agreed that African Americans have made some strides in the breaking through what was previously an iron curtain that prevented them from exercising any real power in these industries, it is obvious a great deal still remains to be done,'' Hooks said. ``We are, therefore, in total support of any and all efforts that will accomplish these goals.'' ``Generations'' deals with two families - one black, the other white - with multigenerational ties. NBC describes it as the first daytime drama to focus equally on two families of different races. Pollard said the American public needs to see blacks ``portrayed as we are every day and not as a subclass or a second class.'' He said the NAACP would urge its 1,700 chapters to lobby NBC affiliates to try to prevent ``Generations'' from being dropped from any more daytime lineups. Sally Sussman, the show's creator-executive producer, said ``Generations'' was broadcast on 99 percent of NBC's 200-plus affiliated stations after it debuted in March 1989, but now it is seen on 92 percent of the stations. She said that even though the network ``totally supports'' the program, it had been dropped recently by NBC affiliates in Boston, Phoenix, Tulsa, Okla.; and Tampa-St. Petersburg, Fla. If more defections occur, Sussman said, ``At some point it will not be economically feasible for NBC to carry the show.'' NBC officials did not immediately comment Wednesday, but NBC Entertainment Group Chairman Brandon Tartikoff was quoted recently as saying he would give the show six more months before re-evaluating its future.

DOC.HEAD: CIA Document Says South Africa May Have Built Nukes in '70s
DOC.TEXT: South Africa has been developing nuclear weapons for years and may have begun producing them in 1979 or earlier, says a newly disclosed CIA document. The memorandum, obtained by the environmentalist Natural Resources Defense Council under the Freedom of Information Act, was written in December 1979 at the request of the National Security Council. It sought to determine who was responsible for a nuclear explosion detected on Sept. 22, 1979, by a U.S. Vela satellite off the African coast. The document did not appear to present a conclusive answer, unless it was hidden in the portions that were blacked out for reasons of national security. While all the intelligence agencies appeared to agree South Africa could have done it, they differed on whether it did. Late in 1977, the CIA found, the South African government suspended preparations to test a nuclear weapon because of strong pressure from the United States. But the CIA said it didn't believe South African denials about the 1979 explosion. The commander of the South African Navy made allegations, ``which we believe to be false, that a Soviet nuclear submarine has been seen in the vicinity ... implicitly denying that the South African Navy was involved in a nuclear test conducted at sea,'' the memo said. The Defense Intelligence Agency, an arm of the Defense Department, ``believes that South Africa probably would have had enough confidence in Israeli security to consider conducting a joint test.'' South Africa and Israel, both ostracized on the international stage in the 1970s, have cooperated on many defense projects. Under strong international pressure, Israel promised last year to stop. ``Israelis have not only participated in certain South African nuclear research activities over the last few years, but they have also offered and transferred various sorts of advanced non-nuclear weapons technology to South Africa,'' the CIA said in the 1979 report. The Natural Resources Defense Council said Wednesday it was making the document public to prevent South Africa from hiding large amounts of enriched uranium from international inspection. South Africa has announced it wants to sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, which would place its nuclear facilities under international inspection to ensure they were only used for non-military purposes. ``If they're going to sign this treaty, let's not forget they had this program way back when. Let's get accountability for what they produced then,'' said Richard Fieldhouse, a nuclear proliferation specialist at NRDC. South Africa has cloaked its nuclear program in secrecy and ambiguity over the years, preferring to keep its adversaries guessing. The 1979 memo said that ``until recently, South Africa lacked the relevant technology and fissile material'' but estimated it ``has by this time acquired sufficient fissile material for the fabrication of several nuclear devices.'' One fissile material is uranium that is enriched to such a concentrated level that it can be used to make weapons. South Africa is the world's third largest producer of uranium. South African President F.W. de Klerk visited the White House ths week, and the United States pressed again for his country to sign the non-proliferation treaty, officials said. Last week, the Customs Service accused an export business in Florida of selling long-range ballistic missile guidance components to South Africa for at least the last year. In its affidavit against the company, York Ltd., the agency said it was aware of ``projects under way relating to the development of guided missile delivery systems for standard and nuclear weapons'' in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Leaky Embargo Fails To Halt All Food, Supplies To Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The six-week-old U.N. economic embargo has not kept Iraq from receiving food and supplies by truck from Jordan, jetliner from South America, via smugglers from Syria and Iran, and even by mule from Turkey. The embargo has halted virtually all of Iraq's oil exports and drastically reduced cargo shipments to the country, but supplies are slipping in thanks to sympathetic governments, pro-Iraqi groups and opportunistic smugglers. ``There are a lot of ways for an innovative shipper to avoid a blockade, and as the price goes up, they become more innovative,'' said Capt. Paul Prokop, commander of U.S. Coast Guard teams enforcing the embargo in the Persian Gulf. The amount of slippage is difficult to determine. Before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, prompting the international community to impose the sanctions, it imported about three-quarters of its food supplies. The trade cutoff has forced strict rationing, but embargo violators may help Iraq resist the pressure aimed at forcing it to quit Kuwait. While the United Nations authorized the naval blockade, the air embargo it approved this week does not condone military enforcement and little is being done to stop overland shipments through neighboring Jordan and Iran. Jordan's King Hussein, an ally of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, has reluctantly agreed to honor the boycott but much food is believed to be going in through Jordan. A convoy of trucks loaded with food left Jordan for Iraq on Monday to raucous cheers in one of the more defiant gestures flouting the embargo. Western officials believe Libya, Sudan and Yemen are also sending food. Most aircraft flying to Iraq would have to cross Jordanian airspace, possibly filing bogus flight plans for Jordan, then continuing to Iraq. Iran has a 730-mile border with Iraq and is believed to be allowing food across overland routes. Officially, Iran says it supports the U.N. embargo. On Monday, it announced the arrest of 29 people for smuggling rice, flour, dates, oil and other foodstuffs into Iraq. But Tehran, Baghdad's foe in an eight-year war than ended in 1988, shares Iraq's opposition to the U.S. military presence in the gulf, and there is heated internal debate over whether to help Iraq beat the sanctions. Iranian newspapers have suggested that Tehran send ``humanitarian shipments'' of food and medicine, and there have been reports that Iran has struck a deal with Iraq to trade refined oil for food. Baghdad residents say food appearing recently in markets in the Iraqi capital has come from neighboring Iran. Also, some shipping sources say Iraqi tankers are delivering oil to ports in Iran by hugging the coastline and staying out of international waters. Syrian President Hafez Assad, Iraq's major rival in the Arab world, made a weekend trip to Iran to try to persuade leaders in Tehran to better cooperate with international efforts to isolate Iraq. But he was unable to obtain a pledge to abide by the U.N. sanctions. There are also illegal food shipments from Turkey, which strongly backs U.S. policy in the region. The number of trucks carrying food into Iraq has tripled since the embargo was imposed, Cumhuriyet, a major Turkish newspaper, reported over the weekend. It quoted the owner of a meat exporting firm as saying Turkish trucks carrying cattle to Iran were diverted to Iraq by Iranian border guards. Other Turkish media reports say smugglers carry contraband foodstuff by mule across the mountainous border region, which is difficult to police and notorious for such activity. Small-scale smuggling from Syria also has been reported in recent weeks, consisting mainly of opportunisic farmers selling their produce across the common border. Even the air embargo adopted Tuesday by a 14-1 vote at the U.N. Security Council is largely symbolic, as it cannot be effectively enforced. The United Nations does not allow the shooting down of civilian passenger aircraft. In one brazen example of defying the sanctions, an Argentinian presidential adviser on Saturday acknowledged sending 154 tons of beef to Iraq over the past two weeks. President Carlos Menem fired the adviser, Alberto Samid, for the embarrassing admission, made more acute because Argentina has pledged two warships to the multinational force standing up to Saddam in the gulf region. Samid said the beef was flown to Iran for overland delivery to Iraq, although Iran's Foreign Ministry claimed no knowledge of the deal. But experts say Saddam cannot rely on airlifts to feed his nation of 17 million people. Nor will his order this week to farmers to devote 80 percent of their land to wheat help much, according to U.S. Agriculture Department officials.

DOC.HEAD: MIT Nears $23,000 a Year, is Nation's Priciest College
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts Institute of Technology has replaced Bennington College of Vermont as the nation's most expensive college, with total expenses nearly $23,000 a year, a survey shows. Overall, college costs this fall rose an average of 5 percent to 8 percent, continuing a six-year moderating trend, according to the annual College Board survey released Wednesday. But with a possible recession and resurgent inflation, some college officials fear tuition may climb more sharply in the next few years. The survey found that fixed charges at four-year private institutions, including tuition, fees, room and board, average $13,544 - an 8 percent increase from last year's $12,557. The increase a year ago was 9 percent. The priciest such school, MIT, costs an estimated $22,945, counting tuition, fees, room and board, books and supplies, transportation and other expenses. Bennington, a small, selective liberal arts college, had been the most expensive private college every year since the 1985-86 school year; MIT was tops for the three years before that. This year, Bennington is fifth at $22,550. Yale University is second at $22,900, New York University third at $22,775 and Brandeis University fourth at $22,690. Rounding out the top 10, in order, are Harvard and Radcliffe colleges, Boston University, Sarah Lawrence College, Columbia University and Stanford University. All cost more than $22,000 a year. Several of the highest-priced schools, however, posted some of their smallest tuition increases in years. Columbia's rates were up just 5.7 percent, Stanford's 5.25 percent. At four-year public universities, fixed costs including room and board average $4,970, up 5 percent from $4,715. At two-year private colleges, fixed costs including room and board average $8,484, up 7 percent from $7,912 last year. Tuition and fees at two-year public institutions average $884, up 5 percent from last year's $841. Few such institutions provide room and board. The survey's averages are weighted to take enrollment into account. Colleges with large enrollments count more heavily than smaller schools. At their worst, costs at public and private institutions rose in double digits from 1981 through 1984. Rates at four-year public colleges shot up 20 percent in 1982-83. They settled into the 5 percent to 9 percent range the past six years. Richard Rosser, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities in Washington, labeled the moderation in cost increases ``progress, though not dramatic.'' ``We'd never expect to see the increases fall sharply,'' he said. But resurgent inflation and a looming recession could upset the pattern, Rosser said. Universities in Northern states, especially, will probably feel the pinch of rising oil prices. Arthur Hauptman, author of the recently published book ``The College Tuition Spiral,'' agreed. ``Assuming there is a decent jump in inflation, I would expect that this would lead to tuitions not further reducing themselves, and they might well go up, though not as fast as the overall inflation rate,'' said Hauptman, a consultant to the American Council on Education. He added that a recession might cause sharper tuition hikes at public universities especially, since economic downturns often prompt states to cut education spending. In response to the survey, U.S. Secretary of Education Lauro F. Cavazos urged parents to save money and familiarize themselves with financial aid sources. ``While the rapid rise of college costs experienced in the 1980s has slowed, many still perceive these costs as beyond their financial reach,'' he said in a statement. Nearly half of all families with college-age students receive public or private loans and grants, which totaled about $28 billion last year, the College Board said. The College Board is a private, non-profit education association whose members include more than 2,600 colleges, school systems and other education associations.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Taking a Long Shot at Capturing Another Seat Once Held By Quayle
DOC.TEXT: The battle for Dan Quayle's old Senate seat pits well-financed Republican incumbent Dan Coats against an obscure state legislator who took a 400-mile hike to meet Indiana voters. Baron Hill won the Democratic nomination to challenge Coats only after two better-known Democrats decided not to run. Coats, a former congressman, has a comfortable lead over Hill in recent polls and a $900,000 bank balance heading into the fall campaign. Hill, a businessman at a family-owned insurance and real estate agency, is short on campaign money. The flamboyant Hill resorted to literally walking the campaign trail, hiking north from the Ohio River to Lake Michigan, where he dived into 60-degree water. ``Whatever happens, this has been a great experience for me,'' Hill said as he dried off. Hill's camp disputes polling daa showing Coats with a wide lead. ``That's nuts,'' said Tim Phillips, the Democrat's campaign manager who says the undecided vote is actually above 40 percent. Coats was appointed to the Senate seat last year after Quayle resigned to become vice president. State law required a special election this year. The winner will face re-election in 1992, the year Quayle's term was to expire. In a March 1989 special election for Coats' congressional seat, Democrat Jill Long captured the heavily Republican district, which had once been held by Quayle. Long's victory stunned GOP chairman Lee Atwater and others in the party. ``Hill and Jill, Democrats in 1990,'' reads a political slogan summarizing Democrats' hopes. Hill attacked Coats early for supposedly lavish office expenses and taking generous advantage of the franking privilege to send voters millions of pieces of mail. A Hill television spot showed a farmer opening his mailbox only to be blown back by a rushing torrent of Coats mailings. A radio spot even offhandedly suggested the mailings posed an environmental threat by clogging landfills. That didn't stop the Coats mailings. But the senator soon took the offensive on an environmental issue, sponsoring legislation to stop out-of-state trash haulers, many identified as New Jersey haulers, from using Indiana landfills. Hill's TV spot ``grabbed enough voter attention to put Coats on the defensive,'' said political pollster Brian S. Vargus. ``So Coats came back with his New Jersey garbage men.'' Coats lately has concentrated on employing the perks and powers of incumbency to woo support. The out-of-state trash legislation passed Sept. 18, and two days later Coats upstaged the opposition by handing the Democratic mayor of Gary, Ind., a $2.5 million check for an airport expansion. He's even scrounged for money to save a local Army Reserve center. Coats is better known than Hill, but hasn't proven he can draw voters outside his former congressional district. ``I'm pretty well convinced that a large proportion of the electorate aren't even aware at this point there's an election in November,'' says Vargus. Coats has struggled to build the loyal following he will need to win if voter turnout is low. ``Name recognition does not always translate into political recognition,'' says Vargus, a sociologist at Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis who predicted Quayle's largely unexpected Senate victory in 1980. ``Even if (supporters) say they approve, they don't necessarily vote.'' The upset victory of Boston University president John Silber over former state attorney general Francis Bellotti in the Democratic primary for governor raises warning flags for incumbents everywhere, says Vargus, ``Lightning can strike, that does prove it,'' said Vargus.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves $2.5 Billion for Water Projects
DOC.TEXT: Legislation authorizing new water projects for flood control, storm damage reduction, inland navigation and port development in 18 states and Puerto Rico is heading to a conference committee. A bill approved 350-55 by the House on Wednesday will be taken up by a joint House-Senate panel soon to blend with similar legislation passed by the Senate. However, the $2.5 billion package of 25 Army Corps of Engineers water projects still must get over some other hurdles before work can begin. The projects are to be joint state-federal efforts, but no federal money has been appropriated yet, and President Bush has threatened to veto the bill in its present form. By far the most expensive project in the House bill is a $1.2 billion flood control effort in New Jersey that would divert waters from the northern Passaic Valley into Newark Bay. The project, with an estimated federal cost of $890 million, calls for construction of two large tunnels to divert water, modifications to the channels of the Passaic River and its tributaries and construction of levees and floodwalls. Rep. Robert A. Roe of Wayne, N.J., ranking member of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee, hailed passage as a ``major step in protecting the lives and property of the residents of the Passaic River Valley.'' A 1984 flood in the area cost three lives, forced the evacuation of 9,000 residents and caused an estimated $355 million in damage to homes and businesses. Flood tunnel opponents have urged the federal government to buy the property. But several New Jersey members of Congress say the purchase would cost about $4.6 billion, three times more than the flood tunnel. Another major project in the bill is a $545 million flood control effort in the Buffalo Bayou and its tributaries in Texas, encompassing most of the Houston metropolitan area. As an authorization bill, the measure does not directly result in expenditures. In order for the authorized money to be spent, it must be appropriated later in other legislation. The Bush administration has threatened to veto the bill for a number of reasons, including environmental and economic feasibility of some of the projects. The administration also opposes federal responsibility for developing recreation facilities, replacing a bridge, levee beautification and agricultural land improvements required in some of the projects. Other projects authorized in the bill are: -Navigation work for Bayou La Batre, Ala. -Storm damage prevention in Homer Spit, Alaska. -Flood control on the San Francisco River at Clifton, Ariz. -Flood control on Nogales Wash in Nogales, Ariz. -Flood control for Coyote and Berryessa Creeks in Santa Clark County, Calif. -Navigation and storm damage reduction in Oceanside Harbor, Calif. -Navigation of Ventura Harbor in California. -Storm damage reduction in Martin County, Fla. -Navigation in Miami Harbor Channel, Fla. -Navigation in the McAlpine Lock and Dam in Indiana and Kentucky. -Flood control in Fort Wayne, Ind., involving the St. Mary's and Maumee Rivers. -Flood control for Aloha-Rigolette, La. -Navigation in Boston Harbor. -Flood control in Ecorse Creek in Wayne County, Mich. -Navigation in the Great Lakes Connecting Channel and Harbors in Michigan and Minnesota. -Flood control in Coldwater Creek in Missouri. -Flood control in River Des Peres in Missouri. -Flood control in Rio De Le Plata in Puerto Rico. -Storm damage reduction in Myrtle Beach, S.C. -Multiple purpose project in the Ray Roberts Lake in Texas. -Flood control in the Upper Jordan River in Utah. -Flood control at Buena Vista, Va. -Flood control in Petersburg, W.Va.

DOC.HEAD: Oppression of Opponents Continues in Zaire, Amnesty Reports
DOC.TEXT: Security forces in Zaire continue to violently repress government opponents despite recent promises to expand the one-party political system and make other reforms, Amnesty International charged today. Although abuses have diminished in recent years, incidents of banishment, torture, and detentions without charge or trial are coming to light, the international human rights group said in a report. ``Appeals to the government to investigate these incidents have been ignored and the authorities have shown themselves unwilling to take disciplinary action against (security forces),'' the group said. The government of President Mobutu Sese Seko, which has ruled the central African country since 1965, last spring promised a series of political reforms. In April, Mobutu made a series of improvements, including giving citizens the right to form opposition political parties and trade unions. In May, he promised an end to internal banishment and incommunicado detention, and the release of all uncharged political prisoners - pledges which remain unfulfilled, said the London-based organization. ``The Zairean security services, which are directly responsible to the president, maintain extensive powers to arrest and detain political suspects and hold them in arbitrary and incommunicado detention, where many have been ill-treated and tortured,'' Amnesty said. Security forces involved in the abuses include a special service responsible for immigration, an elite presidential guard and a paramilitary police group which helps to control borders, it said. Since January 1988, Amnesty has received reports of several hundred people arrested and imprisoned for political reasons, the report says. Most of those targeted are members of the opposition Union for Democracy and Social Progress. In July, more than 12 members were arrested and some were allegedly beaten while holding a meeting, said the human rights group. It did not detail whether the members were detained. Security forces have also killed government opponents, the report says. Most recently, the forces were implicated in the reported killing of at least 12 students on May 11-12 at Lubumbashi University, it says. The government initially denied responsibility for the killings, but a parliamentary inquiry led to the arrests of the governor of the Shaba region and other government officials. Belgium, Zaire's former colonial ruler, has called for an international investigation of the incident and Zaire's refusal has helped sour relations between the countries, Amnesty said. In addition, at least five students were reportedly killed in February 1989 when soldiers dispersed unarmed demonstrators at Kinshasa, said the report.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Kills `Motor Voter' Registration Bill
DOC.TEXT: The Senate has effectively killed the ``motor voter'' bill, which would link voter registration to filling out applications for drivers licenses. The Senate voted 55-42 Wednesday to limit debate on the question of whether to take up the legislation. The margin was five votes short of the 60 needed. ``The Senate will revisit this measure in the next Congress,'' said Sen. Wendell Ford, D-Ky., the chief sponsor. It provides that individuals would automatically be registered as voters when applying for drivers licenses. To avoid becoming registered, they could check off a box designated for that purpose on the license application. State governments would have to use the same forms to license drivers and register voters. Voters also could register through the mail and at the offices of various federal agencies. Backers of the measure say the needy and unsophisticated are discouraged by difficult and overly complex registration procedures in many communities. Critics say the legislation could lead to voter fraud. They questioned whether safeguards would be effective which are designed to verify that those who register actually live where they say they do. Democratic leaders wanted a time limit on debate, fearing that the bill's largely Republican critics would talk it to death by filibustering with only a few weeks left in this year's congressional session. Among Republicans, only Oregon Sens. Mark Hatfield and Bob Packwood voted in favor of taking up the bill. Three others did not vote, Sens. David Durenberger of Minnesota, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and Pete Wilson of California. All other Republicans were opposed while the measure was supported by all but two Democrats, Sens. Max Baucus of Montana, and Howell Heflin of Alabama. Similar legislation was passed by the House on Feb. 6 with bipartisan support. Next year, Ford will ``continue the fight to strengthen our democratic process by making the voting booth more accessible to all Americans,'' he said in a statement. Lawmakers acted out of ``fear that registering millions more voters would upset the political status quo,'' League of Women Voters President Susan S. Lederman said in a statement. ``I think voters will find it unacceptable that the same legislators who argue so righteously for greater turnouts on election day vote to kill the one bill that would make voter registration fairer and simpler,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Nation Tapping Oil Stockpile for First Time
With PM-Bush-Oil, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American taxpayers have paid $19.4 billion to store oil in six underground salt caverns in Louisiana and Texas. Now they will get their first payback. President Bush's decision Wednesday to tap the Strategic Petroleum Reserve for 5 million barrels of oil in hopes of calming soaring prices, is the first time the country's petroleum safety net has been put to use. The reserve has a rocky history and its existence stems from this country's first major oil shock - the Arab oil embargo in 1973-74 that first brought home to millions of Americans the dangers of relying too heavily on foreign oil. It is the first use of the oil reserve as an economic weapon, although the government tapped it for 1 million barrels of crude in 1985 to test the system. A year later, the Reagan administration used the threat of a drawdown to curtail a price spiral that was occurring because of the Iran-Iraq war, industry analysts said. Congress authorized the petroleum reserve in 1975 and the first drop of oil went into storage areas two years later. Over the years, a series of salt caverns were excavated along the Texas and Louisiana coasts to store the oil - 590 million barrels as of today. Creation of the reserve has been a massive undertaking. Early oil shipments went into abandoned salt mines. When those were filled, the caverns were carved out of rock-hard salt through massive injection of water. Oil does not dissolve salt, so the salt created a permanent subterranean enclosure. A typical cavern is 2,500 feet high and 246 feet wide - about as wide and more than twice as tall as the World Trade Center in New York City. Creation of the reserve has not been without its problems and controversies. Originally envisioned to cost $6 billion to $7 billion, the price tag is close to $20 billion and rising. Congress recently voted to enlarge the reserve from a maximum of 750 million barrels to 1 billion barrels by the end of the decade. There have been huge cost overruns and delays. Originally the reserve was scheduled to have been full by this year; instead, it is about 150 million barrels short of the goal. Over the years there have been charges of fraud and mismanagement, millions of dollars of equipment missing, allegations that inferior oil - even toxic waste - was being put into the salt caverns. The government was accused of paying inflated prices for oil. When oil was cheap briefly in the late 1970s, the government wanted to speed up filling the reserve but couldn't build new caverns fast enough to take advantage of the low price. And when the second oil shock hit in 1979 with the fall of the shah in Iran, prices soared and the Carter administration suspended purchases for the reserve altogether. The Reagan administration repeatedly sparred with Congress over how much oil to put into the reserve. In 1984, the administration sought to again halt purchases, arguing that petroleum was too expensive and the purchases were a drain on the budget. Congress disagreed. Today, the reserve holds 590 million barrels of oil, enough to supply the country for 73 days should there be a total cutoff of oil imports. The government must buy oil on the open market for the reserve. Much of it has come from Mexico and British fields in the North Sea. Only 6.6 percent is domestically produced. The salt caverns are connected by a maze of pipelines that can be directly connected to commercial refinery distribution systems. Officials said it would take 16 days for the Energy Department to award oil contracts under an auction system. The reserve can make available 3.5 million barrels of oil a day when in full operation. Bush has only asked for 5 million barrels as a test designed to send a signal to the petroleum markets, according to officials.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pushes for Progress in Clean Air Talks
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is warning that hard-fought clean air legislation may fall apart unless Congress steps up efforts to work out a compromise. The president Wednesday bemoaned the slow progress of House-Senate negotiations on a final clean air package and offered a compromise proposal ``to help break the logjam that once again has appeared.'' House and Senate members have been struggling since early July to resolve differences in separate clean air bills that won overwhelming approval in each chamber earlier this year. The legislation, which calls for tough new air pollution controls on factories, electric utilities and automobiles, represents the first tightening of federal air pollution laws in 13 years. But the talks have bogged down on details of the massive legislation. In a letter to the leaders of the House and Senate negotiating teams, the president said the talks have strayed away from what the administration wants and that ``the slow progress ... may jeopardize enactment'' of a bill before Congress adjourns next month. The administration's new plan took provisions from both the House and Senate bills, did not contain any new initiatives. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House delegation, said he wondered why the administration didn't send up the proposal when the issue was before the House last spring. Environmentalists also were not impressed by the White House initiative. ``They picked the weakest part of each bill except on acid rain,'' said Daniel Weiss, who has followed the clean air debate for the Sierra Club. Administration officials said their new proposal was $3 billion cheaper than either the House or Senate bill. The White House all along has expressed concern about the cost of the wide-reaching air pollution controls, estimating that both the Senate and House versions will cost industry more than $25 billion a year when all the new requirements take effect. While there is general agreement between both the House and Senate on tough new controls to reduce acid rain, toxic industrial chemical releases and urban smog, disagreements remain on details in each of these areas. ``We're concerned that they're not taking action fast enough,'' said William Rosenberg, an assistant administrator at the Environmental Protection Agency. He characterized the administration proposal as an attempt to ``bridge the gap'' between the House and Senate. A White House official acknowledged that the proposal in part was an attempt to get the Bush administration more closely involved in the clean air discussions on Capitol Hill. ``The president has been frozen out in the process and the results have been stalemated,'' said the official, who spoke under the condition that he not be named. He said the view from the White House was that ``the clock is ticking and the conferees were not delivering.'' Earlier this month the negotiators announced a tentative agreement on reducing smog-causing pollution from industrial sources and on permitting requirements for industry. Previously they reached agreement on how to deal with chemicals that damage the atmospheric ozone layer. But the two sides have yet to take up in detail a number of other controversial issues including how far to go to ensure the public protection from toxic chemical releases by industry and whether to provide job-loss assistance to workers who become unemployed because of the tougher pollution controls.

DOC.HEAD: Goetz Version of Shooting Contradicts Defense
DOC.TEXT: Subway gunman Bernhard Goetz, contradicting the defense that got him acquitted in 1987, conceded he stuck his gun in a wounded teen-ager's ribs and shot him, telling the victim: ``You don't look too bad, here's another.'' Goetz, in a deposition released Wednesday, also undercut defense attorney Barry Slotnick's assertion at trial that the gunman never hesitated between shots when he opened fire on four young men in a subway car in 1984. Goetz, who is white, also acknowledged making racist comments before the day he shot the black teen-agers. The deposition is part of a $50 million lawsuit filed against Goetz by one of his victims, Darrell Cabey, 22. ``I hope the jurors in that trial wake up screaming in the night when they read this,'' said attorney William Kunstler, who questioned Goetz for Cabey. Cabey was left paralyzed and brain damaged by Goetz. The three other youths recovered and were later arrested on various criminal charges. Goetz asserts he fired because the four were about to mug him. Goetz, 42, was acquitted of attempted murder, assault and other charges. He served 8{ months in jail for a weapons offense. He never testified at his trial, answering questions under oath Monday for the first time about the shootings. Goetz said he was on the subway less than 30 seconds before opening fire with his .38-caliber revolver. Kunstler asked Goetz about the last shot he fired at Cabey, who was struggling to get out of a seat. ``I walked directly in front of that person, put the gun in his ribs, and pulled the trigger again with the words, `You don't look too bad, here's another,' '' Goetz replied. After his arrest in New Hampshire, he was videotaped by police as giving a similar account. Slotnick had argued at Goetz's trial that his client ``fantasized'' making that statement. Slotnick also argued that Goetz emptied his gun rapid-fire without pause, meaning he could not have spoken to anyone before firing. ``The mind of Bernhard Goetz, full of stress and fear, might have recounted a lot of things that didn't actually happen,'' Slotnick told the jury. Goetz specifically repudiated that and said he stood by all the statements he made on the New Hampshire video. He had also told police there he wanted to gouge out the eyes of one of his victims. Goetz also was asked by Ronald Kuby, Cabey's co-counsel, ``Did you say at a block meeting or community meeting or building meeting, in words or substance, `The only way we are going to clean up the street is to get rid of the spics and niggers?'
