'' ``Yes I did,'' Goetz responded. ``That was at a community meeting.'' Cabey's lawyers believe this demonstrates racism was at play when Goetz opened fire. The youths said they didn't plan to rob Goetz and that they were only panhandling for money to play video games. Goetz also discussed his finances. His defense fund collected about $60,000 in donations. His annual income since the shooting has dropped from as high as $100,000 to about $20,000, and his assets are down from $250,000 to $6,000.

DOC.HEAD: Only Two Eligible to Vote on Montgomery County Ballot Issue
DOC.TEXT: Here's a political prediction that can be taken to the bank: Question J on the Montgomery County, Md., ballot will pass Nov. 6 - overwhelmingly. One elderly couple, who are the only voters eligible to cast ballots on the issue, guarantee it. Sometime before polls close Nov. 6, Montgomery County elections administrator Doug Jernigan will type out two ballots and personally deliver them to Martin and Mildred Darnall. Those ballots will be unique because they'll be the only ones containing Question J, which would put the Hitching Post Restaurant back into Prince George's County. Since the Darnalls are the only property owners affected, they are the only eligible voters. While the ballot question is not the most burning issue of the political season, for Mrs. Darnall it'll mean a chance to putter around the garden. The Darnalls have owned the combination cafe-liquor store near Burtonsville, Md., for more than 41 years, and they've been ready to retire for four years now. ``I got sick. I had a real bad time. I was a cancer patient,'' recalled Mrs. Darnall, 73, in a telephone interview. ``With our age and the physical handicaps, we thought we should sell. We had numerous buyers just hollering to buy the place.'' But when negotiations began to get serious, Mrs. Darnall and her 75-year-old husband were shocked to learn their establishment was part of Montgomery County. For nearly four decades the Darnalls thought they were part of Prince George's County. They paid taxes to Prince George's County, they were registered to vote in Prince George's and their liquor license was issued by Prince George's County. But in the early 1980s, there was a slight shifting on the boundary between the two counties, and the Darnalls weren't informed. The difference is significant for would-be buyers. Montgomery's zoning and liquor control ordinances are much stricter than neighboring Prince George's. Instead of making an easy sale, the Darnalls became frustrated as one prospective buyer after another lost interest after learning they would be subject to Montgomery County regulations. So the Darnalls enlisted the help of state Delegate Sheila Ellis Hixson, D-Montgomery, who pushed a bill through the General Assembly last spring that put Question J on the ballot. There's no doubt how the Darnalls will vote; Mrs. Darnall is more concerned now about getting another buyer given the area's current real estate slump. While she refused to reveal the asking price, other sources say the property is worth slightly more than $1 million. ``There have been no complaints on the price. Except now, nobody has any money,'' Mrs. Darnall said. If the couple is able to unload their business, Mrs. Darnall has her retirement planned. ``I'd just like to one time in my life to have a house, a garden and just live a normal life. I just wanted to be a harried homeowner.''

DOC.HEAD: Bernard Sanders Calls for Troop Reductions in The Middle East
DOC.TEXT: Bernard Sanders, the avowed Socialist who is running for Congress, is calling for U.S. troop reductions in the Middle East. Sanders said President Bush deserves credit for his initial handling of the crisis, adding that he supports having other countries contribute more to the multinational force to prevent Iraq from further expansion. ``It is impossible, of course, to estimate what an effective U.N.'' (United Nations) force would number, but my initial guess would be that it would not be necessary for the U.S. to have more than'' 40,000 to ``50,000 troops in the region,'' said Sanders. His answers were in response to questions from three Vermont newspapers. In an interview Wednesday, Sanders said he would ``like to see ... replacement of American troops with troops from Europe.'' ``I would like to see more of a presence from'' France and England, he said. Sanders, a former four-term mayor of Burlington, is running against first-term incumbent Rep. Peter Smith, a Republican. Sanders is running as an independent. About 165,000 U.S. soldiers are stationed in the Saudi desert and aboard ships in the region. Thousands of Arab and European troops have also been deployed as part of the U.S.-led multinational force.

Vice President Quayle completed a two-day California tour a week after President Bush visited the state, and their appearances raised more than $2.3 million for local Republicans. Most of the money goes to Pete Wilson for his tight gubernatorial race against Dianne Feinstein, a campaign Republicans consider vital because the next governor will have a strong say in drawing congressional districts. ``This is our No. 1 race in the country: to elect Pete Wilson as governor of the state of California,'' Quayle told about 500 members of the Los Angeles Republican Federation of Women on Wednesday. Quayle's fund-raising stops raised as much as $150,000 for the state GOP and another $150,000 for state Sen. Marian Bergeson's campaign for lieutenant governor, said California Republican Party spokesman Dan Schnur. This followed Bush's appearances last week in San Francisco and Los Angeles that raised about $2 million for Wilson.

DOC.HEAD: Gubernatorial Candidates Position Themselves Under Campaign Limit Ban
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, `U.S. Sen. ...' to ADD that Feinstein is former mayor.
DOC.TEXT: California's Republican candidate for governor threatened to ``fight fire with fire'' and crank up fund raising like his Democratic opponent after a judge threw out limits on campaign contributions. Democrat Dianne Feinstein's staff began telling supporters Wednesday they can exceed the state's voter-approved limits because of the judge's ruling. U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson, who is thought to have a fund-raising lead over Feinstein, challenged the former San Francisco mayor to abide by the limits despite the ruling. But he left open the possibility he also would exceed them. ``We may have to fight fire with fire,'' he said. U.S. District Judge Lawrence Karlton on Tuesday struck down as unconstitutional Proposition 73, approved by voters in 1988. It allowed an individual to give up to $1,000 per candidate per fiscal year. It set higher limits for parties and political action committees. Dee Dee Myers, a spokeswoman for Feinstein, said Wilson, as a senator, had been able to set up a network of individual contributors. ``We're not going to abide by fund-raising limits that have been thrown out as unconstitutional because it's in Pete Wilson's advantage to do so,'' she said. ``He obviously has an interest in locking in the status quo.'' Meanwhile, state officials urged a delay of the ruling, which came six weeks before the Nov. 6 election. The state Fair Political Practices Commission asked Karlton to suspend his decision pending an appeal, saying the ruling so close to the election would give an advantage to candidates ``who can raise large sums on short notice.'' Karlton refused to suspend the ruling immediately. Instead, he scheduled a hearing on the motion for Friday. State Sen. Quentin Kopp and Assembly Minority Leader Ross Johnson, authors of the contribution limits, asked an appeals court to delay the judge's ruling, saying the ``integrity of the electoral process'' could be at stake. Wilson, who had only token opposition in the June primary, reported raising $12.5 million through June and said he had $3.9 million in the bank as of July 1. Feinstein raised $8.1 million in the same period and had only $645,344 left after defeating state Attorney General John Van de Kamp in the primary. Spokesman for both candidates claimed not to know how much had been raised since June. The California governor's race has been targeted as a top priority of both national political parties because of the governor's authority to sign or veto the congressional redistricting bill the 1991 Legislature must enact. California is expected to gain seven seats in Congress based on the 1990 census, boosting its delegation to 52 seats. Leaders of both parties say control of 10 or more of those seats could be determined by which party occupies the governor's office.

DOC.HEAD: Troop Deployment Strikes at Heart of Desert Marine Base Town
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto LA4
DOC.TEXT: About the only thing getting a trim at Charlene's House of Beauty these days is Charlene's profits. For Charlene Luongo and other merchants who rely on the adjacent Marine base for their livelihood, the Persian Gulf crisis delivered a one-two punch: first the town lost thousands of Marines, then it lost many of their wives and girlfriends. ``The way I understand it, they went home to mama,'' said Ms. Luongo, her beauty chair empty at midday. ``I've lost about 50 percent of my business.'' The military won't give numbers, but business officials guess at least 6,000 Marines left for Saudi Arabia. About 12,500 people live in Twentynine Palms and a like number at the Marine Corps Training Center, the nation's biggest Marine base. With such a large bite taken out of the local population, signs of change are everywhere in this Mojave Desert city, 140 miles east of Los Angeles in high desert terrain of jagged ridges and hills dotted with Joshua trees. Streets are quieter, many parking lots are vacant, and everywhere, there's yellow ribbon. Yellow ribbons are tied on front door handles, taped to display windows and attached to car attennas. Even the gate to the pet motel on the outskirts of town has yellow ribbon fluttering in the warm desert wind. ``The Marines are very much a part of this community,'' said Ed Haley, a retired Marine and owner of Twentynine Palms Liquor, where business is off 25 percent. ``They're sort of missed. We do want to see more get here. And we hope to get the others get back.'' Though shopkeepers are trying to remain optimistic, business is down at least 20 percent at many stores, according to the Chamber of Commerce. Merchants fear that unless the military sends more troops to the base, some shops will close before year's end. ``The important thing is what the next step is going to be,'' said Bill Gutgesell, the city's community development director. ``Is it going to stay in limbo like this, or will they complement the activity on the base and supply it with more reserves? Of course, they don't tell us anything.'' First and hardest hit were the businesses that cater directly to the Marines: tattoo parlors, bars, nightclubs, tire stores, barber shops that advertise regulation cuts, and laundries with specials for uniforms. Other businesses also are feeling the pinch: women's clothing shops, convenience markets, gas stations and fast-food restaurants. The $150-per-ceremony wedding chapel, packed with couples in the early days of the deployment, stands empty, save for the white benches and peach bows. Mayor Lester W. Krushat said the loss of troops has yet to be felt on the tax base of this young city, incorporated in 1987. ``But time will tell,'' he said. City leaders here are quick to point out that theirs is more than just a Marine base community. They say many residents are retirees, drawn by the warm, dry weather, clean air and friendly neighbors. The city also is near the Joshua Tree National Monument, a camping destination. In October, the town celebrates Pioneer Days, an old-time, Western festival. ``Yes, business is down, but we'll survive,'' said Karen Van den Hout, executive director of the Chamber of Commerce. ``Our main concern is that these guys (troops) are supported, that they know it, and that they get back in one piece.'' The deployment, many residents say, has been hardest on the young wives and girlfriends - the women without children or any strong ties to the community. The military sponsors counseling sessions and support groups for the women, but many just packed up and went home to their parents. Officials estimate at least 5 percent of the Marine dependents have left town. ``To a young girl out here it seems a little difficult for them because there's not the things to do that they're used to,'' said Grace Jernigan at Something Special, an arts and crafts store. Something Special, owned by Jernigan's daughter, is one of the few stores where business hasn't dropped. She said many women in town are turning to such hobbies as needlepoint and quilt-making. ``It's good therapy,'' said Jernigan. ``If you keep your mind off things. You're not sitting around worried all the time.''

DOC.HEAD: Juan Pons Triumphs Over Tragedy in `Rigoletto'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No other version planned.
DOC.TEXT: It was triumph over tragedy for baritone Juan Pons, who portrayed the title role in the first of 11 performances of ``Rigoletto'' by the Metropolitan Opera this season. Pons stood out among the cast Wednesday night as the hunchbacked court buffoon in Giuseppe Verdi's tragic masterpiece. So what if he shouldn't have stood so straight? His voice was great. He sounded convincingly tormented in his Act 1 solo after he is cursed. Particularly compelling was his duet at the end of Act 2 with soprano June Anderson, who portrayed Rigoletto's daughter, Gilda. Although Miss Anderson had some trouble with the high notes throughout the night, her Act 1 solo, especially the cadenza and trill just before Gilda's abduction, was just heavenly. The story, based on Victor Hugo's play ``Le roi s'amuse,'' is set in 16th century Italy and begins at the Duke of Mantua's palace. What's supposed to be an orgy led by the womanizing duke actually seemed a bit tame in the Otto Schenk production. The duke already has seduced the daughter of Count Monterone, paws the wife of a courtier, and lusts for the maiden he has spotted in church. Monterone bursts into the party and after being derided by Rigoletto responds by vowing ``maledetto'' - revenge. After the duke finds out the maiden is his jester's daghter, she is abducted - with the unwitting help of Rigoletto. Cries the clown: ``Ah! La maledizione!'' (the curse). Gilda is carried back to the palace, is conquered by the duke, and tells all to her father. Still, she says, she loves the duke. Rigoletto eventually hires an assassin to kill his employer, but his daughter is murdered instead after the assassin's sister Maddelena is courted by the duke. Bass Nicolai Ghiaurov, as the unscrupulous hitman Sparafucile, gave a brawny performance; Wendy White was an especially tempting Maddelena; and the boyish conductor Guido Ajmone-Marsan did a firm job melding the large ensemble in his Metropolitan Opera debut. Somewhat disappointing was tenor Jerry Hadley as the Duke of Mantua. He's a good actor, but he sounded nasal at times. He got off to a weak start with the aria ``Questa o quella,'' and during the opera's most famous aria, ``La donna e mobile'' in Act 3, his voice just didn't project. Baritone Alan Held, who played Monterone, had the opposite problem. His voice was solid, but his acting was a bit wooden, especially when he cast the hex on Rigoletto. The scenery, slightly different than last year's, was realistic and the sky looked especially ominous. The Met's other performances of ``Rigoletto'' are Sept. 29, Oct. 3, 6, 16, 20, 23, 26, Jan. 4, 9, and 12.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Stocks Fall 2 Percent; Dollar Slightly Higher
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange sank on Thursday to a 21-month low, while the dollar closed slightly higher against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 478.71 points, or 2.15 percent, to post 21,478.71 points at the close of the day's trading, its lowest closing level since Jan. 4, 1988. Volume was 430 million shares. The index on Wednesday shed 1,108.70 points, or 4.75 percent, in its ninth largest single-day decline. The dollar closed at 137.50 yen, up 0.10 yen from Wednesday's close. The currency opened at 137.48 yen, and dealing ranged between 137.40 yen and 138.10 yen. On the bond market, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 8.685 percent by 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT), down slightly from Wednesday's record high 8.690-percent finish. The price was higher at 80.81 points, up from 80.73. Traders blamed the early morning stock market decline on selling by individual investors. The traders said brokers called in loans after Wednesday's steep fall, meaning investors had to sell shares to raise money they had borrowed to buy stocks. Also affecting the market were New York's weak showing and news that Iraq has threatened the death penalty for anyone hiding foreigners in diplomatic embassies. ``The market started down and just slumped for much of the morning,'' said Steve Usher, assistant general manager at Kleinwort Benson International. ``Sentiment is very bad,'' said Hidetaka Yoshida of Kidder Peabody International Corp. Pension funds began purchasing blue chips when the market hit a morning low, traders said. The technical rebound represented a flight to quality by some bargain-hunters who believe the market has bottomed out, Usher said. A significant group of market players thinks there is more downside to come, however. Roughly equal trading volumes before and after the morning low suggest, he said, ``there is not much conviction on either side.'' Higher oil prices from Wednesday spurred pessimism in the market. However, crude oil prices were falling in Asia on Thursday in reaction to news that the United States would be selling 5 million barrels of its nearly 600 million-barrel strategic petroleum reserve. The bad news about Iraq's threat, however, overwhelmed any positive impact from the announcement, traders said. In Asia on Thursday morning, West Texas Intermediate crude oil for December delivery was said to be sold at $1.15 a barrel discount to its closing Wednesday New York Mercantile Exchange level of $37.13 per barrel. The contract for November delivery of light sweet crude settled at $38.67 Wednesday at the Merc.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Experts Preach Calm After Shaker
DOC.TEXT: Experts preached calm after an earthquake that rattled people in six states, saying it isn't necessarily a precursor to the catastrophic Big One predicted for December. No major damage or injuries were reported from Wednesday morning's quake or a second, smaller one that night. The quakes, felt in Missouri, Arkansas, Illinois, Kentucky, Tennessee and Indiana, were in the New Madrid Fault zone. For months, people along the seismic zone have been worrying about scientist Iben Browning's contention that there's a 50-50 chance for a major quake there on or about Dec. 3. Many scientists have dismissed the prediction. Doug Wiens, professor of earth and planetary sciences at Washington University in St. Louis, said there is no extra cause for alarm. ``I'm worried about this sort of hysterical tone that's come out, where people are planning to take trips, close schools, close businesses on December 3, because it is completely ridiculous,'' he said. The U.S. Geological Survey said the first quake Wednesday measured 4.6 on the Richter scale. The second was believed to be an aftershock and measured a preliminary 3.0, said David Stewart, director of the Center for Earthquake Studies in Cape Girardeau. Although the quakes were off the New Madrid Fault proper, they fell within the fault zone. Each year, about 200 measurable quakes occur in the zone, Stewart said, but only about three a year pack enough power to be felt. In fact, before Wednesday, three were felt this year: a 2.8 quake on Jan. 9, a 3.1 on Aug. 7, and a 3.4 on Aug. 29. Said Stewart: ``We expect them every now and then. When they happen, they normally mean nothing.'' Although the quake was relatively minor, it was the second largest in the New Madrid Fault zone this century, said Stewart. The largest - 5.0 - hit in 1976 and was centered near Marked Tree, Ark. A quake of magnitude 7.1 - which was mentioned in Browning's predictions - would be about 3,000 times more powerful than a quake of 4.6. Did Wednesday's shaker make residents more nervous? ``Of course it does, are you kidding?'' said Carolyn Tinsley, who owns a video rental store in Scott City, about 10 miles from the quake's epicenter of New Hamburg. ``I'd like to move if I could.'' In New Hamburg, a town of about 200 in the Missouri Bootheel, students at the Kelso C-7 Elementary School felt the quake. ``It sounded like people moving their desks up on the second floor,'' said eighth-grader John Koepp. ``I wasn't scared.'' Moments before the temblor, teacher Donna Robert had been asking a student whether her mother, who experienced a major earthquake in Alaska, might be interested in coming to class to talk about earthquakes. ``It was like the voice of God speaking. I couldn't believe it,'' she said. In Dover, Tenn., Flossie Rouse said it felt like ``somebody was taking the mattress and shaking it. Dishes and things in my china cabinet were rattling like crazy. The whole house was shaking.'' The New Madrid Fault runs from Marked Tree, Ark., across southeastern Missouri to southern Illinois. It's named for the town of New Madrid, about 40 miles south of New Hamburg and 140 miles southeast of St. Louis. In 1811-12, a series of quakes estimated up to 8 on the Richter scale struck the New Madrid region, causing the Mississippi River to appear to flow backward and ringing church bells in Washington, D.C., more than 850 miles away. Browning, a climatologist and business consultant in New Mexico, said there was a 50-50 chance of an earthquake measuring 7.0 or greater on or about Dec. 3. Browning was unavailable for comment Wednesday, his secretary said. Browning said tidal forces coming to a head on or about Dec. 3 could unleash various kinds of geological violence around the globe. Earthquake experts have for the most part dismissed his theory. Wiens said experts have found no link between tidal forces and earthquakes. In fact, tidal forces were low Wednesday. But school has been canceled for Dec. 3 in at least one district in Arkansas. Vacations by city employees in Carbondale, Ill., have been prohibited that week. Earthquake preparedness seminars have been playing to packed crowds. The Mexico City earthquake in 1985 measured 8.1. Last October's earthquake in San Francisco measured 7.1.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Calcium Stops Bone Loss in Older Women
DOC.TEXT: Millions of older women can keep their bones strong and help avoid the crippling effects of osteoporosis simply by consuming every day the amount of calcium contained in three glasses of milk, a study today concludes. Osteoporosis, the brittle bone disease, is one of the most common afflictions of growing old. It affects an estimated 15 million to 20 million Americans and primarily strikes women after menopause, when their bodies make less estrogen. The research found that by bringing up calcium consumption to the recommended daily allowance - 800 milligrams or the equivalent of 24 ounces of milk - can completely stop the loss of bone in the hips, wrist and spine after about age 55. ``The people who benefited most substantially were those who had a low usual intake of calcium in their diets - under 400 milligrams a day,'' said Dr. Bess Dawson-Hughes, the study's director. ``That's about a serving and a half of calcium rich food. The depressing thing is that millions of women in the United States in this age group have an intake this low.'' While older women are often advised to eat plenty of calcium, some experts have doubted whether it really does prevent osteoporosis. ``It's very important that they showed a calcium effect. That should be trumpeted,'' commented Dr. Robert Recker of Creighton University. Dawson-Hughes and colleagues conducted the study at the U.S. Department of Agriculture Human Nutrition Research Center on Aging at Tufts University. It was published in the New England Journal of Medicine. ``Evidence is mounting that calcium matters,'' said Dawson-Hughes. ``Here is the first real proof that it makes a difference in older women.'' According to a national survey, the average calcium consumption among women over age 44 is 475 milligrams. Dairy products are a primary source of calcium, and a quart of milk contains 1,200 milligrams. Other sources include dark green vegetables such as broccoli, bony fish such as sardines, calcium tablets and foods that are fortified with extra calcium. Women often lose bone rapidly after they go through menopause, typically around age 50. The latest study found that adding calcuum does nothing to prevent this during the first five years after menopause. But by about age 55, enough calcium in the diet can stop the erosion completely. Dr. William Peck, dean of Washington University medical school, said that while the latest finding is important, women can still benefit from estrogen supplements to preserve their bones immediately after menopause. ``You don't want a women to think she can walk into the sunset eating a lot of calcium,'' he said. ``She won't be protected.'' The study was conducted on 301 women with low dietary calcium intake. Doctors tested 500-milligram daily doses of two forms of calcium - calcium carbonate, the type usually sold in calcium supplements, and calcium citrate malate. Calcium citrate malate worked better, stopping loss of bone in the spine, wrist and hip. Doctors said this form of calcium is absorbed more readily, although women may be able to achieve the same effect by taking larger doses of calcium carbonate. Calcium citrate malate is commercially available only in Citrus Hill Plus Calcium brand of grapefruit and orange juice. Procter & Gamble, which makes the juices, co-sponsored the latest study with the USDA. According to the company, 14 ounces of the juice contains 400 milligrams of calcium. Dawson-Hughes said she would like to see calcium citrate malate made available in tablet form. However, she added, ``My first choice for people to get their calcium is to use food sources, because their general nutritional requirements are more likely to be met than by popping pills.''

DOC.HEAD: Rejects Iraqi Threat As Repugnant
With PM-Gulf Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III says Iraq's threat to execute foreigners hiding in diplomatic embassies is ``repugnant'' and rejected a demand for the names of people given sanctuary in the embassies in Baghdad and Kuwait. Asked about the threat Wednesday, Baker said: ``We've received a note to that effect. It falls under the heading of the principle of the three R's, I think,'' Baker continued. ``We've read it, it's repugnant and we reject it.'' The note was delivered to the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. In Washington, however, Iraq's Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat denied Wednesday night that any such threats have been made by Iraqi officials. ``We're not threatening anyone,'' al-Mashat told reporters after a meeting a the State Department. He refused further comment. Later, U.S. officials said al-Mashat, when asked about the Iraqi warning note to the embassy, claimed to be unaware of its existence. These officials spoke on condition that they not be named. Some 300 to 350 U.S. citizens are stranded in Iraq, and an additional 600 to 700 in Kuwait, according to figures released Monday by the State Department. The department released this text of the Iraqi note from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs: ``Revolutionary Command Council Resolution No. 341 dated 8-26-90 stipulates that housing a foreigner for the purpose of hiding him or her from the authorities is a crime of espionage. The punishment of death shall be imposed on the individual who commits such a crime. ``The ministry will appreciate it if the esteemed mission would kindly inform the ministry of whether any of its citizens or any other nation's citizens are residing in the mission's embassies and your diplomatic residences, whether or not these citizens have contracts with the government or are working with foreign companies operating in Iraq.'' The United States has refused to discuss whether non-diplomats have been given refuge in the embassies. Iraq has been attempting to force foreign embassies in Kuwait to shut down for more than a month, contending there is no need for such operations because Kuwait is part of Iraqi territory. At the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, difficult conditions have prevailed for the past five weeks because water and electricity have been shut off and food supplies are scarce. During the meeting with al-Mashat, the U.S. officials also demanded that Iraq allow the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait to function normally by restoring water and electricity, the sources said. Earlier, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher criticized Iraq for refusing to provide the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad with the names of the 93 Americans Iraqi authorities have detained for use as human shields to deter attacks against military installations.

DOC.HEAD: Pizza Hut Gets a Taste of Soviet Bureaucracy, With Pepperoni
DOC.TEXT: Pizza Hut is trying to swallow a big slice of Moscow bureaucracy, battling to keep its two new restaurants open after health inspectors shut them, a company official says. Restaurant officials say the inspectors are unfamiliar with modern technology such as automatic dishwashers, or Western ways of preparing restaurant food, and that it's just a ``simple misunderstanding.'' The pizzerias, part of a $10 million joint venture between PepsiCo. Inc.'s European branch and the Moscow city restaurant department, opened Sept. 11, and feature American-style pizzas, garlic bread and salad bars for both dollars and rubles. Since they opened, Soviets have waited in long lines to dine at the red-and-white checkered tables, amid brass railings and fake tropical plants. On Sept. 20, however, the larger of the two Pizza Huts on Kutuzovsky Prospekt near a large foreigners' compound was shut down for 2{ days. On Wednesday, the second one, on Gorky Street near the Kremlin, also was closed. City sanitary inspector T. Piskaryova told the Tass news agency that raw, semi-cooked and cooked food was found side-by-side, in violation of city standards. The Pizza Huts also were found to lack large sinks to wash dishes, as a backup to their automatic dishwashers. Andrew Rafalat, the British-born deputy general director of the restaurants, said Wednesday that he was surprised by the closures and believes the inspectors are unfamiliar with Pizza Hut's techniques. ``We've set up joint ventures to transfer new ways of running restaurants, new technologies, new ways of training people, and clearly what we're doing is very different from the Soviets,'' he said in an interview at the reopened Kutuzovsky Prospekt restaurant as Western-trained waiters scurried by with pans of pizza and trays of soft drinks and beer. ``Now, I think that realization is just starting to dawn, and when they find that our ways of doing things doesn't jell with theirs, unfortunately the immediate reaction has been (to) close down, which is kind of disappointing to us, because ... if there's any areas that don't jell, let's talk about it,'' Rafalat said. One of the problems has been the lack of a manual dishwashing system. ``We're being told we have to have five-compartment sinks,'' he said. ``Well, we're saying, `Sorry chaps, we use dishwashers, actually, in today's world.' I mean, a dishwasher does the job better, probably. But that isn't taken into account in the Soviet regulations.'' Rafalat said kitchen plans were submitted to city officials months ago, and ``we assumed that those had been looked at, approved, but in reality, no one told us that they hadn't.'' Tass, citing fears of salmonella poisoning that occurred in Moscow a year ago, said unwashed vegetables were found next to prepared foods, in violation of standards. ``Those are things that, once we know about, we'll do to comply with the Soviet law, although we don't do it that way in any other country,'' Rafalat said. ``We have open kitchens because, again, our philosophy is that you have an open planned work area, our employees are trained in hygiene, and they handle it accordingly.'' Once Pizza Hut officials were able to explain their operations to the inspectors, they were allowed to reopen the Kutuzovsky Prospekt restaurant, he said. ``Nothing has changed at all since last Thursday. We're running exactly the same restaurant, but we now have a clean bill of health and we have an agreement to work jointly with the authorities to explain our technologies and the way we do things, which really should have happened a lot earlier,'' he said. Rafalat could not say when the Gorky Street restaurant would reopen, adding that workers there had to throw out about 220 pounds of dough Wednesday. ``It's a pretty substantial amount of food in a city which I don't think should be wasting food,'' he said. The larger restaurant has been serving around 2,000 customers a day, and many want two or three pizzas, forcing officials to restrict the number of pies a person can take out, he said. Rafalat said his objective was to ``find a common language'' with city officials, ``because that's the future of this country here. If they don't find a common language, then there's not going to be many more businesses opening up.'' ``Soviet bureaucracy is renowned for its ability to try and strangle businesses,'' he said. But he noted PepsiCo has 16 years of dealing with the Soviet bureaucracy - ``long enough to know that it's a factor of business life here, and we're going to keep punching our way through.''

DOC.HEAD: Study: U.S. Doctors' Fees Twice as High as Canadians'
DOC.TEXT: An economist delving into why Americans pay more than Canadians for health care has discovered one important reason: U.S. doctors charge twice as much for doing less. Despite their bigger fees, U.S. doctors earn only about one-third more than their Canadian counterparts, said the study. This is largely because they see fewer patients and have higher overhead for such things as fancier offices. Health care for Americans costs an average of $1,780 per year, while for Canadians it costs $1,286, according to the study by economist Victor R. Fuchs of Stanford University. Overall, physician fees are 2.4 times higher in the United States, he said. Differences in hospital bills and other expenses also contribute to the lower cost of medical care in Canada. However, Canadian doctors do not save money by skimping on patient care, Fuchs said. In fact, he found that they provide about 25 percent more services to their patients. Canada provides complete, fully paid health coverage for all citizens. In the United States, one in seven people has no health insurance, and even those with coverage typically have to pay at least part of the bill. ``If physician fees in the United States were the same as in Canada, by how much would total health care expenditures be reduced?'' said Fuchs. ``If the fees were cut in half and lowered to the Canadian level, total expenditures would be reduced by about 10 percent.'' His calculations, which converted Canadian figures into U.S. dollars, were based was based on 1985 data and published in today's issue of the New England Journal of Medicine. Among the findings: -U.S. fees for surgery and other high-tech services, such as X-rays and anesthesia, were more than three times higher. -On a per capita basis, Canada had more doctors but fewer specialists. -In 1985, net income for office-based doctors was $112,199 in the United States and $73,607 in Canada. -U.S. doctors are paid five times more than Canadians for visiting patients in the hospital. Canadian fees are uniform for each service within provinces and are set through negotiations between doctors and the government. Fuchs said he doubts the Canadian system could be adopted in the United States. ``There is reason to question whether the quality of our civil services is up to the quality of the Canadian civil services,'' he said. ``There is also reason to question whether the organization and degree of discipline in the profession is as strong as in Canada. We are very much individualists, and that includes physicians.''

DOC.HEAD: Calls Home Made Easier for Gulf Troops
DOC.TEXT:
U.S. military personnel in Saudi Arabia will be able to get U.S. long-distance operators on the telephone to speed their calls home beginning next week, says American Telephone & Telegraph Co. AT&T said Wednesday its USADirect service enables callers to deal immediately with AT&T operators stateside, thus avoiding possible language problems with international operators. Beginning Oct. 3, callers are to dial 1-800-100 to get an AT&T operator who will complete the call to anywhere in the United States. During an introductory period, AT&T will allow U.S. military personnel in Saudi Arabia to make free three-minute calls to the United States. The service will be available at most phones from virtually all U.S. military bases in Saudi Arabia. ``We want to give all those who are serving in Saudi Arabia a chance to call home,'' said Frank Ianna, AT&T vice president for marketing international communications services.
---
DOC.HEAD: Panel Says Restaurants As Well As Supermarkets Should Disclose
DOC.TEXT: Nutrition

Proposals to require food manufacturers to disclose the nutrition content of their products should be extended to restaurants, says a committee of experts. The Institute of Medicine panel also said Wednesday that nutrition labeling should be required for fresh and frozen meat and poultry, as well as prepared products. Food-labeling proposals on Capitol Hill and by the Food and Drug Administration already include many of the provisions the panel recommended for packaged food, seafood and produce. But neither the pending legislation nor the draft regulations addresses meat, poultry or restaurants. The institute is an affiliate of the National Academy of Sciences, the congressionally chartered private body established to provide scientific advice to government agencies. FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit said the agency planned to consider nutrition-content disclosure for restaurants some time in the future, but ``grocery stores are our higher priority.'' The FDA, part of the Department of Health and Human Services, last July proposed regulations that would require nutrition labeling for nearly all packaged foods and fresh produce and seafood.
---
DOC.HEAD: Sessions Defends FBI Stings
DOC.TEXT: FBI Director William S. Sessions is defending the bureau's undercover tactics, including the sting operation which videotaped Washington Mayor Marion Barry smoking crack cocaine. But Sessions acknowledged Wednesday that a jury's refusal to convict Barry of the charge arising from that sting may have underscored the ``need to be very careful and look very carefully before you elect to use a particular technique.'' Sessions also backed the FBI's use of undercover operations to catch people in the act of other misdeeds, as in the Abscam corruption investigation of a decade ago. ``When we gather evidence, it is not always simply a matter of walking up and asking the farmer if his eggs are fresh,'' Sessions said. The videotapes of Barry smoking crack ``were not suppressed under the law, they were allowed by the court, they were available to the jury and it did what it wanted to do with it, which is the genius of our system,'' Sessions said. On other subjects, the director said the FBI had no indication of Iraqi-sponsored terrorism since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last month.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth S.C. Lawmaker Pleads Guilty in FBI Sting
DOC.TEXT: A fourth state lawmaker pleaded guilty in an FBI vote-selling sting and faces up to 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Rep. Robert Kohn, one of 10 lawmakers indicted in the Statehouse corruption probe, resigned his seat Wednesday and pleaded guilty to conspiracy hours later in a plea bargain. He is cooperating with investigators and disclosed last month he had been working undercover for several months to snare other lawmakers in the FBI's Operation Lost Trust. Kohn, 45, a Republican from Charleston, admitted he offered to push a horse- and dog-racing bill and ask others to do so in return for $10,000. A move to bring up the bill failed in the House this year. At a hearing Wednesday, prosecutors showed a videotape of Kohn pocketing $2,500 on a yacht off Hilton Head Island last April 14. Kohn is seen sitting at a table with a drink when a wad of money is slid across the table. Kohn admitted the money came from lobbyist Ron Cobb, though Cobb is not seen in the picture. Cobb was working undercover for the FBI. FBI agent Mike Clemens said Kohn accepted $2,500 from Cobb on Jan. 16 and another $2,500 on the yacht. Kohn, a state representative since 1975, wouldn't comment after the hearing, citing a gag order imposed by U.S. District Judge Falcon Hawkins. No sentencing date was set.

DOC.HEAD: Hazardous Waste Cleanup Crew Arrested in Incineration Test
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of a plan to burn dioxin-tainted waste at a closed herbicide plant had five cleanup workers arrested for testing an incinerator. The employees of Vertac Site Contractors, a cleanup company, were arrested Wednesday on misdemeanor charges of violating a city ordinance regarding incineration, Police Chief Frank Neely said. The company has a state contract to dispose of nearly 30,000 barrels of hazardous waste at the plant, where herbicides, including the Vietnam-era Agent Orange, were made for decades. Much of the waste is contaminated with dioxin, a chemical believed to cause cancer and a range of other ailments. The plant, last owned by Vertac Chemical Corp., is high on the federal government's priority Superfund list for cleanup of hazardous waste sites. The company on Wednesday burned waste not containing dioxin in order to determine whether an incinerator can meet standards required for disposal of dioxin. ``The people opposed to the burn were able to obtain an affidavit for arrest for burning solid waste in the city,'' Neely said. City ordinances allow the burning of dioxin-tainted waste only; all other incineration is illegal, authorities said. The five workers arrested were released on their own recognizance, he said. Mayor Tommy Swaim, an incinerator supporter, criticized Municipal Judge Robert Batton for acting on the arrest request from two opponents, who contend that burning the waste is dangerous. ``This is a ridiculous arrest, totally ridiculous,'' Swaim said. ``The judge is totally out of line.'' Laura Nelson, a spokeswoman for the cleanup company, said test burning will be halted while ``we take the matter under legal advisement and some decision is made.'' Michael Smith, a lawyer for the workers, also criticized the arrests. ``What they've done is sworn out warrants against innocent people just doing their jobs,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rinfret No-Show at GOP Pow-Wow
DOC.TEXT: Pierre Rinfret's dark-horse gubernatorial campaign took another strange turn when he sat out a unity meeting with Republican leaders, demanding to be declared ``the undisputed head of our party.'' Rinfret, who is challenging Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo but has been fighting with his own party, had agreed to attend Wednesday's meeting of Westchester County GOP leaders but instead sent a spokesman with a resolution he wanted passed immediately. It urged Republicans to endorse his plan to freeze state spending, cut taxes and reduce state government. Rinfret also demanded that county party leaders ``recognize Pierre Rinfret as the undisputed head of our party and designate his race for governor as being of equal opportunity with any and all other races in the state.'' State party chairman J. Patrick Barrett said no action was taken on Rinfret's resolution because the meeting was informal. ``We had a lively discussion on how to elect our Republican state ticket,'' Barrett said. ``We strongly reaffirm our support for Pierre Rinfret for governor.'' In the four months since desparate GOP officials recruited him to challenge Cuomo's bid for a third fourth-year term, Rinfret has garnered attention with proposals like arming and training 100,000 vigilantes to fight crime in New York City, and selling the city subway system. Rinfret, 66, an economist and former unpaid adviser to President Nixon, also invited a TV reporter to his inauguration - and suggested her husband stay home. And the academic creditials in his campaign biography have been questioned. Last week, Rinfret threatened to drop out of the race and lashed out at his party's leaders, accusing them of hoarding a $3.25 million campaign war chest for their own benefit. He later dropped the threat. Republican state Sen. Roy Goodman said Wednesday's meeting was called to ``talk about the unity of this party.'' As the meeting got under way, a Rinfret aide handed out copies of a letter Rinfret sent to Barrett and GOP county chairmen. Rinfret said events in the last 24 hours ``have made my attendance a political impossibility.'' ``The legislative leaders of the Republican-controlled Senate have tried to buy me off with a handful of money,'' he wrote. ``Yesterday, I was offered a grand total of $40,000 to shut up, go away, and run a dismal campaign for governor.'' Nassau County GOP chairman Joseph Mondello said he had offered Rinfret $25,000 to help the campaign. Kavanau wouldn't say who offered the additional $15,000. An aide said Rinfret was unavailable for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor: McDonald's Man Hid Gun, Never Made a Threat
DOC.TEXT: A gunman who holed up in a McDonald's in what police assumed was a hostage standoff actually hid his gun in a bathroom, lay on the floor with 20 others inside and threatened no one, authorities says. Prosecutors said Wednesday they won't press for hostage-taking charges against Douglas Edward Girard, 32. ``There was no crime, period, inside McDonald's,'' said Sandi Gibbons, spokeswoman for the district attorney's office. Police had assumed the worst Monday when a gunman fled into the fast-food restaurant moments after a robbery of about $200 at a clothing store nearby. Police originally alleged Girard held McDonald's customers and employees hostage for nearly seven hours. The wait ended early Tuesday when officers lobbed ``flash-bang'' grenades inside and wrestled Girard to the ground. But on Wednesday, Gary Hearnsberger, a deputy district attorney, said, ``It does not appear that from any of the statements that he ever threatened anybody or said, `You can't leave.' '' ``He was kind of going along with the program,'' Hearnsberger said. ``He laid on the floor with the other people.'' Girard pleaded innocent Wednesday to armed robbery and weapons charges stemming from the clothing store robbery and a holdup of a flower shop Sept. 8. Police Lt. Ron Ingels said that a few people ran from the restaurant but most ducked under tables or fled to a basement after a cashier noticed the .38-caliber revolver in Girard's waistband and shouted a warning. ``He didn't wave the gun and order them to stay there,'' Ingels said. ``I suppose they thought that if they got up and walked out, something bad could happen.'' Knowing that Girard was inside and armed, arriving officers assumed they were dealing with a hostage situation, Ingels said. ``We arrive and we don't know what caused them to lay on the floor. We don't know if the guy ordered them to lay on the floor or what,'' Ingels said.

DOC.HEAD: NFL Calls Player to Explain Harassment Allegations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf pvs, `Kiam denied ...' to DELETE incomplete reference to newspaper; A version also moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: The NFL commissioner has summoned a New England Patriots player to his office to answer allegations he exposed himself and made a lewd suggestion to a woman sportswriter for the Boston Herald in the locker room. Meanwhile, the newspaper and national women's groups are demanding action against Patriots owner Victor Kiam and the player, Zeke Mowatt. Kiam, who also owns the company that makes Remington shavers, has been criticized for not condemning Mowatt. He was also quoted in news reports as referring to the Herald reporter, Lisa Olson, as ``a classic bitch.'' NFL commissioner Paul Tagliabue may decide to suspend, fine or reprimand Mowatt next week after he hears the player's side of the story, league spokesman Joe Browne said Wednesday. Olson has said that several members of the football team approached her naked in the locker room Sept. 17 and made lewd suggestions. The Herald reported five players were involved. Mowatt was said to be among them. The team said earlier this week that it had fined a player for harassing Olson. The player was not identified, and the amount of the fine was not disclosed. Meanwhile, the Herald ran an editorial Wednesday asking fans to stay away from Sunday's Patriots game, and sports editor Bob Sales said he sent a letter to Tagliabue calling for Kiam's suspension. Michele Himmelberg, president of the Association for Women in Sports Media, said her group would demand that Tagliabue make an example of Kiam to prevent ``unjust harassment'' from hindering women reporters in their work. The Boston chapter of the National Organization for Women is considering a boycott of Remington products. Kiam denied the comment attributed to him, saying he called Olson ``agressive'' only. He apologized for any mistreatment by his employees, but Olson refused to accept. ``How can I accept his apology after he questioned my professionalism in front of hundreds of thousands of television viewers?'' Olson said. ``It's obvious the Patriots are trying to bury the sexual harassment issue by trying to discredit me with blatant lies.'' She said the Patriots should name the players she said verbally and sexually harassed her, force them to undergo counseling, slap them with substantial fines and give the proceeds to a shelter for battered women. ``I was humiliated,'' she said. ``I was put through something so vile like that only because I am a woman.'' After the incident, Kiam was quoted as saying the Herald had been ``asking for trouble'' in sending a woman reporter into the locker room. Many newspapers have women sportswriters who regularly enter men's locker rooms for interviews.

DOC.HEAD: X is Out, NC-17 is In - And the Reviews Are Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to ADD Siskel and Ebert comment, raise reference to theaters refusing to show X-rated films; PICKS UP 11th graf pvs, `Laura Morgan ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Theater owners and filmmakers are giving the new movie rating NC-17 mixed reviews, saying it offers improvements over the ruinous X rating but still may prove troublesome. The Motion Picture Association of America eliminated the X rating on Wednesday, replacing it with NC-17, for no children under 17 admitted. It said the new label does not immediately carry the commercial stigma of X, which is so strong that many theater chains - including the nation's two largest - won't show X-rated films and many newspapers won't carry ads for them. The MPAA also said it will give film companies and theater owners more details on films it rates R, noting violence, sex and language. The PG-13, PG and G ratings will remain the same. Universal Pictures' X-rated ``Henry & June,'' a historical drama featuring some sex scenes, will be the first film bearing the NC-17 rating, Universal said. ``It's a great step,'' said Philip Kaufman, director of ``Henry & June.'' ``I'm just really delighted that we can show this film uncut in America and show the film the way I made it. It is not intended as a prurient film.'' Critics of the MPAA had been trying for months to change the system. They said the X rating, never copyrighted, had become synonymous with pornography because makers of hard-core adult films used it freely. The new rating will be copyrighted. That means it cannot be used by porno producers unless they submit their films for MPAA review, something they never do because it costs up to $2,000 per film. Film critics Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert, hosts of a syndicated movie-preview show, applauded the new category. ``It represents a victory for everyone who cares about truly adult films. I'm using adult here in the sense of mature, thoughtful, serious and intelligent - not in the sense of `dirty movies,' '' Ebert said. ``It's good news,'' said Dan Harkins, president of the 23-theater Harkins Theatres chain in Phoenix. ``It takes some of the politics out of the rating system and our advertising will be strengthened.'' It was unclear whether newspapers and TV and radio stations would be more inclined to carry ads for movies bearing the NC-17 mark. Laura Morgan, a spokeswoman for the Los Angeles Times, predicted advertisements would be judged on a combination of their artwork and critics' opinions on the movies' artistic worth. Bert Manzari, president of the 28-screen Seven Gables chain in Seattle, said such an evaluation system could become unworkable. ``It's really going to cause a dilemma for the papers,'' Manzari said. William Kartozian, president of the National Organization of Theater Owners, agreed that advertising NC-17 titles could be difficult. ``I hope the media will perceive that there's a difference between these films and skin flicks,'' said Kartozian, whose organization represents the owners of 13,000 theater screens. Kartozian said the initial response to the new rating had been positive, and he expected most theaters to show NC-17 films. He also said some states may amend the NC-17 rating to NC-18, barring children under 18. The last time the ratings were changed was in 1984, when the PG-13 rating was added between the PG and R ratings. That change was prompted by ``Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom.'' X-rated films have included ``Midnight Cowboy'' in 1969, ``Last Tango in Paris'' in 1973 and ``A Clockwork Orange'' in 1971. MPAA President Jack Valenti said the rating system had been justifiably criticized. ``It's no one's fault, but the X rating has a patina, a complexion which frankly we never intended it to have,'' he said. NC-17 was especially welcome at Miramax Films, which had several recent releases rated X. Miramax sued the MPAA over its X rating for ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' The company lost, but a New York Supreme Court judge warned that the rating system bordered on censorship. ``This just goes to show that being tenacious without waving the flag can get the job done,'' said Harvey Weinstein, Miramax co-chairman.

DOC.HEAD: State Agents Peddle Sex Aids, Steamy Movies to Collect Taxes
DOC.TEXT: State agents were porn peddlers for a day, selling sex aids, steamy movies and spicy novelties to pay off the taxes of a once-bustling topless coffee shop. About 100 people showed up Wednesday for the sale at Debbie Duz Donuts. A back room reserved for those over 21 was filled with movies, magazines, aids and ointments. Milder items included novelty lighters, key chains and coffee mugs. ``I sure am glad I didn't have my glasses on or they would have been all fogged up,'' said Warren Williams. ``Sunglasses probably would have cracked right there on my face.'' Williams, 68, and others at the sale said they wanted to get a first look at the place before it faded into Fort Collins history. ``I didn't make it while they were in business, so I thought I'd see them go out of business,'' he said. The property was seized April 4 and former part-owner Dennis Cortese was charged with selling methamphetamines and cocaine in an undercover investigation by the Sheriff's Department. Cortese said he gave up the fight to save the business because he is broke. The state held the auction to cover about $7,500 owed in state taxes. The auction raised about $10,800, said Dorothy Dalquist, a Revenue Department spokeswoman. The difference will cover auction costs and local taxes owed, with anything left over going to creditors.

DOC.HEAD: Final Mohawk Standoff Ends In Clash, Sparking Second Battle
LaserPhoto NY19
DOC.TEXT: An 11-week standoff over Mohawk tribal lands and sovereignty ended in a brawl as warriors lay down their weapons and left a detoxification center but resisted when soldiers tried to arrest them. About 400 Mohawks who live on a nearby reservation watched Wednesday night's clash on television, grabbed baseball bats, lead pipes and rocks and attacked troops guarding a bridge that links their community with Montreal. A soldier suffered facial injuries in Mercier Bridge incident, which ended after soldiers trained rifles on the protesters, threatening to shoot. Only minor injuries were reported in the earlier brawl at Oka, which began after some of the more than 50 militants who had been holed up for a month at the drug and alcohol treatment center tried to push past troops. The warriors at the Indian settlement 18 miles west of Montreal had agreed to end the standoff peacefully but after leaving the center many tried to evade soldiers and pass through barbed-wire barricades. Brawls broke out when soldiers - some with fixed bayonets - seized warriors and women and children accompanying them. Some Mohawks had small children in their arms and were knocked to the ground, witnesses said. Police arrested six Mohawks outside army lines on unspecified charges and a seventh for obstructing officers. Three Warriors were arrested and placed in provincial police custody. At least 50 Mohawks were in army custody late Wednesday and some could face charges later in connection with a prolonged power struggle that amounted to a series of sporadic clashes. The standoff began July 11 when police tried to storm an Indian barricade outside Oka and a Quebec provincial police officer was killed. Blame has not been fixed in the officer's death. The barricade, put up by Indians opposed to the planned extension of a golf course onto what they claim as tribal land, was dismantled by troops last month. That's when the warriors retreated to the treatment center. Dozens of Indians, troops and police have been injured in the dispute, which has gripped the Canadian nation with its questions of how far the government should go in guaranteeing native rights and sovereignty. No arrests were reported at the Mercier Bridge, which Indians had blockaded for most of the summer in support of their Oka brethren. Maj. Alain Tremblay said it was possible a few of the Oka warriors had escaped into the woods surrounding the treatment center. He said a search was planned for sometime today. At the Mercier Bridge, soldiers were ordered to take aim at the angry Indians from the Kahnawake reservation who were showering them with rocks. ``It was the first time (in the Mohawk crisis) we had to give the order to point weapons,'' said army Lt. Col. Greg Mitchell. ``Thank God it had the effect of getting the people to withdraw. '' The checkpoint was set up to ensure that the bridge - a major commutation route for people who work in Montreal and live on the St. Lawrence River's southern bank - remains open. After the confrontation ended, the Mohawks milled about, watching coverage of the end to the standoff at Oka on a portable black-and-white television set. Jeers erupted when a television announcer said the standoff with Mohawks had cost the Quebec government $180 million. ``It's only a fraction of what they owe us,'' said one Mohawk man. The Oka confrontation had mobilized the support of native communities across the country, said an Indian spokesman. ``There is no question that we have won,'' said Francis Boots, a spokesman for the Warrior Society from the Akwesasne reservation, south of Cornwall, Ontario. ``We have acquired an awareness among Canadian public. We can now talk without bureaucrats sweeping issues like land rights under the rug,'' he said. The decision to leave the center near Oka was made earlier Wednesday. Chief negotiator Terry Doxtator had said it was made because of fear the army would withdraw and be replaced by Quebec provincial police. Some of the Indians were concerned about what treatment they would receive by a force that had lost a member in the initial clash in July. U.S. lawyer Stanley Cohen, who walked out of the treatment center Monday night, was released on $3,000 bail Wednesday. Cohen, 40, pleaded innocent Tuesday to charges of participating in a riot, obstructing justice, and possession of a firearm in manner dangerous to public security. He has been advising the Mohawks since the crisis began.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Generally Lower; Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mostly lower in early European trading today. Gold prices also fell as traders concentrated on oil price movements. Dealers in Frankfurt said attention focused on the Persian Gulf crisis and President Bush's announcement that he is likely to authorize the sale of crude oil from U.S. strategic reserves to moderate oil prices. The move softened oil prices and gold moved down too. ``Oil and rumors are moving this market,'' said a London trader. In Tokyo, the dollar edged up 0.10 yen to close at 137.50 yen. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 137.90 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: -1.5766 German marks, up from 1.5715 -1.3085 Swiss francs, down from 1.3110 -5.2475 French francs, down from 5.2615 -1.7680 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7725 -1,172.50 Italian lire, down from 1,176.00 -1.1573 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1535 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8700, compared with $1.8635 late Wednesday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $401.90 per ounce at midmorning, down from $404.85 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $402 at midday, down from $402.50 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $3.12 to close at a bid $403.29. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.80 a troy ounce compared with Wednesday's $4.81.

DOC.HEAD: Fair Weather Prevails, Heat Persists in Upper Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Fair skies prevailed over much of the nation today, and cooler air settled into the northern Plains. Today's forecast said a band of showers and thunderstorms was expected to extend from Illinois to Colorado. Showers also were likely in central California. Sunny skies were forecast over a large area from the southern Plains to the Ohio Valley, and temperatures were expected to rise as much as 16 degrees above normal. Cool air was expected to filter into the northern Plains, bringing seasonable highs in the 60s and 70s. On Wednesday, temperatures in the mid-90s broke highs for the date in parts of Nebraska, South Dakota and Minnesota. In contrast, temperatures dipped into the 40s Wednesday in parts of the Southeast. Small hail fell near Fort Washakie, Wyo., and Loveland, Colo. The high temperature for the nation Wednesday was 103 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif.
