Marie 44 fair; San Antonio 72 fair. -West: Albuquerque 63 fair; Anchorage 41 cloudy; Boise 61 cloudy; Casper 47 fair; Fairbanks 33 fair; Great Falls 51 fair; Honolulu 76 showers; Las Vegas 71 fair; Los Angeles 64 fair; Medford 55 fair; Pendleton 63 fair; Phoenix 79 fair; Portland, Ore. 64 cloudy; Reno 51 partly cloudy; Salt Lake City 58 partly cloudy; San Diego 68 partly cloudy; San Francisco 61 fair; Seattle 61 cloudy; Spokane 57 fair. -International: Calgary 39 fair; Montreal 59 partly cloudy; Ottawa 54 foggy; Regina 46 partly cloudy; Toronto 50 foggy; Winnipeg 41 fair; San Juan 78 fair.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Gives Kuwaitis One Month to Change Citizenship
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq today gave Kuwaitis a month to become Iraqi citizens, a new measure aimed at further breaking down Kuwait's national identity and making the country part of Iraq. A new law published by the Interior Ministry said citizens of Kuwait - which Iraq proclaimed its 19th province after seizing the oil-rich emirate eight weeks ago - have until Oct. 31 to adopt Iraqi citizenship. The ministry did not say what would happen to Kuwaitis still in the occupied kingdom who do not change their citizenship by the deadline. The law stipulated that only Kuwaitis born in Kuwait of Kuwaiti mothers and fathers are eligible for Iraqi citizenship. According to ministry statistics, the 1988 census numbered so-called pure Kuwaitis at 270,000 out of a total population of about 500,000 citizens. Hundreds of thousands of foreigners also live in Kuwait. They include an estimated 300,000 Palestinians, the largest foreign community still in Kuwait. There are also about 120,000 Indians, many of whom are trying to leave. Scores of thousands of Asians have already fled. Baghdad's Interior Ministry said Kuwaitis abroad can get Iraqi nationality cards from Iraqi embassies - on condition they return their Kuwaiti nationality documents. Baghdad also stepped up its verbal attack on the Soviet Union today in response to statements made by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze at the United Nations earlier in the week. The Al-Thawra daily, the paper of the ruling Arab Baath Socialist Party, accused the Soviets of conducting a ``policy of appeasement'' towards the United States. The newspaper said in an editorial that the Soviet Union, ``which has lost its power and influence in the world,'' had succumbed to bribery from the West and gulf Arab countries to help its own troubled economy. There was a similar attack by the official Iraqi News Agency on Wednesday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Bodine obit to CORRECT that he ran for governor, sted lieutenant governor, in 1968.
DOC.TEXT: Richard Clay Bodine, a state legislator for 16 years who was the Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor in 1972, died Wednesday of a heart attack at St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 62. Bodine was admitted to the hospital with a heart ailment a week earlier. Bodine, an attorney, was first elected to the Indiana House in 1963, and quickly established himself as a Democratic leader. He was elected House speaker in 1965 after he was elected to a second term. Instead of seeking re-election in 1968, Bodine made a bid for the Democratic nomination for governor and lost to then-Lt. Gov. Robert Rock. Bodine returned to the Legislature in 1971 and ran for lieutenant governor on the Democratic ticket in 1972 as a running-mate to former Gov. Matthew Welsh. They were defeated by the Republican duo of Otis Bowen and Robert D. Orr.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says Note to Embassies Was Misinterpreted
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi officials said today that a note asking embassies in Baghdad for a list of non-diplomats living in their compounds had been misinterpreted as a death threat. The Foreign Ministry refused official comment on the note, which was condemned by U.S. Secretary of State James Baker on Wednesday as a threat to hang diplomats harboring foreigners. However, officials did say that the ministry had distributed a memo to the embassies informing them that they should submit a list of nationals who are not diplomats but who are either in embassies, diplomatic premises or houses of diplomats. The memo contained a reminder of an Iraqi law, issued when Iraq annexed Kuwait last month, which stipulated that those who provide refuge for foreigners could be punished by death. The officials said the memo was misinterpreted in that it was not a threat against foreign diplomats, but was just pointing out what the law was as it applied to Iraqis. On Wednesday, Baker said the note ``falls under the heading of the principle of the three R's, I think. We've read it, it's repugnant and we reject it.'' Today, the French Foreign Ministry also said its embassy had also received the note. A spokesman termed it ``utterly intolerable'' and said France was consulting with ``friendly countries'' about the matter. Britain's Foreign Office said today that its diplomats had received ``a note'' but declined to characterize it immediately as a death threat. Iraq's Ambassador to Washington, Mohamed al-Mashat, denied Wednesday night that any such threats has been made by Iraqi officials. ``We're not threatening anyone,'' al-Mashat told reporters after a meeting a the State Department. He refused further comment.

DOC.HEAD: Text Of Iraqi Note As Released By State Department
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The State Department released this text Wednesday of the note it said was received by the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad from the Iraqi Ministry of Foreign Affairs:

``Revolutionary Command Council Resolution No. 341 dated 8-26-90 stipulates that housing a foreigner for the purpose of hiding him or her from the authorities is a crime of espionage. The punishment of death shall be imposed on the individual who commits such a crime. ``The ministry will appreciate it if the esteemed mission would kindly inform the ministry of whether any of its citizens or any other nation's citizens are residing in the mission's embassies and your diplomatic residences, whether or not these citizens have contracts with the government or are working with foreign companies operating in Iraq.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Ritter Cleared of Criminal Charges
DOC.TEXT: Covenant House founder, the Rev. Bruce Ritter, has been cleared of criminal charges, according to a published report today. Attorney General Robert Abrams is concluding a nine-month investigation of charges of sexual and financial misconduct, including an allegation that Ritter spent more than $20,000 on a male ex-prostitute. Tim Gilles, a spokesman for the attorney general, told the New York Post in today's editions: ``There are some questionable financial transactions. But we did not find anything that would constitute theft or larceny or criminal conduct.'' Edward Barbini, another Abrams spokesman, said Abrams has pressed for reforms to ensure the shelter's stability ``while also protecting the interest of people who donate money to Covenant House.'' Robert McGrath, a shelter spokesman, told the Post that 25 of the 30 reforms suggested by Abrams have already been carried out. A remaining issue is Abrams' demand that the shelter make periodic financial reports to the state, the Post said.

DOC.HEAD: Beach-Bumming Roaches and 1.88-Inch Roach Win Contest
DOC.TEXT: Stomping cockroaches is fine with Randy Robertson, but he won $500 by finding another use for them. He won the ``most creative cockroach'' at the International Roach Finals on Wednesday by dressing up a trio as beach bums, complete with trendy sun glasses and a sailboard. ``They're Florida roaches, so I figured they'd be comfortable in that setting,'' explained Robertson, a free-lance artist from North Port on Florida's west coast. There was also ``Elvis Roachly,'' as in ``the King'' of roaches, wearing a white-sequined suit with a tiny guitar. And jolly old Santa Roach, clad in a red felt suit and perched on the roof of a toy house. The contest, sponsored by a pesticide company, also searched for the largest roach - a 1.88-inch colossus Palmetto bug from Okinawa, Japan. Although it was the same size as last year's winner, it was the first time a foreign roach was crowned world's largest in the international contest, beating out more than 1,000 entries.

DOC.HEAD: 3 Killed, 16 Wounded in Riots Over Affirmative Action Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with 3 dead and 16 wounded. Pickup 9th graf `About 20...'
DOC.TEXT: Police opened fire today to quell anti-government riots, killing three people and wounding 16 who were protesting federal job quotas for low-caste Hindus, said doctors and news reports. Police clashed with students in at least three neighborhoods when protesters blocked roads and railway tracks with metal drums and tree branches. It was the third straight day of violence in the capital. Prime Minister V.P. Singh had appealed to the youths Wednesday to give up violence and start talks, but the students rejected his offer. Singh, in a nationally broadcast speech Wednesday, said he would rather resign than give up a cause that ``I believe in so intensely.'' Today's deaths raised to 38 the number killed in street battles with police or by suicide since Singh announced the affirmative action program Aug. 7. United News of India said two people were killed and 13 injured in police gunfire today in Bawli, 35 miles northeast of New Delhi. It did not give details. Press Trust of India said police opened fired when a mob set ablaze some vehicles and hurled stones and bricks at police patrols in eastern New Delhi's Shakarpur neighborhood. Doctors at the Jai Prakash Naraian Hospital said a 33-year-old man died of bullet wounds to the head and chest. Three were wounded, including one suffering critical chest and abdomen wounds. A doctor who declined to give his name said the other two victims were ``under control.'' About 20 students have attempted self-immolation across northern India to protest the quotas, which reserve nearly half of the government's 18 million jobs for lower castes. Press Trust of India said a 13-year-old student, Sachin Kumar, consumed a fatal dose of poison Wednesday in Hapur outside New Delhi, blaming Singh's policy for his action. Today one person died of bullet wounds sustained in police firing Wednesday in Modinagar, 55 miles west of New Delhi. Four people were killed in the firing Wednesday. Singh says the quotas will promote social justice by doing away with inequities imposed by the rigid caste system. Because of their low birth, the lower castes are generally poor and less educated. The policy's opponents say the move is aimed at garnering votes from the lower castes, who form a majority of Indian voters. The protesters maintain that many of the low-castes are no longer underprivileged and do not need affirmative action programs. The latest deaths raise to 36 the number of people killed in suicides and street battles with police since Singh announced the affirmative action program. Student groups have gone on the rampage in several northern Indian towns, torching government vehicles, banks and offices. Middle-class housewives and shopkeepers have supported the protesters, sheltering them from police and sometimes hurling stones at policemen.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Wins Test Case dealing with Substance Abusers Housing
DOC.TEXT: A housing firm violated a new law by refusing to rent apartments to a drug treatment program, a federal jury has decided. The decision Wednesday against Southern Management Corp. of Silver Spring, Md., was the first court test of a fair housing law barring discrimination against handicapped individuals, officials said. Since the law went into effect in March 1989, the Justice Department has defined ``handicapped'' to include recovering substance abusers, an interpretation upheld by U.S. District Judge Albert V. Bryan Jr. After a two-day trial before Bryan, a jury on Wednesday ordered Southern Management to pay $36,280 in damages to the Fairfax-Falls Church Community Services Board, a Northern Virginia public agency that runs a drug rehabilitation program. A Southern Management official last year had refused to rent three apartments to Crossroads, telling program officers, ``I'm not discriminating against you; I won't rent to any drug program,'' according to testimony. Neighborhood opposition has emerged in recent years as one of the biggest barriers to expanding drug treatment, one of the prime goals of the Bush administration's anti-drug strategy. Over the past year, the Justice Department has attempted to use the 1988 law to help break down those barriers, officials said. ``This is significant to fair housing enforcement; it's the first time a case like this was ever presented to a jury,'' said Paul Hancock, chief of housing and civil enforcement of the Justice Department's civil rights division. A lawyer for Southern Management said the firm probably will appeal the verdict. Crossroads is a long-term rehabilitation program that treats about 40 serious drug and alcohol abusers at its residential facility, said Tim Harmon, a director of the Fairfax-Falls Church services board who oversees the program. After graduating from the residential facility, patients are placed in apartments while they work in the community and continue their recovery under supervision.

DOC.HEAD: Another New York Teen Shot To Death
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old boy was fatally shot in the chest today, the second child to die in gunfire since Sunday. Nine children have been gunned down in New York City this week, including four teen-agers in one day. The latest victim, Levy Mitchell, was shot once in the chest in the the Bronx, said Sgt. Grace Ridley, a police spokeswoman. He was dead on arrival at Bronx-Lebanon Hospital after being shot at 2:45 a.m. while he was visiting friends, Ridley said. There were no suspects, and no weapon was recovered. At about the same time, a 15-year-old boy was arrested and charged with the shooting of a 13-year-old girl Wednesday evening, Ridley said. The boy, Richard Burke, was charged with secon-degree assault and criminal possession of a weapon, she said. The victim, whose name was withheld, was with friends when she was shot in the back and hand, Ridley said. She was hospitalized in stable cndition, Ridley said. To combat the escalating crime, Mayor David Dinkins plans to get 7,500 more police officers on the street and to expand the rest of the criminal justice system, a newspaper reported today. But it was unclear how Dinkins would pay for the new programs, the New York Daily News said. The News quoted unidentified Dinkins aides and police officials saying the plan would hire just under 5,000 more officers and more than 3,000 new civilian police employees, who would free deskbound officers for street duty. Four teen-agers were wounded by gunfire Tuesday in the city during a five-hour period. On Monday, a 13-year-old girl was shot in the head with pellets as she and a girlfriend sat on a bench in Brooklyn. She was listed in stable condition. A 15-year-old girl was also shot in the thigh Monday as she was walking with her boyfriend in Brooklyn. On Sunday, 12-year-old Laykama Taylor was shot to death outside a Brooklyn housing project. The girl, whose nickname was ``Sugar,'' spent her last days in fear of retaliation after winning a street fight, neighbors told police. She was the sixth child shooting victim to die since July 22.

DOC.HEAD: Mob Chases Mugging Suspect to His Death on Subway Bed
DOC.TEXT: An angry mob coming to the aid of a woman mugged on a subway in the Bronx chased the robbery suspect onto train tracks, where police say the man fell against the 600-volt third rail and was electrocuted. ``Sometimes it's difficult to feel sad about these things,'' said Transit Police spokesman Al O'Leary. ``Maybe there is a higher state of justice.'' The incident began at 9:30 p.m. Tuesday, when, according to police, 22-year-old Jean Carlos Pabain Perez walked up to a woman, stuck a knife in her face and demanded money. The woman handed over her purse, then Perez used the knife to cut off her watch, police said. The man then jumped out of the train and the woman ran after him, screaming for help, police said. Six men who saw the incident chased Perez into the street. They caught and tried to detain him. But he broke loose, ran down the block and leaped into the nearby Westchester train yard to hide, police said. About 40 minutes later, the transit authority's police found Perez dead on the third rail.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Announces Plan to Send Military Personnel Overseas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 10th pvs, `Kaifu did...' to ADD dropped word ``not.'' Pickup 11th pvs, `Although there...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu unveiled a plan today to dispatch Japanese military personnel overseas for the first time since World War II, but he said they would be unarmed and kept away from combat. The proposal, which must be approved by the Parliament, calls for the establishment of the U.N. Peace Cooperation Corps - a group of military and civilian personnel to participate in U.N. peace-keeping activities. Kaifu acknowledged criticism that Japan is supplying little more than money to the U.S.-led force deployed in the Middle East in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Kaifu flies Friday to the United States, where some of the harshest criticism has been voiced. ``I myself thought we had to do something requiring a little sweat,'' Kaifu told a televised news conference. The Japanese proposal is likely to arouse fears among Asian countries about renewed militarism in Japan. The Asian countries suffered from Japanese aggression before and during World War II. The opposition Japan Socialist Party, citing the country's no-war constitution, expressed opposition to the plan in a meeting with Kaifu earlier today, Cabinet spokesman Misoji Sakamoto said. That could mean difficulty in winning approval for the plan in Parliament because the governing Liberal Democratic Party does not have a majority in the upper house. The legislation may not be voted on until mid-November. Kaifu described the proposal, which has yet to be formally drafted, as part of Japan's effort to define its role in the post-Cold War era. Under the proposal, the corps would be under the prime minister's office and would not be allowed to use force. Activities could include communications, medical support and transportation of goods and personnel, sources have said. Kaifu did not give a size for the corps, although sources have said it could include 1,000 to 2,000 people. Although there has been debate within the government about whether the corps' members could carry pistols, Kaifu said they would be unarmed. ``I know there are many opinions about their role, but my position is I don't want them to go to places where they have to have weapons,'' he said. But Nobutoshi Akao, director-general of the United Nations Bureau in the Foreign Ministry, refused to rule out the possibility members of the corps would carry sidearms under certain circumstances. Masashi Nishihara, a professor of international relations at the National Defense Academy, said: ``I'm not sure it's going to be a big contribution'' to the U.S.-led multinational force in the gulf. Kaifu, when asked why Japan was not willing to play a military role, responded: ``I agree that Japan should do more than just make comments about the situation, but I cannot accept the criticism Japan is not doing enough just because it is not taking military measures.'' Japan's postwar constitution, which was written by U.S. officials, prohibits the use of force to settle international disputes. Before Kaifu's announcement, the government pledged $4 billion in assistance to the U.S.-led multinational force and Middle East nations having economic troubles because of the international embargo on trade with Iraq. Japan last month also pledged to send about 100 civilian medical personnel to the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Home of Air Force General Broken Into in Brussels
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with embassy statement, background on Douglass. Pickup 11th pvs, `In June...'
DOC.TEXT: Two assailants broke into the home of an Air Force general assigned to NATO and overpowered a U.S. guard, but the general was outside the country at the time, the U.S. Embassy said today. The Belgian television station VTM, quoting an unidentified source, described the incident Tuesday night as an attempted kidnapping or murder. The break-in occurred at the suburban home of Gen. John W. Douglass, deputy U.S. representative to NATO's military committee, an embassy statement said. ``The officer was not at home at the time,'' said the statement. An embassy official said he was out of the country. U.S. officials refused to speculate on the motive for the attack, but it appeared they were taking the incident seriously. The two assailants bound and gagged an American security guard at the general's home and used some type of solution to render him unconscious, the embassy said. It said there was ``no evidence of theft'' at Douglass' home in the eastern suburb of Kraainem. VTM reported at least three assailants hadwaited inside the house and another outside using walkie-talkies. One of the men who entered the house was wearing some type of uniform, it reported. Belgium police refused to comment. Callers to Douglass' office at NATO were told by a woman answering the phone: ``You cannot talk to him.'' At his house today, a guard told reporters the general was still out of town. Douglass has been assigned to the U.S. military delegation at the North American Treaty Organization headquarters since summer 1989. NATO's military committee, made up of representatives of the 16 member nations, is the highest military authority in the Western alliance. In June 1979, a remote-control device hidden in a culvert exploded as U.S. Gen. Alexander Haig, then NATO's top military commander in Europe, drove to his headquarters in southern Belgium. The explosion caused only slight damage to Haig's car, but the security car behind him was destroyed. Haig was not injured. The German terrorist group Red Army Faction claimed responsibility for the attack, but Belgian authorities were unable to determine positively who was responsible.

DOC.HEAD: FDIC Raises Insurance Premiums for Banks By More than 60 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lead to fix typo in ``percent''.
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. today raised the insurance premium for commercial banks by more than 60 percent in a move aimed at bolstering its deteriorating insurance fund. Starting next year, the rate will be 19.5 cents per $100 of deposits, up from 12 cents this year. It is the maximum increase allowed by law. The action came after the five-member board heard a financial report showing that losses to the fund from bank failures were even heavier than anticipated in the first half of this year. The fund decreased from $13.2 billion at the end of 1989 to $11.4 billion at the end of June - a 14 percent drop. L. William Seidman, FDIC chairman, said he anticipated losses for the year would be closer to $3 billion rather than the $2 billion he expected only one month earlier. The $1.84 billion loss in the first half of the year has reduced the level of reserves in the fund to only 60 cents for $100 insured deposits. The minimum level considered safe is $1.25 per $100. The level of reserves is at the lowest point in the fund's history. The congressional General Accounting Office has warned that if the economy dips into a recession, the fund could be wiped out and require a taxpayer bailout. On Wednesday, a senior Treasury Department official and Sen. Donald W. Riegle, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, urged enactment of legislation giving the FDIC power to raise premiums higher and more often. A measure to do that passed the House last week. Riegle, D-Mich., and Treasury Undersecretary Robert R. Glauber said Congress must enact one before it adjourns early next month. Meanwhile, Glauber gave Riegle's panel an early look at a more comprehensive plan to reform the banking system, which the administration expects to propose for action next year. It would raise deposit insurance fees for reckless banks and limit the number of insured accounts per depositor. Glauber also suggested that the administration may seek to force banks to conduct commercial real estate lending through separate affiliates that would not use insured deposits. Glauber said the administration favors charging banks making risky loans or operating with low capital more for insurance than conservatively run banks. He said the Treasury is ``closely examining'' proposals that would combine government deposit insurance with private insurance to provide guidance for setting premium levels. The administration also favors limiting the number of insured accounts per depositor. Depositors can now insure far more than the $100,000 per account limit by dividing their money among several banks or among single, joint and trust accounts at a single institution. Other proposed changes listed by Glauber were: -Limiting ``pass-through'' insurance for pension funds and other large institutional investors. Under current rules, a deposit by a pension fund with 100 members would have protection equaling 100 times the $100,000 insurance limit. -Forcing regulators to crack down on weak institutions before they fail. -Requiring annual, on-site examinations of large banks and ailing banks. A study by the Congressional Budget Office supported many of Glauber's points. It backed risk-based insurance premiums, less discretion by regulators over when to close an institution and assumption of some portion of deposit insurance by private companies. The study was presented Wednesday to Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee. In another development, bankers and regulators from nine other countries told U.S. officials at an international conference that the United States had gone too far in protecting depositors, said Seidman, the FDIC chairman. Seidman served as host of the closed-door conference, attended by about 80 officials from the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada, Italy, Belgium, Luxembourg and Switzerland. At a news briefing, Seidman said most countries have private systems protecting only the smallest depositors, although bank regulators generally have the flexibility to decide on a case-by-case basis whether to rescue the largest banks if needed to prevent a shock to the banking system. Most attendees believed the United States should follow their lead by employing ``constructive ambiguity'' as to whether a bank will be rescued, Seidman said.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Defused at Terrorism Conference, IRA Blamed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with police saying device was a bomb, planted by IRA. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Police defused a bomb today planted under a lectern that a government minister, London's police chief and top British and American experts were to use while addressing an international conference on terrorism. Commander George Churchill-Coleman, head of Scotland Yard's Anti-Terrorist Squad, said the device contained enough explosives to cause death and injury and was probably planted by the Irish Republican Army. No group claimed responsibility for the bomb. The plastic lunch box containing the bomb was discovered by security guards as delegates arrived for the conference at the Royal Overseas League building on Park Place near Piccadilly in central London, police and conference organizers said. The conference was postponed as police searched for a possible second device, said Frank Brenchley, chairman of the Research Institute for the Study of Confict and Terrorism. The institute organized the conference. Scheduled speakers at the one-day conference included Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave, Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Peter Imbert and Professor Richard Shultz, of Tufts University in Boston. Churchill-Coleman told a news conference he didn't believe the device was aimed at a particular individual. ``The target of the device was the conference,'' he said. ``The conference, which was widely advertised, would be seen as a legitimate target by Irish Republican terrorist groups.'' The IRA has targeted government officials and security forces in its fight to end British rule in Northern Ireland. Churchill-Coleman said the lunch box ``contained a sufficient high explosive that had the device exploded, which we believe would have been around 10:30 a.m., it would have caused death and serious injury.'' He appealed for information on anyone seen in the area and warned potential IRA targets: ``If you want to live, you must continue to look and keep on looking.'' Joan Bates, spokeswoman for the Research Institute for the Study of Confict and Terrorism, said the package had been found underneath the lectern where speakers would have been. All other buildings on Park Place were also evacuated and the streets sealed off by police. Professor Paul Wilkinson of the University of St. Andrews in Scotland, who is the institute's director and a leading British expert on anti-terrorism, said ``extremely thorough'' security arrangements had been made for the conference. ``An incident like this does remind you of the need for alertness at all times and the professionalism and courage of those whose daily duty it is to deal with emergencies of this sort,'' he said. ``When you are studying a subject, you recognize there is a constant problem and a large number of groups use this sort of weapon. That is why it is important to study it and ways of combating the threat more effectively.''

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Welcomes Soviet Religion Law
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican today welcomed the Soviet Union's new law on freedom of conscience, saying it ``renders justice to millions of believers.'' The freedom of conscience law, promised by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev when he met with Pope John Paul II at the Vatican in December, was approved Wednesday by the Soviet legislature. Chief Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro expressed ``great satisfaction'' and said the Vatican is now looking forward to the approval of the various articles in the legislation. The law, formally ending decades of religious repression, forbids the government from interfering with religious activities, improves the legal status of religious organizations and gives Soviet citizens the right to study religion in homes and in private schools. It also paves the way for legalization of the Ukrainian Catholic Church, whose suppression by Stalin in 1947 has been a major thorn in Vatican-Soviet relations. Under the new law, the church can apply to local authorities to regain lawful status. Gorbachev's historic meeting with the pope has already led to the establishment of official ties between the Vatican and Moscow. A resolution of the Ukrainian issue could lead to full ties and a papal visit.

DOC.HEAD: Former Algerian President Strongly Supports Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 10th pvs, `Bodyguards...' to ADD that former president went into exile voluntarily. Pickup 11th, `He became...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former President Ahmed Ben Bella returned home today after a decade in exile and urged tens of thousands of cheering supporters to volunteer to fight in support of Iraq. He also called on Algeria's government to resign. Many people in a throng that greeted his ferry after an overnight voyage from Spain waved posters of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein along with portraits of Ben Bella, leader of the Algerian war for independence against France. ``Iraq needs support,'' said Ben Bella, 73, a fiery, hour-long speech after coming ashore. ``Telephone the Iraqis, send telegrams and tell them you are with them. Go by the hundreds of thousands to the Iraqi Embassy and don't leave until they sign you up as volunteers.'' He urged supporters to stage a protest at the U.S. Embassy denouncing the American military deployment in the Persian Gulf. More than 100,000 people massed along a seaside boulevard, chanting Ben Bella's name, as the car ferry Hoggar arrived from Barcelona. Other boats in the harbor blared horns and sirens in welcome. Ben Bella said he hoped to weld a new political coalition that would defeat the long-ruling National Liberation Front - to which he once belonged. Legislative elections are scheduled for early next year, but Ben Bella said the government should resign immediately. ``I'm nervous to come back, but I'm very moved,'' he said as the boat docked. ``We have huge problems in Algeria, and I hope I can do something to restore our dreams.'' He embraced his wife and children, who made the voyage with him. Supporters on the ferry tossed posters and books over the railing to people gathered on the dock. Bodyguards then escorted Ben Bella to shore, his first time back in Algeria since he voluntarily went into exile in Europe in 1981. He became Algeria's first president in 1962 after the eight-year independence war against France, but was overthrown in a military coup in 1965 and imprisoned until shortly before he went into exile. In his speech, delivered from a platform erected outside the National Assembly building, Ben Bella described the international mobilization against Iraq as a ``Zionist plot'' supported by the United States. ``If they strike Saddam, that means they strike at us,'' he said. ``We will hit back at everybody.'' One of Ben Bella's former comrades-in-arms, Abdelkhadir Hadj, rejoiced as the ferry docked. ``The country is free again,'' said Hajd, 50. ``I knew one day democracy would triumph.'' As the best-known leader of the war for independence, Ben Bella adds a volatile ingredient to Algeria's experiment with democracy. He returns home as Islamic fundamentalists stand poised to win legislative elections in six months. With or without them, Ben Bella hopes to forge a ``common front'' of dozens of disparate opposition parties against the ruling party. Ben Bella had disappointed partisans by not returning for local and regional elections June 12, Algeria's first multiparty balloting since 1962. He advocated a boycott of those elections, claiming they would be rigged by the National Liberation Front. The fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front swept a majority of local and regional councils in the vote, becoming the country's dominant political group. Ben Bella has since raised his profile. He recently flew to Iraq for talks with Saddam and has appeared on televised news shows in Algeria and France. Ben Bella told Saddam that thousands of Algerians were ready to fight on behalf of Iraq, a Moroccan newspaper reported last week. Despite his erratic three-year rule, Ben Bella retains an immense personal stature among Algerians. Admirers say he alone can unite political factions and lift the country out of economic misery marked by 25 percent unemployment. But critics note that he gave Algeria the Marxist command economy, secret police and one-party rule it is only now shaking off thanks to political reforms that began after October 1988 riots.

DOC.HEAD: Mother's Helper Makes `Hell' For Couple
DOC.TEXT: A nanny from Montana became the ``au pair from hell'' to a couple who says she wrecked their car and racked up more than $70,000 in bad checks. Laurie Bronson and Robert Dolinko said they wanted a wholesome live-in from the heartland to help out while Bronson spent the rest of her pregnancy with her second child in bed on her doctor's advice. What they got was Angela Marie Sandberg, 18, who was eventually fired and pleaded no contest to a charge of passing bad checks, police said. The couple hired Sandberg on July 16 through All-American Childcare Inc., a company that supplies au pairs from the Midwest. ``We'd heard horror stories about the foreign girls who just want to come to California for a good time,'' said Bronson, a psychotherapist. ``So we thought, `Oh great, we'll get someone from the Midwest.' '' Sandberg, from Lolo, Mont., bought a used MG Midget and unsuccessfully tried to buy two new cars, said police Cpl. Michael Sloan said. She wrecked the couple's car in July after driving it to a nightclub, Bronson said. ``She is a personable, likeable, but naive girl who discovered a real quick way to make money and didn't realize she would end up getting put through the wringer for it,'' said police Cpl. Michael Sloan. Sandberg was jailed after pleading no contest to one check-passing charge, Sloan said. Other charges may be filed, he said. The couple ended up with an ``au pair from hell story,'' Bronson said. They fired her July 30, then their telephone started ringing. Clothing boutique owners and grocers left with their ex-nanny's checks wanted their money. Berkeley police arrested Sandberg Sept. 7 at an Emeryville motel after her boyfriend tried to cash a $15,000 check she had written to him so he could start his own business, Sloan said. All-American Childcare, based in Orange County, said a background check on Sandberg with Montana authorities and former employers turned up a clean record. Sandberg, held in lieu of $50,000, was scheduled for sentencing Oct. 16.

DOC.HEAD: Guardian Angels Vote to Leave Baltimore Due To Hostility, Indifference
DOC.TEXT: The Guardian Angels have voted to take their volunteer anti-crime patrols out of Baltimore, saying they face hostility from police and the mayor refuses to intervene. The decision comes a week after the conviction of two Angels and two former members on assault and false imprisonment charges for a citizen's arrest of a suspected drug dealer that went awry. Founder Curtis Sliwa said the group will make daily visits to Mayor Kurt Schmoke's office until Monday, when the 15 members of the Baltimore chapter will join chapters elsewhere in Maryland. ``Our only hope is Mayor Schmoke,'' Sliwa said after Wednesday night's vote. Schmoke, who usually doesn't deal directly with the news media, was in a meeting and unavailable for comment this morning. His spokesman, Clint Coleman, said the mayor opposes the Angels' policy of making citizens' arrests. He said he did not know if Schmoke would meet with the Angels. ``The mayor has always welcomed citizen patrols in our community. But, he has not been supportive of the Guardian Angels' tactics of making citizen arrests. And that's simply because he considers it too dangerous to both the Guardian Angels and citizens,'' Coleman said. Most other chapters of the group, in 67 cities in the United States and Canada, work successfully with police, Sliwa said. He formed the group, recognizable by their red berets, in New York City in 1979 to guard against muggings on the city's subways. The catalyst for the Angels departure was a judge's comments last week comparing the group to the Ku Klux Klan. Baltimore Circuit Court Judge David Mitchell made the remarks when he accepted the guilty pleas from the two Angels and two oormer members. ``Guardian Angels - that is a misnomer,'' Mitchell said. ``In my mind, to this judge, I see no difference between what this organization is and the Ku Klux Klan.'' He called the group ``little boys dressed up like soldiers.'' Sliwa responded that the judge ``obviously needs to get mugged.'' An Angel and two former members received sentences of probation before judgment, meaning they won't have a record if they complete three years of supervised probation. A second Angel, who had a previous criminal conviction, was given a three-year suspended sentence and three years' probation. The convictions stemmed from a July 24 citizens' arrest of a man who needed 40 stitches to close cuts suffered during the incident. The Angels said the man was sniffing glue but police said they found no evidence of that, prosecutor Barry Watson said. The man was not charged. The Angels claim police lied.

DOC.HEAD: Boyfriend Shoots Woman's 13-year-old Son
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old boy who defended his mother while she was being beaten by her boyfriend was shot in the head by the man, police said. Reggie McIver of Baltimore was in critical but stable condition at the University of Maryland Shock-Trauma Unit in Baltimore. The boyfriend, Kenneth Joyner, 21, of Baltimore surrendered to police Wednesday and was being held on a charge of assault with intent to murder after Tuesday night's shooting, police said. McIver's mother, 34-year-old Denise Edwards, said she was confronted by Joyner because she was sitting on the front steps of the home of another man. McIver happened by, saw Joyner hitting his mother and shouted, `You're not going to hurt my mother,''' Edwards said. At that point Joyner pulled out a small Derringer-type handgun, forced the boy face-down on a set of marble steps and shot him in the back of the head, said Edwards. Joyner shook the boy, called his name, then said ``I'm sorry'' and ran off, Edwards said.

DOC.HEAD: Coup Rumors Prompt Assurances From Defense Minister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Soviet media giving prominent play to Yazov's assurance that no coup in works. Pickup 4th pvs, `Yazov's comments...'
DOC.TEXT: Seeking to quell rumors of a military coup, Soviet media gave prominent coverage today to the defense minister's assurance that recent troop movements were related to parade plans and the potato harvest, not a plot. ``No army should use arms against its own people,'' Marshal Dmitri Yazov told Parliament Wednesday in a 10-minute speech. His remarks were reported prominently today in the Communist Party daily Pravda and the capital's Communist youth daily Moskovsky Komsomolets. Sovietsksya Rossiya, a Russian federation party and government paper, displayed a picture of paratroopers digging potatoes near Moscow on its front page. Soviet television today broadcast Yazov's remarks in a midday newscast. Yazov's comments followed two weeks of reports in liberal newspapers and accusations by politicians that the military is plotting to overthrow the government, which faces growing political and economic crises. Such rumors have circulated sporadically throughout President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's 5{-year rule, fueled in part by his supposed alienation of the military brass because of his moves to cut troops and the defense budget and use of soldiers to restore order in restive republics. Such theorists hold that the military - fed up with soaring crime, growing shortages and ethnic unrest - would ally itself with the KGB and orthodox Communist Party apparatus and move against Gorbachev. Only recently have newspapers such as Komsomolskaya Pravda, Literaturnaya Gazeta and Moscow News - freed from strict official supervision - begun examining the possibility of a military overthrow. The reports have spoken of paratroopers dressed in combat gear, bulletproof vests and helmets arriving at a military airfield near Moscow. Some have even reported that the military leadership already has a concrete plan to take control, region-by-region. Embroiled in confusion, protest and economic hard times, the Soviet public has leaned toward believing the rumors, even though the Soviet Union has never had a military coup. The latest publication, prompting Yazov's appearance before the Supreme Soviet, was in Komsomolskaya Pravda, a youth newspaper, on Wednesday. It spoke of alleged military plans to move against democratic forces plotting to take over strategic points such as power stations, television offices and railway terminals. Troops from Ryazan and Tula were reportedly put in a state of combat readiness. The article ended by asking readers: ``Who - by design, out of fear or guided by dangerous political ambitions - issued the order to `take measures?' ... The sooner we find an answer, the safer we shall feel.'' Yazov, speaking to the Supreme Soviet, confirmed there were troop movements in Moscow in recent weeks but said they were related either to soldiers' participation in the traditional Nov. 7 Revolution Day parade or their help in gathering this year's record harvest. He said it was normal for certain types of troops to travel with ammunition and in military vehicles and denied soldiers were put in a state of military readiness. ``All facts spelled out in this article are made up,'' declared Yazov, wearing his drab green uniform emblazoned with a dozen rows of medals. ``I again report fully and officially that our paratroopers and other troops received no missions.'' He then quoted from a statement by some legislators expressing concern about the reported troop movements. ``No army should use arms against its own people. I agree with this,'' he said. At the same time, however, Yazov did not take the opportunity to reiterate his support for Gorbachev, who was not present for the speech. Supreme Soviet Chairman Anatoly Lukyanov spoke for the political leadership. ``Passions are now being fanned deliberately,'' said Lukyanov, who holds powers similar to those of a vice president. ``The passions are connected with some kind of plots and so forth.'' The tense mood prevailed as well at a Wednesday evening meeting of radical lawmakers from the national and Russian Federation parliaments. Several speakers mentioned their fears of a military coup. Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov was critical of the Supreme Soviet for granting Gorbachev extraordinary powers and for being unable to choose among competing economic plans.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Britain Call Iraqi Threat `Repugnant'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th, ``The note...' to CORRECT typo in word ``execute.'' Pickup 7th, `The Iraqi...''
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Britain today joined the United States in rejecting an Iraqi threat to execute diplomats giving sanctuary to Westerners in Baghdad. ``Iraq's threat makes it impossible to take seriously any pretensions on its part to be a civilized state,'' the Foreign Office said in a statement. Secretary of State James A. Baker III first disclosed the threat Wednesday, saying it was contained in an official statement Iraq delivered earlier in the day to the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. A British Foreign Office spokesman said today that British and other Western European diplomats in Baghdad received the threatening note late Wednesday from the Iraqi Foreign Ministry. France also said its embassy in Baghdad received the note today, and a Foreign Ministry spokesman in Paris called the threat ``utterly intolerable.'' He said France would consult with other countries facing the same threat. The note said that giving sanctuary to a foreigner was ``espionage'' and Iraq would execute anyone commiting such a crime. The Iraqi Foreign Ministry refused to elaborate on the message today, but Iraqi officials said it was referring to Iraqis harboring Westerners, not to diplomats giving Westerners refuge. The Iraqi officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the memo only contained a reminder of an Iraqi law, issued when Iraq annexed Kuwait last month, which stipulated that those who provide refuge for foreigners could be punished by death. The officials said the law applies only to Iraqis. On Wednesday, Baker called the Iraqi threat ``repugnant'' and rejected a demand for the names of people given sanctuary in the U.S. embassies in Baghdad and Kuwait. The Foreign Office spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Britain regarded the note as a threat to kill its diplomats. ``We have no option but to regard this as such a threat,'' said the spokesman. He said some 50 Britons were being given refuge in the British Embassy in Baghdad. The embassy also contains 11 diplomats and 11 support staff. The spokesman said Britain also would refuse to give Iraq a list of the people who have found refuge in the embassy. The Foreign Office said it had received no subsequent indication from the Iraqi authorities that the note was not intended as a death threat.

DOC.HEAD: Fire at Oil Refinery Causes Evacuations, Highway Closure
DOC.TEXT: A blaze at an oil refinery sent sheets of flame into the sky, forcing plant workers to evacuate and officials to shut down a nearby highway for nearly three hours early today. No injuries were reported in the fire that erupted Wednesday night at the San Joaquin Refining Co., said Carl Nicita, a dispatcher for the Kern County Fire Department. Ten workers were evacuated after the fire erupted in a refinery tower at 11:15 p.m., Nicita said. Some 100 firefighters extinguished the blaze by 2:30 a.m. The fire's cause was under investigation, although a leaky pump that feeds oil from ground tanks to the 70-foot tower may have contributed to the blaze, Nicita said. There was no immediate damage estimate. State Route 99, which runs adjacent to the refinery, was closed until just after 2 a.m. as a precaution, said California Highway Patrol dispatcher Lolly Craig. Dave Hacker, of radio station KBAK, said the flames could be seen from several miles away, prompting telephone calls from concerned listeners. ``It was lighting up the sky,'' he said.

More Bombings Target U.S. Firms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2 grafs for 4th pvs, `U.S. Ambassador...' to UPDATE with incident near Clark Air Base. Pickup 5th pvs, `Share prices...'
DOC.TEXT: Bombs exploded early today at two U.S. pharmaceutical firms, and another device was defused at a local branch of a U.S. bank in the sixth attack on an American firm within 24 hours, police said. There was no claim of responsibility and no injuries in the pre-dawn blasts, which followed explosions and attempted bombings argeting American, Japanese and Hong Kong business interests. Police believe the attacks have been carried out by military extremists seeking to topple President Corazon Aquino by frightening away foreign investors and embarrassing the government abroad. In a separate development in Angeles, 50 miles north of Manila, unidentified men burned tires and threw homemade bombs before dawn today along a highway about two miles from the U.S.-run Clark Air Base. Police said there were no injuries during the protest, which was apparently against the government's decision last week to raise oil prices. U.S. Ambassador Nicholas Platt said he discussed the Manila attacks today with Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos and urged American firms to ``hang in there and be careful.'' Share prices plunged today to a 3{-year low on The Manila Stock Exchange because of investor fears of more instability. In the first incident today, police defused a small bomb after witnesses saw two men hurl a packet into the compound of the Boston Bank of the Philippines in suburban Kalookan. Police said the bomb contained 10 sticks of dynamite and C-4 plastic explosives, which are issued to the armed forces and not generally available from commercial sources. About a half hour later, two joggers threw a bomb at the headquarters of the Squibb drug firm in suburban Makati. The bomb exploded inside the compound but caused only minor damage, police said. Minutes later, witnesses said two joggers also threw a device at the headquarters of another American pharmaceutical firm - Wyeth Suaco Laboratories. It also caused little damage. Police said the two bombs at the drug firm also contained dynamite and C-4. ``Obviously the exercise is to frighten foreign investors away,'' said Aurelio Periquet, president of the Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry. ``The purpose is to destabilize the political situation here.'' The latest bombings brought to 31 the number of blasts in the capital since Aug. 13. Manila's police commander, Brig. Gen. Marino Filart, said it appeared most of the bombings were carried out by right-wing extremists. Late Wednesday, a small bomb hurled from a passing car exploded at the Colgate-Palmolive plant in Makati, shattering windows but causing no injuries. Earlier Wednesday, small bombs also exploded at the Coca-Cola and Pepsi bottling plants, and another device was defused at a factory operated by the American electronics and communications firm Motorola. Another bomb was discovered and defused in front of a Japanese computer chip plant in the Taguig district. On Sunday, bombs exploded at the Mandarin Oriental, a Hong Kong hotel chain, and the Nikko Manila Garden, a Japanese-run hotel. Eight people - four Japanese and four Filipinos - were slightly injured in the Nikko Garden blast.

DOC.HEAD: Cutting Torch Likeliest Cause of Metro Rail Tunnel Blaze, Probe Says
DOC.TEXT: A blaze that destroyed an unfinished subway tunnel and shut down a major highway last summer probably was caused by a cutting torch, officials say. The July 13 fire in the downtown Metro Rail tunnel caused no injuries or deaths but produced more than $2 million damage. The 750-foot tunnel, which passes under U.S. 101, partially collapsed. The freeway was closed for days until it could be shored up. The report by the so-called Independent Investigation Team was commissioned by Rail Construction Corp., a subsidiary of the Los Angeles County Transportation Commission. The investigation did not rule out arson, but said the fire most likely began with the use of a torchtto trim steel spikes in the tunnel. The tunnel was shored up with timber. A polyethylene membrane was installed over the timber to keep methane gas in the soil from entering the tunnel. The report said the torch flame or hot metal slag probably caused a timber to smolder. Seven or eight hours later, the fire burned through the membrane and spread rapidly through the two materials. The report said two earlier fires in the same 24-hour period had been quickly extinguished. The Fire Department hasn't completed its investigation, and the district attorney is investigating whether safety violations were a factor. Ed McSpedon, Rail Construction's president and chief executive officer, said Wednesday the firm has implemented a fire safety plan that includes a constant fire watch at construction sites. In the future, pre-cast concrete liners will be used instead of the timber and polyethylene combination, McSpedon said. The first 4.4-mile segment of the $3.3 billion subway is scheduled to open in 1994. It is $135 million over budget and 18 months behind schedule. Metro Rail will eventually stretch 17 miles from downtown to the San Fernando Valley.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Renews Attack; Leaders Say Deal May be Near
With PM-Government on Furlough, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs. Negotiators expected to meet early afternoon; may stand.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush resumed his attack on congressional Democrats today, saying they had delayed a budget deal that would avoid deep spending cuts. Congressional leaders, however, expressed optimism that a compromise may be near. ``There may be senior citizens wondering why their Social Security checks are late,'' Bush said, referring to one effect of federal cuts that will otherwise be triggered Monday. ``We can't afford business as usual. The American people deserve better.'' While Bush spoke at a campaign breakfast for Republicans in Minneapolis, leading lawmakers said progress was being made in the 4-month-old budget negotiations. ``We're a little bit in the precincts of reaching a conclusion, rather than at the wrap-up stage,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. ``A good deal has been agreed to tentatively.'' ``They're basically there outside of capital gains,'' said Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass. ``Get rid of that darned thing, we're home free.'' Bush has tempered his demand for a lower capital gains tax rate, which has been the major obstacle to a budget pact. Should no action be taken by Monday, the start of the 1991 fiscal year, government spending will be slashed by $85 billion and many of its 2.4 million civilian workers will face payless days off as the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law takes effect. Wednesday's bargaining session capped a day in which participants said Bush was moving toward defusing the prickliest issue remaining between the two sides: whether tax rates on capital gains should be dropped. But the president and Democratic congressional leaders also traded accusations that the other side was jeopardizing the negotiations. ``If and when the ax falls, the Democratic Congress knows that it will be held accountable,'' Bush told a Republican campaign rally in Akron, Ohio. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., and Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, fired back, saying the remarks could damage the talks. ``Ironically, I thought we were making progress,'' Mitchell said. Bargainers also reported progress at recent sessions in narrowing differences between the two sides over defense cuts and reductions in domestic programs. The overall goal is to take a $500 billion bite out of the federal deficit over five years. Since talks began in May, Bush has sought to honor a campaign pledge and lower the rates of the capital gains tax, which is charged on profits from the sale of real estate and other investments. Democrats say the proposal, which Bush contends would spur the economy, would merely put money in the pockets of wealthy property owners. They have demanded tax hikes for the rich as a tradeoff. Administration bargainers offered to leave the capital gains tax rate at current levels, in exchange for exempting the increased value of assets due to inflation, said officials who asked not to be identified. ``I think it's still a very viable option,'' said one Republican official. Democrats brushed aside the idea, one official said. But there were other signs of a new White House flexibility on the issue. Republican lawmakers who met with Bush at the White House early Wednesday said that rather on insisting on a capital gains tax cut, the president was demanding a package with items intended to spur economic growth. These might include tax breaks for companies that conduct research or do business in deteriorating cities or rural areas, the Republicans said. ``A number of options have come up,'' Foley said during a break in the closed-door budget talks. ``But whether they can be called a true alternative (to a capital gains tax cut) is debatable.'' The two top Republicans in Congress, Michel and Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., have already said a reduction in the capital gains tax rate should not be an absolute demand at the negotiations. Bargainers racing to hammer out a deal faced a dwindling number of days in which to act. With Congress planning to recess from Friday afternoon through Saturday for the Jewish holiday of Yom Kippur, a full-fledged Sunday session seemed likely. The House was ready to vote on a bill temporarily financing the government beyond Sunday, when its authority to spend money expires. The measure contained language delaying the spending cuts. Administration officials said that unless a budget deal was reached, they would oppose a postponement of the reductions as a way of pressuring the bargainers. Domestic programs would be slashed by 32.4 percent and defense programs by 35.3 percent if the Gramm-Rudman spending cuts take effect Monday. Social Security, the military payroll and many benefits for veterans and low-income people are exempt from the cuts.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Tap Nation's Oil Reserve to ontrol Escalating Prices
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs graf 8, At a fund-raising, to CORRECT Grunseth's first name to Jon.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, concerned about price speculation, has ordered the sale of 5 million barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to fight escalating prices. The administration said today the oil would be available on the market in about two weeks. Bush said Wednesday he was prepared to take additional steps if ``intensive and unwarranted speculation'' continues. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater indicated the move was as much to warn off price escalation as to test the reserve system. But Energy Secretary James Watkins told the House Energy and Commerce Committee today the sale is just a test set in the law by Congress earlier this month. ``This is not an emergency drawdown of the reserve,'' Watkins said. ``But, it will clearly ... be an important factor should it become necessary in the future to conduct an emergency strategic stock drawdown in coordination with our allies.'' Bob Porter, an Energy Department spokesman, said the department expects to put the oil on sale between Oct. 12 and 15. Under the sale, about 167,000 barrels of oil - far short of the 500,000 barrels analysts say would be needed to drive prices down significantly - will be released daily for 30 days, Porter said. At a fund-raising breakfast this morning for Minnesota Republican gubernatorial candidate Jon Grunseth, Bush praised ``the commitment of U.S. servicemen and women to contain aggression.'' He also said the ``most meaningful and most hopeful sign for change in the world'' is the cooperative effort demonstrated by the United States and the Soviet Union in opposing Iraq's aggression. The petroleum reserve, now containing 590 million barrels, was established in 1975 to ward against potential future oil shortages. The president said he wanted to test the process of drawing down the reserve. He said the country has ``sufficient oil to meet current needs,'' and added that ``there is no justification for the intensive and unwarranted speculation in oil futures.'' Oil prices have skyrocketed to nearly $40 a barrel since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and the United Nations imposed a trade embargo against Baghdad. Bush's decision marks the first time the government has tapped into the reserve. It comes at a time when the administration says there is not an oil shortage, but as officials are warning the Middle East crisis could result in tight supplies by the end of the year. ``We've been suggesting this to him,'' said Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. But he said the administration needs to call on West Germany and Japan to also tap their stockpiles. Administration oficials do not use the word gouging, but claim that the price escalation is unwarranted. Bush said Wednesday: ``At home and abroad, let me caution those who might take advantage of the current crisis in the Persian Gulf, those who might seek profit by subverting the sanctions, or here at home, those speculators who might try to drive up the price of oil.'' Oil supplies were reduced by the international embargo against Kuwait and Iraq, following Iraq's invasion of its neighbor. But industry experts estimate production in other countries has restored about two-thirds of the 4.8 million daily barrels of oil production removed from world markets by the embargo. The United States uses more than 17 million barrels a day, about half of it imported. With winter heating needs approaching, ``We do anticipate that there could be shortages and that we could have a need to rely on the petroleum reserve in a more permanent fashion,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Announces His Resignation From Bench
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge says he is going to resign from the bench, mainly because he's unhappy with sentencing guidelines enacted by Congress. U.S. District Judge J. Lawrence Irving said Wednesday he plans to notify President Bush that he will resign effective Dec. 31. Irving, 55, a 1982 Reagan appointee, said the strict guidelines - which sharply reduce a judge's discretion in sentencing convicted criminals - have taken much of the enjoyment out of being a federal judge. ``To me the job just isn't as much fun as it used to be,'' he said. ``The purpose of the guidelines is admirable - to do away with disparity in sentencing. It just doesn't work out that way.'' In a March 1988 case, Irving declared the sentencing guidelines unconstitutional, joining three other federal judges in San Diego who had issued similar rulings. They were among the first in the nation to challenge the standards, which were upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court in January 1989. Irving said he believes he's the first judge in the nation to quit because of the rules. Federal judges, appointed by the president and approved by the Senate, have life tenure. They earn about $96,000 a year, and that will rise to $120,653 in February. The Sentencing Reform Act of 1984 established a sentencing commission that set the new guidelines, which took effect in November 1987. The guidelines use a point system based mainly on the severity of the crime to determine sentences. A person's background, role in the crime, past record or remorse cannot be used to reduce the sentence below the minimum guideline. ``It used to be that a judge could do some good in sentencing'' by being lenient when leniency was called for, he said. ``Now I can't do that.'' ``I'll tell you, it really tugs at your heart when you have to sentence a first-time offender to a 10-year minimum-mandatory (sentence) or a 15-year minimum-mandatory, with no parole.''

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Meets with Protest Leaders at University
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with Barry meeting, editing.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry met today with protest leaders at the University of the District of Columbia, where students were occupying two buildings and demanding the resignation of most of the school's trustees. Mark Thompson, a protest leader at the 12,000-student public university, said the demonstration was prompted by ``our disgust with the board of trustees.'' ``This school is in a situation of disarray,'' Thompson said. ``Our accreditation is in jeopardy and that is a direct result of the board of trustees.'' He also said months of attempts to resolve some of their grievances through negotiation had failed. Thompson said the students would remain in the buildings until a list of demands were met by the administration, including one that Barry dismiss 11 of the school's 15 trustees. A university spokesman, John Britton, announced that the university would be closed for the day. ``We're asking students to boycott classes,'' Thompson said. ``Students should not come to any classes until all our demands were met.'' Members of the student government and others took control of a building that houses the university radio station, bookstore and several offices and classrooms late Wednesday after blocking entrances earlier. About 200 students subsequently shoved their way past four security guards standing in a doorway to take control of the main administration building. The students met briefly with UDC interim President Miles Fisher IV outside his office after forcing their way into the building. They agreed to leave a third-floor area housing offices of the school's top administrators after Fisher agreed to surrender the rest of the building to them. UDC trustees who attended an emergency meeting off campus sent two of their members to the school to discuss the terms and conditions of a meeting, but they were rebuffed by students. Students entered and left the occupied buildings freely, taking in pillows and blankets and market baskets filled with groceries and taking out bags of garbage. Part of the protest involved the university's plans to spend $1.6 million to renovate a library so that a controversial artwork, ``The Dinner Party,'' can be installed there. The House of Representatives voted to cut that same amount from UDC's operating budget after some lawmakers described the artwork as obscene. The work is a large ceramic sculpture that depicts the history of women in 39 place settings, some of which contain images of female genitalia. The students also complained about the turnover rate for faculty and administrators and the school's athletic program.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
U.S. Boards Iraqi Tanker
DOC.TEXT: A team from a U.S. warship in the Red Sea boarded an Iraqi tanker today after firing warning shots when orders to stop were ignored, the Pentagon said. But tanker Tadmur was allowed to proceed after it was found to be empty, the Pentagon said.. The U.S.S. Elmer Montgomery, a frigate, fired bursts of .50 caliber machine gun fire across the bow of the tanker in an incident that began at 6 a.m. EDT, said spokesman Pete Williams. A Coast Guard and Navy team then boarded the Tadmur, Williams said. He said the tanker, built in 1976, weighed 1,598 gross tons and was 270 feet long. The Tadmur, he said, was heading South out of the Gulf of Aqaba into the northern Red Sea when it was boarded. More than 1,400 hundred ships have been intercepted since the United Nations imposed an economic embargo against Iraq after its Aug. 2 invasion and occupation of Kuwait, Williams said. More than 125 ships have been boarded, 110 of them by U.S. vessels and 15 by the ships of other navies which are assisting in the embargo. He said six of the intercepted ships had been diverted and six had been boarded.

DOC.HEAD: Potential Jurors Asked Views on Homosexuals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with jury selection resuming, judge's threat to take over questioning of potential jurors. Picks up 5th graf pvs: `On Wednesday, ...'
DOC.TEXT: A county judge said he would take over questioning of potential jurors today if lawyers in the nation's first obscenity trial of a museum and its director failed to make a more serious effort to seat a jury. ``I'm going to have to do something to move this along,'' Hamilton County Judge David Albanese said. He had said Wednesday that the court would remain in session as long as necessary today to get a jury seated. The Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, face misdemeanor charges of pandering obscenity and displaying nude photos of children in an exhibit of photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, a homosexual who died of AIDS last year. By Wednesday, lawyers had rejected eight prospective jurors and tentatively seated seven. Albanese warned attorneys to limit their questions to those that would determine whether a juror could be fair and impartial. ``They're not going to be educated in the law or indoctrinated into cases of the state or defense,'' the judge said. While defense lawyers had sought to expose bias toward homosexuals, potential jurors must distinguish between art and obscenity in weighing the charges over seven of the 175 photos from the exhibit. One photo shows a man urinating into another man's mouth. Others show anal penetration with objects and other homosexual or sadomasochistic images. On Wednesday, the defense persuaded the judge to remove two prospective jurors who admitted they were prejudiced against homosexuals. Marc Mezibov, the gallery's lawyer, asked one potential juror, ``Was that a strike against the Contemporary Arts Center to know it was exhibiting works of a homosexual?'' She replied that it was not. Each side is allowed six peremptory removals for which the lawyers need not give a reason, and an unlimited number of challenges for cause, in which they must convince a judge that the juror is biased. Prosecutors have used three peremptory challenges to remove a man and a woman who saw the exhibit, and a man who said adults do not need the protection of obscenity laws. If convicted of both charges, Barrie, 43, could be sentenced to a year in jail and fined $2,000. The gallery could be fined $10,000. The exhibit, now concluding a national tour in Boston, drew more than 80,000 viewers during its seven-week Cincinnati exhibition ending in May. Lawyers also have tried to determine potential jurors' opinions about pornography, the role of an art museum and the types of photographs that should be allowed to be exhibited. Barrie's attorney, H. Louis Sirkin, asked one woman if she had stayed away from the exhibit because of its content. ``No,'' she said. ``It rained the day I was going to go.'' Defense attorneys rejected two potential jurors who indicated they were unfamiliar with the community's social standards, and one woman who said she would give ``God's law'' priority over ``man's law'' in deciding if the photos are obscene. Under a U.S. Supreme Court ruling, material alleged to be obscene must be judged according to the community's standards.

DOC.HEAD: Kentucky Woman Says Federal Inspectors Partly to Blame for Fatal Blast
DOC.TEXT: The widow of a Kentucky coal miner said today federal inspectors are partly to blame for a methane explosion that killed 10 miners because of their ``lax inspection policy.'' Sharon Scott, 36, said the Mine Safety and Health Administration knew prior to the September 1989 blast near Wheatcroft, Ky., that water had backed up in the mine, jeopardizing ventilation. ``MSHA inspectors routinely failed to order remedial measures for safety violations that they did see,'' Mrs. Scott told the House Education and Labor Committee's health and safety subcommittee. William J. Tattersall, assistant labor secretary for mine safety and health, acknowledged there were ``shortcomings'' in MSHA's enforcement of regulations at the Pyro Mining Co. mine where the blast occurred. But he said those shortcomings did not cause the explosion. Tattersall said enforcement had been stepped up at the mine, but the sanctions imposed by inspectors were not strong enough to change Pyro's ``poor attitude about safety, poor safety management and disregard of the law.'' James Greenlee, executive vice president of Costain Coal Inc., based in Evansville, Ind., and owner of Pyro Mining, declined to comment at length on the hearing. ``Obviously, we would not agree with Mr. Tattersall's analysis of our performance,'' he said. The federal government has proposed fines of more than $500,000 against Pyro for 121 alleged violations of federal safety laws, some of them which allegedly were directly linked to the explosion. Mrs. Scott, who is a coal miner, was working in a different part of the mine when the blast occurred and she escaped. She fought back sobs as she told the committee about the events leading up to the explosion that killed her husband, Curtis, and nine others. She said that Pyro managers frequently made miners hide safety violations from federal inspectors. On one occasion, Mrs. Scott said, she was ordered to stick blasting caps inside her blouse so that the inspectors would not discover that blasting had been done. ``I do not believe that MSHA should be held responsible for facts that were hidden from them by mine management,'' Mrs. Scott said, but she added that federal inspectors simply overlooked many dangerous violations. ``I believe this lax inspection policy and carefree attitude about ordering management to correct dangers makes MSHA partially responsible for the deaths of my husband and friends,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Large Quake Reported Southeast of Tehran
DOC.TEXT: A powerful earthquake struck about 930 miles southeast of Tehran outside of Iranian territory, Iran's official news agency reported Thursday. The quake, measuring 6.6 on the Richter scale of ground motion, struck shortly after 7 p.m. Wednesday and was felt in southeastern border areas of Iran including Zahedan, a provincial capital near the borders of Afghanistan and Pakistan, the Islamic Republic News Agency said. The news agency, which is monitored in Nicosia, reported that the Geophysics Center of Tehran University said the quake was too far away to determine its epicenter. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. A magnitude of 6 can cause severe damage, especially in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Customs Seize Haul Of Money And Artifacts
DOC.TEXT: Customs officers seized more than $1.6 million worth of precious objects, including paintings from Leningrad's famous Hermitage Museum, from a man trying to cross into Poland, Tass reported Thursday. The official Soviet news agency said the seized goods included $15,000 in U.S. currency, 22 paintings - some from the Hermitage, 15 ancient Russian icons, a collection of valuable coins and gold and silver items. The Soviet Chief Department for State Customs Control said the objects were taken from an employee of an unnamed joint venture who was heading for West Germany. His name was not released. The customs department said the man was stopped at by customs officers at Lazdijai in the Soviet republic of Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: British Transsexual Loses Court Bid Top Marry A Man
DOC.TEXT: A transsexual lost her six-year battle for the right to marry a man when the European Court of Human Rights on Thursday endorsed a British law barring the marriage. Caroline Cossey, 36, who works as a model and who has campaigned to be treated officially as a woman, sought the right to have her birth certificate changed to show she is now female. She underwent a sex change operation in 1974, but is forbidden by law to marry in Britain because her birth certificate says she was born a male. The Strasbourg court, following its decision in a similar transsexual case two years ago, ruled on a 14-4 vote that British policy is fair and that Cossey's human rights had not been violated. The court also rejected her claim that she was being denied the fundamental right to marry contained in the European Convention on Human Rights. The court affirmed its support for ``the traditional concept of marriage.'' It noted that there was no legal obstacle preventing Cossey from marrying a woman. Born with the name Barry Kenneth, she adopted the name Caroline at the age of 18. She initiated the legal challange with the Strasbourg court in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Air Transport Association Asks that Traffic Controllers Remain at Work
DOC.TEXT: The Air Transport Association of America asked President Bush today to allow air traffic controllers and other essential Federal Aviation Administration employees to continue working if a budget agreement is not reached by the start of the new fiscal year on Monday. ``Your action would ensure continuity in the day-to-day operation of our air traffic control system,'' Robert J. Aaronson, president of the industry association, wrote to the president. ``This is essential to protect the overall public interest as well as the continuing viability of the nation's airline industry and the many other industries which depend on it,'' Aaronson said. Deputy White House Press Secretary Stephen Hart said the White House would make no response unless deep budget cuts required by the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law go into effect on Monday because an agreement has not been reached. White House Chief of Staff John H. Sununu told Senate Republicans on Tuesday that an attorney general's opinion issued late in the Carter administration would be relied on to keep essential personnel at work. An administration official, speaking on condition he not be identified, said this probably would mean that the air traffic controllers would continue working.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Emir an Autocrat Who Tolerated Some Dissent
DOC.TEXT: Four months ago, 70 professors staged a sit-in at Kuwait University to protest a decree limiting the powers of parliament. It was an act of defiance hardly imaginable in most of the Persian Gulf, ruled by a collection of dictators, hereditary monarchs and fundamentalist leaders. But Kuwait's 64-year-old emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, was different. A contradictory jumble of benevolent father, autocrat and parlor liberal, the emir has tolerated other voices. Shrewdly, the al-Sabah family has shared Kuwait's vast wealth with their countrymen, ensuring a measure of loyalty. Even at the height of pro-democracy demonstrations last winter, no one was calling for the al-Sabah's ouster - they were asking for more power sharing. President Bush has invited al-Sabah here Friday to show Iraq that the United States still views the emir as the legitimate ruler of Kuwait.
