U.S. insistence that al-Sabah be restored to power is second only to its demand that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait. Some lawmakers criticize the U.S. stance toward the autocratic government. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the House Mideast affairs subcommittee, has said that unconditional support for al-Sabah ``would put us in conflict with the worldwide trend toward democracy, as well as with out own democratic values.'' But unlike Latin America and other parts of the world where the United States has made demands for democracy a pillar of its foreign policy, stability is the main U.S. goal in the oil-rich Persian Gulf. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said this is not the time to insist on reforms. ``The one thing we have to be careful about is getting into the position of saying that because a particular former government ... was not a form of government that we prefer, therefore, we somehow change that or participate in changing that form of government,'' he said. ``That would be nothing more than rewarding Saddam Hussein's aggression.'' Since assuming leadership in 1977, al-Sabah walked a precarious line between progressive forces at home who wanted democracy and repressive forces next door in Saudi Arabia who feared democracy might spread and endanger their conservative, theocratic rule. But unlike the Saudi king, al-Sabah allowed a lively media albeit one periodically reined in with censorship. Unlike Saudi laws, Kuwait's allowed women to drive and vote. There was nothing clandestine about the Kuwaiti opposition, which enjoyed wide support among the country's merchants and leading families. ``They discussed, argued, talked back to'' the emir, said Judith Kipper, a Mideast expert at the Brookings Institution. The al-Sabah clan, which has ruled Kuwait for more than 200 years, experimented with parliamentary elections several times since gaining independence from Britain in 1961. But each time, the legislature was decreed shut when lawmakers became too critical of the government or of other regional leaders. Last June, the emir tried again. This time, he named one third of the 75 deputies and the rest were elected. The professors were among several groups to voice outrage at the emir's decree, which they said violated the constitution. Kuwaitis have one of the highest per capita incomes in the world, about $20,000 a year, and the al-Sabah clan is greatly admired for its shrewd investment of the oil wealth. The family business - some 1,000 al-Sabah princes fill key government and financial posts - brought in more from investments last year than from oil revenue. The clan's legitimacy derives in large measure from its longevity. It ruled uninterrupted from 1751, through British control from 1899 to 1961, and until it was forced to flee ahead of invading Iraqi troops Aug. 2. Most got away to Saudi Arabia. The emir's young brother was killed defending the family palace. It was a measure of al-Sabah's acceptance that when Iraq tried to install a provisional government of Kuwaiti dissidents, not one serious participant was found. But the al-Sabah benevolence did not extend to the expatriates who accounted for more than 60 percent of Kuwait's 1.9 million people. Foreigners were excluded from the perks of citizenship such as land ownership. Two serious violations of traffic laws, for example, could result in summary deportation. For thousands of impoverished Asians and Arabs, menial work in Kuwait was a livelihood they could ill afford to lose. ``Kuwaitis looked down on other Arabs,'' said Hooshang Amirahmadi, head of the Middle East Studies Department at Rutgers University. Kuwaitis had a special name for the Palestinians, Egyptians and other Arabs who worked there - ``khadama'' meaning servants, he said. That attitude accounts in part for the bitter resentment of Kuwait that led some Arab governments to gleefully support the Iraqi invasion. Kuwaitis, too, were growing dissatisfied with al-Sabah, especially after seeing the revolutions that overthrew the Communist rulers of Eastern Europe last winter. If al-Sabah is reinstated, Kuwaitis are certain to demand change. Kipper predicts upheavals throughout the region. ``The invasion,'' she said, ``will be their fall of the Berlin Wall.''

DOC.HEAD: Mulroney Gets Permission to Expand Senate
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney received permission today from Queen Elizabeth II to expand the Canadian Senate. Mulroney wants the eight additional senators to push through a controversial new tax. The eight have been notified of their appointments, and they will likely be named today, government sources in Ottawa said. An opposition leader called Mulroney's unprecedented move ``unbelievable.'' Mulroney made the request based on an obscure section of the 1867 Constitution as a last resort to save the unpopular goods and services tax. Such a request had only been made once before in Canada's 123-year history, and that appeal was not granted. The section of the Constitution allows the British monarch to add four or eight members to the Senate on a request by the governor-general, the Canadian representative to the Commonwealth. John Haslam, a spokesman for the queen, said in London that Elizabeth, as the constitutional monarch of the former British colony, was following the provisions of the Canadian Constitution in making the decision. The measure would expand the Senate to 112 seats from 104 and establish a slim Tory plurality. The new senators will be appointed by Mulroney and therefore be members of his Conservative Party. But even with the additional seats, the fate of the tax could rest on the votes of a handful of Independents. The Liberals now hold 52 seats and the Tories 46, with one Reform Party representative, four Independents and one Independent Liberal. Mulroney said he wanted to increase the number of Conservative senators to push through the tax despite Liberal opposition in the Senate. Liberal Party leader Jean Chretien was incredulous after learning of Mulroney's latest move - particularly in view of the prime minister's low standing in recent public opinion polls. ``It's unbelievable that they'd do that,'' he said. ``At 15 percent in the polls, using the Queen.'' Such a move was tried only once before. Prime Minister Alexander Mackenzie, a Liberal, made such a request in 1873, but the British Cabinet did not advise the Queen to appoint the additional senators. Such a move by Mulroney could touch off a legal dispute. British Columbia has said it will challenge Ottawa's ability to create the extra Senate seats, and Ontario has said it may join that campaign. Alberta has promised a separate challenge on some aspects of the tax itself.

DOC.HEAD: Biographer: King Who Abdicated Told Lies About Income
DOC.TEXT: King Edward VIII, who abdicated in 1936 to marry an American divorcee, lied about the size of his fortune, pleading poverty to secure a royal income before going into exile, his first official biography said Thursday. Author Philip Ziegler has written ``King Edward VIII: The Official Biography'' with the approval of Queen Elizabeth II, Edward's niece. Working from the archives of Buckingham Palace and government papers, Ziegler reveals that Edward told a meeting of his family and their advisers that his income would hardly be $22,500 a year and that his total fortune was $405,000. As a result, he was guaranteed a yearly income of $94,500, on condition that he went abroad and would not return without government consent. He immediately left for France, taking the title Duke of Windsor. Ulick Alexander, Keeper of the Privy Purse, later calculated that Edward's fortune amounted to nearly $5 million, excluding real estate in Canada. The sum would be equivalent to $43 million at present-day values. When this was told to King George VI, who had succeeded his brother on the throne, he wrote to Edward three months after the abdication: ``You were under great strain and I am not seeking to reproach you or anyone, but the fact remains that I was badly misled.'' Ziegler says the financial arrangements for Edward's future did more than anything else to poison the atmosphere between him and his family. Their relations remained strained for the rest of his life. In June 1937, six months after abdicating, Edward married Wallis Warfield Simpson of Baltimore in a private ceremony at the Chateau de Cande near Paris. Mrs. Simpson had divorced her first two husbands, Lt. Winfield Spencer of the U.S. Navy, and Ernest Simpson, a U.S.-born British citizen who was a stockbroker in London. Edward abdicated because his insistence on marrying a divorcee created a constitutional crisis: the monarch is temporal head of the state Church of England which opposes divorce. The duke was governor of Bahamas during World War II and subsequently lived in France, where he died at age 77 in 1972. The Duchess of Windsor died in 1986 at age 89. The duke was always bitter that King George VI did not grant the title ``Her Royal Highness'' to his wife, and Ziegler says the royal advisers and law officers had grave doubts about the legality of depriving the duchess of the title. But a conviction that the marriage would not last long seemed to have been an important factor in the decision, the author says. King George VI told Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin: ``Is she a fit and proper person to become a Royal Highness after what she has done in this country? And would the country understand it if she became one automatically on marriage? ... I, my family and Queen Mary (his mother) all feel that it would be a great mistake to acknowledge Mrs. Simpson as a suitable person to become royal. The monarchy has been degraded quite enough already.'' Ziegler's book, published by Collins at about $38, is the most complete account of the abdication crisis to date. The 60-year-old author is a former publisher's editor. He has written 11 books of history and biography and edited the diaries of Adm. Lord Louis Mountbatten, a relative of the royal family and last viceroy of India.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Seeking $7.5 Billion Arms Sale to Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with proposal, snag on resolution supporting Bush
DOC.TEXT: President Bush asked Congress today to approve a $7.5 billion package of new arms for Saudi Arabia, including missiles, tanks and other weapons to beef up the Saudi military following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Bush's arms sale proposal included 150 M-1A2 tanks, 1,750 advanced TOW anti-tank missiles and 6 Patriot anti-missile batteries, according to a formal request to Congress. The package also included 200 Bradley armored fighting vehicles, 12 Apache ground-attack helicopters, nine multiple-launch rocket systems, seven KC-130 tanker planes and 10,000 trucks, transporters and trailers. In another development, House members hit snags when they sought to move ahead with a resolution backing Bush's moves in the Persian Gulf crisis. The House Foreign Affairs Committee adjourned without action on a proposed resolution of support. Speaking of the Saudi arms proposal, Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., said, ``This is a significant improvement.'' Levine, a staunch supporter of Israel who had objected to an earlier $21 billion Saudi arms package that also drew objections from Israel, said, ``This is what should have been proposed in the first place.'' Levine said lawmakers concerned about Israel's security support Bush's military moves to counter Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But the earlier, larger arms sale proposal appeared to be an attempt ``to use the crisis as justification for sending items not needed for the crisis,'' he said. At the Pentagon, spokesman Pete Williams said the proposed sale is ``urgently needed.'' But some supporters of Israel said there still was concern about offensive weapons included in the new package. They said those worries could be calmed if the administration comes up with a counterbalancing security package for Israel. Meanwhile, a tentative agreement that had been reached late Wednesday between the White House and the Democratic-controlled Foreign Affairs Committee began to unravel amid Democrats' fears that the document implied congressional consent for future military action in the Middle East. ``Some members think there's an implication of the use of force'' later in the crisis, said Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind. Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., fumed that it was ``amazing that we can get approval through the United Nations for the president's actions, but not through the Congress... I think it's unfortunate that we can't even get approval when we've got 80 percent of the American people behind the president.'' The administration has decided to divide the Saudi arms package into two parts: one to meet immediate Saudi defense needs in the current crisis, including weapons that can be delivered from current stocks or quickly taken off the production line; and a second, $14 billion package to be proposed in January to meet the country's longer-term needs. The latter package will include F-15F fighter planes and more tanks, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The delay will give lawmakers more time to deliberate how the sale might change the military balance in the volatile region, Levine said. At the same time, the administration has been discussing a new package of military aid to Israel and senior officials have promised to maintain Israel's qualitative military advantage over neighboring states. In deliberations a day earlier two Foreign Affairs subcommittees sought to make it clear their support for Bush's moves so far did not imply authorization for future military action. ``We have no interest in providing conditional authority to the president with regard to future military actions,'' committee Chairman Dante Fascell, D-Fla., said during a meeting of the Middle East and arms control subcommittees on Wednesday. ``We will deal with that, judge that, as the American people will, if and when that time arrives,'' Fascell said. Action by the full committee would culminate a week-long internal debate between lawmakers who believe Congress should take a formal part in the gulf situation and those who prefer to keep their political distance from it. Similar talks are under way in the Senate. ``I think it's important for Congress to act here,'' said Hamilton, chairman of the Middle East subcommittee. ``I know some of our colleagues would prefer not to take any action. But this is ... one of the most significant foreign policy moves in a long time. I would be uncomfortable if we ignored it.'' The resolution condemns the invasion of Kuwait and supports Bush's diplomatic efforts and use of the United Nations to bring international pressure on Iraq to leave Kuwait and release hostages. ``The United States shall, to the extent possible, use diplomatic and other non-military means in order to achieve those objectives and policies, while maintaining credible United States and multinational deterrent military force,'' the resolution says. Fascell said he does not consider the resolution to trigger the War Powers Act, which would start the clock running on a 60-day limit to the U.S. troop deployment. He said Bush has consulted well with Congress and met the objectives of the War Powers Act, and a confrontation with the White House over the law's technicalities would not be useful. The resolution also calls for continued international efforts to contain Iraq's military might, including proliferation of ballistic missiles and weapons of mass destruction, and reaffirms the U.S. policy of maintaining Israel's qualitative military edge over its neighbors.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say Sudan Tries To Bomb Food Shipments While Asking for More
DOC.TEXT: Administration officials expressed outrage Thursday over a Sudanese government request for $150 million in food aid at a time when, they said, its air force is bombing humanitarian relief sites, including a Red Cross food barge, in rebel areas. Sudanese officials submitted their request this week as Bush administration officials held high-level meetings to devise ways to help that country out of what may become the worst of several food crises in recent years. ``The problem is so big, we're really at a loss on how to proceed,'' said one official. The officials said one target of the bombing raids is a food barge donated by the Norwegian government to the International Committee for the Red Cross. The barge has been located in the Nile River adjacent to the southern Sudan town of Bor, a main transit point for relief supplies, they said. ``I think it's almost unimaginable that a government facing a (famine) disaster of epic proportions would have the audacity to bomb food shipments at the same time they are asking for more food assistance,'' said Andrew Natsios, head of the U.S. Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance. Natsios and other officials said Air Force bombs have rained down on Bor and other towns where international relief programs are in operation. They are run by the World Food Program, the United Nation's Children's Fund (UNICEF) and the International Committee for the Red Cross. According to Natsios, the areas which have been subject to air raids recently all had been designated as off limits to offensive military operations by the government and had been regarded as safe for the relief operations. Two officials, who discussed the issue on condition of anonymity, disagreed as to whether the headquarters of these relief operations were targets of the air raids. One official said he believes the real targets were rebel military encampments but another said the Sudanese government is eager to stop the relief efforts because they assist people in rebel-held areas. ``The objective is to run UNICEF out,'' the official said. UNICEF runs intensive feeding programs, child immunization programs and other ``militarily threatening programs'' he noted with heavy sarcasm. Sudanese President Omar el-Bashir plans to join about 70 other heads of government this weekend at the United Nations for the World Summit for Children. President Bush also plans to attend. A Sudanese Embassy official had no comment on the U.S. allegations, saying, ``We have no news from the Sudan at this time.'' The United States has for years been attempting to persuade both sides in Sudan's civil war to agree to a cease fire. The war involves the largely Moslem north against the mostly non-Moslem south. Richard Reid, the regional UNICEF director for the Middle East and North Africa, said he was aware of bombing raids in the Bor area but was unable to say who the planes belonged to. He said 250,000 persons died in Sudan two years ago from disease and starvation but that a major international effort called Operation Lifeline Sudan succeeded in preventing a similar calamity last year. This year, he said, ``we're facing a repetition of 1988 because crop failures have set in. We're facing a human tragedy that could surpass 1988.'' The $150 million Sudanese food aid request would provide about 970,000 tons of wheat, 10 times more than the amount sent last year under the lifeline program.

DOC.HEAD: Heflin Defends Senate Seat With Humor; Bush, Reagan Help Republican
With AM-1992 Risks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Howell Heflin pokes fun at ``Gucci-poochie'' Republicans and cultivates the image of a back-slapping Southern politician as he asks voters to re-elect him to the U.S. Senate. But his Republican challenger is hoping to cut short Heflin's Senate career with the same kind of upset that Democrat Richard Shelby pulled off in Alabama in 1986 against Republican Sen. Jeremiah Denton. ``Every poll shows us closing,'' says state Sen. Bill Cabaniss. ``The race is winnable.'' Cabaniss has a lot of distance to close - polls put Heflin's lead at about 3-1 this summer. His long-shot campaign is getting some high-level help. President Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle, and federal drug czar William Bennett have come to Alabama to campaign for him, and former President Reagan is coming Saturday. Heflin, who at times plays the role of a country store humorist, fills his campaign speeches with jokes about Republicans, or, as he calls them, ``the Grey Poupon crowd, the Gucci-poochie-coochie shoe-wearing, Mercedes-driving, polo-playing, jacuzzi-soaking, Perrier-drinking, Aspen-skiing, ritzy rich, high-society Republicans who eat broccoli.'' Cabaniss does live in Mountain Brook, Birmingham's wealthiest suburb, and was a director of Alabama's largest bank until he resigned to prevent any conflict with his Senate bid. He also belongs to an all-white country club, but he drives an American-made car and has long worn plain support shoes. ``If that's all Heflin has to run on - personalities and personal criticism - he has no business being a U.S. senator,'' Cabaniss said. ``I consider politics serious business.'' Cabaniss, 52, has earned a reputation as being all business during his four years in the Alabama House and eight in the state Senate. His starched white shirt and short, slicked-back hair have become trademarks of a man who explores the smallest details of state budgets. Heflin, 69, resembles the stereotypical Southern politician with his hefty frame, cream-colored suits, and warm personality. But his work on the Senate Judiciary Committee has earned him a reputation as a thoughtful questioner of presidential appointments and as one who often casts the deciding vote. Heflin's Senate voting record shows him siding with the Republican administration more than 70 percent of the time and often being more loyal than some Republican senators, including Quayle in 1988. But his crucial votes on the Judiciary Committee against Robert Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court and U.S. Attorney Jeff Sessions' nomination to a federal judgeship in Alabama have become central issues in the campaign. Bork himself has campaigned on Cabaniss' behalf. ``When you look at the votes that define a person's philosophy, you are going to see Mr. Heflin lined up with Ted Kennedy and Joseph Biden,'' Cabaniss said. Pat Cotter, a University of Alabama political scientist and pollster, said Heflin's conservative voting record on economic and social issues has left Cabaniss without the usual campaign issues raised by Republicans. ``One indication of that is Cabaniss' use of the environmental issue, which is not normally a Republican issue,'' Cotter said. Cabaniss spent a month paddling Alabama rivers during the summer campaign. He has picked up endorsements from environmental groups, including the Alabama Sierra Club, that were upset by Heflin votes against stronger amendments to the Clean Air Act and to delay legislation that would expand a federal wilderness area in north Alabama. Heflin, who was first elected to the Senate in 1978, dismissed the endorsements as coming from ``extremist groups.'' He said the groups ignored many strong points in his environmental record, including getting double liners installed at Alabama's giant hazardous waste landfill. Last week, Cabaniss called on Heflin to resign as chairman of the Senate Ethics Committee because he accepted a $2,000 contribution last year from a political action committee affiliated with Sen. Aln Cranston, who is under investigation by the committee for his intervention with bank regulators. Heflin said the donation was unsolicited and the name of the donor, the National Committee for Democratic Consensus, gave no indication it was tied to the California senator. After discovering the donation's origin in July 1990, ``we returned it ... out of an abundance of caution,'' Heflin said. Along with a lead in the polls, Heflin is running well ahead in campaign funds. Financial reports on June 30 showed him with $2.7 million, compared to Cabaniss' $444,000. Cotter and Margaret Latimer, an Auburn University political scientist specializing in Alabama politics, said Heflin appears to have nothing to worry about. ``I perceive him to be very safe,'' Latimer said. ``I don't think Cabaniss has brought up much he can hold against Heflin except the environmental issue.''

DOC.HEAD: Officers Will Meet to Analyze String of Coin-Shop Killings
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of murdering two people in a Billings coin shop is drawing the attention of law officers from around the country and Canada who want to question him in similar crimes. A man known to Montana authorities as Charles T. Sinclair was arrested Aug. 13 in Alaska and is fighting extradition to Montana to face murder charges for the Billings homicides. Alaska authorities say Sinclair is an alias for Jimmy Weir. Law officers from at least 15 different agencies will meet next week in Billings to compare notes on a string of killings they believe are related. Billings Police detective Sgt. Jerry Archer said Sinclair is a suspect in at least 12 slayings, including the July 31 killings in Billings. The conference will give investigators a chance to share evidence and background information and to track Sinclair's movements during the time the slayings occurred, Archer said. ``Basically, the idea is for the agencies to assist each other in any way they can,'' Archer said. ``Some of the agencies have information that only they are aware of.'' Sinclair also has been charged with wounding a coin shop owner in Murray, Utah, last May. Investigators want to question Sinclair in connection with the killing coin shop workers in Everett, Wash., in January 1980; Vacaville, Calif., in November 1986; Spokane, Wash., in July 1987; Kansas City, Mo., in March 1988; Watertown, N.Y., in September 1989; and Vancouver, British Columbia, on June 19. Police in Houston and in Mishawaka, Ind., said Wednesday they are investigating Sinclair for the slaying of coin shop workers in their cities.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Officials Deny Threat to Execute Envoys; Iraqi Ship Boarded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with eight grafs to UPDATE with arrival of regularly scheduled Iraqi Airways flights in Jordan, details. Picks up graf 5 pvs, `The Pentagon...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY6,7,10,11
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has threatened to execute U.S. and other diplomats unless they hand over Westerners they're sheltering, and an American warship fired across the bow of an Iraqi tanker today to force it to stop and submit to a search. The threat against the diplomats was contained in official statements to the U.S., French and British embassies in Baghdad Wednesday and today. The Iraqi Foreign Ministry today refused to comment on the statement, but Iraqi officials speaking on condition of anonymity said the memo only contained a reminder of an Iraqi law - issued when Iraq annexed Kuwait last month - which stipulated that those who provide refuge for foreigners could be punished by death. The officials said the law applies only to Iraqis. The Iraqi statement, first disclosed by Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Wednesday, was denounced by Western governments today. In another development, three regularly scheduled Iraqi Airways flights arrived in Amman today, and Jordanian officials insisted such passenger flights do not violate the U.N. air embargo ordered Tuesday by a 14-1 Security Council vote. About 485 people, mostly Asians and Arabs, arrived on the flights from Baghdad. The U.N. resolution prohibited all flights carrying cargo in or out of Iraq and occupied Kuwait. It also called on all states to forbid the use of their airspace to any aircraft carrying non-mercy cargo to the two countries. Officials in the United States and Britain also have said the embargo does not ban passenger flights. The Pentagon said a team from a U.S. warship in the Red Sea boarded the Iraqi tanker today after firing warning shots when orders to stop were ignored. The tanker, the Tadmur, was allowed to proceed after it was found to be empty, the Pentagon said. The U.S.S. Elmer Montgomery, a frigate, fired bursts of .50 caliber machine gun fire across the Tadmur's bow, the Pentagon said. A Coast Guard and Navy team then boarded the tanker, which was heading south out of the Gulf of Aqaba into the northern Red Sea. More than 1,400 hundred ships have been intercepted since the United Nations imposed an economic embargo on Iraq. More than 125 ships have been boarded, 110 of them by U.S. vessels and 15 by the ships of other navies. At the United Nations today, the emir of Kuwait thanked the world community for its support in his nation's fight against Iraq's ``naked, brutal aggression'' in invading and occupying his country. As Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah spoke to the General Assembly, the Iraqi delegation stormed out. In Tokyo, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu today unveiled a plan to dispatch Japanese military personnel overseas for the first time since World War II, but he said they would be unarmed and kept away from combat. The proposal, which must be approved by the Japanese parliament, calls for the establishment of a group of military and civilian personnel to participate in U.N. peace-keeping activities. Kaifu acknowledged criticism that Japan is supplying little more than money to the U.S.-led force deployed in the Middle East in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Kaifu is to travel Friday to the United States, where some of the harshest criticism has been voiced. Hurt by new and tougher trade sanctions, Iraq's leaders said Wednesday they would cut off food to non-Arabs in their country. They also announced they plan this weekend to extend nationwide rationing to rice, flour, sugar, tea and cooking oil. Bread has been rationed since Sept. 1. Before it invaded Kuwait and set in motion the retaliatory international moves against it, Iraq was importing three-quarters of its food. Diplomats in the Iraqi capital, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Wednesday that starting Monday, Iraq will halt food rations to diplomatic missions in Baghdad for distribution to their communitie. The envoys said they did not know how much foreigners would suffer because most people had stockpiled basic foods. They said that in September they received rations for distribution to their communities. These included rice, flour, sugar, tea and cooking oil. In other gulf-related developments: -Algeria's former president, Ahmed Ben Bella, returning home today after a decade in exile, urged tens of thousands of cheering supporters to volunteer to fight in support of Iraq. He also called on Algeria's government to resign. -Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak warned today that if Iraq installs missiles in Sudan, Egypt would destroy them ``the following day.'' But Mubarak, aboard a ship carrying his soldiers to Saudi Arabia, denied reports that Iraq had set up surface-to-surface missile bases in Sudan. ``If there were, we would have hit,'' he said. -Spain today ordered four Iraqi diplomats to leave the country within a week, its Foreign Ministry said. That was in retaliation for Iraq's expulsion of Madrid's military attache and assistant from Baghdad, the ministry said. The French said their embassy in Baghdad received the note today from Iraqi authorities threatening the death penalty for anyone harboring foreigners. It appeared to be the same note Baker said was received a day earlier by the U.S. Embassy in the Iraqi capital. Britain today rejected the Iraqi threat and said about 50 Britons are at its embassy in Baghdad. The Foreign Office said its diplomats received the threatening note late Wednesday from the Iraqi Foreign Ministry. Baker called threat ``repugnant,'' and a French Foreign Ministry spokesman in Paris called the threat ``utterly intolerable.'' The State Department quoted the text of the Iraqi Foreign Ministry message as saying that ``that housing a foreigner for the purpose of hiding him or her from the authorities is a crime of espionage. The punishment of death shall be imposed on the indiviudal who commits such a crime. ``The ministry will appreciate it if the esteemed mission would kindly inform the ministry of whether any of its citizens or any other nation's citizens are residing in the mission's embassies and your diplomatic residences.'' In Washington on Wednesday night, the Iraqi ambassador denied the threat was made. ``We're not threatening anyone,'' Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat told reporters after a meeting at the State Department. He refused further comment. Baker, in New York on Wednesday, rejected the Iraqi request for the names of the people given sanctuary in the U.S. embassies in Baghdad and Kuwait. About 300 to 350 U.S. citizens are stranded in Iraq, and 600 to 700 in Kuwait, according to figures released Monday by the State Department. The United States has refused to discuss how many are on U.S. embassy grounds. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Wednesday that Iraq had rounded up at least seven more Americans, bringing to about 100 the number being detained.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Shot to Death After He Took Hostages, Killed 1, Wounded 7
LaserPhoto FX2-FX3, LaserGraphic NY27
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with number of hostages up to 30 hostages, details of police decision to storm bar. Picks up 14th graf pvs: `The gunman ...'
DOC.TEXT: A heavily armed gunman invaded a residential hotel and opened fire, killing one young man, wounding seven and taking up to 30 hostages before police shot him to death today. The man, described by witnesses as an Iranian in his 30s, was shot when he ``got close enough to a window that we were able to take him out,'' Berkeley Police Capt. Phil Doran said. ``He was apparently very confused,'' said Doran. ``Deranged is not a bad description.'' The gunman - identified by University of California at Berkeley spokesman Ray Colvig as Mehrdad Dashti - was naked and bleeding when he was put into an ambulance and taken to Highland Hospital. He was dead on arrival, hospital spokeswomen Phyllis Brown said. Police would not confirm the identification. Police Lt. Jim Polk, field commander at the scene, said he ordered six heavily armed officers to storm the hotel bar after veteran police negotiators concluded there was ``no other way'' to resolve the standoff. The gunman, who had been drinking beer all night, would ``alternate between hyper and coming down,'' said Polk. ``It was felt that if we let it go much longer, he might go off and start shooting people.'' A young man and his girlfriend, who had been hostages in the besieged Durant Hotel, appeared red-eyed and upset as they were hustled into a nearby building by authorities. Both declined to give their names. ``You can't believe something like that can happen,'' the young man said. ``It was like living in a dream but it's over now,'' his companion added. Doran offered no clear motive for the attack. ``We really don't know, except that he is apparently upset because he didn't get a student loan,'' he said. The gunman was apparently hit by a burst of gunfire heard around 7:20 a.m. Seconds later, hostages, some of whom had been forced to sit in the windows of Henry's Bar in the hotel as human shields, began to run from the hotel. The standoff began shortly after midnight, when the man, armed with a half-dozen weapons including handguns and rifles, stormed in. Officials at the University of California, Berkeley campus, just a block from the beseiged hotel, said classes would be held as scheduled. Counselors were available to help those traumatized by the ordeal. The gunman shot six people after entering the Durant Hotel, Doran said. Police reported two other people were shot during another round of gunfire about 3:15 a.m. in Henry's Bar and Grill on the hotel's second floor. Witnesses said the shooting was punctuated by the gunman screaming: ``When is it going to end? How long? How long?'' Doran said one hostage escaped at the onset of the second shooting spree and did not require medical attention. The gunman, who periodically sent hostages outside with messages for police, threatened to execute a hostage if authorities did not turn off outside lights. But those hostages were not freed and were ordered to return. He also closed the drapes and rearranged furniture, police said. John Sheehy, 22, died at 2:35 a.m. of a gunshot wound to the chest during surgery at Eden Hospital in Castro Valley, said hospital spokesman Thomas McGarry. Graduate student Chris Hobbes, 20, was in fair condition with a gunshot wound to the leg, said McGarry. Hobbes was scheduled for surgery this morning. The English pub-style bar was crowded with about 35 to 40 students when the gunman rushed inside, witnesses said. About 20 were able to flee periodically during the confusion, witnesses said. One escaped hostage, who gave her name only as Rebecca, told a local television reporter that the gunman instructed all the blonde women in the hotel to ``take off your pants.'' Another woman who managed to flee said the gunman then ``had them do something sexually perverse,'' but she did not elaborate. A bar patron who escaped after about 20 minutes in the bar said the gunman initially fired blanks, then injured a hostage. Sheeye apparently was killed before the threat to execute the hostages was made, officials said. Police Sgt. Ron Barela was grazed by a bullet when he arrived at the scene, Doran said. Barela was treated at a hospital and released. A 23-year-old male and a 22-year-old female were listed in guarded condition at Highland Hospital in Oakland with multiple gunshot wounds, hospital spokeswoman Brown said. Alta Bates Hospital spokeswoman Gail Radzevich said a 26-year-old female and a 21-year-old male were treated for gunshot wounds to the arm and released. A 22-year-old woman who suffered a gunshot wound to the leg was transferred from Alta Bates to Kaiser Permanente in Oakland, Radzevich said. During the standoff, officers kept onlookers two blocks from the hotel. Residents in the immediate vicinity were not evacuated, but asked to stay away from windows. ``You have to get back. You have to get back. He just shot another one,'' an officer told about 30 people gathered at police lines after 2 a.m. Steve Cahn, a 20-year-old sophomore, was not permitted by police to return to his house across the street from the hotel. ``We just went out to do our laundry and we come back and we can't even get back on the block,'' Cahn said.

DOC.HEAD: Coroner's Body Mix-up Erupts in Funeral Furor
DOC.TEXT: Two bodies were switched at the medical examiner's office, and the mix-up went undetected until relatives went to a funeral home and saw a stranger in the casket. ``It was a nightmare,'' said Velma Romeo, who had expected to see the body of her balding, 76-year-old husband, Anthony. ``When I came up to view the casket, I saw a man with a full head of hair. He was dressed in my husband's clothes and he had on my husband's glasses.'' The body was that of a 53-year-old Tampa man who died of cancer on Sept. 17, the same day Romeo died of heart disease at his home in suburban Seffner. Romeo's body was later found in the Hillsborough County morgue. ``We're very, very sorry that it happened,'' said Betty Buchan, interim director of the county Medical Examiner's Office. ``We're very sorry for the emotional trauma the family went through. We're still trying to figure out what went wrong.'' It is the second mix-up involving the medical examiner's office in four months. Last June, the office sent the wrong body to a crematorium. Mrs. Romeo said that when her husband died she asked that his body be taken directly to the funeral home. It was not clear why the body was taken to the medical examiner's office. The next day, a private courier picked up a body and took it to the specified funeral home. ``My grandson just flipped out,'' Mrs. Romeo said. ``He blew his stack. He said, That's not my grandfather!' They said, `Are you sure?' and I said, `Where's my husband?' '' ``I had my whole family with me,'' she said. ``One girl fainted, another one was screaming.'' Mrs. Romeo said the funeral was postponed a day.

DOC.HEAD: NASA's `Cannibalization' of Parts Picks Up Speed
DOC.TEXT: The stalled shuttle program has prevented NASA from ending the scorned practice of ``cannibalizing'' spaceship parts. Discovery, due to lift off Oct. 6 with a satellite to study the sun, received an auxiliary power unit and a metal grounding strap from Atlantis in August. Atlantis was grounded by leaking hydrogen fuel in June, a month after Columbia's hydrogen leaks were detected. Atlantis, in turn, got an auxiliary power unit this week that was removed from Columbia. Atlantis is due to fly around Nov. 7, four months later than planned. ``We're concerned because every time you remove a part from one orbiter and put it into another orbiter, you get two chances to introduce a problem - when you took it out of the one and when you put it in the other,'' said William Lenoir, head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's space flight program. The problem is that NASA has eight serviceable auxiliary power units, but needs nine - three for each shuttle. The units pressurize the shuttle's hydraulic system. ``If I don't have one on my `spares shelf' in stock, then I either don't fly or I have to go get one from another orbiter. Unfortunately, that's where we've found ourselves recently,'' Lenoir said Wednesday. The presidential commission that investigated the Challenger explosion recommended that NASA stop removing parts from one shuttle to supply another. NASA was forced into the situation because of an increasing flight rate and an insufficient supply of spare parts, the commission concluded. When Challenger lifted off for the last time on Jan. 28, 1986, it had 25 ``cannibalized'' parts, none of which are believed to have contributed to the disaster. The number of swapped parts per flight is going down. It has not exceeded 10 in the past two years, NASA figures show. The last shuttle flight, in fact, had no borrowed parts and the three before that each had only one. Since the last shuttle flight in April, NASA also has replaced Columbia's leaky hydrogen fuel line assembly with one from Endeavour, the shuttle under construction in California. ``It's hard from a logistics standpoint to try to keep three vehicles (outfitted), any one of which you're trying to launch,'' said Roger Enlow, logistics director and overseer of the 220,000 shuttle parts. ``If you had had the first flight go when the first flight was supposed to, you would have had them (parts) in the right ones,'' said Ann Montgomery, deputy director of logistics. Of the 220,000 parts that make up each shuttle, about 55,000 are stocked at Kennedy Space Center. There is not enough room and money to stock more, Montgomery said. Besides, some components need to be replaced so infrequently it would be impractical to keep extras on hand, she said. Although more spares are available now - one of the many changes resulting from the 1986 Challenger accident - there never can be enough, Enlow said. ``Cannibalization can never totally be avoided. There's just not enough money to do that,'' Enlow said. The current logistics budget totals $193 million. NASA is seeking $210 million for fiscal 1991, which begins Monday. The last time NASA had an extra auxiliary power unit, or APU, was in July. Another is expected in November from the manufacturer, Sundstrand Corp. of Rockford, Ill., but NASA officials are uncertain whether it, like many of late, will be unusable because of cracked valve seats. NASA is reluctant to order more APUs - at $2 million each - since an upgraded model is due out early next year. Formal approval from about a dozen NASA officials is necessary before parts can be swapped. The board is much less prone to grant such sanctions than it was before Challenger's seven crew members were killed, said Jay Greene, deputy manager of the shuttle program office at Johnson Space Center in Houston. David Acheson said he and others on the presidential commission opposed the practice because of the ``degree of uncertainty'' introduced each time a part is swapped. ``If you multiply those uncertainties, however small they may appear individually, you are necessarily increasing the risk of some maladjustment or some slight injury to a component or some little glitch in the assembly,'' said Acheson, executive director of George Washington University's Institute for Technology and Strategic Research. NASA recently learned the risk of tampering with installed components. While searching for contamination in Columbia's engine compartment following the shuttle's January flight, workers apparently crushed a seal on a valve, which contributed to the hydrogen leak. More such damage is feared.

DOC.HEAD: Pat Robertson Attacks Arts Endowment for `Oral Sex' Puppet Show
DOC.TEXT: Evangelist Pat Robertson charged Thursday that a children's puppet show featuring simulated oral sex was performed last week at an Atlanta arts festival allegedly subsidized by the National Endowment for the Arts. Robertson's claims were vigorously denied by the NEA, the Georgia state arts council and puppeteer Jon Ludwig of Atlanta. ``This is just the latest example of the continual distortion of fact by the arts endowment's most virulent critics, those intent on eliminating the agency at any cost, even that of the truth,'' said chief NEA spokesman Jack Lichtenstein. Robertson said the puppet show, performed at the Atlanta Arts Festival last Friday before 800 people, including children, featured ``approximately five minutes of simulated foreplay between two puppets followed by an exhibit of oral sex acts.'' Robertson, a 1988 presidential candidate, said his Christian Coalition in Chesapeake, Va., responded by generating 27,000 petitions demanding that the NEA be abolished and sending them Tuesday to every member of Congress. ``The Atlanta Arts Festival is supposed to be a family affair,'' Robertson said in a statement. ``If the weirdos on the federal dole do not stop peddling obscenity and pornography, members of Congress will hear from angry voters in November.'' Robertson said 8 percent of the festival's $760,000 budget came from public sources, including NEA money funneled through the Georgia Council on the Arts, a state government agency. But Lichtenstein and Frank Ratka, the council's execttive director, denied that any NEA funds went to the festival. Ratka said the council gave the festival $33,500 in state funds only this year. The Lichtenstein, Ratka and Patrician Gann, executive director of the Atlanta festival, said the puppet show was financed entirely by earned income - such as ticket sales and concessions - and received neither federal nor state funds. Ludwig, artistic director of the Center for Puppetry Arts in Atlanta who wrote and directed the festival puppet show, denied that it contained simulated oral sex. He characterized it as a ``morality play'' intended only for adult audiences. The show was titled ``Zeitgeist'' or ``The Spirit of Our Times: the Spirit That Always Denies'' and contained a 60-second scene in which a demon used the bottom half of a female mannequin to lure the play's artist hero. ``This was a scene about temptation,'' Ludwig said. ``It was intended to be satirical. After all, what literally happened is that two pieces of plastic rubbed against each other.'' ``The intent was to satirize all the lust and all this hoo-haw over lust in our society,'' he said. `It was not simulated oral sex. It's impossible. How can puppets do that? They don't even have the parts. It was like finding children playing with Ken and Barbie dolls in the back room and calling Pat Robertson.'' Ludwig said the puppet show got a standing ovation from the audience, a rave review in the local press and only one complaint, which Ms. Gann said came from a Marietta, Ga., clergyman. Ms. Gann said the festival theater stage was fenced off from general view because of the adult nature of evening performances. About a half-dozen children were among the audience of 800 people at the puppet show, despite warning signs and pre-performance announcements to parents that the material was unsuitable for children, she said. Robertson's latest attack on the NEA came as House members braced for an emotional floor battle over legislative proposals to extend the endowment's life past Sunday, when its statutory authority expires. Plans to begin floor debate late this week were scrapped, partly to give House negotiators more time to draft a compromise bill aimed at satisfying conservative lawmakers' demands for assurances that the NEA won't spend federal funds on obscene or blasphemous art. The debate was expected to begin sometime next week. Robertson said that in addition to flooding congressional offices with petitions demanding a fund cutoff for the NEA, the Christian Coalition is distributing literature and photographs from a controversial exhibit of works by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe to ``the districts of wavering members of Congress'' in several states. Conservative criticism of an NEA grant underwriting the Mapplethorpe exhibit prompted Congress to approve a ban last fall on federal support for works that ``may be considered obscene,'' including depictions of homoeroticism and sadomasochism and sexual exploitation of children.

DOC.HEAD: State Attorney General Clears Covenant House
DOC.TEXT: A state investigation has cleared Covenant House, the home for runaway children, of any criminal charges in its handling of charitable contributions, a spokesman for the state attorney general said Thursday. The state and officials at the shelter once run by the Rev. Bruce Ritter were negotiating changes in financial procedures to prevent any future problems, said Ed Barbini, spokesman for state Attorney General Robert Abrams. ``There are some questionable transactions we are talking to them about,'' said Barbini. ``We hope Covenant House will accede to our requests, and make the reforms.'' Covenant House came under fire when allegations of Ritter's sexual liaisons with runaway boys were made public. Ritter, a Roman Catholic priest, denied the charges but resigned his position. Barbini and Covenant House spokesman Robert McGrath said the organization has implemented 25 of the 30 recommendations made by Abrams' office. The rest should be in place shortly, said Barbini. Among those recommendations were the severing of all ties with Ritter and establishment of a more powerful board of directors. A remaining issue is Abrams' demand that the shelter make periodic financial reports to the state, said Barbini.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Deer Decoy Not Wildlife, Dismisses Charges
DOC.TEXT: A decoy doesn't count as wildlife, a judge said as he reversed the convictions of two hunters who were bagged by state game officers for shooting at a stuffed deer. Aaron J. Stiffey Sr., 46, of Bolivar, and James Wagner, 31, of New Florence, were arrested Dec. 7, 1989, during buck-hunting season. They were charged with shooting at the decoy from a vehicle on a public road, not wearing proper hunting garb or having their hunting licenses, and having loaded firearms in their pickup truck. Wildlife officers testified that the decoy, nicknamed ``Officer Buck,'' was shot twice and that they saw Stiffey fire one of the shots. And they said that when Stiffey was cited, he remarked: ``I guess you got me.'' Westmoreland County Common Pleas Judge Richard E. McCormick Jr. on Wednesday ruled on appeal that there was no evidence against Wagner. And he overturned Stiffey's conviction because the stuffed deer was not alive and did not meet the state definition of wildlife. Assistant District Attorney Patrick Noonan said the use of the stuffed five-point buck was not entrapment, as the men had argued. ``The use of this decoy is no different than an undercover policemen soliciting for prostitution,'' he said. Stiffey had been fined $648.50 and Wagner was fined $548.50 after they were convicted by a magistrate.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Issues First Order Under New Economic Powers
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev began using his sweeping new powers to rescue the collapsing Soviet economy on Thursday, ordering businesses to fulfill supply contracts and the government to ensure distribution. But it was far from clear that people would comply with his order. Many are uncertain how they will fit in the market economy Gorbachev is trying to establish and they find it more profitable to trade goods on the black market, rather than distribute them in the established structure. A Western specialist called the order ``a waste of time.'' In his first decree since the Supreme Soviet legislature on Monday granted him new powers to shore up the economy and maintain law and order, Gorbachev said told government businesses, ``regardless of their administrative subordination and location,'' to preserve economic ties. He said the businesses should meet all contract obligations for raw materials and other goods in the last quarter of this year and throughout 1991. It is during that period that the country will be trying to switch from a centrally planned to a market economy under a plan the Supreme Soviet is to select after Oct. 15. Gorbachev's decree, read on the nightly TV newscast ``Vremya'' and released by the Tass news agency, was an attempt to preserve the status quo at a time when many businesses are trying to bypass Moscow and trade directly with each other. The restive republics, for instance, have been signing economic cooperation agreements in a preliminary step toward a common market. That leaves the Moscow ministries - which since the 1920s have issued five-year plans that told thousands of factories, farms and businesses what to produce, where to sell it and how much to charge - out of the picture. Gorbachev said it was ``impermissible'' that managers had disrupted economic ties and referred to ``the extraordinary nature of the situation.'' In a harkening back to Bolshevik appeals to the proletariat, Gorbachev urged workers to join their bosses in making sure contracts are kept. He also said the Council of Ministers, the Soviet Cabinet, should if necessary ``introduce a special regime for the operation of railways and other all-state life-sustaining systems of the country.'' Bottlenecks in railroad deliveries, in part caused by a shortage of railroad cars, have reportedly disrupted the distribution of food and other goods nationwide. Soviets face shortages of housing, food and consumer goods, and the government daily Izvestia on Thursday warned that power failures are possible this winter because fuel reserves are running low and two-thirds of power equipment is worn out and unreliable. Jan Vanous, director of the economics research firm PlanEcon, called Gorbachev's decree ``misdirected.'' ``What the Soviets need is price liberalization,'' Vanous said in a telephone interview from his Washington office. ``Passing some decree on relations between enterprises is a waste of time.'' Several proposals before the Supreme Soviet legislature would free prices of goods, now set by the government. The most radical blueprint, written by economist Stanislav Shatalin, calls for junking the central planning system and moving to a market economy within 500 days by selling factories to private owners and breaking up collective farms. Gorbachev had said he would not wait for the economic rescue plan to be approved before issuing decrees to stablize the economy. But Vanous said Gorbachev is making a mistake. ``What is needed for stabilization is destabilization. Unleash market forces and let the economy take a deep plunge, then it stabilizes,'' he said. Several statistics point to a breakdown of the system. Interior Ministry officials said investigators have found corruption at half the 160,000 businesses they inspected this year and incidents of serious embezzlement are running at twice last year's level. From January through June, the Gross National Product dropped 1 percent and labor productivity fell 1.5 percent, government reports have said. At the same time, the government printed 9 percent more rubles and the average wage for industrial and service workers shot up.

DOC.HEAD: `Good Morning America' Wins First Week of New Season
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``Good Morning America'' won the morning-show ratings race in the season's first week. NBC's revamped ``Today'' remained second, dropping slightly in the ratings, A.C. Nielsen Co. estimates said Thursday. ABC's show, which also was first for the 38th consecutive week, averaged a 4.5 rating, up slightly from the previous week. NBC's show declined by a tenth of a ratings point to a 3.2 average in the week ending Sept. 21. Ratings for ``CBS This Morning'' rose slightly to a 2.6 average. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: There's More Than One Way to Cut Capital-Gains Taxes
With AM-Budget Talks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The latest Republican proposal for breaking the deadlock over deficit reduction would give President Bush the capital-gains tax cut he demands. Only the method would be different. Instead of excluding a flat 30 percent of long-term capital gains from taxation, as the president proposes, the new plan would exclude an amount that would vary with the inflation rate. Backers of a capital-gains cut say the new proposal, called indexing, would increase incentives for investment, although in the short run the ``punch'' might not be as strong as under Bush's plan. Opponents, who have shown no sign of endorsing the new proposal, say it has the same flaw as its predecessor: the lion's share of the tax cut would go to those with incomes over $100,000 a year. ``It's still a capital-gains cut,'' Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee, an opponent of a reduction, said after the indexing proposal was offered to deficit negotiators earlier in the week. Indexing is designed to prevent taxation of capital gains that result only from inflation. Present law taxes capital gains - which are profits from the sale of investments - at the same rates applying to wages and other income: 15 percent, 28 percent and 33 percent. Assume, for example, that a piece of real estate was bought in 1983 for $50,000 and sold in 1990 for $100,000. Under present law, the $50,000 profit would be taxed fully; a person in the 28 percent bracket would pay $14,000. Under Bush's original plan, 30 percent of the $50,000 - or $15,000 - would be excluded from taxation, resulting in a tax of $9,800 for a person in the 28 percent bracket. Because consumer prices have risen about 25 percent since 1983, one-quarter of the $50,000 profit is illusory; that portion has not increased the seller's purchasing power at all. Under a proposal for fully indexing against inflation, that 25 percent would not be taxed, leaving the seller in the 28 percent bracket with a tax bill of $10,500 instead of $14,000. Sellers of long-held property might be better off with indexing than under Bush's original plan. In other cases, a flat exclusion would be more profitable. Details of the indexing proposal being considered by the negotiators have not been made public, leaving key questions unanswered. Would investors be protected fully against inflation or, perhaps, only against inflation above 2 percent or 3 percent a year? Would capital losses caused solely by inflation by deductible? Before 1986, only 40 percent of gains were taxed. With a maximum income-tax rate of 50 percent, that had the effect of a top capital-gains tax rate of 20 percent. If Bush's original proposal for a 30 percent exclusion were to become law, the richest Americans, who pay a maximum income-tax rate of 28 percent, would pay 19.6 percent on capital gains. However, some upper-middle-income people, who face a top rate of 33 percent, would pay a top capital-gains rate of 23.1 percent. Past attempts to index capital gains have prompted protests that this would discriminate against other investors, whose money is in savings accounts or other investments that also are hurt by inflation.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-AID Official Sentenced for Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A former U.S. foreign aid official was sentenced Thursday to nine months in prison for accepting $11,130 from a medical consultant who was awarded contracts for public-health assistance programs. John Massey, who was also fined $2,000 by U.S. District Judge George Revercomb, was the last of three defendants who received prison terms for corrupting the award of contracts for aid projects in Central America. Earlier this year, the No. 2 official who supervised humanitarian aid to the Nicaraguan Contras was given a 12-month sentence by another federal judge. That official, Donald F. Enos, the former deputy director of the agency's task force for humanitarian assistance to Central America, pleaded guilty to accepting nearly $100,000 in bribes from medical consultant George F. Kraus. A firm owned by Kraus, who began cooperating with investigators after he was videotaped paying a $3,000 bribe to an undercover operative, once had $3.5 million worth of consulting contracts with AID, officials said. Revercomb sentenced Kraus on Sept. 11 to eight months in prison and fined him $6,000 for bribing the undercover operative of the AID inspector general's office. Massey's sentencing Thursday came on his guilty plea to conspiring to defraud the government, a charge that carried a maximum sentence of five years imprisonment. The AID project officer in Guatemala City, Guatemala, from 1987 to 1989, Massey, 51, admitted receiving the money during a time when he was giving Kraus inside information about contracts the agency was preparing to put out for bids. Massey also admitted helping Kraus write bid proposal documents. Defense attorney Howard Katzoff sought leniency for his client, noting that Massey was recently divorced and a recovering alcoholic when he first met Kraus in 1987. Katzoff argued that while Massey had some influence over how the contracts were awarded, he did not control the process. But Justice Department prosecutor David Green said that Massey held ``a position of trust and he abused that trust.'' ``This kind of government corruption calls for some period of incarceration as the only way to send the message that this type of conduct is totally intolerable in our system,'' Green argued.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The National Enquirer isn't backing down from its stories portraying Elizabeth Taylor as a heavy drinker, the tabloid newspaper's editor said after the actress filed a $20 million libel lawsuit. ``All I can really say is we stand by our story, which we investigated very thoroughly,'' Iain Calder, president and editor of the Florida-based supermarket tabloid, said Wednesday. Citing the advice of the newspaper's attorneys, Calder said he could not discuss the suit in detail. The Superior Court lawsuit filed Tuesday said the actress was hospitalized with near-fatal pneumonia when a front-page headline June 12 screamed: ``Liz Docs Furious. She's Boozing It Up in the Hospital.'' The inside headline read: ``While Doctors Battle to Save her Life ... Liz Boozes It Up In The Hospital.'' The complaint alleges that the Enquirer was notified about inaccuracies in its stories and headlines four days before publication. Miss Taylor entered Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 9 with a persistent fever and sinus infection. Her condition worsened and she was transferred April 16 to St. John's Hospital and Health Center, where she battled and overcame pneumonia. In 1983, the actress acknowledged a 35-year addiction to sleeping pills and pain killers. She has been treated for alcohol and drug abuse. --- ARLINGTON, Va. (AP) - Singer Ann Wilson, whose latest hit with her band Heart describes picking up a hitchhiker and getting pregnant from a one-night stand, says she's adopting a child o her own, a newspaper reported. Wilson says she's going to adopt a child that is to be born in late February, USA Today reported Thursday. ``I have a lot to give a child, and this has the overwhelming support of my family,'' said Wilson, who is not married. Wilson said she decided to reveal her adoption plans when she heard a national tabloid was going to do a story on it. ``When my child grows up, I don't want him or her ever to have to question the facts behind the adoption,'' Wilson said. Ann Wilson and her sister Nancy said they think their latest hit, ``All I Want to Do Is Make Love to You,'' is pure romantic fantasy. The song, from the Seattle band's album ``Brigade,'' tells of two lonely people meeting on a rainy highway. They spend the night together and later the woman bears the hitchhiker's child. But their relationship is never fully realized because the woman is involved with another man. The tune climbed to No. 2 on Billboard's Top 100 this summer. --- RALEIGH, N.C. (AP) - Was Rue McClanahan, the actress who plays Blanche Devereaux on the TV series ``The Golden Girls,'' considering an appearance on ``L.A. Law?'' No, McClanahan said she was just a curious spectator when she made an appearance at the Wake County Courthouse on Wednesday. During a court break, Miss McClanahan said she was in Raleigh for a few days to visit friends. One friend, David H. Rogers, was defending a client in a trial and she wanted to hear the case. ``I'd never been in a courtroom before,'' she said. ``I wanted to go someplace where I wouldn't be noticed.'' But the courthouse was the wrong place for that. As word spread, prosecutors, clerks and law-enforcement officers asked for autographs. The actress complied graciously. One of them was Ron Rawlings, a Highway Patrol trooper, who handed her a business card and told her his name. ``I'm a die-hard fan of hers; she's hot,'' the trooper said. --- ATHENS, Greece (AP) - Former President Carter and West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher were named recipients of the 1991 Onassis Foundation awards Thursday. Two other awards will go to Greenpeace International and prominent Cypriot archaeologist Professor Vassos Karagiorgis. The awards were announced by Ioannis Georgakis, president of the Lichenstein-based foundation, established under the will of the late Greek shipping magnate Aristotle Onassis. The foundation honors the memory of Onassis' 23-year-old son, Alexander, killed in an airplane crash at Athens Airport in 1973. The prizes are accompanied by $100,000 each and will be presented at a ceremony in Athens in April. Georgakis said Carter was chosen for his international peace-keeping efforts and for establishing the Carter Presidential Center in Atlanta to support education, human rights and humanitarian activities. He said Genscher would receive the Athinai prize for being a ``decisive factor in the shaping of today's East-West relations, part of which is the unification of Germany.'' --- SALT LAKE CITY (AP) - Mormon Church President Ezra Taft Benson's condition has been improving after being hospitalized for bleeding around his brain, officials said. Benson was listed in fair and stable condition Thursday at LDS Hospital. The 91-year-old church leader was ``sitting up, talking with visitors'' a church spokesman said Wednesday. A brain scan on Tuesday showed no new bleeding, and Benson was ``showing some signs of improvement,'' said spokesman Don LeFevre. ``He's sitting up today. That's something he hasn't done since last week.'' Benson was admitted to the hospital Sept. 18, complaining of headaches and difficulty swallowing. He underwent surgery the following day to remove clots from both sides of the head. A second operation was performed Sunday to remove a reaccumulation of blood on the left side of the head. Benson became president of the 7.5 million-member Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Kids Issued Plastic ``Credit Cards'' to Buy Lunch
DOC.TEXT: Some kids don't need lunch money anymore. And, no, there's no free lunch for them. Instead, several elementary schools have introduced a plastic ``credit card'' for those who have a habit of losing lunch money or spending it on something else. ``You hand 'em your card, and whoosh! they put it through the machine,'' Danny Vigil, a third-grader at Rancho Las Positas Elementary School, said Tuesday. ``It saves time. We go out on the playground.'' Unlike regular credit cards, parents pay lump sums in advance for these plastic accounts. Card purchases are then deducted from individual accounts. Schools in Livermore, San Jose, Dublin, Antioch, Vallejo and Fairfield recently joined schools around the country, including those in Philadelphia and Fort Worth, Texas, in using plastic lunch money. Officials for card manufacturing companies say some schools have had the cards for as long as five years. ``We have technology in our lives, and now, so do children,'' said Chip Goodman, president of School Nutrition Accountability Systems Co. of Santa Monica. Goodman said his business makes cards for about 100 school districts around the nation.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Chamber Waged Secret Campaign for Nobel Prize
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce has waged an elaborate, secret campaign for the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize, according to internal documents and former officials of the business group. The business federation, which nicknamed its campaign ``Special Project,'' courted U.S. lawmakers, world leaders and a former prize-winner to get itself nominated for the award, the documents show. It hired an editor to research and prepare a narrative of the chamber's overseas activities. The award, worth $653,000 this year, will be announced on Oct. 15 in Oslo, Norway. Candidates may be nominated by previous laureates, members of parliaments or political science faculty members of selected universities. The chamber's pitch was that it has helped bring democracy and a free enterprise economy to Eastern Europe and Third World countries. Nominations closed on Feb. 1. The chamber was nominated by David A. Morse, a New York attorney who was director general of the International Labor Organization, which won the prize in 1969; and Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind. ``I'd be embarrassed if I were promoting myself that much,'' said Barry King, the organization's media relations director until June. ``It seems to me the people who have won it didn't need to toot their own horn so much.'' But Milt Mitler, chamber vice president for public liaison, said Wednesday, ``It was not a campaign. We were nominated for the prize by Sen. Lugar and Mr. Morse. We had to give them both historic information on what the chamber does or has done.'' Being nominated ``is a feather in our cap,'' Mitler said. Last year, the chamber drafted a nominating letter that said it ``richly deserves international recognition for its bold and visionary leadership in the cause of human freedom, which is a prerequisite to world peace.'' The nominating process is secret, and it is uncertain whether Morse or Lugar used the letter. The campaign was the chamber's ``secret project. They were consumed by it during a three-month period,'' said King, who resigned from the chamber to become a private consultant in Atlanta. Details of the campaign were also provided by a second former chamber official, on condition of anonymity. However, Mitler said, ``How could we push ourself? You can't contact the committee. We did not go out and canvass people, we did not advertise.'' Last year's winner was the Dalai Lama, Tibet's religious and political leader. Polish Solidarity leader Lech Walesa and India's Mother Teresa also are recent winners. Rep. Lee Hamilon, D-Ind., declined a request by chamber President Richard Lesher and other chamber officials to nominate the business group. Hamilton told Lesher ``that he just could not nominate because it would be inappropriate,'' according to a chamber-prepared chronology that chronicled the campaign from September 1989 through last January. In December 1989, Hamilton had been visited by Lesher, Mitler and other chamber officials, and presented a document about the business group and a proposed nominating letter. Hamilton, who declined comment this week, said at the time that he ``doesn't think he has the clout in Norwayto make a difference,'' according to a chamber outline of the meeting. The chamber devoted time ``to gathering information on the award from various sources including the committee in Norway, strategizing on how best to secure nominator support and making the appropriate contacts,'' its chronology said. The chamber is a federation of 180,000 businesses, trade and professional associations and satellite chambers in the 50 states and overseas. Members pay dues, and receive publications and a voice in chamber programs and lobbying. According to the chronology, the chamber's original list of potential nominators included former President Reagan, Turkish President Turgut Ozal, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and Oscar Arias, the former Costa Rican president and a Nobel winner. Before narrowing the list, the chamber assigned officials to try to win nominations from each leader, as well as from Morse and Lugar. The Nobel selection committee, whose members are elected by the Norwegian Parliament, says it is not swayed by lobbyists or by thousands of letters promoting favorites among candidates. Norwegian news reports said this year's nominees include Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, and Czechoslovakia's President Vaclav Havel and former Foreign Minister Jiri Hajek.

DOC.HEAD: National Landmarks Feeling the Crunch
With AM-Budget Talks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: From Independence Hall to Yosemite National Park, America's best known landmarks are already feeling the sting of the federal budget crisis. The roof at Independence Hall leaks. Yosemite had to scale back its 100th birthday party. And a Texas memorial had to cancel a popular folk festival for the first time in 18 years. Things could get worse. The cash crunch threatens to make the Washington Monument into a massive symbol not only of America's first president, but of a government unable to operate its historic treasures. Absent a congressional budget agreement before Monday, the monument would have to close on the two days producing the least number of visitors - probably Mondays and Tuesdays, the National Park Service said Thursday. For years, the park service has been accused of ``gamesmanship'' by threatening to close such a visible and popular monument, said park service spokesman Duncan Morrow. ``The Washington Monument has been the great symbol of the budget game for several years. But under the basic rules of Gramm-Rudman (the budget deficit law), each park is a separate item that has to get the same degree of cut,'' Morrow said The Statue of Liberty would also shut down two days a week, the park service said. Budgets are already lean at national parks and monuments. But administrators are preparing for the possibility that the president may have to order automatic spending cuts Monday, the first day of the government's 1991 fiscal year. That would force most government agencies, including the park service, to trim expenses by 32.4 percent. Already, Philadelphia's Independence National Historical Park has announced the indefinite closing of the Second Bank of the United States, the Marine Corps Museum, the Army-Navy Museum and Old City Hall. The park's most popular attractions - the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall - remain open. But Independence Hall's roof is in disrepair, prompting an urgent plea from Rep. Thomas Foglietta, D-Pa., not to allow ``a vital part of this country's history'' to ``slide into ruin.'' Provisions of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget deficit law require the park service to impose reductions evenhandedly on its nearly 600 parks, programs and activities. Parks could choose to absorb the cuts in different ways. At Grand Canyon National Park, the 32.4 percent cut would probably mean reductions in the number of seasonal staff, said spokesman Chuck Lundy. That could jeopardize operation of the park entrance stations, which collect $5 fees from motorists. In Hawaii, the USS Arizona memorial to Americans killed at Pearl Harbor would close one or two days a week, said chief ranger Gary Warshefski. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan would be unable to attend Yosemite's long-planned 100th anniversary celebration, scheduled for next week. ``How can you justify to a furloughed worker the price of a plane ticket to fly across the country for a ceremony?'' Morrow asked. Administrators of the Chamizal National Memorial in El Paso, Texas, canceled next week's $70,000 music and dance festival celebrating a bridge of U.S. and Latin American cultures. The memorial marks the settlement of an American-Mexican border dispute. ``It's sort of a heartbreaker to everybody. After 17 years, we were starting to think we were secure,'' said memorial Superintendent Frank Smith.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Says Gulf Crisis Draining Its Funds
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank signalled for the first time Thursday that it may not have sufficient resources to handle the economic shocks resulting from the Persian Gulf crisis without appealing to rich countries for extra donations. Officials of both the World Bank and its sister lending organization, the International Monetary Fund, expressed worries about the possibility that the turmoil in the Mideast could result in a global recession. But the two institutions continued to insist that such a calamity could be avoided with sensible policies to control the inflation expected to result from the doubling of oil prices since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``We face the risks of recession and higher inflation. It is time for a steady response. We need to maintain confidence,'' IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus said at the close of the 45th annual meetings of the two institutions. ``Countries will suffer from the gulf crisis, but this is manageable as long as (debtor nations) follow good policies and the international support matches the efforts of the countries themselves,'' Camdessus said. World Bank President Barber Conable said that if oil prices remain at current high levels over the next three months, then his institution would likely not have sufficient resources to cushion the impact on developing countries. He said that if that proves to be the case he would seek approval from the countries that make up the bank's board of directors to establish a special fund for voluntary contributions from oil-rich nations and others. The money would be used to provide no-interest loans to nations having the greatest difficulty coping with the jump in oil prices and other economic fallout from the Persian Gulf crisis. Conable did not mention any possible candidates for such aid. But a World Bank report earlier in the week singled out 10 countries whose economies stood to suffer the most from the Iraqi invasion. The list included Jordan, Turkey and Egypt, the nations the Bush administration has been focusing its fund-raising effort on in a belief that without significant aid the resolve of these nations to support the campaign against Saddam Hussein could crumble. The World Bank report also listed Morocco, Bangladesh, India, Pakistan, the Philippines, Sri Lanka and Sudan as countries that would be seriously affected from such factors as higher oil prices, loss of export markets and returning refugees. ``If the price of oil stays up and there continues to be turmoil and uncertainty and an impact on the global economy, clearly it will have a major impact on significant parts of the developing world,'' Conable told reporters. His comments Thursday represented a change from an earlier stance that the World Bank did not need to create programs and could handle the crisis with existing resources.
