In part, the change of view reflected the escalating economic fallout that has seen world oil prices climb toward $40 per barrel. Other World Bank officials suggested that the proposed new lending program could be used to disburse funds raised by the Gulf Crisis Financial Coordination Group, a steering committee unveiled in a speech by President Bush to the opening session of the IMF-World Bank on Tuesday. However, they said discussions on this possibility were still in a very preliminary stage. On Monday, both the IMF and the World Bank endorsed U.S.-backed proposals to boost their lending in response to the gulf crisis, but those increases were to be made in the context of existing programs at both institutions. On another matter, both Camdessus and Conable said they had held discussions with a delegation from the Soviet Union, which was attending this year's annual meeting for the first time. However, both officials indicated it would be some time before the Soviet Union would qualify for membership, something the Soviets desire because it would allow them to tap the huge loan resources of both agencies. While membership is not immediately possible, both Conable and Camdessus said their institutions would provide technical advice to help the Soviets in the massive job of reforming their economic system.

DOC.HEAD: New Hope For Hostages: But Rushdie Dispute Remains
With AM-Britain-Iran, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The resumption of diplomatic ties between Britain and Iran on Thursday raised modest hopes of freedom for British hostages in Lebanon, but left unresolved the original dispute over author Salman Rushdie. ``This is good news,'' said Paul Handley, spokesman for Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie. The archbishop's envoy, Terry Waite, is among three Britons believed held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian Moslem fundamentalists. ``Of course it does not mean all the problems are solved,'' Handley added. ``But they will be much easier to solve through normal diplomatic channels.'' For both countries the move involved some concessions - largely unspoken. They severed relations in 1989 over Rushdie's ``The Satanic Verses,'' which many Moslems regard as blasphemous. DOC.HEAD: Brown Sees Himself Taking Big Role In Selecting Dem's 1992 Nominee
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, I did, to correct year to 1980 sted 1976.
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Party chairman Ronald H. Brown has no intention of sitting back and watching his party self-destruct in the 1992 presidential election. But he concedes his determination to play a ``major role'' in selecting the Democratic nominee is a risky business. ``I'm not advocating smoke-filled-room politics,'' he said in an interview. ``I am advocating common-sense, pragmatic politics which says we're serious about winning the White House and which says, if you're serious about that, you've got to take some risks and you've got to be willing to take some heat.'' ``We haven't been real successful five of the last six times and to ignore that fact is really lacking in good judgment,'' Brown said this week, referring to the fact the Democrats have elected only one president since 1968. Certain to generate the most intense heat was Brown's idea that not onlyillion barrels in its strategic reserve. Japan has 208 milion barrels, West Germany claims 53 million barrels, Sweden has 1 million barrels and the rest of Western Europe, 6 million barrels, according to statistics from the U.S. Energy Information Administration in Washington. The IEA official said President Bush's decision Wednesday to sell 5 million barrels from the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve wasn't out of line with the agency's position. He said Bush wanted to test the reserve system to be sure it works. The official said he hadn't heard of any U.S. effort to convince other countries to follow suit. U.S. Rep. John Dingell, a Democrat from Michigan who is chairman of House Energy and Commerce Committee, said the Bush administration should ask West Germany and Japan to tap their stockpiles. The International Energy Agency's members include the United States, Canada, Japan, Australia, New Zealand and virtually every major Western European country except France and Finland. The agency estimates the total crude output by the 13 members of OPEC at 22 million barrels a day in September, up from 19.7 million in July. This has helped offset the loss of embargoed Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil, which totalled about 4.8 million barrels daily. The official said OPEC's increased production came primarily from Saudi Arabia, which has produced an average 7.3 million barrels a day this month compared to 5.6 million a day in August. Given the rise in OPEC output, the official said the world oil supply was ``manageable, though not comfortable.'' He said oil companies have had to draw on stockpiles during a period normally reserved for building up supplies ahead of the high-demand winter season. The U.S. petroleum reserve was established in 1975 as a cushion against potential future oil shortages. Bush said he may expand sales from the reserve if ``intensive and unwarranted speculation'' continues. The United States uses more than 17 million barrels a day, about half of it imported.

DOC.HEAD: Judiciary Committee Approves Souter Nomination
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS graf 5, Souter issued, with Souter statement.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted 13-1 today to approve President Bush's nomination of Judge David Souter to the Supreme Court. The panel sent its recommendation to the full Senate, where confirmation was expected within a few days. Republicans urged a speedy vote so Souter could take his seat before the court opens its term on Monday. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., cast the only vote against Souter. Souter did not attend the committee session. He remained in New Hampshire, listening to the proceedings from a radio in the law office of his close friend, former state attorney general Tom Rath. Souter issued a statement several hours after the vote thanking members of the committee ``for their courtesy and consideration'' and said, ``I am gratified by their action. I await the decision of the full Senate.'' Committee Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., joined with six other committee Democrats and all six Republicans in supporting Souter. Like many of his Democratic colleagues, Biden said he was troubled by uncertainty surrounding Souter's positions on rights issues including abortion. ``He's about the best, though, that we're going to be able to do from this administration,'' Biden said. President Bush, in Cleveland to campaign for Republican candidates, said the committee vote ``is good news for all of us who are committed to the Constitution of the United States. He'll be a superb justice for the Supreme Court.'' He urged the full Senate to ``act as quickly as possible to confirm this man'' so that he could be seated when the court opens its session next week. ``We probably have as moderate a choice as George Bush will send to the Senate,'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill. While Souter did not attend the meeting, many of the activist groups that worked for or against his nomination were present in the packed hearing room. For nearly two hours prior to the vote, 13 of the 14 senators read statements on their positions before the television cameras in the paneled committee room. Sen. Gordon Humphrey, a Republican from Souter's home state of New Hampshire, submitted a written statement for the record, saying he wanted to speed action on the vote. Kennedy broke ranks with his colleagues who wanted to give Souter the benefit of the doubt. ``The lesson of the past decade ... is that we must vote our fears, not our hopes,'' he said. Molly Yard, head of the National Organization for Women, praised Kennedy for his opposition, telling reporters afterward that his action was a ``Profile in Courage,'' a reference to a book on great Americans written by his late brother, President John F. Kennedy. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said women's groups and civil rights groups urged him to vote against Souter, but he said ``my sense is that David Souter is a fair and open-minded jurist who knows well the weight of the responsibilities which will be placed upon him.'' ``I hope I'm not wrong,'' he added. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, chided any Democrats who use a ``litmus test'' on abortion in opposing Souter. ``I do not believe that he will impose his own policy preferences on the American people in the guise of judging.'' Souter, 51, who spent 12 years on the New Hampshire bench before joining the federal appeals court in Boston this year, would be the 105th Supreme Court justice if confirmed by the full Senate. Souter is Bush's first nominee to the high court and the president asked the Senate to confirm him before Monday, the first day of the Supreme Court's 1990-91 term. The only announced opposition to Souter in the Senate was from lawmakers supporting abortion rights. Souter, who would succeed pro-choice Justice William Brennan, would swing the court against abortion rights if he voted to overturn the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion. During his confirmation hearings, Souter said he had not made up his mind on Roe vs. Wade. But given Bush's anti-abortion stance, lawmakers were suspicious. Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., said he will vote against confirmation of Souter, ``because I can find no basic commitment to preserving the right to privacy and the right of women to make their own decisions in the area of reproductive rights,'' Adams said in a Senate floor speech. Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J, said Wednesday in announcing his opposition to Souter that overturning Roe vs. Wade would ``return us to the day when illegal back-alley abortions put the lives of thousands of women at risk.'' ``That's a chance I'm not willing to take,'' he said. Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., one of two women in the Senate, said ``we must fear the worst'' because ``Judge Souter refused to talk about whether, and how, the Constitution protects the women of America.'' The Senate majority appeared to be firmly in Souter's camp, however. Several other Democrats, including four on the Judiciary Committee, announced their support in advance of today's vote. One Souter ally tracking the nomination said he would be surprised if there were 20 votes against the nominee in the 100-member Senate. Sen. Herbert Kohl, D-Wis., a committee member who announced his support for Souter on Wednesday, reflected the views of many abortion-rights lawmakers who planned to support the nomination. ``At least we didn't hear him say that a woman does not have that right,'' he said. ``He told me that he would not prejudge the issue and maybe that is the best we can hope for at this time.''

DOC.HEAD: Indian Refugees Angered By Long Delays In Squalid Camps
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto AMM5
DOC.TEXT: Indian refugees angered by harsh conditions and long delays in a desert transit camp attacked an airport-bound van Thursday, staged demonstrations and angrily confronted a visiting official. The incidents betrayed a growing frustration among the nearly 14,000 refugees at the camp, some of whom have waited up to eight days in the heat and dust with only cucumbers, tomatoes and canned sardines to eat. Children at the transit camp, who now number in the thousands, are suffering heat exhaustion and diarrhea. Another 14,000 refugees wait in similar conditions at the adjacent camp of Azraq II, while thousands more have been placed in camps in Amman. Refugees surrounded a van as it was leaving the Azraq I camp, pulling out the nine people who were on their way to Amman airport for the trip home, according to witnesses. The eight men and one elderly woman on the bus were named Gujral, the same as India's Foreign Minister Kumar Gujral, and the refugees mistakenly thought they were relatives being given preferential treatment, said Dr. A.K. Amrohi, first secretary at the Indian Embassy in Amman. People complain of bureaucratic bungling, insufficient food and water and cramped conditions that make sleep impossible and the spread of contagious diseases increasingly likely. Some people say their passports have been lost. At least one man saw his baggage leave on a bus without him. Another hasn't seen his family since they were put on different buses from the Iraqi border to the transit camp. ``We are trying to sort things out,'' Amhori said, standing in an airless, hot military tent where five of his staff worked at tables piled with blue Indian passports. ``But the problem is of such a huge dimension, we really can't move things in an orderly or organized manner,'' he said. The Indian government has been flying two planeloads of refugees a day out of Amman. But many people fear that they are being forgotten. ``We are being told there are flights. If so, they must be moving buses straight from the border to the airport and not taking us out,'' said Vincent Pinto, who saw 100 or more refugee surround the van. ``Some people come in and go out the same day, whereas others wait here six or seven days,'' said Ernest George, a bank teller in Kuwait until the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion. ``We are all behaving poperly, but how long? How long? We are desperate.'' Jordanian officials blame the Indians for the delay, while the Indians blame the Jordanian police for handing them sacks of unsorted passports taken from refugees on arrival. Vir Singh Jubal, another witness to the van incident, said Jordanian police arrested an unknown number of refugees. Pinto said the detainees were released after refugees surrounded the police post near the camp and threatened to storm it. Camp officials denied anyone had been detained. They said the nine people on the van were allowed to leave within a few hours, after Indian officials met with angry demonstrators. The camp, in the desert outside the oasis of Azraq, is buffeted by sandstorms that have turned the white tents orange and coated the beards of the men and the faces of the children with sand and grit. Annamma James arrived in Azraq I eight days ago with 31 members of her family, including 11 children. ``The children have diarrhea. There is not enough to eat. Look at us, we are all dirty because there is no water to bathe. The food we brought with us is gone, tomorrow there will be nothing left.'' Gazing through glasses covered with dust, she said: ``What are we going to do?''

DOC.HEAD: South Africans Feel More Welcome, But Still Not Ready to Seek Loans
DOC.TEXT: South African officials attending annual world financial meetings say they'e getting an unusually warm reception this year but that they don't plan to create any embarrassment by applying for loans. South African Finance Minister Barend Du Plessis said the well-received visit of President, F.W. de Klerk to Washington earlier this week would have no short-term economic impact. But he said it would help build credibility as the country dismantles its white supremacist system of apartheid. Chris Stals, head of the South African government bank, said there were no plans to apply for IMF loans because of the U.S. sanctions. ``It would unavoidably lead to discussions of the situation with the U.S. Congress and could embarrass us,'' Stals said. Stals, who was attending his 22nd IMF-World Bank meeting, said private bankers generally talked to him in the past because they wanted to be polite or were curious about South Africa. ```But this year, they're much more interested in the basic realities,'' he said. ``They're updating files ... and preparing to do business again.'' Du Plessis, Stals and other South African officials talked to reporters during the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and its related institution, the World Bank. Despite South Africa's past political isolation because of apartheid, Du Plessis said, the country has had normal relations with world financial institutions and was a founding member of both the IMF and the World Bank. It has, however, been denied a seat on the bank's board of directors and any application for IMF loans must be referred to the U.S. treasury secretary. Congress has imposed sanctions against South Africa because of apartheid. Du Plessis said South Africa could use help in its efforts to grow economically. ``It is a strange thing for us to be regarded as a developed country, with very definite needs,'' he said. South Africa has complied with all commitments to the two institutions, paying off its last loans several years ago, he said. However, it's ineligible for World Bank loans because its per capita income exceeds $2,000.

DOC.HEAD: Marshall Turner Elected Chairman of CPB
DOC.TEXT: Marshall Turner has been elected chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and Daniel Brenner was re-elected vice chairman, CPB said. Turner was appointed to the CPB board in June 1987 for a term that expires in March 1992. He succeeds Ken Towery. Brenner was appointed to a five-year term on the board in October 1986 and was elected vice chairman in September 1989. Turner is a general partner of Taylor & Turner Associates investment firm in San Francisco. Brenner is a lawyer and director of the communications law program at the University of California, Los Angeles. Turner was on the board of directors of KQED-TV and KQEC-FM in San Francisco for 10 years, serving as board chairman from 1986 to 1987. Brenner is counsel to the LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae law firm. The elections were conducted Tuesday at the annual meeting of CPB, which is a congressionally mandated, private, non-profit corporation that develops non-commercial radio and TV services for the American public.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
Polish Official Says Attempt to Turn Capitalist Endangered
DOC.TEXT: Poland's finance minister said Thursday the effects of the Persian Gulf crisis combined with failure to ease the massive Polish debt were endangering his country's attempt to turn capitalist. The loss of revenue from business contracts with Iraq and Kuwait, in addition to the rising price of oil, will cost Poland $2 billion over the coming year, said Leszek Balcerowicz. ``Poland has been very severely hit, at a very delicate time'' of the reform program, he told reporters. Iraq had been selling oil to Poland at cut-rate prices in return for a write-off of an estimated $600 million debt incurred during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. Poland also sold Iraq large quantities of weapons, and Polish companies were engaged in construction projects for Iraq's post-war rehabilitation, officials said. The Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait has stopped all that, and sent some 1,000 Polish workers home. The crash reform program initiated Jan. 1 by Poland's first non-communist government is designed to turn the centralized economy into a market-driven capitalist system. Government subsidies to businesses have been cut off, raising prices sharply and forcing enterprises to become competitive or go bankrupt. Resulting layoffs have driven unemployment to 5 percent, a level unknown under the Communist Party which ruled Poland until last year. Balcerowicz, who also serves as deputy prime minister, said Poland's top priority was to trim its $40-billion debt, two-thirds of which is owed to other governments and the rest to banks. ``How can we convince people there's a light at the end of the tunnel with the growing debt overhang?'' he said. But four days of talks with finance officials and bankers gathered here for the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, he said, had failed to yield concrete results. ``There was considerable progress in understanding, but a lack of readiness to act,'' he said. ``Time is crucial.'' Poland is also facing the problem of having to pay with hard currency for much of its imports once its main trading partner, the Soviet Union, goes to a cash-only trade system based on realistic market values starting Jan. 1. Balcerowicz said Poland was negotiating with the Soviets to ensure there is no disruption in the gas pipeline supplies. The Soviets have told Poland they will cut the supply from 8.2 billion cubic meters to 5.2 billion. But Balcerowicz said he views this as ``an opening position'' in negotiations. ``We are insisting on maintaining the supply,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Army Wife Says Her Letters Aren't Getting to the Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The wife of a soldier stationed in Saudi Arabia said he isn't receiving her letters because thousands of well-meaning people are jamming the military postal system with letters addressed to ``Any Soldier.'' Annie Berg, wife of an Army sergeant first class usually stationed at Fort Stewart, said Wednesday her husband is ``worried sick'' because no family letters have reached him during the month he's been in the desert. ``We love their patriotism, but if they could just stop with the letter writing to just `any soldier,' '' she said. ``My husband is not just any soldier. My friends' husbands are not just any soldier. They have families trying to get their letters through. The letter from home is the best mental nourishment they can get.'' ``We've had quite a few people complain that they aren't getting their mail,'' said Dean Wohlgemuth, a spokesman for the 24th Infantry Division (Mechanized) at Fort Stewart. ``We're trying to speed it up.'' Leon Wood, postmaster at the Hinesville post office, said letters for Fort Stewart soldiers are turned over to the Army Post Office in New York. He said domestic postal workers treat all first-class letters the same, whether they are addressed to specific soldiers or ``any soldier.'' Maj. Carl Gidlund, spokesman for the Central Command at MacDill Air Force Base in Florida, said there were complaints about slow mail deliveries early in the operation and the Army and Air Force responded by sending more mail specialists. Gidlund described Mrs. Berg's problem as ``an isolated incident.'' ``All I can do on behalf of the armed forces is apologize,'' he said. Mrs. Berg declined to identify her husband, a 14-year veteran. She said she feared he might be punished for her remarks. ``My husband is worried sick because he hasn't heard from me,'' she said. ``I have many, many friends and their husbands are writing them saying, `How are you? How are the kids? We've heard nothing from you.' '' Mrs. Berg said she has written her husband at least every other day and has sent three packages since he left for the Middle East on Aug. 26. She has received three letters from him. She said their three daughters - Karen, 13; Tia, 9; and Jean, 7 - are upset because their father writes and says ``Have the girls write me.''

DOC.HEAD: Faxes From Home: Americans Faxing Messages From Mom
DOC.TEXT: Maureen Nwoye tried to win back an ex-boyfriend Thursday by long distance - via fax to Saudi Arabia where he is stationed with the Army's 82nd Airborne division. And it was free. AT&T's began offering its ``Desert Fax'' service, in which people can fax messages to relatives and friends, on Sept. 21. ``We send out about 4,000 faxes a day,'' said Rick Wallerstein, a spokesman fr AT&T International. Customers can send messages to members of the military in the Middle East from any of the company's 400 Phone Stores nationwide. The service is expected to continue through December. ``It's been going very, very well,'' Wallerstein said, adding that the kinds of faxes going out are ``really a slice of life.'' ``We have kids who have done drawings for daddy. One person wrote a letter as if it was from a baby who was just born. It was the serviceman's nephew and it went something like, `You don't know me yet. I was just born yesterday.' '' ``Sometimes it's quite an emotional scene. You see various family members who are very worried about their loved ones,'' he said. Miss Nwoye, 22, admitted she was to blame for the breakup with her boyfriend, whom she identified only as John, and said she'll keep up her faxes every other day until he breaks down and writes back. ``And I also want to let him know that somebody's thinking about him back here,'' she said as she scrawled her message at an AT&T Phone Center in Manhattan. Emilia Diez, of Yonkers, also stopped at the store to fax her two nephews - Roy Saravia, 19, in the Air Force, and Luis Saravia, 21, in the Navy. Her message included some aunt-like advice: ``Lay down when you have to'' and ``we don't need any heroes at home; we just need you back, safe and sound.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules California's Shield Law Protects Reporters in Civil Cases
DOC.TEXT: Reporters who cover events that lead to civil lawsuits can't be jailed for refusing to provide notes, photographs or news sources to parties in the suits, the state Supreme Court ruled Thursday. The unanimous decision said a shield law added to the California Constitution by voters in 1980 protects reporters from being held in contempt of court for withholding confidential sources, notes or unpublished material. The court ruled in May that the law can be breached in a criminal case, requiring a reporter to provide evidence necessary to protect a defendant's constitutional right to a fair trial. But the justices said Thursday that parties in a civil case have no similar constitutional right. ``This is a complete victory for the journalists and the public,'' said C. Michael Cooney, lawyer for The New York Times Co., publisher of the Santa Barbara News-Press. The ruling was prompted by a lawsuit involving News-Press photographer Robert Ponce. The photographer took pictures of an auto accident on a U.S. 101 ramp in June 1984, two of which appeared in the newspaper. Volkswagen of America, sued by an injured passenger, sought Ponce's unpublished photos as evidence. Santa Barbara County Superior Court Judge Patrick McMahon ordered the newspaper to release the photos, saying they showed public events and were not confidential. The 2nd District Court of Appeal overturned his ruling and was upheld by the state Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Ask FEC to Halt GOP Fund-Raising Operation
DOC.TEXT: Democrats asked the Federal Election Commission on Thursday to halt a Republican fund-raising scheme they said could illegally raise millions of dollars for GOP Senate candidates. The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee asked the commission to ``put an immediate stop'' to the Republican Senatorial Inner Circle, which already has disbursed about $1 million to dozens of candidates. The Inner Circle is a ``dressed-up version'' of a 1986 GOP operation that the FEC found in violation of limits on party contributions, said Bob Bauer, general counsel for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. Republicans defend the Inner Circle as a legitimate joint fund-raising operation exempt from the contribution limits. Federal law allows party committees to give candidates $17,500 and spend an additional amount on their behalf according to individual state populations. A federal judge last year ruled in a lawsuit filed by Common Cause that the National Republican Senatorial Committee illegally funneled $2.7 million in individual contributions to a dozen 1986 Senate candidates through a maneuver known as ``bundling.'' The FEC has asked the court to fine the NRSC as much as $2.7 million. The differences between the 1986 and 1990 operations ``are no more than cosmetic,'' the Democrats said in a complaint filed with the FEC. The Inner Circle cannot qualify as a joint fund-raising operation if NRSC controls where the money goes, provides the staff and receives just 1 percent of the money it raises, the complaint said. ``The scale of the ... effort is extraordinary,'' the complaint said. ``It is the most monumental fund-raising effort ever mounted by a national party committee on behalf of its individual federal candidates.'' NRSC spokeswoman Wendy Burnley called the complaint ``a last gasp desperate attempt to gain press attention, particularly in the states where the most hotly contested campaigns are going on.'' Democrats are worried about the money that the Inner Circle could infuse into campaigns for television advertising that could tip some close races, she said. The operation replaces a fund-raising program started 11 years ago in which $1,000 donors were invited to Washington for briefings on issues and social events with Republican lawmakers and officials, Burnley said. The Inner Circle is run separately from the NRSC, which is reimbursed for staff costs, she said. The operation expects to raise as much as $11.5 million this year, with most of that going to GOP candidates, according to a letter mailed to potential contributors under the signature of Vice President Dan Quayle. Four dozen campaigns are members of the Inner Circle, including the 27 candidates running this year and 21 GOP senators who face re-election in 1992 or 1994. Contributions are divided according to a formula based on the needs of the candidates. Candidates received shares of $7,200 to $43,500 in June and additional amounts in August, mostly in amounts of $4,000 to $10,000, according to FEC records.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Wants Air Traffic Controllers Exempted from Furloughs
With AM-Budget Talks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The airline industry Thursday asked President Bush to exempt air traffic controllers from furloughs if a budget agreement isn't reached by Monday. ``Your action would ensure continuity in the day-to-day operation of our air traffic control system,'' Robert J. Aaronson, president of the Air Transport Association of America, said in a letter to the president. Aaronson said traffic controllers, maintenance technicians, safety inspectors and weather personnel are ``vital to the safe and efficient operation of the nation's air traffic control system.'' ``This is essential to protect the overall public interest as well as the continuing viability of the nation's airline industry and the many other industries which depend on it,'' he said. Stephen Hart, deputy White House press secretary, said the administration would not respond until and unless Monday's deadline is reached without agreement to avoid deep budget cuts. Progress was reported Thursday in the continuing talks. ``A good deal has been agreed to tentatively,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. One administration official, speaking on condition he not be identified, said the air traffic controllers were likely to be exempted even if an agreement isn't reached. The administration has said it will continue essential services on the basis of an opinion issued by Attorney General Benjamin Civiletti during the Carter administration. If budget negotiators fail to reach an accord by the start of the new fiscal year Monday, the Federal Aviation Administration has proposed to furlough each of its controllers for two days every two weeks. That would mean an average 25 percent reduction in the number of controllers available for work each day. Jack Ryan, association vice president for air traffic management, said plans called for dealing with the situation by delaying flights next Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. On Thursday, he said, flight cancellations would begin. He said delays at major airports would be ``in excess of three or four or five hours'' if the weather was good and even longer if it was bad. Aaronson told reporters ``It's absolutely ludicrous to hold the air traffic control system of the country hostage to a budget crisis.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Seeks to Restore Spending Cut Before Oil-Prices Run-Up
DOC.TEXT: The dramatic run-up in oil prices is boosting Alaska's treasury and has prompted the administration to propose restoring millions of dollars to programs that were cut in July. One of eight barrels of North Slope oil goes to the state, which also derives revenues from severance taxes on oil production. The state derives 85 percent of its revenue from oil and gas production. A $1 a barrel increase in oil prices adds $150 million in yearly revenues to the state treasury. Oil prices shot up from $13 a barrel in July to current spot market prices of $37 a barrel, fueled by fear of war with Iraq. State budget director Alison Elgee said a proposed $50 million supplemental spending package of more than $50 million is being prepared for the next governor who will be elected in November. Any new spending plan would have to be approved by the Legislature, which convenes in mid-January. Elgee said about half the proposed supplemental expenditures would go toward restoration of programs and services cut by Democratic Gov. Steve Cowper's vetoes in July. The rest would cover such things as state employee wage increases and expenses for oil spill litigation, she said. Current state spending is pegged at $2.6 billion for the current fiscal year. Cowper cut $325 million in July, citing sagging oil prices and overspending by the legislature. Cowper, who is not seeking re-election, said he wants the state to save most of the windfall generated by the Middle East crisis. ``I think most people believe there will be a substantial surplus,'' Cowper said. ``My view is that most of the money should be saved. We're not going to recommend enormous sums be put back into the budget.''

DOC.HEAD: World Community Gives Standing Ovation to Exiled Emir of Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The exiled emir of Kuwait thanked the world community Thursday for its support and mourned the destruction of his country at the hands of Iraqi invaders. ``The crisis of Kuwait is a manifold tragedy whose dire consequences affect not only Kuwaitis, but other peoples as well,'' the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, told the United Nations General Assembly. ``In fact, it has jeopardized stability in the world, especially in the (Persian) Gulf region.'' The three-member Iraqi delegation got up and walked out as the emir began speaking, but the rest of the General Assembly greeted his remarks with prolonged applause and a standing ovation. Al-Sabah, speaking in Arabic through an interpreter, told delegates that ``rape, destruction, terror'' now reign in Kuwait, overrun by Iraq's ``naked, brutal aggression.'' Addressing his own people, he expressed hope that the occupation would end. ``The withdrawal of the invaders is, God willing, undoubtedly imminent,'' he said. ``We shall return to our Kuwait, the oasis of safety and peace.'' Iraq has said it will never relinquish Kuwait. During the Aug. 2 invasion, the emir escaped from Dasman Palace in Kuwait by car, fleeing just moments ahead of Iraqi troops sent to seize him. The undersecretary-general for General Assembly affairs, Ronald Spiers, pointedly introduced the emir as the leader of the ``state of Kuwait,'' and Guido de Marco, the president of the General Assembly, heavily stressed the phrase ``state of Kuwait'' in thanking the emir for his remarks. Iraq annexed Kuwait six days after the invasion, and says it now considers the emirate an Iraqi province. But the world community has refused to recognize the Iraqi claim. The emir thanked the assembled diplomats for their ``rock-solid international rejection of the assassination of the norms of international law and of good neighborly relations,'' and denounced the ``armed military invaders whose tanks rolled over and crushed all those customs.'' Al-Sabah appealed for continued support from the world body. ``The fate of a nation is in your hands,'' he said. The emir, whose exile government is headquartered in Saudi Arabia, said reports of conditions in Kuwait under the Iraqi invasion were devastating. ``I came here to tell you of the horrors and suffering we are enduring both inside and outside our occupied homeland,'' he said. ``Rape, destruction, terror and torture are now the rule of the day in the once peaceful and tranquil land of Kuwait.'' But he added that ``an enormous source of solace to us has been the position taken by virtually all countries of the world in support of Kuwait's rights.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Plane Door Found on Floor of Ocean
DOC.TEXT: Part of a cargo door that tore away from a United Airlines jet over the Pacific Ocean in 1989 has been recovered from the ocean floor 100 miles south of Honolulu, the National Transportation Safety Board announced today. Nine people died when the door and a large chunk of fuselage broke off from the Boeing 747 shortly after takeoff from Honolulu International Airport on Feb. 14, 1989. The board said the recovered piece - the lower half of the door - measures 6 feet by 10 feet. The announcement said the fragment was recovered overnight from a field of debris at a depth of 14,100 feet. Officials said they hoped to retrieve the other half of the door by the end of the week. The board said the Navy submarine Sea Cliff videotaped the piece of the airplane on the ocean floor and raised it to the surface with hydraulic jaws. It was brought onto the deck of the Navy vessel the Laney Choust at about 5 a.m. EDT today, midnight Honolulu time. The safety board said a preliminary examination by one of its investigators showed the door had fractured longitudinally near the midspan latch. The eight sectors of the latch lock were all in the locked position and were deformed. The board said the Sea Cliff had also detected a strong sonar target near the spot where the door portion was found. It said the submarine would return to try to locate the remainder of the door after being recharged for about 20 hours. After investigators examine the recovered debris, parts of it will be sent to Boeing in Seattle for a more detailed review under board direction, officials said. The door flew off after United Airlines flight 811 experienced an explosive decompression at about 23,000 feet.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Buildup Will Be Exempted From Possible Budget Cuts
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf buildup will be insulated from possible mandatory budget cuts but other military operations will be severely affected, the Defense Department said Thursday. ``One of the goals is to try to prevent any impact on Operation Desert Shield,'' said Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams. ``We are attempting to isolate that from the effects of a sequestration.'' But Williams said other spending would be cut by as much as 35.3 percent in all areas except military personnel. The readiness of military forces outside the Persian Gulf area, where about 150,000 U.S. military personnel are on guard against an attack by Iraq against Saudi Arabia, ``would have to be degraded,'' he said. Cuts in such operations of a third to one half could be expected, he said. If cuts are made, the Pentagon said: -Disruption of the work force would be avoided as much as possible but civilian employees of some small defense agencies could expect furloughs of several days. -A temporary halt of payments in all medical benefit claims made by Army civilians and their families and by the families of Army personnel would be ordered. -Depot maintenance and other logistics programs would be done out at ``the lowest practicable level'' while still supporting Desert Shield. The Pentagon said that would mean revoking NATO agreements, adding that posed the potential for grounding aircraft. -All base engineering and housing construction and maintenance would be deferred, except for work to correct life-threatening conditions or to address major environmental concerns. -Travel, transportation, rents and utilities would be severely restricted. There is a possibility Congress may extend the deadline for budget cuts beyond Monday, the start of the 1991 fiscal year, to give White House and congressional negotiators more time to reach a budget compromise, Williams said. ``But if sequestration is not suspended, then the impact would be very severe here,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Milwaukee Approves Two Schools Tailored for Black Males
DOC.TEXT: Public school officials have approved of a plan to create two schools next year that will cater to the needs and experiences of young black male students. The Milwaukee School Board voted 5-3 Wednesday night to designate an elementary school and a middle school beginning with the 1991-92 school year as African-American Immersion Schools. Milwaukee is believed to be the first public school district in the nation to approve a specific curriculum for black males, supporters said. The District of Columbia's school board is considering a similar plan. ``It's fair to say that the achievement levels of African-American males have not been good,'' said Milwaukee school spokesman Dave Begel. ``This is an attempt to improve it.'' While the two experimental schools will be open to all students to comply with anti-discrimination laws, their curriculum will stress African heritage and the special educational, social and emotional needs of young black males, Begel said. More than 50 percent of the Milwaukee Public School District's 98,000 students are black. Supporters claim many blacks suffer low achievement in the district because they lose their identity or become discouraged by a curriculum that stresses the heritage of whites. A citizen's task force initiated the African-American school plan after its study found that fewer than 20 percent of the 5,716 black male students in Milwaukee high schools had a grade average of C or better. The group also found 50 percent of all students suspended from district schools last year were black males, even though they make up only 27.6 percent of the total enrollment. The district's high school dropout rate also stood at 14.4 percent last year. The task force didn't study the rates for black female students. Leaders of Milwaukee's black community have supported the plan throughout its development, saying the schools will be an alternative to traditional public education that has stressed European heritage. ``A lot of African-American students, male and female, just don't have any sense of what we have gone through and come through as a people,'' said Alderman Marvin Pratt, who represents a mostly black, inner-city district. ``What's missing for a lot of young people is the pride in African history that I think an Afro-centric curriculum will foster,'' he said. The approved proposal was modified from an earlier plan to establish three all-black, all-male schools. The earlier plan was scrapped after educators and lawyers advised it would be challenged as unconstitutional. Board Member Doris Stacy opposed the proposal, arguing ``it's unconstitutional, it's educationally unsound, it's morally wrong. To isolate students by race in America in 1990 is wrong.'' Ms. Stacy said the district needs to focus on black males but it would be better to create a program that ``incorporates a nurturing environment for all our children.'' The poor performance of black students was cited in another educational experiment began this year. The Wisconsin Legislature this spring approved a plan to provide $2,500 vouchers to as many as 1,000 poor Milwaukee students, allowing them to leave public schools for private, non-sectarian schools. The plan survived a court challenge and began this month with about 400 students enrolled in private schools.

DOC.HEAD: Burma Harassing Diplomatic Compounds, Envoy and State Department Say
DOC.TEXT: Burma is harassing foreign diplomats by sending soldiers into the religious ceremonies for them. The practice has spread to some monasteries in Rangoon, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Blaze Kills Parents of 9 Kids
DOC.TEXT: A rooming house blaze killed a man and a woman as they struggled to save their nine sleeping children early Thursday, fire officials said. The children escaped. The fire broke out about 12:30 a.m. and destroyed the two-story wooden house before firefighters could respond, said Deputy Fire Chief Ed Spann. Several of the children were treated for minor injuries, but the only fatalities were the two adults, said Spann. Details of how the children escaped were not immediately available. Identification of the victims was delayed until relatives could be notified. The cause of the blaze was being investigated.

DOC.HEAD: Secret Police Still Hold High Positions in Business
With AM-Germany-Bismarck, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former East German secret police officers still hold top jobs in business, while others have thwarted police investigations, a parliamentary report said Thursday. ``There is the possibility that parts of the Stasi apparatus are still functioning,'' said Joachim Gauck, head of the lawmakers' commission overseeing the breakup of the secret police. The secret police was known as the Stasi. East Germans have become obsessed with the brutal legacy of the Communist organization, and have unmasked former members and collaborators. West Germany's ARD television this week ran a documentary with interviews of East Germans complaining that former secret police members still retain a grip on the nation's factories. Almost daily, new disclosures emerge about the Stasi, which had about 200,000 members, collaborators and informers before the government said it would disband. Of the 2,448 elite Stasi officers put in top positions throughout the country by the Communists, one-half have been targeted for investigations, said Gauck, chairman of the parliamentary commission. The other half remains active, especially in the nation's businesses, he told a news conference. Gauck is a member of the leftist party Alliance 90. East German companies are attempting to break free from 40 years of centrally planned Communist administration, to be transformed into capitalist enterprises. There have been concerns that members of the old government, especially former Stasi members, could try to disrupt the economic transition with West Germany. The merger between the two Germanys is set for Wednesday. Another parliamentary commission member, Jes Moeller of the Social Democratic Party, said that former Stasi members still on the job had hindered investigations into economic crimes. ``In police offices, the Stasi officers are responsible for economic crimes and they have thrown out criminal complaints against managers of Stasi-run companies,'' Moeller said. For months East Germans have complained that the same people who were in key functions under the Communists have stayed in those posts under the democratically elected government. The mass-circulation Bild newspaper reported Thursday that the Stasi transferred about $100 million to the renamed Communist Party. Leaders of the party then distributed the money to numerous people, apparently to keep it from being seized by investigators, according to Bild.

DOC.HEAD: Here's the Museum and Don't Forget the Tip
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT to by sted buy. Also moved for PMs
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CX7
DOC.TEXT: The Art Institute of Chicago hopes a free breakfast will go a long way toward steering visitors in its direction. The museum treated about 100 taxi drivers to Danish pastry, juice, coffee and a tour Wednesday in the hope that the steering-wheel philosophers will talk up the place to their fares. ``Chicago taxi drivers really are roving ambassadors,'' museum spokeswoman Eileen Harakal said. ``Not only do they answer passengers' questions on Chicago's attractions, but they help steer people to them.'' The Art Institute's current special exhibit, ``From Poussin to Matisse: The Russian Taste For French Painting,'' is sponsored by Sara Lee Corp., which provided the breakfast to cabbies and chauffeurs. The museum waived the exhibit's $6 entry fee and opened the show an hour early for the drivers. ``It's a great idea,'' said cab driver Bill Hogan as he contemplated Henri Matisse's ``Still Life with a Blue Tablecloth.'' ``When people ask what there is to see in Chicago I usually say the Sears Tower, the Museum of Science and Industry and the Shedd Aquarium. Now I'll mention the Art Institute.'' Talk of taxi lease increases and rising gas prices intermingled with conversation about French art as the cabbies strolled past the exhibit's 51 paintings. ``Cab drivers bring the Art Institute quite a bit of business,'' said cabbie Charles Thomatis. ``I always tell passengers how nice it is. Now I've got the chance to come in and take a peek for myself.'' Enjoyment of the paintings seemed to override worries about missed fares for some drivers. ``You've got to take a little time out for yourself,'' said cabbie Bill Davis. ``Drivers spend 10-12 hours sitting behind the wheel of a cab. So this is fantastic. It's one of the best things people have done for us.'' Not all taxi drivers were impressed. ``If they really wanted to thank us they would've served breakfast at the curb,'' John Martins said. ``They could have let us roll by, pick up our coffee and doughnuts and go back to work.''

DOC.HEAD: Deposit Insurance Fund Dwindling; Regulators Boost Rates
LaserPhoto WX24
DOC.TEXT: Regulators learned Thursday the government fund protecting bank accounts is dwindling faster than thought only two months ago, and they voted a 1991 increase of more than 60 percent on the deposit insurance premiums charged banks. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.'s bank fund dropped from $13.2 billion at the end of last year to $11.4 billion at the end of June - a 14 percent decline. FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman said he now expects that by the end of the year the fund will have lost ``closer to $3 billion'' rather than the $2 billion he earlier predicted. ``This ... is the result of an increased number of institutions being likely to fail and continued erosion in real estate markets,'' Seidman told members of a House panel in a meeting which followed the FDIC vote to boost premiums. If continuing bank failures were to exhaust the insurance fund, Congress and the Bush administration would have to consider a taxpayer bailout, as they have with the S&L insurance fund. After receiving the new financial report, the five-member FDIC board raised the insurance premium charged banks by more than 60 percent. Banks in 1991 will pay 19.5 cents for every $100 in deposits, up from 12 cents this year and 8.3 cents last year. The higher rate will raise the fund's premium income from $2.8 billion in 1990 to $4.8 billion in 1991. Under last year's S&L bailout law, the premium had been scheduled to rise to 15 cents. Regulators began considering an added emergency increase after Seidman told senators in July that the bank fund likely would suffer its third consecutive loss. In mid-August they proposed the maximum increase allowed by law, to 19.5 cents. By comparison, savings institutions pay a 23-cent premium. The bank fund's $1.84 billion loss in the first six months of 1990 has reduced the level of reserves in the fund to only 60 cents for every $100 of insured deposits. The minimum considered safe is $1.25 per $100. At the end of 1987, the level was $1.10. Sixty cents is the lowest point in the fund's history and the congressional General Accounting Office has warned that if the economy dips into a recession, the fund could be wiped out. Banks have a variety of options for absorbing higher premiums including charging savers higher fees and paying them less interest, charging borrowers more for loans, reducing dividends to stockholders or cutting payroll and other expenses. ``Undoubtedly some part of it will be passed along (to bank customers), but certainly all of it won't be passed along,'' Seidman told the House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions. The agency's staff calculated that if all of the difference between the 19.5-cent assessment and the previously scheduled 15-cent assessment were passed to depositors, the annual return on a $10,000 deposit would decline by $4.50. If the 19.5-cent rate had been in effect last year instead of the 8.3-cent rate and banks absorbed all of it, 69 additional banks would have recorded losses instead of a profit and four more banks would have failed. Administration-backed legislation that passed the House last week and is pending in the Senate would give the FDIC power to raise premiums as high as it decided was necessary. If the legislation passes before Congress adjourns next month, Seidman said his board would consider further premium increases. With a 19.5-cent premium, the fund would not reach the minimum safe level until after 1995, he told the House panel. However, he warned that at some point forcing banks to pay more becomes counterproductive by weakening the industry. Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., has proposed assessing banks a one-time charge of $1 for every $100 in deposits, raising $25 billion for the insurance fund. They would be expected to replenish the money as it is spent. That, Seidman warned, could drive 28 banks into insolvency and push 241 banks below minimum capital requirement. Rep. Jim Leach, R-Iowa, said regulators should force banks to raise more capital from investors or retain earnings as a buffer against losses. Regulators should threaten to remove senior bank management unless they raise capital, he said. ``One has to be a logical nincompoop to think that more premiums are a preferable route. More premiums make the system weaker. More capital makes the system stronger,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former President Returns from Exile, Hails Iraqi Cause
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ahmed Ben Bella, Algeria's independence leader and first president, ended a decade of exile Thursday, deman you up as volunteers.'' Ben Bella, who recently flew to Iraq for talks with Saddam, urged supporters to stage a protest at the U.S. Embassy denouncing the American military deployment in the Persian Gulf. It was Ben Bella's first time back in Algeria since he voluntarily went into exile in Europe in 1981 following 15 years in prison. He became Algeria's first president in 1962 after the eight-year independence war against France, but was overthrown in a military coup led by Army chief Col. Houari Boumedienne in 1965 and imprisoned. A throng of people massed along a seaside boulevard, chanting Ben Bella's name, as the car ferry Hoggar arrived from Barcelona. Other boats in the harbor blared horns and sirens in welcome. Ben Bella said he hoped to forge a new political coalition that would defeat the long-ruling National Liberation Front, to which he once belonged. Legislative elections are scheduled by the end of March, but Ben Bella said the government should resign immediately. ``The government has no more credibility, and thus cannot prepare for the next elections,'' he said. In his rambling address in French and Arabic, Ben Bella hailed radical Arab leaders and their causes. ``Long live Palestine!'' he cried. ``Long live Iraq! Long live Saddam! Long live Libya! Long live Moammar Gadhafi!'' Ben Bella returns home as Islamic fundamentalists stand poised to win legislative elections in six months. With or without them, Ben Bella hopes to forge an alliance of opposition parties. The former president had disappointed partisans by not returning for local and regional elections June 12, Algeria's first multiparty balloting since 1962. He had urged a boycott of those elections, claiming they would be rigged by the ruling National Liberation Front. The fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front swept a majority of local and regional councils in the vote, becoming the country's dominant political group.

DOC.HEAD: Corn Inventory Down 30 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The nation's inventory of corn as of Sept. 1, the beginning of the new crop marketing year was more than 1.34 billion bushels, down 30 percent from a year ago, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Despite the drop from the year-earlier level, the estimated Sept. 1 corn inventory was slightly more than the 1.33 billion bushels USDA had projected Sept. 12. Of the total stockpile, 755 million bushels were stored on farms, down 22 percent from a year earlier, according to the quarterly report. The off-farm stocks of 590 million bushels were down 39 percent. Soybean inventories, reported at 239.1 million bushels, were up 31 percent from a year earlier. On-farm stocks, at 86 million bushels, were 2 percent below Sept. 1, 1989. The off-farm supply of 153 million bushels was up 62 percent. All wheat was reported at 2.4 billion bushels, up 25 percent from a year earlier. On-farm inventories of 995 million bushels were up 20 percent, while the off-farm stocks of 1.41 billion bushels were up 30 percent. Barley stored in all positions on Sept. 1 were reported at 411 million bushels, down 1 percent from a year ago. Farm-stored inventories totaled 258 million bushels, up 2 percent. The off-farm stockpile was 152 million bushels, down 7 percent. Sorghum holdings on Sept. 1 were estimated at less than 220 million bushels, down 50 percent from a year ago. Those included 30.3 million bushels on farms, down 37 percent, and 189.5 million bushels off farms, down 52 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Science Foundation Funds Reforms
DOC.TEXT: The National Science Foundation is awarding $8.6 million in grants to encourage middle schools and high schools to begin making sweeping changes in the way science is taught, officials said Thursday. The grants represent the foundation's largest single effort to reform pre-college science education since the Sputnik era of the 1950s, said Luther Williams, assistant director for education and human resources. The project wants to update teaching methods, increase the time students spend on science and strengthen teacher training. Six three-year grants were awarded from 12 proposals. The National Science Teachers Association, the overall coordinator of the project, received $1.5 million; Baylor College of Medicine, $1.3 million; the California Department of Education, $1.4 million; the University of Iowa, $1.4 million; the University of North Carolina at Wilmington, $1.5 million; and the University of Puerto Rico, $1.4 million. The Education Department funded $1.6 million of the earlier stages of the project. The grant recipients will develop programs that will be tested in schools. Current science education follows a pattern in grades seven through nine - life science in grade seven, earth science in grade eight, and another year of science in grade nine, either life science or physical science, said William Aldridge, executive director of the science teachers group. Aldridge said that high school sciences follow a ``rigid layer cake approach'' that teaches facts and terminology without relating the information to the students' daily lives. Using the grants, new science curriculum materials will be tested in regional middle and high schools. National curriculum materials based on the regional materials then will be developed and distributed by the science teachers association. Aldridge said course content would be coordinated and subjects offered over three or four years instead of just one year, which would lead to a more integrated high school science education. The California Department of Education is coordinating the reform efforts of 214 high school and junior or middle schools across the state, said Tom Sachse of the California education department. A key focus will be on teacher training, he said. The University of Puerto Rico plans to develop techniques to integrate mathematics with the sciences in grades seven through nine. It also will produce materials in Spanish. The grants were awarded under the foundation's Science and Math Education Network's Scope, Sequence, and Coordination program.

DOC.HEAD: Finale of Canada's Indian Standoff Does Not Mean End to Problems
DOC.TEXT: The 78-day standoff between Mohawks and authorities in Quebec left ill feelings that may not quickly fade, but one positive offshoot was that it focused attention on the plight of Canada's native tribes, experts said Thursday. After the surrender of the last Mohawk holdouts on Wednesday, federal and provincial governments were congratulating themselves for avoiding major violence, and creating a new program designed to be more sensitive to Indians. Meanwhile, Indians and other observers warn it won't take much for similar situations to erupt again. ``The Indians are starting to say that we've come down to the wire and we are going to hold the white man to his word,'' said Bruce Clark, a London, Ontario, lawyer who has studied historical documents relating to Indian relations with the government. ``The white man talks about the rule of law as his great gift, let's see if we can hold him to it,'' he said. Georges Erasmus, grand chief of the Assembly of First Nations, the national grouping of Canadian Indian bands, said ``there is a tremendous onus now on the Canadian government and the Quebec government.'' About 50 Mohawks, including women and children, surrendered Wednesday after being camped for nearly a month inside a drug and alcohol treatment center in Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal. They were taken to a nearby military base. The withdrawal ended a conflict that began July 11 over plans by Oka officials to expand a golf course onto land claimed by Indians. Dozens of people were injured and one Quebec police office was killed in clashes. The golf course issue was settled early on when the federal government bought the disputed land and said it would turn it over to the Mohawks. But blockades set up at Oka and Kanawake, south of Montreal, were joined by sympathy blockades by Indian bands across the country. Most observers feel it was the public pressure and the continuing negative image of Canadian officials that finally pushed Prime Minister Brian Mulroney on Tuesday to announce his new program for dealing with natives. He said the program would cover four points: ``land claims; the economic and social conditions on reserves; the relationship between aboriginal peoples and governments, and concerns of Canada's aboriginal peoples in contemporary Canadian life.'' ``Canada's aboriginal peoples deserve a special place in this country as our first citizens, based on the aboriginal and treaty rights recognized in the constitution,'' the prime minister said. But he added: ``I will be very clear on this point: native self-government does not now and cannot ever mean sovereign independence. Mohawk lands are a part of Canadian territory, and Canadian law must and does apply.'' That issue of law and jurisdiction are major issues between the government and many of the country's native bands. ``The situation is, we do not have ordinary Canadians here,'' Erasmus said, referring to the Oka crisis. ``We have Mohawk people that have been here for tens of thousands of years. They have not ever voluntarily entered into a treaty that has extinguished their rights. ``What is necessary is an understanding of how aboriginal rights, treaty rights, mesh with the civilian code in Quebec and with Canadian law.'' There are about 450,000 ``status,'' or registered, Indians in Canada and 33,000 Inuit, often called Eskimos. These native people make up 593 bands on 2,234 reserves covering 6.4 million acres. For many reserve Indians, life is a continuous struggle against poverty, alcoholism, poor health services. They also face lack of plumbing, sewage disposal and drinking water. Death by injury or poisoning is quadruple that for the rest of Canada; life expectancy is nine years less than for a white Canadian. Natives in general have a deep well of sympathy among white Canadians, but the Indian struggles take place mostly in obscure camps and reserves far from the general population. Taking up arms ``can't help but come up again,'' said attorney Clark. ``There are two solutions. One is the rule of law. The other is self-help. We are at the point now where Indians are tired of talking. Will violence happen again? It's almost a certainty that it will.'' Clark quotes from a royal proclamation of 1763 that guarantees the right of Indians to self-government. He says that was reaffirmed in the 1982 constitution. ``Canadian history from that point took a very different road from that of the United States. From that point, the Indians in Canada laid down their arms. There was no Indian warfare. ``Either Canada will honor its own constitutional law, or it will have to change its constitutional law.'' The natives say they have taken the government at its word, that it will enter into serious negotiations with the Indians now that the Mohawks at Oka have laid down their arms. ``The end of the standoff is just the first step,'' said Ethel Blondin, an Indian member of the House of Commons. ``The government must cough up what it appeared to promise. ``The only way that's going to work ... is to move quickly.''

DOC.HEAD: Britain, Iran Restore Diplomatic Relations; Key Issues Unresolved
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 9th pvs, `Hurd also...' to UPDATE with U.S. reaction. Pickup 10th pvs, `The Iranian...'
DOC.TEXT: Iran and Britain announced Thursday that they have restored relations, the latest of several diplomatic successes for Iran since neighboring Iraq threatened the Persian Gulf with its invasion of Kuwait. London and Tehran had severed diplomatic ties following Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's call in February 1989 to kill British author Salman Rushdie, whose novel ``The Satanic Verses'' infuriated Moslems worldwide. The restoration raised modest hopes of freedom for British hostages held by pro-Iranian extremists in Lebanon, but left unresolved the dispute over Rushdie, who has been in hiding since Khomeini's death call. The announcement at the United Nations - by British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and in a statement from Iran's U.N. Mission - said the embassies would reopen in London and Tehran within a month. Hurd retreated into heavy diplomatic parlance when asked about Rushdie. ``It is our understanding from public statements made by Iranian officials that the Iranian government respects the law and would not interfere in the internal affairs of any other country - anymore than the United Kingdom would.'' That was taken as an assurance that Iran would not try to send assassins after Rushdie, who is believed to still be in Britain. Hurd said the other outstanding issues between the two countries, including the British hostages held in Lebanon by Islamic fundamentalists loyal to Iran's Shiite revolution, are better discussed at the full diplomatic level. Hurd also praised Iran for voting for U.N. embargoes against Iraq despite improving relations between Iran and its former emeny. In Washington, the State Department said it had no comment on British-Iranian announcement. ``That's between them,'' department spokesman Richard Boucher said. The Iranian statement gave no the reason for the restoration of relations, saying only that it was based on ``mutual respect.'' In the past six weeks, Iran has gained land, peace, money and some respect, benefiting at least in part from the changing alignment of the Middle East following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Iraq, facing a U.S.-led multinational force in Saudi Arabia and the gulf, caved into Iranian demands to seek a formal end to the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. The two sides exchanged prisoners of war, freed hundreds of thousands of troops from their border and agreed this month to resume diplomatic relations. Iraq also withdrew from Iranian territory occupied during the war and agreed to share sovereignty over a disputed waterway. Western nations, meanwhile, have sought closer relations with Iran, whose more than 700-mile border with Iraq makes Iranian support critical to U.N. trade sanctions on Iraq. Iran has said it will honor the trade embargo. On Sept. 21, the United States paid a $200 milliion claim for undelivered American equipment orders dating from before the 1979 Islamic revolution. It was the largest claim before a tribunal settling billions in Iranian assets frozen by the United States. Iran has recently been less hostile to the West, and Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani is seeking Western ties and aid to rebuild Iran following the war. In February 1989, Khomeini issued the death threat against Rushdie, saying his novel blasphemed Islam. Iranian officials did not terminate the threat when Khomeini died in June 1989. They had demanded that Britain condemn the book as a condition to restoring relations. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government did not do so, but it acknowledged that parts of ``The Satanic Verses'' might be considered insulting to Moslems. Rushdie, who was born in India, is a British citizen. The resumption of relations raised hopes Tehran might now work for securing the release of the British hostages held in Lebanon. The resumption of ties also raised speculation that Roger Cooper, a British businessman imprisoned in Iran since 1985 on espionage charges, may be freed. Iranian authorities have said Cooper, 54, has been tried and convicted, but the sentence has never been made public. British officials had cited Cooper's ordeal and that of the hostages in Lebanon as major obstacles in resumption of London-Tehran ties. There have been increasing signs from Tehran that it is searching for an end to the hostage issue. It admitted in April that it helped free two Americans, Frank Reed and Robert Polhill, and President Bush's administration publicly thanked Iran. Last month, Tehran also was said to have played a major role in securing the release of Irishman Brian Keenan, a native of Belfast who also carried a British passport. The four British hostages are among the 13 Westerners believed held, most by captors loyal to Iran. They are Church of England envoy Terry Waite, retired fighter pilot Jack Mann, and journalists John McCarthy and Alec Collett.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Limits Birth Mother's Visits in Custody Battle Over Test-Tube Baby
DOC.TEXT: A surrogate mother who gave birth to a baby created by another couple's sperm and egg was limited Thursday to two visits a week with the child, who is living for the time being with his genetic parents. Superior Court Judge Richard Parslow cut birth mother Anna Johnson's daily visits to twice a week after hearing testimony from the infant's court-appointed guardian, William Steiner, that tension between Ms. Johnson and the genetic parents was detrimental to the baby. Parslow also followed Steiner's recommendation that the baby remain in the custody of genetic parents Mark and Crispina Calvert at least until a parental rights hearing Oct. 9. ``I think it would be in the best interest of the child to remain with the Calverts,'' Steiner said. Ms. Johnson, 29, sued last August for custody of the child. Attorneys in the case have called it unprecedented because Ms. Johnson is seeking custody of a child to whom she has no genetic link. In the much-publicized Baby M case in New Jersey, the surrogate mother was also the baby's genetic mother. Ms. Johnson, who worked with Mrs. Calvert at a Santa Ana hospital, was hired by the couple for $10,000 to bear their test-tube baby. Mrs. Calvert, 36, was medically unable to carry a child, although she could produce ova. The surrogate sued for custody, child support and damages on Aug. 13, alleging the couple failed to provide agreed-upon financial and emotional support after supposedly losing interest in the pregnancy. Attorney Richard Gilbert, representing Ms. Johnson, argued Thursday that his client should be allowed to continue seeing the child each day. Ms. Johnson did not attend the hearing. Gilbert maintains the baby belongs with Ms. Johnson because she was the birth mother. The Calverts are seeking custody because it was the embryo from their egg and sperm that was implanted in Ms. Johnson. The baby, born Sept. 19, was discharged from St. Joseph Hospital in Orange on Saturday and given to the Calverts. Technically, the baby is still unnamed, but Ms. Johnson calls him Matthew and the Calverts call him Michael Christopher. Last Friday, Parslow awarded temporary custody of the baby to the Calverts. The judge was going to send the baby to a foster home because attorneys for the couple and the surrogate were unable to agree on interim custody. But Ms. Johnson rejected the foster home idea.

DOC.HEAD: KKK Endorses Hunt in Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Guy Hunt's re-election bid has picked up the endorsement of the Alabama Empire of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, but he said the organization's backing does not mean he supports the group. Steve Stone, grand dragon of the white supremacist group, said the KKK was backing the Republican Hunt, but ``not because he is a good old boy.'' ``As the political system has evolved in the last decade or so, we've got very few choices to really endorse,'' said Stone. Hunt said earlier this week that he was unaware of the Klan endorsement, which was announced over the weekend. ``People have to accept me for what I am,'' he said. ``An endorsement from someone doesn't mean I accept them. It means they're accepting me, but I haven't heard anything about it.'' Michael Tucker, a spokesman for Democratic gubernatorial nominee Paul Hubbert, said he could ``never envision'' the Klan backing Hubbert.
DOC.HEAD: Dems Say Thompson Uses `Scum Money' to Defend Tax Position
DOC.TEXT: Democratic leaders Thursday accused Republican Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of accepting ``scum money'' from race track interests to buy campaign ads defending his record as governor. Jeffrey Neubauer, chairman of the Democratic Party of Wisconsin, said he was referring to the more than $280,000 the Thompson campaign is reported to have received from investors in Wisconsin dog tracks. ``He sold his soul to raise historic amounts of scum money,'' said Neubauer. ``You can buy a lot of deception with scum money.'' The chairman and Democratic Assembly leaders held a Capitol news conference to blast Thompson's campaign ads, particularly one that accused the Legislature of blocking property tax relief proposals. ``The governor's trying to redirect the blame'' for the lack of property tax relief, Neubauer said. ``He's attempting to do it with money that was raised in an unethical fashion.'' Neither Thompson nor his campaign director, Scott Jensen, was immediately available for comment.
DOC.HEAD: Levin Shows Big Lead, Blanchard Also Ahead
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Carl Levin has a substantial lead over U.S. Rep. Bill Schuette, while Gov. James Blanchard has stretched his margin over state Sen. John Engler, a new poll shows. Democrat Levin was favored by 63 percent of 800 registered voters in the Senate race, says the poll, conducted by Market Opinion Research for the Detroit Free Press and television stations WDIV and WXYZ. Schuette was favored by 27 percent, with 5 percent undecided. The telephone poll conducted Sept. 21-23 has a margin of error of 3.5 percentage points. The poll also showed Democrat Blanchard with an advantage over Engler in the gubernatorial campaign, 55 percent to 35 percent, with 5 percent undecided. In August, a similar poll showed Blanchard with a 13-point lead.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say Only Insider Could Topple Saddam
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's security shield is so thick and mobile that the only way he'll be toppled is if one of his intimate advisers turns against him, U.S. officials said Thursday. Based on reports from Iraq, the officials said they've concluded that Saddam remains in Baghdad but moves around frequently from his various palaces in the capital. The officials spoke on condition they remain anonymous. ``He is moving around a lot,'' one official said. Saddam's houses are ``well-defended and structurally strong'' and he is taken from place to place usually in a heavily secured convoy. Saddam's whereabouts and his habits have been somewhat of a mystery since he ordered his troops to invade Kuwait on Aug. 2. Before the invasion, Saddam was a visible leader, making frequent public appearances at mosques and schools. But he has been in virtual seclusion since the invasion, apparently because he fears for his safety. His pronouncements are usually by his spokesman on television. ``Saddam is alive, well and breathing,'' said an official. Various visitors have seen him recently, including the Mooccan foreign minister and Palestinian officials. But Saddam, who has been the target of 11 assassination attempts in the last 13 years, apparently only deals face-to-face with a handful of close advisers. Among them are Taha Yasin Ramadan, the first deputy prime minister, and Latif Nasuayyif Jasim, the minister of culture and information. Were Saddam to be assassinated, the plotters ``would have to be senior enough to get through the security,'' the official said. ``It would have to happen very fast. ... They would have to go directly to Saddam.'' But the officials said the top advisers ``keep each other in sight'' to ensure none of them disappears. ``They know if one is missing what that means,'' the official said. Saddam has a history of ruthlessness; he once shot to death a health minister who disagreed with him. ``He doesn't allow a whiff of opposition,'' an official said. Saddam's security apparatus is awesome. It is comprised of various forces, many of them controlled by Saddam's relatives. He also has the elite Revolutionary Guards numbering about 100,000. The officials said they believe Saddam's conspiratorial tendencies have been heightened by the gulf crisis. ``He is obviously spending a lot of time thinking about his security,'' one official said. At the same time, government officials are unsure how Saddam is filtering information he receives from the West. Their assessment is that he's prepared ``for what he sees as an inevitable battle'' over Kuwait but is unwilling to provoke war. Despite the hardships he has inflicted on his country, internal opposition to Saddam remains limited, the officials said. Dissidents either don't exist or they have been silenced through death or exile. The Kurds, a mountain people who seek independence from Iraq, were brought to heel when the Iraqis resettled thousands of them in a desert area and used chemical gas against others. There have been unconfirmed reports U.S. intelligence is helping the Kurds. But U.S. officials said any anti-Saddam sentiment had been hushed. ``We don't see any signs of dissidents,'' said an official. The officials also cautioned against underestimating Saddam's appeal to his people. ``He is not unpopular,'' said the official, noting that the Iraqi president has managed to improve his people's standard of living, feed them and instill in them a sense of national pride. ``He is not a Ceausescu,'' the official said, referring to Nicolae Ceausescu, the Romanian president who was executed in December after being toppled.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Slain as Police End Seven-Hour Standoff
LaserPhotos FX2,3,4,6,7,8,12, LaserColors FX5,10
DOC.TEXT: A ``deranged'' Iranian gunman with a hatred of blond Americans died in a burst of police bullets Thursday, seven hours after he stormed a bar, killed one man, wounded seven people and took 33 hostages. Six officers stormed Henry's Publick House and Grille in the Durant Hotel after police negotiators decided they couldn't talk the gunman out of the bar, said Lt. Jim Polk. ``We decided there was no other way,'' said Polk. He said the gunman, identified by University of California, Berkeley, spokesman Ray Colvig as Mehrdad Dashti, gave away his position inside the bar by using one of the terrorized hostages as an intermediary in talking to police by telephone. ``Every time the hostage would have to ask a question of this bad guy, he would have to turn around and look at him and this gave us a good idea of where he was,'' said Polk. Seconds after the burst of police gunfire around 7:20 a.m., hostages, some of whom had been forced to sit in the windows of the bar as shields, ran from the hotel. Dashti, 30, a native of Iran, was naked and bleeding when he was loaded into an ambulance and taken to Highland Hospital.
