He was dead on arrival, according to hospital spokeswomen Phyllis Brown. ``He was apparently very confused,'' said Berkeley Police Capt. Phil Doran. ``Deranged is not a bad description.'' ``For some reason, he had something against blonds, Caucasian women and blond-haired, blue-eyed men,'' said Douglas Moore, 25, a UC student and manager of the bar who was one of the hostages. ``He had something against Americans.'' ``He accused the women of showing too much leg,'' Moore said. ``He accused them of wearing tight skirts, short skirts ... ``He said it was that kind of trash that was leading guys like him on and that they deserved to be punished. ... He did a pretty good job of degrading the women.'' Mayor Loni Hancock said women hostages were sexually abused, but wouldn't give details. Moore, however, said no one was sexually abused. Moore said Dashti claimed the ``government owed him $16 trillion for mental telepathy work and this was his way of getting it back.'' San Francisco Police Sgt. Jerry Senkir said Dashti was named in a warrant charging grand theft in connection with cashing two stolen checks worth more than $16,000. He said Dashti had been advised of the charges and police expected him to turn himself in. One of Dashti's demands was that San Francisco Police Chief Frank Jordan appear live on television and ``drop his drawers,'' according to Doran. Doran said one of Dashti's complaints was that ``he didn't get a student loan.'' The English pub-style bar, a popular student hangout one block from the UC campus, was crowded when the gunman rushed inside, witnesses said. Several escaped soon after the standoff began, police said. Dashti shot six people after entering, said Doran. Police reported another two people were shot during another round of gunfire about three hours later. Moore said John Sheehy, 22, of Lafayette, was shot in the chest at close range early in the incident. Sheehy, a UC student, died during surgery, said Thomas McGarry, a spokesman at Eden Hospital in Castro Valley. Witnesses said the shooting was punctuated by the gunman screaming, ``When is it going to end? How long? How long?'' Frederick Smith, 19, a UC junior from Los Angeles and Dashti's roommate for a month, said Dashti grew up in Iran and moved to this country about eight years ago. He said Dashti was a gun collector and had given Smith shooting lessons. Smith said Dashti told him Wednesday that Smith would have to move out because Dashti was flying to Hawaii to meet a woman his parents had arranged for him to marry. Smith said Dashti had earned an engineering degree from San Francisco State University but couldn't find a job. The apartment they shared was cluttered with family photographs, ammunition, drab furniture and bookshelves crowded with books. One document found in the apartment, a form from the Alameda County Department of Health Services, described him as a paranoid schizophrenic. Two of the wounded were in guarded condition with multiple bullet wounds, two were being treated for leg wounds, and three were treated and released, hospital officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Bows to Key Student Demand, but Protest Continues at UDC
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, bowing to a chief demand of students occupying two buildings at the University of the District of Columbia, said Thursday he will ask 10 of the school's 15 trustees to resign. However, the mayor added that he is powerless to force anyone on the trustee board to quit. ``We had a good dialogue, a good session,'' the mayor said after emerging from a 4{-hour meeting with students who have occupied the two buildings at the city-run university. ``I told them I'd give it my best shot.'' The 200 students continued their protest, meanwhile, with another meeting with Barry planned for Friday. ``We had a very productive meeting with Mayor Barry,'' said Aisha Murray, a protest leader. ``We are searching for quality education.'' The demonstrators are seeking a number of changes at the school, including a restructured board. Chairwoman Nira Long is among those whose resignation they have demanded. The school's faculty senate, which has disagreed with the school's administration on a number of issues in recent years, backed the students - who also want an improved athletic program, compliance with education standards set by a regional accreditation board, and an increased emphasis on an AfricanAAmerican curriculum. ``The faculty leadership is in general supportive of the demands made by the students,'' said Prof. Emanuel Chatman in a letter signed by other faculty senate members. ``Over the past several years, the board of trustees of the University of the District of Columbia have often acted in a manner contrary to the best interests of the university.'' Under city law, trustees are approved by the city council but cannot be forced to resign. The positions are not salaried, but board members are paid on a per-diem basis and reimbursed for expenses. They cannot collect more than $4,000 per year. University officials canceled classes on Thursday, but gave no word on whether instruction would resume Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Precede: WASHINGTON
Navy Finds Part of Cargo Door From United Plane
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout
DOC.TEXT: A Navy submarine recovered part of the cargo door that broke away from a United jetliner over the Pacific last year, sweeping nine people to their death, authorities said Thursday. The crew of a deep-sea submarine retrieved the lower half of the hatch from the ocean floor and located what is believed to be the door's upper half, a Navy spokeswoman said. United Airlines Flight 811 had just taken off from Honolulu International Airport when the door and a large chunk of fuselage tore away at 22,000 feet. The piece was found late Wednesday in 14,100 feet of water 90 miles south-southwest of here, said Lt. Cmdr. Sandy Stairs, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Pacific Fleet. The 31-foot submarine Sea Cliff videotaped the 6-by-10-foot piece on the ocean floor and brought it to the surface with its hydraulic jaws, Stairs said. It was brought onto the deck of the Navy vessel the Laney Choust at about midnight Wednesday. During the 18-hour dive Wednesday, the submarine's three-man crew believed it also found the upper half of the cargo door about 200 yards away from where the lower half was found. Stairs said the submarine planned to dive again Thursday night to examine the debris, which was spotted as a strong sonar contact. The National Transportation Safety Board called for the search in hopes that examining the door will lead to better aviation safety rules. In Washington, the safety board said a preliminary examination by one of its investigators showed the door had fractured longitudinally near the midspan latch. The eight sectors of the latch lock were all in the locked position and were deformed. After investigators examine the recovered debris, parts of it will be sent to the Boeing Co. in Seattle for a more detailed review under board direction, NTSB officials said. If the submarine is able to retrieve the top half of the door, the Sea Cliff and its support ship are expected to return to Pearl Harbor late Friday or early Saturday. The jumbo jet carried 355 passengers when it took off for New Zealand on Feb. 24, 1989. Shortly after takeoff, the cargo door opened at 22,000 feet. Nine passengers were swept out of the plane and five others suffered serious injuries. The crew managed to return the jet to Honolulu. The NTSB inquiry determined that faulty design of a locking mechanism probably caused a cockpit light to falsely indicate the door was locked. The agency blamed United, Boeing and the Federal Aviation Administration for failing to correct problems with the door. Debris from the jet was located in July by a sonar-scanning sled that can spot metallic objects over wide areas. Markings on debris found on several dives indicate it is from a Boeing 747, Stairs said. She said the debris also included pieces of fuselage and window frames with ``747'' written on them.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Killed Wife 14 Years Ago Sentenced to Prison
DOC.TEXT: A man who lived as a fugitive for nearly 14 years after stabbing his wife to death and dismembering her body was sentenced Thursday to six to 18 years in prison. ``I'm sorry for the crime,'' said Fred Weldon, who had pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter. ``I'd like to pay my debt to society.'' Weldon disappeared the day after the headless, handless body of his wife, Norma, 29, was found in Harlem's Mount Morris Park on Dec. 20, 1976. Police say the woman was slain during an argument three days before. Weldon, 50, initially fled to the Central America country of Belize but returned to New York and worked for years at a print shop. Detectives arrested him there in August after checking his income tax returns, which he had filed under his own name. Weldon had also remarried and lived with his wife, Celestine, and a 10-year-old son who suffers from cerebral palsy. He was originally charged with second-degree murder and could have been sentenced to 25 years to life in prison if convicted. Assistant District Attorney Harvey Rosen said prosecutors allowed Weldon to plead guilty to manslaughter because the case had been weakened by the passage of time. He said some evidence had been lost or destroyed and some witnesses were no longer available. Weldon worried that he would never see his son again if he were convicted of the more serious charge, said his lawyer, Eugene Kaplan. ``He's a better person now,'' Kaplan said.

DOC.HEAD: Plan Would Allow Tripling of Strategic Reserve Sale
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee chairman moved Thursday to allow a tripling of President Bush's first oil sale from the government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The move came after Energy Secretary James Watkins said the planned 5-million-barrel sale would have no significant effect on gasoline prices. Bush ordered the test sale Wednesday, with his spokesman saying it was intended in part as a ``signal'' to quell speculation in the oil markets and halt skyrocketing crude prices. On Thursday, however, prices shot up briefly to above $40 a barrel for the first time on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Watkins, meanwhile, told the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on energy and power that the administration ``has no expectation that it (the sale) is going to have any significant long-term market impact.'' ``But we're not going into this test with the idea that it's going to bring the cost down $8 a barrel or something,'' he said. ``That's not the purpose. If Saddam Hussein makes another threat, the market could jump again regardless of the test sale.'' Watkins told the panel the 5 million barrel test sale, which was authorized by Congress two weeks ago, was too small to indicate how the government's 590-million-barrel stockpile might fit into the world oil market if Bush should decide to order an actual emergency drawdown. ``This is not a drawdown,'' he emphasized, adding that the test will ``give us optimum readiness to open the spigot if that is required in the future.'' Recalling that the administration just two weeks ago threatened to veto a larger test sale, Rep. Phil Sharp, D-Ind. and the subcommittee chairman, asked Watkins how large a test he would like. ``Three times the (5 million) number is the number,'' Watkins replied. ``We welcome the change,'' said Sharp, who had his staff draft a bill authorizing a new test sale of 15 million barrels and gather the signatures of several other committee members on it while Watkins was testifying. Anticipating no opposition in the Senate, Sharp said the bill could be on Bush's desk for his signature in two week. Bid notices on the 5 million barrel test will be sent out Friday; the Energy Department expects to award sale contracts in mid-October. Bob Porter, a department spokesman, said an average of 167,000 barrels of oil - far short of the 500,000 barrels that analysts say is needed to drive prices down - will be released daily for 30 days. Lawmakers including Senate GOP Leader Bob Dole of Kansas urged Bush for more than a month to tap the reserve to stem the runup in oil prices since Iraq's takeover of Kuwait Aug. 2 and the subsequent embargo removing about 4.3 million barrels daily from the world market. Watkins said Thursday that ``U.S. crude stocks are above normal as of the moment, but they could go below normal by the end of October. ``We are concerned about the ability of refiners to continue operating as they have been at near-maximum capacity. With our system so fully utilized, we are more vulnerable to accidents, transportation problems or bad weather.'' The U.S. stockpile, stored in salt caverns along the Louisiana-Texas coast, is capable of pumping up to 3.5 million barrels a day. The White House, meanwhile, shrugged off the fact that oil prices rose Thursday. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, with Bush in Cleveland for a Republican fund-raising speech, said driving down world oil prices was not Bush's purpose for taking the action. ``In the president's mind, it was the unfairness issue,'' Fitzwater said. On Wednesday, the spokesman said he expected lower prices would be one effect of the president's action. He would not repeat that characterization Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian, Soviet Officials to Discuss Independence
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov and Lithuanian officials have agreed to meet next week for long-awaited talks on the Baltic republic's drive for independence, news agencies reported Thursday. Both sides declined to term Tuesday's meeting at the Kremlin ``negotiations'' or ``consultations,'' the official news agency Tass and Baltic news organizations said. Lithuania announced its independence March 11, but agreed to suspend the declaration in exchange for the lifting of an oil and natural gas embargo imposed by President Mikhail Gorbachev in May. Lithuanian officials also called for negotiations with the national government. Talks between officials of another breakaway Baltic state, Estonia, and the Soviet parliament were suspended Sept. 6 after the Soviet side announced it had no authority to engage in ``negotiations.'' Agreement on the Lithuania meeting came Thursday in a phone conversation between Ryzhkov and Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, the Estonian News Service and Lithuanian news agency Elta reported. Ms. Prunskiene and other Lithuanian officials had earlier accused the Kremlin of stalling on talks. Lithuania's eight-member delegation to the meeting will be led by its president, Vytautas Landsbergis. Ryzhkov is to head the Soviet team. Lithuania, Estonia and the third Baltic republic, Latvia, are refusing to take part in negotiations with Soviet officials on a new union treaty. Gorbachev met Thursday with Latvian Prime Minister Ivars Godmanis and stated that ``the people of Latvia should themselves choose between two ways of developing relations with the Soviet Union - the Latvian republic as a member of a union of sovereign states, or the Latvian republic as an independent state outside the Soviet Union,'' Tass reported. Gorbachev sugggested Latvians hold a referendum on the issue, said Tass, citing Latvian government officials. Tass also reported Thursday that the Soviet prosecutor's office declared illegal a decision by Latvia's parliament to appoint and control its own prosecutor and deputies. The Soviet prosecutor's office said its appointees will continue to work in Latvia.

DOC.HEAD: Infertility Clinics Back Off Success Claims Under FTC Pressure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Officials of... for comment,' with comment from clinic operator
DOC.TEXT: Two infertility clinics charged by the Federal Trade Commission with misrepresenting success rates have agreed not to make such claims in the future, the FTC announced Thursday. One of the clinics, IVF Australia, one of the largest providers of fertility services in the United States, said its claims were not inaccurate but may have been hard to understand. ``We have always provided the public with accurate information,'' said Vicki Baldwin, a founding director of the firm, in a news release issued from its headquarters in Greenwich, Conn. ``We do agree that some prospective patients may have found our success rate reports difficult to interpret,'' Ms. Baldwin said. ``Thus, in cooperation with the Federal Trade Commission, we have revised our materials to improve clarity.'' The cases involve in vitro fertilization (IVF) services, in which the sperm and the egg are joined together in the laboratory instead of naturally in the womb of the mother. IVF Australia offers medical services at United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y., Waltham Weston Hospital and Medical Center in Waltham, Mass., and at a clinic in Mineola, N.Y. The other clinic involved is the West Boca Medical Center in Boca Raton, Fla. Sid Tyler, executive vice president of NME Hospital Group in Santa Monica, Calif., operator of the Florida clinic, said, ``We don't agree completely with the FTC on this, but nonetheless we have agreed with the consent order and we are certainly going to comply with the request that they have made that any statistical comparisons or statistical claims that we make ...are done comparably to similar national data so that we are talking about apples and apples.'' The FTC invited public comment on the consent agreements with the clinics and noted that the allegations do not concern the quality of the services provided. ``These two cases will provide important guidance to a growing industry about the support necessary to make valid success rate claims,'' Gloria Cordes Larson, deputy director of the commission's Bureau of Consumer Protection, said. The commission said infertility affects one in six U.S. couples. IVF Australia advertised in newspapers and magazines that ``more than 28 percent of the couples who complete a cycle of treatment are becoming pregnant'' and that ``one out of three couples who complete a cycle of treatment is becoming pregnant.'' A brochure sent to prospective patients said, ``Our experience indicates that when a patient at an IVF Australia program completes four IVF treatment cycles, the chance of giving birth is about 50 percent.'' The FTC said these claims misled consumers by overstating the likelihood of achieving either a live birth or a pregnancy. It said a significant number of unsuccessful outcomes were excluded from the calculation used to determine success. The consent order requires IVF Australia to include in its calculations all patients who begin the program. The complaint against the Boca Raton clinic charges that it advertised in local newspapers and national magazines that ``four of our first 12 patients participating in our In Vitro Fertilization program have achieved pregnancy'' and that ``our success rate is an impressive 30 percent, well above the national average.'' It said these determinations were based entirely on a chemical test, which should have been subjected to confirmation by an ultrasound, or sonogram, test and was not. The commission said its order provided that in making future claims the clinic ``must use the same tests that the other success rates use.'' The agreement are open for public comment for 60 days, after which the commission will decide whether to make them final. Final consent orders do not involve admission of a law violation but carry the force of law with respect to future actions. Each violation of such an order may result in a civil penalty of up to $10,000.

DOC.HEAD: Fleeing Subway Mugger Dies on Third Rail
DOC.TEXT: A young man found electrocuted on the third rail in a subway yard is almost certainly the mugger who attacked a woman on a train and fled from a group of men who cornered him, police said Thursday. The man's name has not been established but witnesses have identified him as the mugger, Transit Police Sgt. Robert Valentino said. A wallet grabbed from the mugger Tuesday night by his temporary captors contained $22 and an identity card of Jean Carlos Pabain Perez, 22. But investigators found no trace of any such person at the address given, Valentino said. The mugging occurred on a northbound No. 6 train that had just left a station in the Bronx. The victim handed over her purse when the mugger put a knife to her face. The thief also cut her watch from her wrist and ran from the train at the Middletown Road station. His victim followed him and screamed to a group of bystanders, who grabbed the thief. They pulled off his shirt and got his wallet, but he broke free and eluded his pursuers by running into a nearby train yard. About 40 minutes later police found a shirtless man fitting the mugger's description dead against the 600-volt third rail. Neither the mugger's knife nor the woman's purse and watch has been recovered, Valentino said.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Hopes to End Investigation by Spring
DOC.TEXT: The Iran-Contra special prosecutor indicated Thursday that he may seek more indictments but expressed determination to conclude the investigation by next spring. Independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh said his office is reviewing recently obtained records of the Iran-Contra affair and questioning previously unavailable witnesses as prosecutors work to conclude the nearly four-year-old investigation. In remarks prepared for delivery Thursday in Topeka, Kan., Walsh said he would not make a decision about closing down his office until after an appeals court reviews the convictions of former national security adviser John M. Poindexter. Poindexter is appealing his six-month sentence for obstructing congressional inquiries about covert military aid to Nicaraguan rebels and the sale of arms to Iran. A decision on Poindexter's appeal of five felony convictions is not expected until spring. ``Ideally, the work of the office, except for possible appeals and the trial of any outstanding indictments - should be concluded after this decision,'' Walsh said. ``During the intervening months, our investigation should be completed,'' Walsh said in the speech at Washburn University. Walsh's remarks indicated that his original timetable for closing down the investigation had slipped at least six more months. Following Poindexter's conviction in April, Walsh said he hoped to decide by this fall on whether to conclude the investigation. Since his appointment in late 1986, Walsh has obtained eight convictions of Iran-Contra figures, including Poindexter and former White House aide Oliver L. North. In his speech, Walsh held out the possibility of more indictments from a grand jury that sources say is continuing to investigate the role of Reagan administration officials in covering up the affair. But Walsh said his efforts will be largely focused on defending the convictions of North and Poindexter in appellate courts. North's convictions were set aside in July by a federal appeals court panel that ordered a hearing to determine if references to testimony that he gave Congress under a grant of immunity seeped into his trial. Walsh is asking the appellate court to reconsider its decision. Poindexter, who also testified before Congress under a limited immunity grant, is expected to raise the same issues on his appeal of a six-month sentence for obstructing congressional inquiries and lying to lawmakers about covert military aid to the Nicaraguan Contras and the sale of arms to Iran. With the Sept. 18 tax-evasion conviction of Thomas Clines, a former CIA agent who helped broker U.S.-Iran arms sales, Walsh has no pending indictments to prepare for trial. ``All of our efforts can be devoted to pending appeals and remaining areas of investigation,'' Walsh said. ``Even at this late date, some records have only recently come into our possession.'' Walsh did not describe the records or identify previously unavailable witnesses who are now being questioned. But he appeared to be referring to North and Poindexter, who have both appeared as witnesses before the grand jury that meets periodically to take testimony. ``As court proceedings are being concluded, our remaining investigation will be completed,'' Walsh said. ``If there should be further prosecutions, they will be pressed without delay.'' The continuing expense of the investigation, which has cost more than $21 million, ``must also be considered in connection with any extension of activities.'' The prosecutor blamed delays in his investigation on the decision by Congress to force Poindexter and North to testify under immunity grants that barred prosecutors from using theirtestimony as evidence. The grants ``doubled the time taken from indictment to final disposition'' because it forced the court to try North and Poindexter separately, Walsh said.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Cocaine Cases Dismissed Because Ex-Police Chief Used Drug
DOC.TEXT: Authorities dismissed hundreds of drug cases Thursday, saying they couldn't be prosecuted because the city's former police chief stole the evidence to support his cocaine habit. ``It's basically the loss of two years' work,'' Plymouth County District Attorney William O'Malley said. ``It all goes down the drain.'' About 380 cases were dismissed in Plymouth Superior Court and District Court. ``The overwhelming majority of these cases would have resulted in convictions if it weren't for these problems,'' O'Malley said. He said some of the defendants can still be prosecuted on other charges, however. Former Police Chief Richard J. Sproules pleaded guilty in June to stealing large amounts of cash and cocaine from the police department's evidence room dating back to 1984. He also pleaded guilty to two counts of intimidating witnesses. He was ordered to serve at least two years and four months in state prison. Authorities said Sproules took about $170,000 from the evidence room, but returned $25,000 he had hidden in his cellar. Sproules, 46, said he used cocaine every day for five years after trying some of the samples he took to anti-drug lectures. The drug ``possessed me like a demon,'' Sproules said.

DOC.HEAD: Light Rain, Cooler Over Plains
DOC.TEXT: Light rain was widely scattered east of the Rockies on Thursday, and a record heat wave on the northern Plains was over. During the afternoon, rain and occasional thundershowers extended over eastern Colorado, western Kansas, southwestern and eastern Nebraska, eastern South Dakota, southern Minnesota, Iowa, west-central Wisconsin and northern Missouri, and along the lower Texas Gulf Coast, Florida, and central Maine. There were no reports of significant rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT. Temperatures over the northern half of the Plains and much of the upper Mississippi Valley were more seasonable then they have been during the past several days. But Moline, Ill., tied its record of 89. Hollywood, Fla., cooled to a record low of 65. High wind warnings were posted for Yakutat, Alaska, through Friday, with gusts expected to 75 or 80 mph. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 32 at West Yellowstone, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 52 at Truckee, Calif., to 95 at Enid, Okla.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Outlaw GOP Fund-Raising Tactic
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS grafs 6-7 and 11 pvs to UPDATE with fresh comment from GOP spokeswoman, Wendy Burnley,; delete now-outdated last graf
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Bruce Vento of the House Banking Committee introduced legislation Thursday designed to outlaw a Republican fund-raising tactic he says is deceptive. Earlier this year, the National Republican Senatorial Committee sent $25 checks to a million prospective contributors. Fine print on the back of the checks, if they are endorsed, authorizes the GOP committee to deduct $12.50 a month from recipients' checking accounts. Vento's Account Fraud and Deception Prevention Act would amend the Electronic Fund Transfer Act to ensure that the endorsement, cashing or deposit of a check cannot be used to authorize automatic withdrawals from a checking account. ``If left unchecked this new bait-and-hook gimmick will become the scam artist dream of the '90s,'' Vento, D-Minn., said in a statement. Democratic attorneys general in Alabama and Illinois have filed suit to stop the Republican committee's solicitation. Republican attorneys general in Wisconsin and Oregon and the Democratic attorney general in Minnesota have said they were investigating the tactic. Wendy Burnley, a spokeswoman for the Republic committee, had no comment on the bill. But she said the fund-raising letter accompanying the checks clearly explained that endorsing them would authorize automatic withdrawals. She said that only the first two withdrawals were mandatory and that further withdrawals could be stopped at any time and that a full refund could be obtained by calling a toll-free number provided in the letter. However, some recipients have complained that they did not realize they were authorizing deductions. Vento said he hoped to move the bill, which has six Democratic co-sponsors, before Congress adjourns next month. ``It is imperative that we close the door before any more bogus checks are foisted on the American people,'' he said. Burnley said the Republican committee has agreed to meet with state officials objecting to the solicitations, but not until after the election. ``There are some places where this has become highly politicized,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Patsy Mink Returns to House
DOC.TEXT: Patsy Mink, who served in Congress from 1965 to 1974, was sworn in Thursday to fill Hawaii's vacant seat in the House. The 62-year-old Mink, a Democrat, said she was honored ``once again to be able to join this distinguished body. It's almost unbelievable that my constituents made it possible for me to return.'' Mink was elected Saturday in a special election to fill out the term of Rep. Daniel Akaka, who was appointed April 28 to succeed the late Spark Matsunaga in the Senate. Mink also has won the Democratic nomination for the Nov. 6 general election for a two-year term in the House. Her recent election raises to 29 the number of women among the 435 members of the House.

DOC.HEAD: Police Defuse Bomb Found at Conference on Terrorism in London
DOC.TEXT: Police on Thursday defused a bomb planted in a lunch box that had been taped to a lectern at a conference on terrorism in central London. Commander George Churchill-Coleman, head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist squad, said the device contained enough plastic explosives to kill and was probably put there by the Irish Republican Army. But no group immediately claimed responsibility for the bomb, found in the Royal Overseas League building on Park Place in the Piccadilly section in the center of London. A sound engineer checking the public address system before the start of the conference found a plastic lunch box taped to the lectern at 9:30 a.m., police and television crews covering the conference said. Anti-terrorist squad officers defused the bomb, which was scheduled to go off an hour later, police said. The conference was to have begun 30 minutes earlier, at 10 a.m. Foreign Office minister William Waldegrave was to have been the first speaker, but a change in his appointments forced a last-minute schedule switch and he was moved back to 3:30 p.m. Churchill-Coleman said he did not believe that Waldegrave or Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Peter Imbert, also scheduled to speak at the one-day conference organized by the Research Institute for the Study of Conflict and Terrorism, were the targets. ``The conference, which was widely advertised, would be seen as a legitimate target by Irish Republican terrorist groups,'' he said. Scotland Yard said police had found nothing in a comprehensive search of the building at 6 a.m. Independent Television News sound engineer Pat Hillyard said he noticed the conference sound engineer trying to fit the top on the lectern. ``He found out that what was stopping him from fixing the top of the lectern was the package,'' Hillyard said. ``They looked at it and asked if anybody was responsible for putting it inside. We said it was nothing to do with us. ``They realized quickly that it was something suspect and got us out quickly - within a minute,'' Hillyard said. The building and others nearby were evacuated, the conference abandoned and police closed off busy central London streets while they searched for a second device. Churchill-Coleman said it was a sophisticated terrorist device that would have been activated by a timer. ``It did contain sufficient high explosive that, had the device exploded, which we believe would have been about 10.30 this morning, it would have caused death and serious injury. ``It would have killed the speaker and other people as well,'' he said. The IRA has targeted government officials and security forces in its fight to end British rule in Northern Ireland. Professor Richard Shultz of Tufts University in Boston, who was scheduled to address the conference on American views of terrorism, said there had been an ``embarrassing security lapse.'' ``I am not happy with this, but if someone got through it was a fairly sophisticated move because there were a lot of people around,'' Shultz said.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Symphony Orchestra Opens 100th Season
LaserPhoto CX8
DOC.TEXT: Pound the kettle drums and sound a fanfare: The world-renowned Chicago Symphony Orchestra is opening its 100th season as director and Grammy king Sir Georg Solti begins his triumphant farewell. Thursday's season-opening performance at Orchestra Hall begins a year of programs featuring some of the orchestra's greatest triumphs. Included will be Paul Duakas' ``The Sorcerer's Apprentice,'' which Chicago introduced to this country in 1899. It was incorporated 40 years later into the soundtrack of the Disney film classic ``Fantasia.'' Solti, winner of a record 29 Grammy Awards - 23 for Chicago Symphony recordings and six for other works - will retire next fall after 22 seasons with the orchestra. Daniel Barenboim was named two years ago as his eventual successor, although Solti will return as a guest conductor at least once a year. The 77-year-old maestro told a news conference Thursday it is ``wonderfully appropriate'' that his final year as conductor is also the orchestra's centennial. ``If you have to leave your family, this is the moment to leave it in,'' Solti said in his thick Hungarian accent. After more than two decades of globe-trotting with the orchestra, Solti said, ``what probably pleases me more than anything else is that we have never had any major disagreements. I never had to raise my voice.'' Solti, who took over in 1968, said he selected 66 of the orchestra's 105 musicians. By that measure, it truly is Solti's band. But the Chicago Symphony Orchestra also belongs to the world. Critics rank it among the world's finest, and its recordings with Solti are consistently best-sellers in the classical category. In the early years under Solti, the orchestra was still the butt of Chicago gangster jokes: Were those really violins in their instrument cases? But the orchestra may be best known today for its virtuoso performances of Gustav Mahler's long, wide-ranging symphonies. Thursday's program included Mahler's Symphony No. 5, which was both the first piece the Solti-led orchestra performed at Carnegie Hall in 1970 and the first symphony they recorded together. ``I suppose it became a hit, using this nice American slang,'' Solti said. He said its inclusion would make the opening-night performance ``a very sentimental occasion.'' David Stearns, classical music critic for USA Today, said the orchestra means Mahler to many but that its trademark is its versatility. ``Under Solti it's like a big, gleaming Rolls-Royce, polished within an inch of its life. It's aggressive, it's commanding,'' Stearns said in a telephone interview from New York City. ``Under Barenboim it's softer and more voluptuous because that's Barenboim's style.'' And always, Stearns said, the orchestra is unfailingly professional: ``There is a certain standard under which they will not fall.'' Solti said he told his musicians much the same thing when rehearsals for the centennial season began in the summer. ``I told them that what distinguishes you above all orchestras is the spirit of the music you make under any circumstances. That distinguishes you above all others.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Fund-Raising Speeches Sound Warning About Budget Cuts
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 6-7: ``Later, at,'' with Detroit remarks
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget Talks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush monitored budget negotiations from afar on Thursday as he repeated to Republican fund-raising audiences a message not usually heard from incumbent politicians: how bad things could get. Bush has been painting a nightmarish picture of what will happen to government services beginning Monday in the absence of a budget agreement as he winds up a tour that is raising $4 million for Republican candidates in Ohio, Minnesota, Illinois and Michigan. No matter that Bush himself - who convened the so-called budget summit last spring - is far from the bargaining table. He has been blaming Democrats for the failure to move the talks along. He also suggests that, when his presence is needed, he'll join the talks. At a Cleveland luncheon for GOP gubernatorial candidate George Voinovich, Bush said automatic budget cuts would mean an end to federal clean-up of toxic waste sites. Later, at a Detroit fundraiser, Bush said that in Michigan ``the Social Security office will be closed on Friday'' and ``investigations of white collar criminals will drop by 25 percent.'' ``Congress has got to stop beign manic-depressive,'' he added in prepared remarks. ``Manic on spending, depressive for the economy.'' Earlier Thursday, he told a Minneapolis breakfast for GOP gubernatorial candidate Jon Grunseth that many of ``Minnesota's spectacular parks'' would close and there would be Head Start teachers ``who can't go to work.'' And, Bush said, ``there may be senior citizens wondering why their Social Security checks are late.'' The night before, in Chicago, he raised every travelers' worst fears: the specter of ``untold hours of flight delays'' at busy O'Hare Airport. And, in Akron, Ohio, he told an audience that under budget cuts, poor kids would not be able to attend Akron University. ``Four days from now, the fiscal year ends and still no budget agreement,'' Bush told his Cleveland audience, calling the impasse in Washington a ``fiscal fiasco.'' The last thing the nation needs, he added, ``is a budget breakdown that puts them on the road to recession.'' Administration officials said privately that a budget accord seemed to be near. One official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that a pact seemed likely by the weekend. Their new optimism matched expressions of optimism voiced by congressional budget negotiators. Some Democrats have said that the president's criticism of Democrats from the campaign trail hasn't helped the negotiating process. Even so, Bush on Thursday told his Minnesota audience, ``I hope there will be the compromise needed to help this country from coming to a screeching halt.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards Comic $725,000 in Suit Against Caesars
DOC.TEXT: Rodney Dangerfield was awarded $725,000 on Thursday by jury that believed the comedian's eye problems were caused by a steam bath accident at Caesars Palace. Dangerfield sued the casino-hotel for $5 million after Caesars balked at paying him for shows he missed after he claimed he was burned in a steam bath in March 1988. ``We showed Rodney some respect,'' an unidentified juror said after Dangerfield thanked jurors as they left U.S. District Court. The jury deliberated less than a day before awarding Dangerfield $225,000 for five missed performances and $500,000 for pain and suffering. The jury ruled that Dangerfield's contract obligated Caesars to pay for the missed shows because the injury should have excused him from performing. It rejected a $100,000 countersuit filed by Caesars against its former headliner. ``The truth won out,'' said Dangerfield. He decried as ``nonsense and untrue'' Caesars' accusations that he used drugs. ``I'm surprised they went to that level to degrade me falsely like they did,'' Dangerfield said. ``All they did in this entire trial was to try to degrade my character. ``I wasn't concerned with the amount of money,'' he said. ``Money is money. I was concerned about the truth. I was right. I wouldn't have gone through this unless I was right.'' Dangerfield said Henry Gluck, chairman of the resort's parent Caesars World Inc., had refused an offer to settle for $225,000. ``We're very disappointed,'' said Bruce Aguilera, attorney for the casino. ``We'll have to have our lawyers look at the case. Dangerfield sought $5 million in damages plus $45,000 for each show he missed the week of the accident, claiming Caesars was negligent in installing and maintaining a steam bath. The hotel, in its countersuit, accused Dangerfield of breaching his contract and contended during the 2{-week-long trial that the comedian did not suffer permanent damage. The 68-year-old comic testified he was hit in the eyes by a burst of steam as he opened the door to the steam room on March 16, 1988. He skipped four performances, then returned for two shows but walked off the stage without performing on closing night because he was angry that Caesars wanted to withhold payment for the missed shows. Caesars claimed Dangerfield went out on the town two nights that he claimed he was too hurt to perform. A doctor who examined him after the incident said that Dangerfield could have performed. Other eye specialists testified for the casino-hotel that symptoms Dangerfield claimed to suffer only since the accident actually first appeared in the 1970s. However, an eye doctor who has examined Dangerfield three times in the last year testified that he continues to suffer pain from the steam injury.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli-Backed Militiamen Kill Two Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: Militiamen of the Israeli-allied South Lebanon Army killed two guerrillas Thursday after they infiltrated into Israel's self-designated ``security zone'' in south Lebanon, police said. They said the shooting occurred on a dirt road between the villages of Shomarieh and Deir Semaan near Marjayoun, provincial capital of the 350-square-mile zone. The National Resistence Front, a coalition of 12 pro-Syrian Lebanese leftist factions and radical Palestinian groups, claimed the attack in a communique issued in Beirut. The communique claimed the guerrillas engaged Israeli troops and SLA militiamen in a three-hour battle in the Marjayoun area, destroying an Israeli tank and an SLA armored personnel carrier. ``At least 15 enemy soldiers and militiamen were either killed or wounded in the clash,'' the communique said. It did not mention the front's casualties. Police in Hasbaya, one of the closest Lebanese towns to the security zone, said they could not confirm that Israeli troops were involved in the clash. Israel carved out the enclave in 1985 to serve as a buffer against cross-border guerrilla forays after withdrawing the bulk of its army, ending a three-year invasion. The enclave, stretching from the Mediterranean coast to the foothills of Mount Hermon, is patrolled by the 3,000-strong predominantly Christian SLA and an estimated 1,000 Israeli troops.

DOC.HEAD: Surgeons Give New Face to Disfigured Teen-ager
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A Mexican teen-ager flew home Thursday with a new face and a Mickey Mouse cap to replace the ski mask he wore to hide his disfigurement. ``He came in with a mask covering him completely. He's going out in a baseball cap,'' said Dr. Mutaz Habal, the plastic surgeon who last month built a new skull and half a face for 18-year-old Pablo Hernandez-Pina. ``Pablo does not look like an animal - he is human now,'' said his mother, Severiana Hernandez-Pina. The young man was so badly deformed, said Habal, that he had his doubts that he could help him when he heard of the case 18 months ago. Congenital birth defects left Hernandez-Pina with a severely disfigured face and cleft palate. ``He was what you call a monstrosity,'' the doctor said. ``You could see how he frightened people. The first time I looked at him I thought it was probably almost impossible to do.'' When Hernandez-Pina arrived in Tampa on Aug. 12 he couldn't close his mouth or eat solid food. He had no nose. His right eye socket was just above his ear. A large hole in the bone of his forehead left his brain protected only by a flap of wrinkled skin. In a 15-hour operation at St. Joseph's Hospital, Habal and his team of surgeons cut the teen's scalp from just above one ear to the top of the other and pulled his face down like a mask. Surgeons then moved his right eye socket to the front of his face and built a nose. They closed a large hole in his skull and shifted his brain from the oral cavity back into his head. A section of skull was used to build the teen's forehead and two ribs were made into cheekbones. After the operation, Hernandez-Pina, who had lived only on goat's milk, tasted his first solid food - chicken, eggs, cookies, chocolate, spaghetti and french fries. ``I liked all of it,'' the shy, slight youngster said through an interpreter at Habal's office, where he had a final examination before boarding a flight for central Mexico. The family lives on a farm in Apaseol Ginade village in Guanajuato province. The young man still has a lot of work ahead, said his doctor. His face is swollen from where the skin was moved, he must learn to wear an artificial eye and he has been fitted with braces to straighten his teeth. More surgery may also be needed. But hospital officials say his outlook on life has already changed for the better. ``I saw him go from total withdrawal to absolute excitement after the bandages came off,'' said Karen Parker, director of surgical services at St. Joseph's. ``He went from following behind in his mother's shadows with a mask on to running ahead of her laughing.''

DOC.HEAD: Tass: Soviets Have Joined Interpol; Iraq Attends, Not Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union on Thursday became a member of the international police agency Interpol, the official news agency Tass said. In a one-sentence report from Ottawa, Tass said, ``At a session of the Interpol general assembly that opened here on Thursday, the Soviet Union became a member of this organization uniting more than 150 countries.'' But Interpol secretary-general Raymond Kendall was quoted by Canadian Press as saying the Soviets had applied to join Interpol and, ``Never in history has an applicant been refused membership.'' Kendall made his remarks at Thursday's opening of the 59th general assembly of Interpol where a Soviet delegation is attending. ``By the end of the year, all these countries (in Eastern Europe) will be in,'' Kendall added. Czechoslovakia and Poland, which have emerged over the last year from Communist rule as new democracies, are joining this year, he said. Yugoslavia, a Communist country not considered part of the Soviet bloc, is an Interpol member, though Kendall said much of Eastern Europe has been ``an empty space on the map for us.'' Would Soviet membership make a difference in the international battle with crime? ``Oh yes,'' Kendall said, mentioning as an example possible drug routes through countries in which Interpol has had little previous contact with police. About 500 delegates from 150 countries were present for the opening speech by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney but absent was Kuwait, which was invaded Aug. 2 and annexed by Iraq. Kendall said Kuwait had told Interpol it would attend the meeting. But an aide was unable to say whether Kuwait's reply to the invitation had come before or the invasion. Both Kuwait and Iraq are Interpol members. Delegations were seated alphabetically, with Iraq's Faisal Hussein, minister-counselor at the Iraq embassy here, next to the Iranian delegates. The Israeli members were nearby. Asked how he felt about Kuwait's possible attendance, Hussein said: ``So what?'' In his speech, Mulroney made only a brief reference to ``attacks on Kuwait by a neighboring country'' and focused on the international flavor of the meeting. ``The hopeful symbols of our new age are compelling,'' he said. ``The Iron Curtain is in tatters. Germany is uniting. The two Koreas are talking. The United Nations is working. ``And right here in Ottawa, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Poland - in another symbol of this new age - are adhering to the constitution of Interpol.'' Despite all this, crime still posed problems. ``Crime is going global,'' Mulroney said. ``If Interpol did not exist, it would have to be invented. ``Interpol extends `the long arm of the law' around the globe.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Arrested For Conspiring To Bribe Maritime Administration official
DOC.TEXT: An Indian businessman and his U.S. representative were arrested Thursday on a charge of conspiring to bribe a Maritime Administration official $201,000 for preferential treatment in buying a ship. O.M. Prakash Agarwal, 56, the managing director of a Bombay company that scraps oceangoing ships, was arrested along with his U.S. representative, Rashmi R. Kant, 37, prosecutors said in a statement. Laxmi Chand, the 49-year-old president of a local travel agency, was also arrested, said the statement by Henry Hudson, the U.S. attorney in Alexandria, Va. More than $3.2 million in cash and checks that authorities charge was used to pay the bribe and for the attempt to purchase the ship was seized during the arrest, prosecutors said. The official of the Maritime Administration, which finances the construction of ocean-going ships and sells vessels when loans are defaulted, cooperated with the investigation, said Transportation Department spokesman Bob Marks. The investigation by the FBI and the Transportation Department's inspector general began in June, prosecutors said. The official allegedly offered the bribe was not identified. Kant, who lives in the Washington suburb of Fairfax, Va., is vice president of Trident Trading Corp. of Arlington, Va. Agarwal is managing director of Hariyana Ship-Breakers PUT. LTD. of Bombay. Chand is president of Worldwide Travel Inc. of Washington and lives in suburban Great Falls, Va. The conspiracy charge carries a maximum sentence of five years imprisonment plus a $250,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Policemen Reportedly Targeted in Prostitutes' Death, Disappearance
DOC.TEXT: A task force investigating a string of slayings is focusing on six former or current police officers in the death and disappearance of two prostitutes, two newspapers said. Meanwhile, authorities continued their search Thursday for another killer believed to have fatally stabbed five women since January. The San Diego Union and the Los Angeles Times reported the Metropolitan Homicide Task Force is investigating six current or former officers wh reportedly knew slain prostitute Donna Gentile or her friend Cynthia Lynn Maine, who is missing. Both women were prostitutes, had served as police informants and were romantically involved with at least one officer, the newspapers said. Gentile, who was found dead in 1985, is believed to be the first victim in a string of 43 slayings in San Diego County. The victims, all women, were dumped in remote areas of the county. Most were prostitutes with histories of drug abuse and most were strangled. Gentile died soon after testifying before a city Civil Service Commission investigating police misconduct. Rocks had been packed in her mouth, suggesting to detectives that she was killed because of her testimony. Maine, the daughter of a former San Diego police officer, disappeared in 1986, three months after being released from jt to travel as much or they might not stay at a full service hotel such as Marriott,'' said Marriott spokesman Terry Souers. As a partial result, last week Marriott announced a 12 to 18 month stall of construction starts. The company sold approximately $900 million in assets so far this year with an additional $700 million scheduled for the auction block in the next few months. Discounting the unforseen food service expenses and the revenue from the sale of the London Marriott last year, earnings increased 9 percent in the third quarter, Souers said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Approves Bill to Compensate Miners and Nuclear Test Neighbors
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 12th graf: ``Calling it,'' quote from Udall
DOC.TEXT: Congress approved a bill Thursday offering money and an apology to the so-called ``victims of the Cold War'' in some western states who may have developed cancer from nuclear bomb testing or uranium mining. The bill, approved on voice vote by the House and sent to the president, is an admission that the government was wrong to test nuclear weapons above ground in Nevada while people were living in fallout areas downwind, said Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., who led debate for the measure. It also recognizes the government's liability in allowing people to mine uranium for nuclear weapons without protective gear, he said. ``American citizens going about their business were exposed to radiation in degrees we would not allow now,'' said Frank. ``Miners sent into the mines without even the slightest protection against the material they were being asked to mine.'' The bill authorizes $10 million for a Radiation Exposure Trust Fund. Money for the fund would have to be appropriated in a separate bill. The bill provides compensation for people who got cancer in certain time periods and: -Spent two years - one year for some cancers - in downwind areas of Nevada, Arizona or Utah from nuclear tests between 1951 and 1958, or between June and July, 1962. -Or mined uranium in Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, Wyoming or Utah from 1947 to 1971. The Justice Department would process claims and determine the amount due. A driving force behind the legislation was Stewart Udall, former member of Congress and interior secretary, whose brother Rep. Morris Udall, D-Ariz., is chairman of the House Interior Committee. Stewart Udall represented the uranium miners in a lawsuit against the federal government. The courts ruled the government was immune from prosecution because national security dictated a need for the uranium, but judges involved in the case urged the miners to seek redress from Congress. Calling it ``a good day for the people,'' Stewart Udall said, ``I'm hearing all kinds of voices that the president will sign it, and I hope he will.'' Rep. Wayne Owens, D-Utah, who once was a lawyer for the downwinders, sponsored the legislation. ``It seems so appropriate as we have watched in wonder at the demise of the Cold War that we come and compensate the victims of the Cold War that were downwind of the testing and the miners who mined the uranium,'' said Owens. Owens said he was a high school student in Utah during the testing. The government knew the potential dangers of nuclear fallout and no tests were conducted when the wind was blowing towards densley populated areas of California and Nevada, he said. ``In very real fact the federal government made the decision to bomb these people to whom this bill makes an apology and a compensatory payment of a small amount,'' he said. Above-ground nuclear tests throw radioactive debris into the atmosphere that can settle far away from the explosion site. A major source of radioactivity in such cases was an isotope of strontium which was eaten by cows in their pastures, passed on in their milk and taken up in human bones like calcium. The United States and the Soviet Union agreed to stop testing above ground in 1963. The radioactive decay of uranium releases radon, a radioactive gas that can build up in mines. It was the increase of lung cancer among miners that alerted public health authorities to the dangers of radon buildup in homes, usually to much lower concentrations than in mines.

DOC.HEAD: Macao Governor, Linked to Corruption Probe, Offers to Resign
DOC.TEXT: The governor of Macao, linked to a corruption probe in the Far East colony, offered to resign Thursday. Carlos Melancia contends there were irregularities in the seven-month investigation into alleged attempts to sell privileges t a West German company seeking work on a planned international airport at the colony on the Chinese coast near Hong Kong. At a Lisbon news conference, Malancia said he was ``indignant and surprised'' by the findings of the Public Prosecutor's Office, and claimed the investigation was politically motivated. Malancia's assistant, Francisco Murteira Nabo, would take over as acting governor of the enclave of about 290,000 people if the resignation is accepted, Macao government officials said. The prosecutor's report will be passed to a judge, who has eight days to decide whether to charge Melancia. ``I'm certain the courts will recognize my innocence,'' said Malancia. The investigation began following a series of Portuguese newspaper reports. In February, the conservative Lisbon weekly O Independente published a copy of a fax, allegedly sent to Melancia from Weidleplan Consulting demanding the return of $368,000 after the company failed to win a contract for work on the airport. Melancia's supporters denounced the fax as a fake. Some have suggested the governor is victim of a plot to discredit President Mario Soares, who appointed Melancia to the governorship in 1987. ``The false accusations of which I have been the target were in the framework of a public poison campaign orchestrated with political intentions,'' Melancia said. He has threatened to press charges against O Independente. An official at Stuttgart, West Germany-based Weidleplan contacted Thursday said the company would not comment on the case. Soares has called presidential elections in Portugal for January. The former Socialist Party leader is widely expected to run for a second term. Opinion polls show he has support of more than 60 percent of voters. Political analysts suggest a scandal in Macao could hurt Soares' re-election bid. Other figures named in connection with what has become known as ``fatal fax case'' include Socialist supporters closely linked to Soares. A statement from the Public Prosecutor's Office said evidence had been found against others, but they were not named. Europe's oldest colonial outpost in the Far East, Macao was ceded to Portugal in 1557. The 6.4-square-mile territory has grown rich as a gambling and tourism center.

DOC.HEAD: Tremors Kill Two South African Miners
DOC.TEXT: Two quakes measuring 4.3 and 4.7 on the Richter scale shook central South Africa early Thursday, killing two miners working more than a mile underground. Five other miners at the President Brand gold mine southwest of Johannesburg suffered minor injuries, officials said. The tremors hit seconds apart before dawn in the Orange Free State and Western Transvaal areas, according to news reports. Cracks in buildings and other minor damage were reported in Welkom, about 125 miles southwest of Johannesburg. Mine officials said they would investigate the deaths and injuries in a shaft 1.3 miles beneath the surface. South Africa's gold mines are the deepest in the world. Accidents claim dozens of lifes in the mines each year. A quake of magnitude 4 is capable of causing moderate damage, while one of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Wins Panel Approval; Final OK Unlikely Before Court Session

DESK: SUBS lede with two grafs; vote scheduled for Tuesday; DELETES 5th graf pvs: ``Full Senate,'' as redundant; SUBS grafs 7-8: ``A vote,'' with two grafs bgng: ``But Senate,'' Mitchell making timing announcement; INSERTS grafs 16-17: ``Humphrey's New Hampshire,'' comment from Rudman
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Judiciary Committee approved the nomination of New Hampshire jurist David H. Souter to the Supreme Court on Thursday with but one dissenting vote. The full Senate is expected to confirm him easily when it votes next Tuesday, the day after the court begins its session. Democrats as well as Republicans on the committee said they saw in President Bush's nominee a brilliant legal scholar and a man of good temperament and integrity. In the 13-1 vote, only Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., opposed him, saying he feared Souter would ``solidify a 5-4 anti-civil-rights, anti-privacy majority.'' Howell Heflin, a conservative Alabama Democrat whose opposition helped kill the 1987 Supreme Court nomination of Robert Bork, said he liked Souter's ``clearheaded approach'' and lack of an ideological agenda. Added Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio: ``My sense is that David Souter is a fair and open-minded jurist who knows well the weight of the responsibilities which will be placed upon him,'' Bush hailed the committee action and repeated his request that the Senate ``act as quickly as possible to confirm this man'' so he could be seated when the court begins its new session. But Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell announced Thursday night that he and Republican leaders agreed to hold the confirmation vote on Souter on Tuesday. The Jewish holiday Yom Kippur which was interrupting Congress' schedule Friday. And Biden and other Democrats were loathe to waive rules that give senators time before voting to review a committee's findings. Souter, 51, in a statement released in New Hampshire, thanked committee leaders and members ``for their courtesy and consideration. I am gratified by their action. I await the decision of the full Senate.'' Earlier, Tom Rath, like Souter a former New Hampshire attorney general, said Souter heard of the panel's action on a radio in Rath's law office. ``To get this kind of overwhelming support makes us feel very good,'' Rath said, adding that Souter would issue his separate statement as soon as the White House approved it. The lopsided vote did not show the widespread unease on the committee caused by Souter's refusal to state his positions on abortion and other critical issues before the court. ``Judge Souter is not the sort of judge I would nominate if I were president,'' said committee chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., a supporter of abortion rights. Souter ``just barely'' met his criteria, Biden said. ``But I think that he is about the best we can expect'' from Bush, who opposes abortion rights, he said. ``Aspects of Judge Souter's testimony were of little comfort to legal conservatives including this senator,'' said Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., in a statement released at the committee session. ``But we recognize that the president is entitled to considerable deference in his choice for the Supreme Court.'' Humphrey's New Hampshire colleague, Warren Rudman, a Republican not on the Budget Committee who has been Souter's mentor and Senate champion, said he was pleased with the vote and not disturbed by the reservations expressed by some members. ``That's normal,'' Rudman said. ``Those are people whoare obviously concerned about staking out political grounds for the future and I can understand that.'' Democrats who supported Souter expressed faith that he was as open-minded on women's rights and other issues as he professed to be. But Kennedy refused to go along. ``I am troubled that... he will solidify a 5-4 anti-civil-rights, anti-privacy majority inclined to turn back the clock on the historic progress of recent decades,'' Kennedy said. ``I hope I am wrong. But I fear I am right,'' Kennedy said. ``The lesson of the past decade ... is that we must vote our fears, not our hopes.'' ``I hope I'm not wrong,'' said Metzenbaum, usually a Kennedy ally, in revealing his affirmative vote. Kennedy won't be quite so alone when the nomination comes before the full Senate. Five other Democrats had announced their opposition to the nomination by Thursday, mostly based on the abortion issue. Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women, attended Thursday's committee meeting and said afterward: ``I tremble for the women of the United States.'' Senate Republicans urged the majority Democrats to schedule a full Senate vote before Monday. ``If we delay for only three days there will be a dozen cases in which he cannot participate,'' said Sen. Alan K. Simpson, R-Wyo., the deputy GOP leader. The court planned to hear arguments on four cases on each of the first three days next week.

DOC.HEAD: Lower House Passes Presidential Election Laws in Poland
DOC.TEXT: The lower house of Parliament on Thursday overwhelmingly approved constitutional changes and a law that could result in a presidential election as early as Nov. 25. The election law, passed 268-12, authorizes the speaker of Parliament to set a date for elections as quickly as 60 days. A second round of elections is possible if no candidate gets 50 percent of the ballots in the first round. Under the constitutional amendment, approved 325-4, the president is elected in a general ballot and may serve up to two five-year terms. The Parliament banned campaign financing from foreign sources and campaigning 36 hours before the election. Deputies refused a proposal to bar campaigning at churches and other religious sites, a common activity in Poland. The changes require approval by the upper chamber - Senate - and the president, but that is considered likely. The Senate is in session Friday. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa has already declared his candidacy in the first popular presidential ballot since before World War II. He seeks to succeed Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who is stepping down early as head of state. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a former adviser and ally of Walesa, also is considering running and is expected to announce his decision next week. Several other candidates are likely. A candidate must be nominated by a party or else collect 100,000 signatures to get on the ballot. A caucus representing former Communists tried unsuccessfully to lower the number of signatures required to 50,000. Jaruzelski asked Parliament on Sept. 19 to shorten his term of office in order to permit an election. In recent months, there were increasing calls for the former Communist Party leader to step down as an unwanted symbol of the country's old hard-line order. Jaruzelski, who ordered martial law in 1981 following Solidarity-led unrest, was elected to a six-year term as president in July 1989 by a joint session of the Sejm, or lower house, and the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Church Leaders Condemn New Movie Rating System
DOC.TEXT: Religious leaders Thursday condemned a new movie rating system as pandering to ``sexually exploitative material.'' The church officials urged the Motion Picture Association of America to reconsider its action replacing the ``X'' rating with the new ``No Children'' or ``NC-17'' rating. ``It is an arrogant and ill advised decision which deeply affects the public good. It was made in isolation, without public consultation. The change is neither in the public interest nor in the best interest of the community,'' the church leaders said in a joint statment. The statement was issued by communication leaders of the U.S. Catholic Conference and the National Council of Churches, which includes most major Protestant and Eastern Orthodox denominations. They spoke out after the motion picture association Wednesday said it has decided to substitute the new ``NC-17'' category for the ``X'' rating used on adult films since 1968. The church officials charged that the association ``has caved in to the commercial interests of those who are attempting to get sexually exploitative material into general theatrical release.'' They urged members of the National Association of Theater Owners to refuse to book NC-17 movies, and newspapers and others to refuse to accept advertising for them. ``Changing the name of the `X' category does not change the nature of the material,'' the statement said. Local congregations were also urged to monitor enforcement of age restrictions under the NC-17 category and other categories. The statement was issued by Bishop Edward J. O'Donnell, chairman of the communication committee of the U.S. Catholic Conference, and by Beverly Chain, who heads the National Council's communications unit. They said the motion picture association's action ``will be used by those who already are calling for government regulation of the media. ``That is unfortunate, because a voluntary system of self-regulation that skirts Constitutional concerns, yet affords at least a minimum of protection to the public, is workable.'' The motion picture association said that under its changed rating system the existing ``R'' or restricted rating would be clarified to include an explanation of why a film was placed in that category. Such explanations could be an emphasis on such themes as sex, violence, profanity, drug use or sucicide, and would be made available to parents and other moviegoers. As for the new ``NC-17'' films, the association said they would ``continue to be evaluated as X-rated films have been in the past, that is, on the basis that most parents would agree'' such films should not be viewed by youngsters.

DOC.HEAD: Last of Florida's Huge Jackpot Winners Claim Prize
DOC.TEXT: A retired steel worker jumped for joy and his wife said a prayer when they won a share of Florida's $106.5 million jackpot, but they waited nearly two weeks to claim the prize. John and Phyllis Pacilio of Winter Haven turned in their winning ticket Thursday, the last of the six winning tickets submitted for validation. They will receive $17.75 million over 20 years. Mrs. Pacilio, a former banker, said she and her husband had known since the Sept. 15 drawing that they had a winning. ``We looked at each other in amazement,' she said. Then her husband leaped for joy, ``and I said a little prayer down on my knees and gave thanks,'' she recalled. Asked what they do with the money, her husband replied, ``Spend it.'' ``We're going to buy a home and help our children with education, travel some,'' Mrs. Pacilio said.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Report Criticizes Sematech Companies' Relations With Suppliers
DOC.TEXT: Members of the Sematech semiconductor research consortium have troubled relations with companies supplying materials and manufacturing equipment, the General Accounting Office said Thursday. These weak relations, coupled with the high cost of capital, hinder efforts to strengthen the U.S. materials and equipment industry, supplier executives believe. Mark Nelson, Sematech's director of government relations, said the consortium has taken steps to better those relations. ``The GAO recognized a problem which we were already aware of and in the process of addressing,'' Nelson said. ``We've already made significant progress since that survey'' with a new program of links with supplier companies. Fourteen computer companies belong to the Sematech consortium, backing it with $100 million that has been matched by Congress each of the last three years. The consortium undertakes research in the computer chips that form the foundation of a half-trillion dollar worldwide electronics industry. In manufacturing equipment, the Japanese market share rose from 25 percent in 1983 to 40 percent in 1988 while the U.S. share dropped from 69 percent to 51 percent in the same period, GAO said. GAO, the investigating arm of Congress, interviewed 31 supplier industry executives last spring. It was supplier relations of consoritum members, not the Austin, Texas-based consortium itself, that drew criticism. The GAO report said the suppliers want the consortium members to ``emulate Sematech's example'' in working more closely with them. The GAO interviewers found that half their subjects said Sematech's member companies need to establish better relationships with them. The suppliers particularly wanted long-term relationships permitting them to participate in their customers' planning, to share technical performance data and to get their customers to assume some of the costs and risks associated with developing the next generation of equipment. Three suppliers noted ``Japanese companies provide better feedback than their U.S. counterparts on how their equipment is performing.'' Sematech implemented a program last month called Partnering for Total Quality to improve those relationships, Nelson said. The plan calls for sharing of strategic goals and plans, performance information and some cost information, he said. ``This initiative, which is directed at one of the central issues that suppliers' executives highlighted for reasserting U.S. technological leadership, requires that Sematech's members change the way they have traditionally conducted business with their suppliers,'' the GAO report said.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Claim Congressman Kidnapping; Peruvian Mine Accord Reached
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Cuban guerrillas claimed responsibility for the kidnapping of a congressman, the highest-level political official seized by rebels in 10 years of guerrilla insuurgency, a Lima newspaper said Thursday. The Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement sent photos to the daily Pagina Libre showing Gerardo Lopez sitting beneath a rebel flag. Lopez, 34, who heads the governing Cambio 90 Movement congressional delegation, was dragged from his home Sunday by three rebels with machine guns. The Tupac Amaru used similar methods in the Sept. 11 kidnapping of a cement company executive, who is still missing, police said. In a phone call to the newspaper, a guerrilla spokesman said Lopez was in Lima and was unharmed. The spokesman said they had ``invited him to talk'' and would be released later. The movement has not demanded a ransom. Two congressmen were killed by guerrillas in April 1989, but police ruled out the Tupac Amaru in both cases. The head of the Tupac Amaru and 47 other members staged a spectacular jailbreak in July and have not been recaptured. The movement, much smaller and less violent than the Maoist Shining Path, took up arms in 1984. Shining Path began its bloody insurgency in the Andes in 1980. Elsewhere in Peru, workers at the state mining company Mineroperu on Thursday agreed to end their 41-day strike, a mining federation spokesman said. More than 80 percent of Mineroperu's 12,500 miners agreed to an accord guaranteeing an unspecified pay rise, said Simon Diaz Huamani, spokesman for the National Miners Federation. The federation said the strike produced losses of $1 million a day, but the company refuses to give a figure. The strike was centered in the Mineroperu facilities in Cerro Verde, Cajamarquilla and Ilo. Ricardo Salzedo, spokesman for Mineroperu, said the company would renew copper, gold and zinc shipments ``as soon as possible,'' but would not specify a date.

DOC.HEAD: New CIA Deputy Director For Operations Appointed
DOC.TEXT: Central Intelligence Agency Director William H. Webster announced Thursday the appointment of Thomas A. Twetten, a career CIA officer, as deputy director for operations. The CIA said in a statement that Twetten, 55, on Jan. 1 will succeed Richard F. Stolz, 64, as chief of operations, the division that oversees espionage and covert activities. Stolz, who served in the agency from 1950 to 1981 and then returned to CIA duty in 1988, is retiring. Webster, in a statement, said Stolz ``has made an enormous contribution in charting the role of human intelligence in a rapidly changing world. He has dealt with some extraordinarily challenging issues, serving the agency and the country with great distinction.'' Twetten has served as Stolz's deputy since June 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Mulroney Gets Queen's Permission to Expand Senate By Eight Seats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with senators sworn in, picking up 3rd graf pvs `An opposition...' and edits thereafter to conform
DOC.TEXT: Using an obscure constitutional provision, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney received permission Thursday from Queen Elizabeth II to appoint eight partisan senators to help push through a controversial tax. The new lawmakers, who serve until age 75, bring the Senate to 112 seats and give Mulroney's Conservative Party a majority in both the Senate and House of Commons. The new members were sworn into office by the Senate clerk late Thursday, but will not take their seats until the chamber resumes work next week. An opposition leader called Mulroney's move ``an abuse of power'' and legal challenges loom. The only other similar request was in 1873, but the appeal was not granted. The nation's 1867 Constitution allows the British monarch to add four or eight members to the Senate on a request by the governor-general, the Canadian representative to the Commonwealth. Mulroney used the measure as a last resort to save the 7 percent goods and services tax, stalled in the Liberal-dominated Senate. The Commons, dominated by Conservatives, supported the tax. The proposed consumption tax would replace a 13 percent tax paid by manufacturers. Some basics, such as groceries, would be exempt from the tax, but it would affect even such services as a haircut. Mulroney said the debate goes beyond the tax proposal to the principle of whether the elected Commons should prevail over the appointed Senate. ``The consequences for our parliamentary system are enormous,'' he said. ``What is at stake is one of the principles of our freedom. '' John Haslam, a spokesman for the queen, said Elizabeth, as the constitutional monarch of the former British colony, followed the provisions of the Canadian Constitution in making the decision. But even with the additional seats, the fate of the tax could rest on the votes of a handful of Independents. Before Mulroney's move, the Liberals held 52 seats and the Conservatives 46, with one Reform Party representative, four Independents and one Independent Liberal. Over the last two months, Mulroney has filled 15 Senate vacancies with Conservative loyalists to narrow the gap. Liberal leader Jean Chretien warned the public will not back Mulroney, whose popularity has dipped sharply in polls. ``When you are 15 percent in the polls and taking an abuse of power and stacking the Senate, he might find that he will not go very far politically with that,'' he said. And Liberal Senate leader Allan MacEachen promised that the fight against the tax will intensify. ``It leaves me in an even more agressive mood,'' MacEachen said. ``We'll continue the battle ... (But) unless all the Independents vote with us, we can't defeat it.'' Also, legal challenges are threatened. British Columbia has said it will contest Ottawa's ability to create the extra Senate seats, Ontario has said it may join that campaign. Alberta has promised a separate challenge on some aspects of the tax.

DOC.HEAD: Dictator's Son Ordered Released on Grounds of Health
DOC.TEXT: A military court on Thursday released Nicu Ceausescu, the youngest son of the former dictator, from jail for three months because of failing health, the official Rompress news agency said. The same court on Friday convicted Ceausescu, who is suffering from an advanced case of cirrhosis of the liver, of complicity in murder and sentenced him to 20 years in prison. But it also agreed to Defense Attorny Paula Iacob's request for a third medical examination after two earlier ones reached contradictory conclusions about the 39-year-old Ceausescu's ability to withstand an extended stay in jail. Thursday's decision apparently was a result of the latest medical examination. Ceausescu also is appealing the conviction. He initially was charged in connection with 89 deaths that took place during December's revolution in the Transylvanian city of Sibiu, where he had been Communist Party chief since 1987.
