His father, Nicolae Ceausescu, and mother, Elena, was executed in the revolution, which ended more than four decades of communism in Romania. Nicu, who had earned a reputation as a hard-living playboy with political ambitions, also is recovering from a stab wound suffered when he was arrested Dec. 22. He was held in prison hospitals during most of his five-month trial. According to Romanian law, Ceausescu is eligible for successive releases on health grounds until he either recovers or the sentence expires. Prosecutors were given three days to appeal the decision to release him.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Leaders Praise New Law, But Call It Stopgap
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with Vatican, Ukrainian statements. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Russian Orthodox...'
DOC.TEXT: Soviet religious leaders said Thursday they are satisfied with the country's new law on freedom of conscience, but consider it a stopgap measure. The law, which the national legislature approved in principle on Wednesday, calls a halt to decades of repression by forbidding the government from interfering in the practice of religion. It also improves the legal status of religious organizations, guarantees the right to study religious doctrine and calls for a religious council to advise the government on human rights. Vatican chief spokesman Joaquin Navarro said the new law ``renders justice to millions of believers.'' ``The Ukrainian Catholic Church welcomes this first step toward true religious freedom,'' added church head Cardinal Myroslav Ivan Lubachivsky. Russian Orthodox, Baptist and Jewish leaders told reporters at a press conference organized by the Foreign Ministry that the law is a major step forward. But they said it is complex and unclear on some points. ``I think this law will be of a transitional nature,'' said Georgi Komendant, president of the Soviet Baptist Society. ``In due time, if eveything is OK, it should be more brief, less complicated.'' Komendant also said the spirit of the law - official tolerance for religion - is more important than the wording. ``This is a good law ... and as Baptists, we are satisfied with it,'' he said. Metropolitan Pitirim, a leader of the dominant Russian Orthodox Church, called the law ``unprecedented'' and said ``it can be considered successful as a first offspring'' of democratic reforms. But, he added, ``A lot of provisions need clarifying.'' Among the ambiguities are whether public schools can teach about various religions, whether the military should hold services for religious soldiers and whether conscientious objectors will be allowed an alternative to military duty. The chief rabbi of Moscow, Adolph Shayevich, said he helped draft the law and is generally happy with it. But he expressed concern that it may not be respected. ``Our Supreme Soviet has adopted a lot of laws, but unfortunately, not all of them are fully effective,'' he said. ``It would be very regrettable if after adoption, it takes a long time to implement this law.'' Shayevich also said he does not believe the law will reduce the flow of Soviet Jews to Israel. The main reasons for Jewish emigration, he said, are anti-Semitism - which ``has become more open and organized'' in recent years - and the Soviet economy, which is beset by shortages, inflation and inefficiency. A member of the Supreme Soviet committee that drafted the law, Andrei Sebentsov, said the legislature is expected to give it final approval Monday. It was adopted in principle early Wednesday by a vote of 341-1 with one abstention. ``We want to put an end to harassment of religious people and give them equal rights, as they have in most countries,'' Sebentsov said. ``Of course, we can't say that (the law) is ideal for the future, but for the decade, it is what our society needs,'' he added. Western scholars estimate one-quarter of the 285 million Soviet people practice some faith, and the number appears to be rising fast as official tolerance replaces hard-line communist opposition to religion. In recent years, churches confiscated by the government have been reopened, Jews have been allowed to hold Hebrew classes, state-run television has broadcast holiday church services and government propaganda against religion has subsided.

DOC.HEAD: Second Test in A Week at Nevada Site
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department conducted a nuclear weapons test at this remote desert site Thursday, the second time in a week a device has been detonated in the same area. The test, code-named Ledoux, was conducted 75 miles northwest of Las Vegas. ``Everything went very well,'' said Energy Department spokesman Derek Scammell. ``There were no problems. It was a very small test. Everybody was happy with it.'' The nuclear device was buried in a shaft 1,000 feet beneath the surface of Yucca Flat. The weapon had an explosive force of less than 20 kilotons. All tests are announced as having a force of less than 20 kilotons - 20,000 tons of TNT - or 20 to 150 kilotons. The most recent previous test, code-named Sundown, was conducted Sept. 20, also at Yucca Flat. The test was the sixth this year at the Nevada site and the 705th since testing began at the test site in January of 1951.

DOC.HEAD: Former Pakistan Prime Minister Faces More Corruption Charges
DOC.TEXT: A judge Thursday ordered ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto to stand trial on two more corruption charges in a mounting legal onslaught that could disqualify her from next month's election. Judge Wajihuddin Ahmed issued the notice for Ms. Bhutto to appear before the tribunal on Sunday to answer charges of misconduct and abuse of power during her 20-month administration. Ms. Bhutto's husband, Asif Ali Zardari, is also ordered to appear in court on Sunday charged with failing to cooperate in a police investigation, said the state news agency. Associated Press of Pakistan claimed the 38-year-old Zardari ignored several official requests to appear before the Federal Investigation Agency. Ms. Bhutto, already facing trial on two corruption charges in the eastern city of Lahore, was campaigning in the Sindh Province countryside and unavailable for comment. Her lawyers have not said whether she will appear before the special courts, which could disqualify her from the Oct. 24 election and bar her from politics for seven years if she is convicted. She can be tried in absentia. Ms. Bhutto, who won election in November 1988 and became the first woman to lead a modern Moslem nation, is a candidate for five seats in the 217-member National Assembly, the policy-making lower house of Parliament. Her aides say Ms. Bhutto ran for five seats in case she was disqualified from some of the races. The army-backed caretaker government has accused Ms. Bhutto of illegally using an Asia Development Bank loan to hire a foreign consulting firm to oversee a Karachi power project. She also have been accused of allowing a British-based firm to export cotton at rates far below the international market rate, costing the government an estimated $100 million. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan invoked his constitutional powers and dismissed Ms. Bhutto on Aug. 6. He alleged that, among other things, her government used tens of millions of dollars in special funds to buy votes and political favors, awarded lucrative buisness deals to friends and relatives and demanded commissions on government contracts. Earlier this week, a tribunal in Lahore ordered the 37-year-old former prime minister to stand trial Oct. 2 for allegedly approving the illegal sale of 287 acres of federal land to a London-based company operated by a cousin. She is to be tried Oct. 9 for allegedly canceling contracts for distribution of liquified gas and awarding them to friends and relatives that she claimed had suffered during a decade of martial law. Ms. Bhutto has vehemently denied any wrongdoing and repeatedly accused the president of corruption and nepotism. The caretaker government, comprised largely of Ms. Bhutto's opponents and former allies, has spent much of the past month trying to portray Ms. Bhutto's administration as the most corrupt in Pakistan's 43-year history. Most analysts say Ms. Bhutto and the People's Party appear to be gaining strength and could emerge from next month's election as the single largest bloc.

DOC.HEAD: Toy Bear and Elephant Recalled
DOC.TEXT: Two distributors are recalling toy bears and elephants, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Thursday. Consumers may take the toys to the stores where they were bought for a refund, the commission said. F.J. Strauss Co. Inc. of North Bergen, N.J., is recalling 3,600 ``Music Maker'' toy elephants because of excessive lead in the paint and small parts that could choke young children if broken off. The Music Maker is a blue plastic elephant, painted yellow in some places, with a xylophone, drum, bells and ball popper built into the top. It carries the legend ``STRACO MADE IN CHINA,'' the commission said. The commission said it knew of no injuries from the toy. Soft Things Inc. of Brooklyn, N.Y. is recalling 30,240 Video Bear Babies because the eyes and nose of the stuffed bear could break off and choke young children. The 5{-inch bear comes in various colors with a sewn-in tag reading ``China Berrries for China House, Los Angeles XXX MADE IN CHINA.'' The commission said it knew of no injuries from the bear.

DOC.HEAD: Hightower: FBI Inquiry Is Political
DOC.TEXT: The FBI is inquiring into the campaign finances of two Texas Democrats, one of them running against the son of U.S. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher and the other against a candidate backed by President Bush's eldest son. The inquiries are politically motivated, says one of the Democrats, Agriculture Commissioner Jim Hightower. On Monday, FBI agent Greg Rampton obtained from the secretary of state copies of 1988-90 campaign finance reports filed by Hightower and lieutenant governor hopeful Bob Bullock. ``I resent the FBI getting into my political campaign with these kinds of overt acts of political activity,'' Hightower said Thursday. ``It amounts to Nixonian dirty tricks here.'' Bullock's Republican opponent is Rob Mosbacher Jr., son of U.S. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher. Hightower faces state Rep. Rick Perry, a Republican who has received backing from the president's eldest son, George W. Bush. ``Two Democrats who the administration seems most interested in getting: Mr. Bullock because he's had the gall to run against Mr. Mosbacher's boy ... Myself because I've been something of a burr under the saddle of the Bush administration on their price-busting, farm-bankrupting agriculture policies,'' Hightower said. Perry and Mosbacher said they had nothing to do with the FBI inquiry. ``I don't know anything more about it than I've read in the papers,'' Mosbacher said. ``I don't know anybody in the FBI, and I can assure you that none of them have talked to me,'' Perry said. But he said the inquiry shows that ``irregularities in (Hightower's) agency have caught the attention of federal authorities.'' At a news conference, Hightower said Rampton had questioned many of his agency's employees and tried to get one to wear a hidden microphone. ``They tried to put a wire on one of my employees and send him in to talk to me. They have harassed our office staff,'' he charged. Neither Byron Sage, agent-in-charge of the Austin FBI office, nor Rampton returned telephone calls from The Associated Press. Their office referred inquiries to FBI spokesman Claude Martin in San Antonio, who didn't immediately return a call. Bullock, the five-term state comptroller, said the FBI inquiry may have stemmed from complaints by a disgruntled former employee. Bullock and Hightower, who is seeking re-election, said they had done nothing wrong and had nothing to hide.

DOC.HEAD: Neighbor Pleads Innocent in Girl's Death
DOC.TEXT: A man who took part in a search for a missing 13-year-old neighbor girl has been charged with murdering the girl and burying her body in his basement. Henry L. Meinholz, 52, pleaded innocent to murder Thursday in the death of Melissa Benoit, who disappeared Sept. 15. He was ordered held without bail and sent to a state psychiatric hospital for evaluation. Meinholz's lawyer, Jack Atwood, said: ``At this point, he denies any memory of the incident whatsoever.'' Police Chief Alan Ballinger later said police believe another body may be buried on Meinholz's property. ``We are looking for a connection between any missing child in this area,'' he said. Meinholz was arrested Wednesday after Melissa's artially clad body was found buried in his basement. An autopsy was being conducted to determine the cause of death. Officials would not say what led them to Meinholz, who is an accountant at a lumber store. About 150 people booed and shouted ``Guilty'' and ``Hang him'' as Meinholz, entered the courthouse in this town 35 miles south of Boston. Meinholz's lawyer said the court's psychiatric consultant testified at a closed hearing after the arraignment that Meinholz had some mental problems, including sleeping and eating disorders. Meinholz's wife, Jane, a nurse at a psychiatric hospital, said her husband ``has been a very gentle husband for 27 years. He's a wonderful, warm, compassionate man.'' And then she added: ``My heart is aching for the Benoits.''

DOC.HEAD: Seven Held in Beheading of American Innkeeper
DOC.TEXT: Four soldiers and three civilian military aides are being held in connection with the beheading of an American innkeeper, a federal human rights official said Thursday. Meanwhile, a rights group claimed an army colonel and another officer are also involved in the June murder of Michael Devine, 49, who ran a small inn near the Mayan ruins of Tikal in northern Guatemala. The United States has threatened to cut off military aid to Guatemala if the murder of Devine, a 19-year resident of Guatemala, is not fully investigated. Guatemala's rights ombudsman, Fernando Hurtado Prem, said his office had been conducting an independent investigation since June 12, three days after Devine's body was found by a roadside. Hurtado Prem cannot prosecute, but can investigate and make recommendations. He said the inquiry found several witnesses who linked the vehicle used by the killers to the military base at Santa Elena, near the provincial capital of Flores in northern Guatemala. He identified the soldiers suspected in the killings as Rafael Tiul Cucul, Pablo Lajuj Ixmalej, Carlos Zelada Marroquin and Augustin Esquivel Hernandez. No ranks were given. Also held were Ricardo Guzman, Andres Morente Tipol and Benjamin Punji Perush, all civilians who work for the military as local ``commissioners,'' Hurtado Prem said. The Guatemalan military maintains an extensive system of civilian collaborators, such as commissioners and civil defense patrols, to enforce its authority in the countryside and help battle the small force of leftists guerrillas who have been fighting the past 30 years. The Mutual Support Group said the ex-commander of the base, Col. Mario Garcia Catalan, was also involved in the murder. The colonel was relieved of his command earlier this month. The rights advocacy group also accused another officer at the base. The group's president, Nineth Montenegro de Garcia, said she had discussed the case with a United Nations rights observer, Christian Tomuschat. Guatemala's bleak rights record prompted a total suspension of U.S. aid between 1977 and 198, when a civilian government took office. In the last year, however, the number of murders, kidnappings and disappearances linked to the right wing and the military began rising sharply. President Vinicio Cerezo promised a full investigation into Devine's murder in a recent letter to U.S. Ambassador Thomas Stroock. Devine, a former Peace Corps volunteer, was from Belleville, Ill. According to some reports, U.S. officials suspect he may have stumbled on evidence of military involvement in the drug trade.

DOC.HEAD: Sellers Use Computer Glitch to Buy Illegal Winning Lottery Tickets
DOC.TEXT: Ticket agents took advantage of a computer glitch that allowed them to buy winning lottery tickets worth a $1 million after the numbers were drawn, lottery officials said Thursday. James Wimsatt, New Hampshire Sweepstakes director, said six people illegally played the winning numbers in the Tri-State Megabucks game for Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. The Wednesday night drawing had a $1.1 million jackpot for which one legitimate winning ticket was sold. No payments were made for the invalid Megabucks' tickets, Wimsatt said. However, he said at least 10 vendors issued about 50 winning tickets, worth a total of about $156,000, for the daily lottery drawn the same night. Some of those winning tickets - worth as much as $5,000 each - were cashed in, but the state won't lose any money because it is insured against such a problem, he said. The state is investigating the scam and if any of the ticket buyers are caught they will be required to return the ill-gotten winnings, Wimsatt said. ``It's like if you walk into a bank and the vault's open and no one's watching you,'' he said. ``You don't just walk in and help yourself.'' The daily numbers tickets cost 50 cents and $1; Megabucks tickets are $1. Officials said the computer program that is supposed to halt ticket sales 10 minutes before the drawings malfunctioned. Dave Long, a spokesman for the Megabucks game, said three people in Maine, two in New Hampshire and one in Vermont played the winning numbers right after the drawing. The legitimate winning ticket was sold in Maine.

The six-week-old U.N. economic embargo has not kept Iraq from receiving food and supplies by truck from Jordan, jetliner from South America, via smugglers from Syria and Iran, and even by mule from Turkey. The embargo has halted virtually all of Iraq's oil exports and drastically reduced cargo shipments to the country, but supplies are slipping in thanks to sympathetic governments, pro-Iraqi groups and opportunistic smugglers. ``There are a lot of ways for an innovative shipper to avoid a blockade, and as the price goes up, they become more innovative,'' said Capt. Paul Prokop, commander of U.S. Coast Guard teams enforcing the embargo in the Persian Gulf. The amount of slippage is difficult to determine. Before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, prompting the international community to impose the sanctions, it imported about three-quarters of its food supplies. ---= MINNEAPOLIS (AP) - President Bush is warning U.S. and world oil markets that if ``intensive and unwarranted speculation'' does not end, he may expand the first-time use of the national petroleum stockpile to control escalating prices. The president announced Wednesday he will sell 5 million barrels from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. ``I'm prepared to take additional steps, if necessary, to ensure that America stays strong right here at home,'' Bush told a political fund-raising audience in Rosemont, Ill., on Wednesday night. He announced his decision during a two-day trip to help Republican gubernatorial and Senate candidates. ---= DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia (AP) - The Persian Gulf crisis is forcing Saudi Arabia, which traditionally has relied on quiet diplomacy, to take aggressive steps - even against Arab states once considered allies. Jordan and Yemen have already experienced the newfound Saudi punitive power. Indications are that the Palestine Liberation Organization, or at least its leader Yasser Arafat, will be next. Sudan, another recipient of Saudi financial aid that has not broken with Iraq over its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, could soon see its relations with Riyadh sour. ``There will be a settlement of accounts when this is over,'' a Saudi diplomatic official said Wednesday. ``We have to stand up for principle. It is no more Mr. Nice Guy. . . . There is no longer the fear of offending Arabs.'' ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - There will be fewer maps for troops in the Middle East. A million children won't be vaccinated against polio, measles and diphtheria. There may not be enough government lawyers to argue before the Supreme Court. Airline flights will be reduced and most space shuttles won't fly at all. All this, and more, is predicted if there is no budget agreement and the president orders automatic spending cuts Monday, the first day of the government's 1991 fiscal year. For 2.4 million federal employees with mortgage payments and mouths to feed, the impact could range from a few days off without pay to the devastation that faces Jeannette Gordon. She could be laid off 255 days out of a work year of 260. Most agencies of the government expect to be forced to trim expenses by 32.4 percent. They'll do it by cutting services to the taxpayer, suspending programs, furloughing employees, putting off that needed paint job or turning out the lights at night. ---= ASHINGTON (AP) - The Sudan has asked the United States for $150 million in food aid at a time when the Sudanese Air Force has been attempting to bomb existing food shipments earmarked for rebel areas, U.S. officials say. The officials said one target of the raids is a food barge donated by the Norwegian government to the International Committee for the Red Cross. The barge has been located in the Nile River adjacent to the southern Sudan town of Bor, a main transit point for relief supplies, they said. ``I think it's almost unimaginable that a government facing a (famine) disaster of epic proportions would have the audacity to bomb food shipments at the same time they are asking for more food assistance,'' said Andrew Natsios, head of the U.S. Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance. Natsios and other officials said bombs have rained down on Bor and other towns where international relief programs are in operation. They are run by the World Food Program, the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and the International Committee for the Red Cross. ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - Theater owners and filmmakers are giving the new movie rating NC-17 mixed reviews, saying it offers improvements over the ruinous X rating but still may prove troublesome. The Motion Picture Association of America eliminated the X rating on Wednesday, replacing it with NC-17, for no children under 17 admitted. It said the new label does not immediately carry the commercial stigma of X. The MPAA also said it will give film companies and theater owners more details on films it rates R, noting violence, sex and language. The PG-13, PG and G ratings will remain the same. Universal Pictures' X-rated ``Henry & June,'' a historical drama featuring some sex scenes, will be the first film bearing the NC-17 rating, Universal said.

DOC.HEAD: `Twin Peaks' Returns to the Air Waves
DOC.TEXT: It has not been a quiet week in Twin Peaks, the enigmatic little lumber town in the Pacific Northwest where the women are strange, the men are odd-looking, and the children are all above suspicion. Lake Woebegon it ain't. ``Twin Peaks'' is not a place, it's a state of mind to which millions of Americans will return Sunday night for the season premiere of television's oddest nighttime drama. After eight episodes - just seven days in Twin Peaks time - we still don't know who killed Laura Palmer, the homecoming queen whose plastic-wrapped corpse fuels the series' central mystery. She is still dead. Maybe. Then there's wacky, cherry pie-gobbling FBI agent Dale Cooper (Kyle MacLachlan). He has declared he knows the killer's identity but, in the season finale, was laid low by an unknown assailant and three gunshots to the chest. There's more. One suspect in Laura's killing has been smothered by her father, another has been shot, there's been a heart attack, a drug overdose, a life-threatening fire, and a brothel-keeper has unknowingly hired his own daughter. As actor Michael Ontkean (Twin Peaks' doughty Sheriff Harry S. Truman) observed, the series is ``a Kabuki-style Peyton Place on peyote buttons.'' ABC says little about the two-hour, special ``ABC Sunday Night Movie,'' directed by David Lynch and written by Mark Frost, co-creators of the series: ``The investigation into the mysterious killing continues, sorrow settles over the community as several lives hang in the balance,'' ABC said, ``Audrey Horne finds herself a terrified prisoner, and Donna Hayward receives a strange message.'' This is a strange time for a strange series. It was conceived by Lynch, the high priest of cinematic anxiety (``Eraserhead,'' ``The Elephant Man,'' ``Dune,'' ``Blue Velvet'' and ``Wild at Heart'') and Frost, an established TV producer from ``Hill Street Blues.'' A midseason replacement, ``Twin Peaks'' was the year's most written-about show even before its April 8 debut won a 33 percent share of the TV audience. It quickly became the most talked-about show on television. ``We're just trying to reimagine the genre of the nighttime soap, in the way that `Hill Street Blues' did the cop show a decade ago,'' Frost said. But it was much more than that. Viewers got a sense of place in Twin Peaks, its geography and exteriors provided by the lovely town of Snoqualmie, Wash. The town was as placid as a forest pond where every droplet teems with violent, microscopic life. The critics loved the show's dreamlike, allusive imagery, the dazzling cinematography of Ron Garcia and the ethereal score of composer Angelo Badalamenti. Most of all they loved the townspeople, mordantly eccentric characters whose plots and subplots were cryptic to the point of inscrutability. Every conversation had meaning, every gesture was freighted with hidden significance, every scene charged with a sense that something dreadful was about to happen. The tension wasn't relieved, only punctuated by black comedy. There had never been anything like it on television. Even film critic Pauline Kael of The New Yorker magazine was hooked: ``It has both the insidious weirdness of of Lynch's best movie work and the weird insidiousness of top-of-the-line TV trash. ... Lynch sets us drifting through a vivid dream of American life.'' The New York Times adored ``Twin Peaks.'' ``Don't miss it,'' said one review. Its editorial page ventured that the series ``has been hailed as revolutionary TV. It has become, in any case, a phenomenon.'' Heady stuff, that. ``I killed Laura Palmer'' T-shirts appeared. Food writers devoted columns to cherry pie. On Fridays, the show's ardent fans would gather to analyze every clue and argue over meanings. Computer enthusiasts would bicker about the show on electronic bulletin boards. Ordinarily sensible people who wouldn't admit to watching ``thirtysomething'' became instant, babbling fans. Hailed as the television show of the '90s, ``Twin Peaks'' was everything except a hit. Its opening audience share of 33 percent quickly slumped when ``Twin Peaks'' went to its regular time slot Thursday nights against NBC's blockbuster ``Cheers.'' ``Twin Peaks'' gradually lost about half of its viewers. The season finale won its time period with a 12.6 rating and a 22 share, or about 9.7 million viewers. A ratings point represented 921,000 TV households, a share the percentage of all TV sets in use tuned to a given show. It finished the season with a respectable if unspectacular tie for 40th place, but ABC already had decided to renew the show. On Oct. 6 it moves to Saturday night with ``China Beach,'' the critically acclaimed Vietnam war series. ABC says both shows attract adult viewers ages 18 to 49, a demographic group prized by advertisers, about 40 million of whom tune in on Saturday nights. ABC's secret fear is that ``Twin Peaks'' will lose to rented videos. ``Twin Peaks'' fared poorly in the annual Emmy Awards, despite its 14 nominations, the most of any drama. It won only two technical awards. Daily Variety, the trade journal, blamed that on critics who ``may actually have done it a disservice, attaching expectations to it that it will be hard-pressed to meet.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... TWIN PEAKS SIDEBAR ALERT!!! - VH-1 presents a visually stylish documentary Saturday night on the collaboration of the ethereal ``Twin Peaks'' singer Julee Cruise, series composer Angelo Badalamenti and producer-director David Lynch. It features interviews with the principals, clips from ``Twin Peaks'' (but no clues to the series' mysteries) and excerpts from their performance piece ``Industrial Symphony No. 1.'' Diehard ``Peaks'' fans will not want to miss this. Put down that log, lady.

DOC.HEAD: Who Is Michael Milken?
DOC.TEXT: Is Michael Milken the selfless, quiet, conservative, religious, civic-minded, philanthropic father, husband and family man he is depicted in letters to the judge who will sentence him? Or is he the greedy, power-seeking, conspiratorial, corrupt, confessed criminal who systematically and fraudulently engaged in illegal payoffs and other acts to gain a fabulous income, as depicted by prosecutors? Hundreds of letters in support of Milken have been received by Judge Kimba Wood, leading a reader to wonder if Michael Milken is possessed of two utterly disparate personalities. That is only the beginning of the questions provoked by the letters, all written in an effort to convince Wood that Milken should be sentenced to less than the maximum term of 28 years, and instead be ordered to assist in community projects. The letters, whch describe a private person so unlike the public image of Milken, the confessed criminal, provide an unusual psychological case study of human behavior and perception. There are letters from attorneys, for instance, that emphasize Milken's personal values and contain nothing whatever about legal issues. There is praise from beneficiaries of Milken's charities, without reference to the possibility that the funds assigned to them were obtained illegally. There are business people suggesting that Milken's values are so unlike, and higher, than those of so many business people. And there are educators who tell of how Milken, by his personal example and effort, is a positive influence on the education of children. Daryl Gates, Los Angeles police chief, says he pursues a hard line against criminals. He suggests the court could consider Milken's financial expertise in arriving at a productive rather than solely punitive sentence. Los Angeles Archbishop Roger Mahony observes that his schools seek to instill decent values in the lives of young students. He asks that Milken be sentenced ``to enhanced community service'' rather than punished by jail. Richard Adler is a judge of the California Superior Court, but his letter to Judge Wood refers only to Milken's character and his ability as a mathematics teacher, including personal help he gave to the judge's son. Steven J. Ross, chairman of Time-Warner Inc., is widely known as a sharp, no-nonsense, hard-driving businessman. He writes that Milken ``is no Ivan Boesky or Martin Siegel, no Gordon Gekko, no yuppie, no wheeler and dealer.'' Instead, he says, Milken ``is a person of ideas and ideals,'' and ``strangely immaterialistic,'' a ``long-term thinker, not a quick-buck artist,'' a man who sometimes put client financial interests ahead of his own. The letters are almost invariably long, far longer, rambling, repetitive and anecdotal than ordinary business letters, but otherwise unsually well presented. Ross' letter is five typwritten pages, but others are twice that length. Almost all writers comment positively on an aspect of Milken's personality and way of life - his loyalty, concern, love of children, quiet family life, religious commitment, honesty, or devotion to people and causes. Themes reappearing throughout the file of letters are that bad things happen to good people, that the tragedy of human frailty can destroy otherwise strong human beings, and the belief that good deeds should mitigate penalties. Whatever is made of the letters now is likely to be magnified and examined in detail after the sentence is pronounced, and one question that will be asked over and over is whether the support of the big would ever be so available to the small.

DOC.HEAD: Mideast Kid's Books Show Arabs With Scars Fighting Israeli Rats
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers are drawn as dogs and Jewish settlers as rats toting rifles. As for the Arabs, they're depicted as having sinister mustaches and jagged scars across their cheeks. The drawings are not the work of political cartoonists on one side or other in the Arab-Israeli conflict. They are illustrations for children's books meant to entertain and teach Palestinian or Israeli youngsters. Professor Adir Cohen, author of a study of Herrew children's literature called ``An Ugly Face in the Mirror,'' says such books give birth to lifelong hatreds among Israelis and Palestinians. ``We learned from Freud how stories and fairytales enter our subconscious. ... It infiltrates to those places of the subconscious and comes up repeatedly,'' said Cohen, head of the education department at Haifa University. He described Arabs in Hebrew children's books as having ``a huge terrible mustache and scary eyes, the nose of an eagle ... a scar and a narrow forehead.'' ``We are talking about processes of dehumanization that are connected to the (Arab-Israeli) struggle, connected to defense and wars,'' he said. ``It is much easier to fight a roach.'' Cohen used as an example the typical detective stories for young boys - who in a few years will be soldiers - in which the Israeli hero battles Arab murderers, bandits or terrorists. In Avner Carmieli's ``The Young Detectives Settle in the Wild Negev,'' a young hero overcomes hundreds of Arabs, among them kings. He lines up his prisoners and strides up and down shouting: ``Left, left - faster Gamal, Abdul, Nasser! Straighten your backs Hussein and Faisel! Look front Nuri a-Said!'' The book goes on to explain how ``the kings and dictators and leaders marched forward quickly'' under his orders. The names used are typically Arab, but Gamal Abdul Nasser was also the late Egyptian president who was one of Israel's chief enemies. Many of the Hebrew books with such messages are aimed at boys in their pre-teens. Similar Arab literature is intended for even younger readers who in other societies might be reading about fairy princesses. In Nasser Abed Alaltif's ``The Flower Beauty Queen,'' Jewish settlers in the occupied West Bank are pictured as rats wielding rifles. Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin curls his dragon claws over an Arab village in Hamdan Yusef's ``The Sad Times of Deir Yassin.'' Khawla Abu Bakr, author of a study called ``The Political Socialization of Palestinian Children by Means of Arab Children's Literature,'' says West Bank children's books have as many stereotypes as Israeli works. ``The (Israeli) soldier is always depicted as a wolf, a chicken, an elephant, dogs,'' she said. ``Human figures are always seen as bureaucrats, inconsiderate officials, police who break arms or cruel soldiers.'' Abu Bakr, an Arab Israeli from the Jewish-Arab seaside town of Akko, defended the stereotypes of Israeli soldiers as a reflection of the Arab children's daily life. For example, she said, a story by Rawdeh Alhodhod called ``The Secret of the Red Devils In El Bire'' tells of Arab boys on a trip who are arrested after one of them throws a stone at an army jeep. Youngsters often have been at the forefront of the Palestinian uprising that began in December 1987. Thousands of youngsters have been arrested, and 158 Palestinian children aged 16 and under have died of Israeli army or civilian gunfire. Palestinian children's books also make references to the real world. The Deir Yassin mentioned in Hamdan Yusef's book was an Arab village where more than 200 Palestinian men, women and children were massacred by Jewish militiamen in 1948. Another feature of the Arab children's books is a clearly stated moral. The story of the arrested boys concludes: ``Our enemy is not the boy but the soldier. ... (The boy) is a hero and did nothing wrong to be punished for. You have to suffer and be a man.'' Cohen agreed that the intefadeh, or Palestinian uprising, enforces the message in the Palestinian books, but he noted many were published before the revolt. ``No doubt, had we known how to read this literature correctly years ago we would have seen how they were preparing for the intefadeh,'' he said. For his study, Cohen examined more than 500 Hebrew works and interviewed hundreds of Jewish children to determine the influence of the books. Abu Bakr studied 300 books written in Israel, the West Bank, Jordan, Lebanon and Egypt. Cohen said he hoped a new stream of Israeli children's literature stressing coexistence would gain in readership. But he added that adventure stories featuring Israeli heroes and wicked Arabs remain more popular. Abu Bakr said stories without stereotypes are too much to expect from an occupied people. She added that her favorite story was ``Hassan and the Monster'' by Taghred el Najer, which tells of a little boy who ignores villagers' warnings and climbs a mountain to meet the one-eyed, hairy monster who eats children. At the top, it's the monster who is frightened by the boy's strange appearance - his two eyes and fair skin. Boy and monster realize they can be friends, despite their differences and fears, and they walk off together into the sunset.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thursday AMs, Oct. 4

DOC.HEAD: GOING HOME: William Styron's Unfinished Business
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: --- ``Yesterday he had been happy, but this sorrow - descending upon him as it had the night before - seemed to have confounded him beyond all hope, since, for the first time in his life, he was unable to cut his trouble adrift, to shed it like some startling and unwelcome chrysalis ... '' - ``Lie Down in Darkness.'' ---

Late afternoon. William Styron looks tired, slouched in a chair in his hotel room, his tie and jacket lying on the bed. The air is hot and musty and the curtains are almost completely drawn, blocking out the sun of a crisp September day. The author is making a two-day trip to New York to promote ``Darkness Visible: A Memoir of Madness,'' a brief chronicle of his near-suicidal bout with depression, and eventual recovery. The night before, he appeared in a packed Manhattan auditorium at the 92nd St. Y Poetry Center, reading one passage from his new book and another from a novel in progress. He seemed comfortable discussing his problems and expressed delight that his book had temporarily knocked Donald Trump's latest opus from the top of best-seller lists; the audience responded enthusiastically. But Styron was also anxious to finish, agreeing to a mere five to six minutes of questions and checking his watch to make sure that limit was not broken. At his hotel room, the author is again checking his watch. He seems edgy, distracted, noting periodically he has to leave the hotel at 5:15 p.m. sharp; that evening Vanity Fair is holding a reception in his honor at the Century Club. His original article on depression had first appeared in the magazine. --- ``I barely realized it but I was in a deep crisis. I actually had ached so intensely over this wicked, this monstrous disappoinment - this betrayal! - that a kind of quivering St. Vitus' dance had begun to possess my limbs. ... I was suffering from an anxiety attack which each one of my psychic monitors had begun to regard gravely, flashing alerts all through my flesh.'' - ``Sophie's Choice.'' --- ``Darkness Visible'' begins with a trip to Paris in the fall of 1985 when Styron realized his emotional difficulties of the past several months ``might have a fatal outcome.'' He soon broke down completely, unable to sleep or drive or write and barely capable of speaking. Alcohol nauseated him (in the book he admits to a history of heavy drinking and at the reading he said he still enjoys a glass of wine), and the author was seized by uncontrollable fits of anxiety. Anti-depressant medication prescribed by a psychiatrist only worsened his condition. By early December he was ready to kill himself - he couldn't even write a suicide note - but ``drew upon some last gleam of sanity'' and checked into a hospital instead, recuperating after a seven-week stay. ``I haven't had any real afteraffects for a long, long time,'' Styron insisted during the interview. ``It's over. I've tried to make a point about it. Once it's over, it's over. Once people get well, they're restored to the way they were before.'' Other writers have suffered from depression including F. Scott Fitzgerald and Sylvia Plath. Leo Tolstoy's midlife crisis led him to become a devout Christian. Philip Roth writes about his problems in ``Zuckerman Unbound'' and ``The Counterlife,'' and Camus' novel, ``The Fall,'' is a monologue by a depressed lawyer. William James in ``The Varieties of Religious Experience'' says, ``It is a positive and active anguish, a sort of physical neuralgia wholly unknown to normal life.'' Styron, 65, could easily pass for a senator or a head of state. He is stocky and broad-shouldered, with a wide forehead, jowls, nearly white hair and narrow eyes, pinched at the edges. His speech is fluid, polished, the vowels clipped, the timbre rich. He is a man who likes to get things finished, done with. A native of Newport News, Va., he knew in his late teens he wanted to be a writer and was impatient to get his first book published. That came in 1951 with ``Lie Down in Darkness,'' a sprawling novel influenced by William Faulkner and centered, ironically, on a young woman's suicide. Styron has since become one of the most honored writers of the past 40 years, winner in 1967 of the Pulitzer Prize for ``The Confessions of Nat Turner'' and the American Book Award in 1979 for ``Sophie's Choice,'' which included a double suicide. But there has also been this nagging sense of unfinished business. It started at age 13, the author said, with the death of his mother. He became a ``hell raiser'' as a child, admitting now he should have properly expressed his grief, allowed it to work its way through his system. If there were any guilty feelings about his mother, Styron did have a chance to make amends at an early age. He served as a lieutenant in the Marines during World War II and in 1945 was stationed in Okinawa. He was to take part in the invasion of Japan and didn't expect to come out alive. The invasion never occurred; the United States dropped the atom bomb instead. ``Some of my problems I think came from a continuing anguish over my mother's death and if I had gotten shot it would have been, I suppose, some kind of completion. It's hard to say how that would have worked out,'' said Styron, who lives in Connecticut with his wife. They have four children. ``When I was a young Marine platoon leader, there was this incredible sense of fate. The myth at that age is you're going to live forever. Well, I never believed that and my friends didn't. I thought I was going to die.'' Styron insists ``go with the flow'' is now his philosophy. ``The world will roll merrily on without me if I stop writing,'' he says. There are regrets about not having written ``Richard III,'' but the author still looks back on a ``respectable'' body of work and considers ``Darkness Visible'' a fitting way to put his troubles behind him. ``One thing you do learn is that you're really at the whim of forces beyond your control,'' he said. ``Most people think mental health is something they're invulnerable to. They go through life thinking it's something that happens to other people.'' When the interview ends, Styron puts on his jacket, moves over to the bed and sits for his picture to be taken, his wrist turning for another look at the watch. It's 5:05 p.m. He doesn't shake hands, but shyly lowers his face and mumbles goodbye, perhaps thinking about the evening ahead - or simply looking forward to finishing this trip and going home. --- ``The grief is coming now, she said to herself: He's beginning to know what suffering is. ... Perhaps that's good for a man - finally to know what suffering is, to know what a woman somehow knows from the day she was born.'' - William Styron, ``Lie Down in Darkness.'' ---
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Oct. 7

DOC.HEAD: Current GATT Talks Help Shape Common Market Future
DOC.TEXT: Whatever results from the ongoing multinational trade talks in Geneva will help set the tone for the European Community's new togetherness in 1992. If the talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade wind up on a liberalized note of international cooperation and good will, the mood could prevail after the 12-nation EC further integrates itself two years from now. At least that's the rough idea being tossed around by some Agriculture Department analysts looking at the 1992 plan shaping up to make the EC truly a common market in Europe. The current GATT talks, the so-called Uruguay Round of negotiations, are scheduled to conclude at the end of this year. In many respects, the negotiations have been a snarling confrontation between the United States, which wants to phase out export subsidies and a bundle of other protectionist policies, and the EC, which prefers less drastic remedies. Walter Gardiner of the department's Economic Research Service says there has been a mixed reaction among Americans to Europe's unification plan designed to make the bloc a true ``common market'' by the end of 1992. Many believe the EC will be an even more powerful bloc that will mean greater competition for U.S. goods and services in Europe and in foreign markets generally. ``The label `Fortress Europe' has been used by a number of U.S. and other non-EC officials to describe the potential market and investment environment that could emerge'' if non-member countries don't pay close attention to developments, Gardiner said. Basically, he said, the plan is to ``remove all existing internal barriers to the free movement of goods, services, people and capital.'' That, Gardiner said, was what the community's founders had in mind 33 years ago. Gardiner's analysis was described in the October issue of Farmline magazine and in a paper published last summer by him and two other economists, Steve Neff and David Kelch. Despite the hundreds of directives involved in developing the 1992 plan, there are no provisions for liberalizing any of the EC's external trade barriers - the ones that affect the United States and other trading partners. Any progress on that front will depend on the outcome of the GATT talks in Geneva. ``However, the adjustments to investment, production, consumption and trade patterns within the EC in response to the large number of 1992 directives will be felt far beyond the EC's borders,'' Gardiner said. There will be greater opportunities for those able to compete in a deregulated EC economy, particularly those firms already doing business there and who are making the necessary changes in anticipation of 1992, he said. ``For companies such as equipment manufacturers that are required to build as many as eight production lines for tractors because of different regulations in EC countries, any harmonization should be a welcome development,'' he said. Also, eliminating customs regulations at borders within the EC should reduce significantly the cost of transporting goods within the community, he said. But as of now, there are no clear indications whether the EC will adopt standards and regulations more restrictive than those now in place, or whether the EC may raise new barriers against the goods of non-member countries. Gardiner said the EC and the United States ``share a number of important economic relationships'' that indicate a high degree of mutual dependence. For openers, he said, the United States and the EC are the world's two leading economic blocs, accounting for about one-half of the world's gross domestic product (GDP) and merchandise trade. The GDP is the total of a country's goods and services. The United States is also a major EC investor, with $128.5 billion invested directly in 1988, or 39 percent of total U.S. foreign investment. That represents a vast increase over the $20.1 billion invested in 1970, which was 27 percent of total U.S. foreign investment at the time. Also, he said, ``The United States and the EC are each other's largest trading partners, with two-way trade totaling $160.9 billion in 1988. U.S. mercandise exports to the EC have risen sixfold, from $12.3 billion in 1970 to $75.9 billion in 1988.'' In the same period, U.S. imports from the EC rose nearly ninefold, from $9.7 billion to $85 billion. Agricultural trade is an important part of this trade, although there were large fluctuations in the 1980s, Gardiner said. U.S. agricultural sales totaled $2.3 billion in 1970, peaked at $11 billion in 1980 and then plummeted to $6.5 billion by 1985. ``With the weakening of the dollar relative to European currencies near the end of 1985, farm exports began to recover slightly in 1986, rising to $7.3 billion by 1988, but amounting to only two-thirds of the record level set in 1980,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Sept. 30

DOC.HEAD: Heads of State Gather at UN To Make Children a Worldwide Priority
An AP Photo Package
DOC.TEXT: From Manila to Managua, from the Bronx to Brazil, the littlest victims of poverty, disease and war suffer silently, but their eyes tell the story. It is a litany of despair, of hunger and homelessness and hopelessness. Every day somewhere in the world, 40,000 children die. Most succumb to preventable diseases like measles and diarrhea. The rest are victims of abuse, neglect, poverty, starvation and war. Amnesty International recently reported that police in Brazil and Guatemala torture and summarily execute street children. Hundreds of Iraqi children have been tortured or murdered by Saddam Hussein's government. In Liberia, the government and its opponents have killed or mutilated thousands of children. During states of emergency in South Africa, an estimated 10,000 children were detained without charge or trial, some for as long as a year. Millions of children in developing countries die each year from diarrhea. By the year 2000, at least 10 million children will be infected with the AIDS virus and another 10 million will by orphaned by the fatal disease, the World Health Organization estimates. As the problem has intensified, so has the call for action. Some 70 heads of state, including President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, gather at the United Nations in New York this weekend to adopt a declaration making children one of their highest national priorities. The Convention on the Rights of the Child calls for, among other things, a one-third reduction in infant mortality by the end of the decade; access to family planning for all couples and prenatal care for all women; and immunization of 90 percent of children against childhood diseases. In the United States, which has one of the worst infant mortality and immunization rates among industrialized countries in the world, about 40,000 children die each year before their first birthdays. Last year, 2.4 million children were reported as suspected victims of child abuse or neglect; about 400,000 of those had been sexually abused. One of every five U.S. children lives in poverty. About 10 million have no health insurance. Every night, an estimated 100,000 American children go to sleep homeless.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Sept. 29-30

DOC.HEAD: CENSORSHIP: The Dark Sheep of the American Family
DOC.NOTE: Eds: note contents of 16th graf
DOC.TEXT: --- ``If censorship reigns there cannot be sincere flattery, and only small men are afraid of small writings.'' - Pierre de Beaumarchais, ``Le Mariage de Figaro'' (1784).
``The proof of a poet is that his country absorb him as affectionately as he has absorbed it.'' - Walt Whitman, ``Leaves of Grass'' (1855). ---

In the 200th year since the birth of the First Amendment, the winds of censorship are gusting stronger than ever. This could be called the year of the censor. Federal support of arts projects deemed obscene has been threatened; record store owners face fines and possible arrest for selling LPs containing lyrics or artwork dubbed obscene; a rash of movies have been slapped with the dreaded X rating; and a museum is going on trial for obscenity - an American first. Already, the film industry is adjusting. The X rating was eliminated Wednesday by the Motion Picture Association of America, which substituted a new NC-17 rating that bars children altogether but does not carry the stigma of the X. Throughout the history of the United States, censorship in one form or another - political, religious, moral or military - has stalked literature, dance, opera, film, music and art. This, the land of the fruited plain, home of the brave and citadel of free speech, banned Walt Whitman's ``Leaves of Grass,'' took the wiggle out of Mae West's walk, cut the moaning from Ray Charles' ``What'd I Say,'' burned James Joyce's ``Ulysses,'' put Lenny Bruce in jail and kept Isadora Duncan from dancing. Now the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati and its director, Dennis Barrie, face misdemeanor charges of pandering obscenity and displaying nude photos of children in an exhibit of photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, a homosexual who died of AIDS last year. Jury selection in a county court began last week. A Mapplethorpe exhibit last June at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington was canceled after Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., declared some of the artist's photographs to be obscene. Helms' objections resulted in a move by Congress to limit federal funds to the arts. ``I wasn't starting out to make a statement, that isn't the way I work,'' Mapplethorpe once said. ``The statement grows out of what I do.'' In 1979's ``Easter Lilies With Mirror,'' Mapplethorpe uses four panels to form a cross around a center mirror. The lilies are shown in dramatic shadows, a dusting of light illuminating their inner and almost religious beauty. It is a way of engaging the viewer beyond mere voyeurism; the viewer becomes a part of the work. But other works are disturbing, unraveling a violent homosexual mystique for an unsuspecting audience. They are terrifying, sadomasochistic tableaux - chained men, leather-bound men, men prepared for pain in an aristocratic setting, anal sex games, urination. Mapplethorpe's defenders cite the First Amendment, which says that Congress ``shall make no law ... abridging the freedom or speech, or the press. ...'' But courts have issued opinions back and forth since 1791. In 1957, the U.S. Supreme Court gave its first ruling on a definition of obscenity saying it could not be protected by the First Amendment. Justice William Brennan, however, added: ``The portrayal of sex, e.g., in art, literature and scientific works, is not sufficient reason to deny material the constitutional protection of freedom of speech and press.'' In 1973, the high court agreed to a new set of rules for states to determine what was obscene. States could enact laws banning artistic works if they portrayed sex ``in a patently offensive way, and which taken as a whole, do not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value.'' In June, a U.S. District Court judge ruled that the rap group 2 Live Crew's LP, ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' which speaks graphically about sexual violence towards women, was obscene. Plays and playwrights have faced censorship in America: - In a Boston production of Edward Albee's ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?,'' the character Martha bellowed at her husband, ``Jesus Christ, you're trying to hump the hostess.'' City censors forced the playwright to change the line because it ``took the Lord's name in vain.'' Said Martha in the rewritten version, ``Mary Magdalene, you're trying to hump the hostess.'' - The muted nudity in the Broadway smash ``Hair'' was challenged in New York by a group of clergymen in 1968. - ``Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All for You'' incurred the wrath of Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn when it ran there in 1984 because it discussed abortion and homosexuality. Music, too, has had its romp with censors. Elvis the Pelvis had to be shot from the waist up when he appeared on ``The Ed Sullivan Show'' in 1956 so Americans wouldn't be offended by those gyrating hips that helped make Presley famous. A decade later, Sullivan made the Rolling Stones change the lyrics to their song, ``Let's Spend the Night Together.'' They sang, ``Let's spend some time together'' instead. In 1967, Van Morrison had a hit with ``Brown-Eyed Girl,'' which contained the line ``making love in the green grass.'' An alternate version had to be made for objecting radio stations. Radio stations also demanded an alternate version to Lloyd Price's ``Stagger Lee'': In one, two men have a fight playing cards and one shoots the other; in the cleaned-up version, the men argue but patch it up and ``are sore no more.'' Jimi Hendrix had to take the naked women off his ``Electric Ladyland'' LP about 20 years ago, and in 1968, the Stones were forced to part with the graffiti-filled bathroom stall on ``Beggars Banquet'' LP.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

For Release Sunday, Sept. 30, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: Banquet'' LP.
DOC.TEXT: But in no area has censorship so inflamed a passionate public as in literature. According to the postmaster general of the United States in 1959, ``Lady Chatterley's Lover'' was ``an obscene and filthy work'' that could not be sent through the mail. The ban was lifted a year later. The post office burned 500 copies of ``Ulysses'' in New York in 1922, and the book, considered a literary masterpiece, was banned until 1933. The novel, much of it written in stream of conciousness, ripples with sex and sensuality: ``... and then I asked him with my eyes to ask again yes and then he asked me would I yes to say yes my mountain flower and first I put my arms around him yes and drew him down to me so he could feel my breasts all perfume yes and his heart was going like mad and yes I said yes I will Yes.'' Henry Miller's ``Tropic of Cancer'' and all of his other works were banned in the United States until 1961. Theodore Dreiser's ``An American Tragedy'' was kept off the shelves in Massachusetts. ``The Diary of Anne Frank,'' ``The Wizard of Oz'' and works by Mark Twain and Stephen King have at one time or another been removed from libraries. Movies also have been a target. As early as 1897, moralists railed against anything remotely suggesting sex. Some movie theater owners put white stripes across the screen when showing ``Fatima,'' a reel featuring a fully clothed dancer wiggling her hips and shaking her breasts. There were censorship drives by clergymen to tell the public what they should and should not see. And in 1922, Hollywood decided to censor itself and made President Harding's campaign manager, Will H. Hays, the head of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America. He reigned for 25 years until the current ratings system came into being. The Hays Office initially held up ``Gone With the Wind'' because of Clark Gable's famous exit line, ``Frankly, my dear, I don't give a damn.'' As late as 1953, Otto Preminger's ``The Moon Is Blue'' earned a Production Code ban for using such naughty words as ``virgin'' and ``mistress.'' Other terrible words appeared in ``Anatomy of a Murder,'' such as ``contraception.'' And in 1988, Martin Scorsese's ``The Last Temptation of Christ'' was called ``blasphemy'' by religious leaders. More recently, a rash of movies has earned the now defunct X rating, including Pedro Almodovar's ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' Filmmakers hope the new rating will carry none of the advertising and exhibition restraints of the X rating, which had become synonymous with hard-core pornography and served no purpose in evaluating artistic films best suited for adults. ``It's a great step,'' said Philip Kaufman, director of the X-rated Universal Pictures film ``Henry & June.'' The historical drama, which features some explicit sex, was set for a ratings appeal next week and will be the first recipient of the new NC rating, which would bar children under age 17. ``I'm just really delighted that we can show this film uncut in America and show the film the way I made it,'' Kaufman said. ``It is not intended as a prurient film.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Dolores Barclay has been arts and entertainment editor for The Associated Press for 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Court Begins Term With Wealth of Controversial Cases
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court begins its 1990-91 term Monday with disputes looming over abortion counseling, fetal protection, school desegregation and the war on drugs. There will also be a new face on the court this term - David H. Souter. Among the cases to be heard this week, without Souter, are an important desegregation battle from Oklahoma City and a big-money showdown over punitive-damage awards. President Bush picked the conservative Souter, a federal judge from New Hampshire, as the 105th member of the high court, replacing its longtime liberal leader, Justice William J. Brennan. ``We see troubled times,'' said John Powell, chief lawyer of the American Civil Liberties Union, in assessing the coming term. ``The court has shown a willingness to reconsider and cut back hard-won victories we thought were long over.'' Souter, whose vote is seen as pivotal in abortion, affirmative action and church-state relations cases, could pad Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist's working conservative majority. Souter's nomination was endorsed Thursday by the Senate Judiciary Committee and sent to the full chamber for confirmation. Abortion rights advocates who oppose his selection said Souter, if given the chance, would provide the critical fifth vote to overturn the court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision, which legalized abortion. ``His adamant refusal'' in his Senate confirmation hearings ``to be candid in the area of privacy and abortion can do nothing but create the very reasonable and strong inference that he is prepared to jettison established law,'' said Helen Neuborne of the National Organization for Women's Legal Defense and Education Fund. Under Supreme Court practice, Souter would not be able to participate in cases argued before he joined the court. If the justices find themselves split 4-4 on such a case, they could order it reargued later in the nine-month term to let Souter cast the deciding vote. The court already has agreed to decide 54 cases by July, when its term will end, and probably will add 70 to 80 more in the coming weeks. The first cluster will be added Monday, when the justices are expected to issue orders in more than 1,000 appeals. The vast majority will be rejected but some will be granted review by the court. In one of its most closely watched cases, the justices must decide whether federal regulations violate free-speech rights by barring government-financed family planning clinics from offering abortion counseling. At stake is the future scope of a $200 million-a-year federal program that finances more than 4,000 clinics serving some 5 million low-income women. The family planning program, enacted by Congress as Title X of the Public Health Service Act, forbids clinics from using federal funds to perform abortions, although it originally let clinic staffs tell women about the abortion option. But the Reagan administration in 1988 issued regulations that say clinics receiving federal support may not ``encourage, promote or advocate abortion as a method of family planning'' or even distribute written materials on abortion. If a woman visiting such a clinic asks about abortion, the regulations tell doctors and counselors to say the program ``does not consider abortion an appropriate method of family planning'' and to offer help in obtaining prenatal care. The Senate last week voted to amend Title X to nullify the regulations against abortion counseling. If the Senate action becomes law, the court challenge of the regulations will become meaningless. In a case that could affect millions of working women, the court is reviewing an employer's policy of excluding all women of childbearing age from some hazardous jobs. A fetal-protection policy used by Johnson Controls, a Milwaukee-based battery manufacturer, bans women who cannot prove they are infertile from jobs that expose them to lead. The policy is being attacked as a form of illegal sex discrimination. Among those who sued were a 50-year-old divorcee and a woman who submitted to sterilization to preserve her job. A federal appeals court upheld the policy by a 7-4 vote, but one dissenting judge said 20 million industrial jobs may be closed to women because ``many substances in addition to lead pose fetal risks.'' The Oklahoma City desegregation case asks whether school districts may abandon mandatory busing and other court-ordered plans after achieving racial balance in student populations. Hundreds of school districts, including those in most major cities, operate court-ordered desegregation plans. Only a few have persuaded courts to declare their once-segregated systems fully integrated. Nevertheless, the potential impact of the court's ruling is great. Critics say letting students attend neighborhood schools will result in ``resegregation.'' The court will confront one aspect of the war on drugs when it reviews a Michigan law that imposes mandatory life sentences without possibility of parole for people, even first-time offenders, convicted of possessing certain amounts of drugs. A man convicted of possessing 23 ounces of cocaine and given such a sentence says he received ``cruel and unusual punishment.'' His lawyers note that convictions for second-degree murder and other violent crimes do not carry such stiff sentences. The justices were told that Michigan is the only state that imposes such a mandatory sentence. If the law is upheld, other states might follow Michigan's lead. Here, in summary form, are some of the other cases the court is to decide this term:

-Whether skyrocketing awards in personal-injury lawsuits and other cases designed to punish and deter wrongdoing can go so high they become inherently unfair. The court's decision in an insurance fraud case from Alabama could be of enormous importance to American business and consumers.

-Whether a condemned killer who lost his sanity while on death row is being subjected to ``cruel and unusual punishment'' by Louisiana officials who are giving him mind-altering drugs in an attempt to make him sane enough to grasp that his execution is a punishment for his crime. -Whether states may house condemned killers on death rows and keep them apart from other prison inmates. A Nebraska inmate says such segregation is unconstitutional. -Whether prosecutors who exclude blacks as jurors because of their race violate the rights of white defendants. An Ohio court said a 1986 Supreme Court decision barring exclusion of black potential jurors applies only when the defendants are black.

-Whether nonunion public employees may withhold financial support from unions that represent them because some of the money they contribute is used for activities unrelated to collective bargaining. A federal appeals court ruled in a Michigan case that public employee unions must be given more spending leeway than those in private industry. -Whether the secretary of labor or a safety and health review board has the last word on what is required by federal regulations for on-the-job safety.

DOC.BYLINE: Before Long, U.S.-Certified Organic Food Coming to Market ^By CHARLES CAMPBELL
DOC.TEXT: The poster on Christine and Dale Johnson's kitchen wall reads, ``Our Veggies Don't Do Drugs.'' A jar on the kitchen table holds wasp eggs, future natural predators to be used instead of pesticides against the tomato hornworm - ``a nasty critter, a voracious eater,'' said Mrs. Johnson. The Johnsons run an organic farm, growing peppers, squash, kale, cherry tomatoes, eggplant, lettuce and other produce on their 65 acres on the eastern shore of Chesapeake Bay. Many people tell opinion surveys they are willing to pay more for organic food, grown without synthetic fertilizers, pesticides or insecticides. But growers, retailers, consumer groups and environmentalists say the organic food industry has been handicapped by the lack of consistent national standards to answer the question: What is organic food? ``I think the consumer has the right to the assurance that the organic label means something,'' Mrs. Johnson said. ``The consumer can often be deceived, possibly pay more for a product that's no better than another.'' Twenty-two states have regulations defining organic farming. They all follow the same basic idea, but no two are identical. In other states organic farms are certified by private organizations, applying their own standards. ``Organic agriculture is a funny word. Organic by definition in Webster's would just be carbon-based,'' said Joseph Dunsmoor, founder of the organic food distributor Organic Farms in Beltsville, Md. ``You can say organic agriculture means you don't use farm chemicals. It's a whole lot more than that.'' But what? This year Congress is taking a stab at an answer. The House and Senate both approved programs for nationwide organic farming standards as part of the 1990 farm bill. The conference committee that will resolve differences between the two bills is waiting for a budget deal so it knows how much money has to be cut from farm support programs, but the organic provisions are expected to survive. ``Organically produced food defies simple definition,'' the Senate Agriculture Committee said when it adopted its version. So a complicated definition was offered. ``Organic food is food produced using sustainable production methods that rely primarily on natural materials,'' the committee began. There are exceptions - some synthetic chemicals traditionally accepted in organic farming, and a few natural substances so toxic they are banned. Those exceptions are to be spelled out in a list drawn up by a National Organic Standards Board, to be made up of organic farmers, wholesalers and retailers, consumer representatives and environmentalists. Rules for raising organic meat and poultry are even more confusing than for vegetables. It's left to the standards board to figure out what livestock medications, vaccines and parasiticides are to be legal for organic farmers. Within two years, shoppers should be seeing U.S. government-certified organic chickens, tomatoes and bell peppers in the stores. The legislation allows for state and private organizations to do the inspection and certification, so long as they follow the national standards. States also would be permitted to enact stricter standards, if they wished, but could not block imports of nationally certified organic food from other states. The organic farming provisions were backed vigorously by lobbyists from environmental groups, who say overuse of chemical pesticides, fungicides and fertilizers is polluting streams and endangering farm workers. Chemical manufacturers reject any suggestion their products are unsafe, but approve the idea of nationwide standards for organic agriculture, said Christopher Klose, spokesman for the National Agricultural Chemicals Association. The small but growing organic farm industry also supported the plan for nationwide standards and labeling. ``For both the consumer and the grower, there are going to be multiple benefits. It makes marketing much easier,'' said Marty Rice, co-director of the Maryland Organic Food and Farming Association, which was founded last year. Dale Johnson, driving boxes of organic kale in from his fields in a white pickup, said he hoped the government-approved organic labels will boost the market for organic foods. ``People say they want it and are willing to pay more for it, but that hasn't translated into a bigger market on the East Coast,'' he said. Supermarkets, however, report falling interest in organic foods. ``A lot of consumers will buy it one time for the novelty, but the repeat sales don't seem to be there,'' said Nancy Yanish, director of agricultural relations for the Food Marking Institute in Washington. ``If consumers want it, supermarkets will be glad to sell it.'' Two major grocery chains in the Washington area, Giant and Safeway, once had organic produce sections in some of their stores. Both dropped the idea in the past year after disappointing sales. The trade weekly Supermarket News reported similar experiences nationwide, asking in an article last May, ``Is organic produce withering on the vine?'' Organic farm organizations, however, report their production up by as much as 40 percent over last year. Stores specializing in natural and organic foods seem to be doing fairly well, even if organic sales in regular supermarkets are slumping. ``In the last five years we've gone from a fad to a clear market niche,'' said Bob Scowcroft, executive director of the California Certified Organic Farmers. ``The establishment of national standards will allow our growers to compete fairly in all 50 states.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-What's Organic?
Sustainable Agriculture: Using Only the Chemicals You Really, Really Need
DOC.TEXT: Somewhere between smaller chemical-free organic farms and giant corporate cultivators that use tons of pesticides a year is an idea that's getting a lot of attention. The professionals call it low-input sustainable agriculture. What it means is using only the chemicals you really need. In general, organic farming requires total abstinence from chemical fertilizers or pest control. Sustainable agriculture provides a way to cut back on chemicals through better soil monitoring technology, mechanical weed control, crop rotation and what's known as integrated pest management. Sound reasonable? Some parts of the agriculture industry are being dragged along kicking and screaming. They say that thanks to fertilizers and pesticides, a single acre can produce several times the crops of the same acre 40 years ago. Furthermore, say farmers interviewed by investigators for Congress' General Accounting Office, the government's subsidy programs discourage the sustainable approach by linking payments to certain crop yields that require chemicals to be maintained. This means that unless the law is changed, farmers will continue to push for high production of cotton, soybeans, corn and wheat year after year, even though these crops are associated with soil erosion and the chemicals used on them are damaging ground water in some states. ``We must encourage farmers to combine responsible stewardship of natural resources with farm profitability,'' Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, said during debate on the 1990 farm bill, ``but we cannot ignore the bottom line in agriculture any more than you can ignore the bottom line in any business.'' Grassley tried unsuccessfully to change language in the 1990 farm bill calling for reduced chemical use. The Senate bill approved July 27 authorizes $40 million a year to pursue sustainable agriculture programs, provide material to farmers who want to learn more about the methods and requires extension agents to take courses so they can teach farmers about it. And new provisions allow for slightly more crop rotation. The House bill, approved Aug. 1, has similar language. Jay Vroom, president of the National Agricultural Chemicals Association, said his organization is not opposed to sustainable agriculture. ``We are part of the mix,'' said Vroom. ``We don't think farmers should just use our products without looking for other things.'' Garth Youngberg, director of the Institute for Alternative Agriculture, says farmers eventually will have little choice but to pursue sustainable methods. ``We no longer can concentrate solely on producing more,'' he said. ``We didn't have data on ground water 10 years ago. We have a lot of that now. It's getting to the point where people see that we really have a problem here.''
