DOC.HEAD: Ron Brown: Looking for Ways To Pick a Democrat Who'll Win in 1992
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: One quiet step at a time, the Democratic Party chairman has been trying to tailor presidential nominating rules that might just fit a winner for a change. Now he envisions an old-fashioned new look in 1992, one in which he and other party leaders would screen the candidate field, coaxing strong Democrats in and, perhaps, urging divisive ones out. It is ``a role with some risk,'' said Democratic National Chairman Ronald H. Brown, understating the case. It also is a role reversal, since Brown's last candidate client was Jesse Jackson, in 1988, when he helped negotiate party rules that went in the opposite direction. Actually, the turnabout may give him options his predecessors didn't have. As the first black chairman of a national party, and a 1988 Jackson manager, Brown can hardly be accused of trying to rig the system against Jackson now that he seeks ``a major role in trying to shape the process...'' in 1992. ``I think you've got to do it in concert with Democratic members of the House and Senate, and governors, and old hands at politics in this country,'' Brown said in an interview. ``I think, frankly, maybe some major financial supporters of candidates may have to be involved.'' To political veterans, that sounds familiar. That's the way it used to be done before the Democrats overhauled their process in the name of reform, and took away the clout of the political professionals. In the 20 years since, they've lost four out of five presidential elections. That's not all due to the system; as Brown said, ``there are a lot of reasons that are not related to the process at all.'' But it hasn't helped. Before reform, the presidntial primaries were a testing ground, in which presidential candidates would try to show their strength far from home, to show party leaders and delegates that they could be November winners. Now the primaries are the arena in which nominees are chosen; there were 36 of them in 1988. That preliminary competition tends to force candidates toward the left, and to lock them into positions that can be liabilities in the final campaign for the White House. Democratic rules also tend to keep candidates in the race. Because nominating delegates must be assigned in proportion to primary election showings, losers get their weekly share and an early decision on the nominee is almost impossible to gain. ``What I'd like to do ... is get a consensus candidate early in the process and start running against George Bush rather than against each other,'' Brown said. Brown said he doesn't want to go back to the smoke-filled room, but he does want pragmatic, common-sense politics. Those have not been Democratic hallmarks. They weren't showing in Atlanta in 1988, when the winner, Michael Dukakis, agreed to rules concessions for 1992 in order to gain the backing of the loser, Jackson. Brown, as Jackson's convention manager, helped fashion that unity pact. Brown, as party chairman, has changed much of it. The Democrats had set aside a bloc of convention seats, and therefore nominating votes, for elected officials and party leaders, free of commitments to any candidate. That reserved some muscle for the old guard. At Jackson's behest, the number of uncommitted super-delegates was to have been cut next time. He wanted more power in the primaries, and he also wanted something close to pure proportional representation, without the requirement that a candidate get 15 percent of a state's votes to win any of its delegates. A year ago, the Democratic National Committee voted to seat a full roster of 303 super-delegates at the 1992 convention, and reinforced the 15 percent threshold for candidates to gain primary election delegates. Meeting this month, the committee added another 80 appointed delegates for 1992. That's been done without controversy. The steps Brown now envisions are an invitation to controversy, and he knows it. People who think they ought to be president are not inclined to leave the field quietly because party leaders tell them to, or suggest to their supporters and donors that it's time to quit. They're more likely to start protesting that kingmakers and bosses are trying to force them out. ``You would have to do it very carefully,'' Brown said. ``...We still have a caucus and primary system where the voters are the final arbiters. This is not going to be a ham-handed approach.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Try To Teach Computers To Read
DOC.TEXT: While computer scientists consider ways to make Americans more computer literate, a university professor is trying to make America's computers literate. Teaching computers to read involves teaching them to ``think'' like humans - by learning from experience and making educated guesses. But what most people learn easily at age 6 is proving far more difficult for computers. Humans ``don't just do character recognition. We don't just look at one thing,'' said Sargur Srihari, a professor at the State University of New York's Buffalo campus. ``It's going to be many, many years before computers can read documents such as handwritten letters.'' For now, Srihari and his team of about 30 assistants would be satisfied if the computer could read the addresses on the envelopes those letters came in. So would the Postal Service, which is supporting their project with a $2.1 million grant. The central post office in Buffalo, for example, must sort up to 3.3 million pieces of mail a night. Its existing equipment could process up to 42,000 letters an hour - if the addresses were perfectly printed. But those machines reject more than 30 percent of the mail as unreadable, said Dennis Wnuk, a postal operations officer in Buffalo. ``Primarily, what our optical character readers can read is business-type mail, preprinted mail,'' Wnuk said. ``The average piece of mail that a residential customer will put into a collection box, we'll only read about 25 percent of those - and that's only if he prints very well or happens to have a typewriter.'' Business mail is also a problem if it comes in a gaudily printed envelope, if the address is too high, or if it is folded so that part of the letter shows through the window along with the address, said John Gullo, an automation and readability specialist at the post office. ``People who use printers, they don't like to change the ribbon because they want to get every last address out of the ribbon. That gives us trouble,'' he said. The first major problem facing Srihari's team is to find the address itself - simple for humans, but bewildering for computers that must separate the address from the ``noise'' on such things as magazine covers and junk-mail envelopes. The SUNY computer zeroes in on text blocks with the proper shape - those with lines flush to the left, for example - and has already achieved a 90 percent success rate. Next, the computer must figure out as much of the written address as possible. To recognize a `2,' for example, a computer could be taught to look for ends in the top center and lower right, a curve in the upper right and a sharp `V' bend in the lower left, said Alan Commike, a graduate student who is handling the number-recognition aspect of the project. The problem is that there are so many different ways to write numerals that 130 of those rules are needed to sort them all out. ``There are twos with holes,'' or loops instead of points, Commike said. ``There are fives with hats, fives without hats. There are British sevens and American sevens.'' The next step is to teach the computer to make educated guesses to fill in unreadable blanks. For example, if the street address is not entirely legible, the computer narrows it to a few possibilities by matching the part it can read against a list of all strees and numbers in that particular ZIP code. ``This is what is called using contextual information . . . bringing knowledge to bear, which is what people do,'' Srihari said. Srihari's computers can now read about 75 percent of handwritten ZIP codes; current postal equipment can read only about 5 percent of them. But the new process is painfully slow - up to a minute for each piece of mail. Speeding it up will require specially designed hardware, and is 18 months or more away, he said. The researchers are testing their equipment with the real thing. ``We had a team of undergraduates working nights in the Buffalo post office,'' Srihari said. ``We didn't delay anybody's mail. We just took it for a few minutes, captured it and put it in our database.'' Eventually, Srihari said, the technology will have a variety of applications. For example, a busy newspaper reader could feed his paper into the computer, which would cull out only those stories of interest to him. Office workers could do the same with memos. Similar ``videotex'' systems were never very successful. And the prediction that computers would eventually create a paperless office was wrong: if anything, computers have made offices even more papery. Srihari said his project could someday give people the best of both worlds: they could have their paper and computerize it, too. ``People are not going to get away from hard copy. People like to have hard copy,'' he said. ``It's something tangible. It's nice to be able to take it somewhere.''

DOC.HEAD: Microfilm of the 21st Century: A Pictorial Database
DOC.TEXT: Ramesh Jain is building a computer database so complicated it might seem like child's play. The University of Michigan researcher says his work is too early in development to predict its success, but it will debunk the myth that a computer database has to consist of words or numbers. How about pictures? Most existing computers recognize only keyboard symbols, not images that are scanned into their memory. ``The computer we are designing will do that,'' Jain said. ``You can ask questions about pictures using pictures. It's just the research of a new area. All the databases are not in terms of names or numbers, they're in shapes.'' Jain, director of the school's artificial intelligence lab, said the program could eventually be used in classrooms, police labs, real estate offices and museum warehouses. In class, for example, students could use databases to identify leaves in botany education. A tree leaf they couldn't identify could likely be matched by the computer comparing it to shapes, colors, sizes and textures in its memory. Karen Brady, an artist in the school's multimedia lab, is using a sample database with pictures of Oriental rugs. A computer scanner copies the image of each rug into the computer's memory. The computer is programmed to recognize rug features including overall design, patterns of the main and minor borders and color schemes. Sample rugs can be identified by the computer by matching them with such features in its memory. The amount of information requires huge amounts of computer memory, Jain said. He is starting the project on Apple MacIntoshes, but expects to graduate to larger systems. Some existing databases are based on images, but none works directly with the pictures, Jain said. At the Michigan State Police Crime Laboratory in East Lansing, unidentified fingerprints from crime scenes can be matched to suspects through images in police files. But the program does not exclusively work with the images, said Robert Slick, a latent fingerprint examiner at the lab. Instead, the computer assigns numerical values to characteristics of the fingerprint and searches the values in its memory for a match. ``Depending on the level of technology he's using, it could be used in other areas as well,'' Slick said. ``I would think that it could even be used in the identification of people. That's pure speculation but the sky's the limit in technology.'' Jim Blackaby, acting executive director of the Museum Computer Network in Syracuse, N.Y., says image storage is important to museums because it saves wear and tear on collections. By having images on file, researchers can call them up on the screen instead of pulling them out of storage. While copies of paintings and sculptures already are filed on computers, they cannot be retrieved by specifying an image without the key word that describes it, Blackaby said.

DOC.HEAD: Guide to Low-Fat Eating in Restaurants
DOC.TEXT: One of the hardest times to stick to a low-fat diet is when confronted with a restaurant menu. What's really in all those dishes described so temptingly? Since the average American eats several meals a week away from home, it's important to know. A new pocket-size book can provide some guidance. The ``Guide to Low-Cholesterol Dining Out'' by Harriet Roth (Signet, $1.95), focuses not only on the animal products that contain cholesterol but on high-fat foods that can raise the level of cholesterol in the body. Roth advises diners to ask questions and make requests (such as sauce on the side). More and more restaurants are willing to comply with health-conscious eaters' wishes, said Roth, former director of the Pritikin Longevity Center Cooking School. There are general guidelines and lists of foods to enjoy and avoid at 17 kinds of restaurants, in take-out foods, among beverages and when traveling. She also includes a brief list of requests (such as ``I am on a special low-fat, low-cholesterol diet.'') in French, Spanish, Italian and German. ---
DOC.HEAD: Behavioral Problems Shorten Survival of Alzheimer's Victims
DOC.TEXT: Alzheimer's victims who suffer behavioral problems such as paranoia and hallucinations tend to live about two years less than those who do not, according to a published report. A shortened lifespan also was associated with hearing loss and a later onset of the disease, the University of Washington researchers reported in the Annals of Internal Medicine. The study confirmed earlier findings that wandering and falling, a common problem among Alzheimer's patients, reduces lives by about three years. The report ``suggests that we should try to improve the quality of survival and prevent the excess of disability,'' said the study's author, Dr. Eric Larson. Alzheimer's progressively strips a person's ability to deal with and understand events and people, complete household chores and even take care of oneself. No cause or cure is known. According to a recent report by Congress' Office of Technology Assessment, about 1.8 million Americans have Alzheimer's so severe that others must care for them constantly. An additional 1 million to 5 million have mild or moderate dementia. Patients live an average of five to eight years after being diagnosed with Alzheimer's, according to the researchers. The study followed 126 Alzheimer's patients in their late 70s for at least six years. Several factors, including depression, use of prescription drugs, loss of appetite and restlessness did not affect the patients' survival, the study showed. The scientists said they hope their work will be used to develop accurate forecasts of the disease's course. Creighton Phelps of the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association in Chicago said the group planned to disseminate the study to its chapters. ``This information, linking behavioral problems to shorter survival, is something we didn't know before,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Oct. 1

DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors laid out a shrill portrait of Michael Milken in documents they released, depicting the convicted financier as an unapologetic schemer, more evil than Ivan Boesky and deserving of a much harsher prison term. ``Milken's crimes formed a pattern of calculated fraud, deceit and corruption of the highest magnitude,'' they said in a 200-page memorandum to U.S. District Judge Kimba M. Wood, who is to sentence Milken on Monday. ``Put simply, Milken's crimes were crimes of greed, arrogance and betrayal.'' The government, in the documents released Wednesday, did not prescribe a specific sentence for Milken. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A flurry of rumors in the futures market sent oil prices on a rally, pushing prices briefly above $39 per barrel. The surge of more than $1 a barrel Wednesday afternoon erased losses in the morning that came largely on factual statistics. Figures from the American Petroleum Institute showed that the United States had bigger stockpiles of heating oil and gasoline last week. But the gossip on the floor of the New York Mercantile Exchange helped push light sweet crude for November to a high of $39.05 per barrel before it settled back at $38.67, up $1.14 from Tuesday. --- CHICAGO (AP) - The White House, claiming there was `no justification'' for the recent run-up in oil and gasoline prices, announced Wednesday that president Bush had decided to sell 5 million barrels o crude oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The decision to tape the nation's oil reserve was announced by White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Fitzwater said the decision to put 5 million barrels on the market was a ``test'' and the president would take ``additional steps to stabilize energy prices.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Durable goods orders to U.S. manufacturers slid 0.8 percent in August, according to a government report that analysts said indicated cutbacks in business investment plans because of Middle East uncertainties. The Commerce Department reported Wednesday that orders for durable goods - ``big-ticket'' items expected to last more than three years - totaled a seasonally adjusted $127 billion after a revised 2.7 percent gain in July. Analysts pointed to a 11.2 percent drop, to $35.4 billion, in non-defense capital goods orders, which often are a barometer of business plans to expand and modernize. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Consumer spending rose 0.5 percent in August, the government said in a report indicating personal consumption remained reasonably strong despite the Persian Gulf oil-price shock. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that spending totaled $3.69 trillion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, up $16.7 billion from a month earlier. It was the smallest advance since May, when spending was unchanged from April. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A year at college will cost an average of 5 percent to 8 percent more this fall, a slight lessening in the decade-long spell of higher education inflation, according to an annual survey. But some officials fear that encouraging news may end soon, especially at colleges in oil-sensitive northern states, if the overall inflation rate worsens and a recession occurs. The survey, released Wednesday by the College Board, also found that Massachusetts Institute of Technology is the nation's priciest college this fall: an estimated $22,945, counting tuition, fees, room and board, books and supplies, transportation, and other expenses. --- DETROIT (AP) - A new labor agreement containing three years of income guarantees for about 300,000 General Motors Corp. workers appeared headed toward certain ratification by the United Auto Workers union. Even UAW Local 594 at GM's Truck & Bus Group plant in Pontiac, Mich., a center of support for the UAW dissident New Directions Movement, voted 77 percent in favor of the contract in ratification balloting Wednesday. At other locals, ratification margins were much higher - as much as 98 percent, for example, among production workers at GM's Arlington, Texas, assembly plant. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - President Bush may be willing to drop his demand for a cut in the capital gains tax, Republican congressmen said, a compromise that could spur a budget agreement and avert disruptive cuts in government services. Bush said nothing about his reported change in position as he campaigned Wednesday for Republican candidates in Ohio. Instead, he said ``the hangup is with the Democrats,'' whom he accused of refusing to do their part to cut the deficit. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Bush administration wants to raise deposit insurance fees for reckless banks and limit how many insured accounts a depositor may have, a senior Treasury Department official said. Treasury Undersecretary Robert R. Glauber also suggested Wednesday that the administration may seek to force banks to conduct commercial real estate lending through separate affiliates that would not use insured deposits. ---

Bond prices were slightly higher. DOC.HEAD: A New Economic Perspective Is Revealed
Also moved in advance.
DOC.TEXT: If the chief executive officer of a major company ran his business affairs in the same manner as the federal government does, he would lose his job. There is almost no question this would be his fate because the board of directors, answerable to the shareholders, would be compelled to ask why, for example, he was unaware of the company's poor financial condition. And he wouldn't have a good answer. They would ask why he made decisions based on inaccurate information, why his flow of information was inadequate, why it took so long to assemble, why he failed to take action until months after the problems had become crises. The federal government has fought the problem but it hasn't succeeded, and elected and appointed officials still must make decisions on the basis of insufficient or unreliable information. In the second quarter, based on the best evidence available to the Commerce Department in late July, the economy expanded at an annual rate of 1.2 percent -weak, but still strong enough to convince officials to refrain from taking action. This week, three months after the second quarter ended, it became known to the President that the economy had been failing in that period, just skirting recession, growing at a bare four-tenths of a percent. The White House expressed surprise and concern, and Michael Boskin, the White House chief economic adviser, conceded the economy was now on a weaker path than had been known. The administration halved its earlier projections. While the Federal Reserve has its own data retrieval methods, by means of which it seeks to anticipate and fine-tune the economic direction, it too must have been surprised by the tardy news. You can't foresee with ancient data. The situation points up the problem of running an economy so huge that data cannot be assembled in time to act. Not only does its collection take time, but when assembled it is incredibly complex, making it subject to revision. It is such a revision that now reveals the April-June economy was tripping on a tightrope rather than steady on its feet as officials had believed, in spite of fears expressed by private economists and business people. The problem has existed since economic statistics were first gathered, but it becomes more serious when the economy is walking the line between recession and expansion, as it is now, or when efforts are made to fine tune. Fine tuning, defined more by the attempt than the accomplishment, seeks to deal with the economy over shorter periods of time than is usually the case - by the month or even week, for example, rather than the quarter or the year. In the Federal Reserve's area of authority it would mean keeping an especially close watch, among other things, on the money supply and interest rates, which of course rely on accurate measurements of economic activity. Generally speaking, economists both in and out of government have no choice but to use official statistics in analyzing business and economic conditions, but some private-sector economists have recently complained about inaccuracies. Some, in fact, have devised their own computer-aided techniques for gathering and analyzing information, hoping to make themselves less reliant on the official statistics. The latest revision, however, is an extremely critical one that presents a brand new perspective and forces changes in forecasts throughout government and industry, and it will add to the complaints.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Humming Along, But Gulf Crisis Brings Economic Clouds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Lessons learned in the 1973 Arab oil embargo have helped Japan weather the gulf crisis, even though danger lurks in the form of plummeting stock prices and rising interest rates. Nearly two months after Iraq invaded Kuwait, gasoline prices are up only slightly in Japan, and there is little sign of the grave concern that might be expected from a country that relies on the Middle East for 70 percent of its oil. That's largely a result of the government's efforts to avoid a repeat of 1973, when Japan's economy was thrown into chaos through Arab restrictions of oil exports and imports that tripled in price within months. At the time, the ``oil shock'' sent inflation spiraling and led to the first decline in Japan's gross national product during the post-war era. Japanese recall how they rushed to stores to buy toilet paper, kerosene and other commodities amid fears of shortages. The crisis atmosphere was heightened by emergency conservation measures that pulled the plug on neon lighting and closed gasoline stations on holidays and Sundays. But there have been no such scenes this time around. ``The major reason is that the government has a deliberate policy of not causing panic,'' said Gregory Clark, a professor at Sophia University specializing in the Japanese economy. That policy is aimed at dampening expectations of inflation. Japanese ministries have kept a close eye on companies' plans to raise fuel prices to the consumer. Oil wholesalers have raised prices only once during the crisis, and only after the government demanded they narrow the increase. Meanwhile, the powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry on Tuesday asked wholesalers of liquefied petroleum gas to absorb higher costs by streamlining operations and limiting price increases to the minimum, the Kyodo News Service reported. Japan is also less vulnerable to another ``oil shock'' because it has reduced its dependence on foreign oil for its overall energy needs from about 75 percent to under 60 percent, according to a Western energy analyst. For further protection, the country has built up a 144-day reserve of oil. Japan also has been purchasing additional supplies from Saudi Arabia and Iran since the international embargo on Iraq and Kuwait began in early August. ``So far, we have enough supply and enough stock to cover the loss, so I don't think we have serious problems in the short run,'' said Hideki Matsumoto, a senior economist at the private Institute of Energy Economics Japan. He said the government may draw from that stockpile in winter, when demand for petroleum products increases. In the longer term, however, continuing uncertainty in the gulf and sharply increased oil prices pose threats to the world's No. 2 economy, so strong that it has grown each month for nearly four years. The stock market, which was already bearish, has slid 28 percent since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. On Wednesday, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average dropped 4.75 percent to end the day at 22,250.62, its lowest closing level since Jan. 5, 1988. Japanese commercial banks, with their large share portfolios, have been hit particularly hard. The reduced value of those assets rendered some banks unable to meet international reserve requirements that become mandatory in two years. Analysts say this could lead to reduced lending overseas. Economists are particularly worried about accelerated interest rate growth and inflationary pressure since the crisis began. Retail costs of petroleum products are likely to increase in larger and more frequent increments if the crisis persists. ``The real blow will be the price hike of petroleum-related products, which will surface before the end of the year,'' predicted Josen Takahashi, chief economist at the Mitsubishi Research Institute. Perhaps most ominous is the possible effect of rising interest rates on the expensive Japanese realestate market. Although Japan is only 4 percent the size of the United States, its real estate is estimated at nearly four times the total value of U.S. real estate - about $15 trillion. Land prices climbed 13 percent in the 12 months ending in July according to one government survey. Some analysts believe the interest rate increases could force land speculators to sell their holdings and burst the real estate bubble. A collapse of the real estate market, said Clark, would ``have staggering effects on this economy'' and could lead to a lengthy recession. So far, said Clark, the government has done well to avert the inflationary scare of the 1973 oil shock. ``What they can't control is the period over which interest rates remain high,'' he added. ``And this is what's going to make or break this economy.''

DOC.HEAD: Even Dissident UAW Members Like New Deal With GM
DOC.TEXT: Even dissident United Auto Workers members seem to like the union's new deal with General Motors Corp., making ratification of the three-year contract a virtual certainty. A suburban Detroit UAW local active in the New Directions Movement, which voiced the only organized opposition to the GM-UAW contract, voted overwhelmingly Wednesday to ratify the pact. ``This is the first one we've ratified in nine years,'' said Howard Farnsworth, a shop committeeman at UAW Local 594 at GM's Truck & Bus Group plant in Pontiac. His local, which voted to reject tentative agreements in 1984 and 1987, approved the 1990 agreement, 77 percent to 23 percent. ``Finally we get to ratify one here at 594,'' Farnsworth said. Voting on the proposed agreement, which contains three years of income guarantees for about 300,000 GM workers, continues through the weekend. Some large locals at assembly and stamping operations scheduled votes for today, tonight and Friday. Other locals approved the contract by much wider margins than did Local 594. Production workers at Local 276 at GM's assembly plant in Arlington, Texas, for example, approved the contract by a 98 percent margin and workers at Local 549 at GM's stamping plant in Marion, Ind., approved the contract on a 95 percent vote. The union said it would release results at the end of the month, after ballots from all 155 locals at GM plants are counted. After the GM-UAW pact is ratified, the union will announce whether it will resume bargaining next with Ford Motor Co. or Chrysler Corp. UAW contracts with the Big Three automakers, covering more than 450,000 active workers, expired at midnight Sept. 14, although provisions of the agreements have been extended. Meantime, the Canadian Auto Workers union on Wednesday set an Oct. 10 deadline for reaching a new contract with General Motors of Canada Ltd. On Sunday, the union said its 12,800 members ratified a new three-year contract with Ford of Canada after a one-week strike. The two unions, which split in 1985, say the contract they reach first will be used as a pattern for agreements with other automakers. UAW members contacted this week have said one of the big selling points was a GM promise to pay up to $4 billion to guarantee wages for workers laid off more than 36 weeks during the next three years. Other apparently well-received contract provisions include health care benefits that stay the same and increases in pension plans. The UAW had tapped job security as its top issue. Guaranteeing income is seen as the next best thing to guaranteeing jobs. ``Anytime you guarantee every soul in GM a job or income for three years, it's good,'' said Oscar Bunch, president of Local 14 at GM's Hydra-Matic plant in Toledo, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: German Consumers Unite, But West's Investors Shy Away from East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: Graphics
DOC.TEXT: The two German economies, the juggernaut and the wheelchair, have little to do with each other three months after they merged. It's a big disappointment for those who believed capitalism would bring benefits and progress to the East soon after economic union occurred on July 1. Instead, there has been little investment in East Germany. Many businesses have failed and there has been a tidal wave of unemployment. East German industrial production in July was a whopping 42 percent below July 1989. But German economic officials and analysts think things are fine, that the problems were inevitable. ``The conditions for further growth in Germany are extraordinarily good,'' said Peter Pietsch, an economist with Commerzbank, one of West Germany's leading banks. Pietsch thinks the only problem for the German economy these days is the Persian Gulf crisis, meaning possibly higher oil prices. The Bundesbank, the West German central bank, said in its monthly report released Sept. 18 that there had been continued economic growth in West Germany since July 1. Depressing effects of the gulf crisis and slackening demand in export markets were ``more than compensated for by the swift expansion of 40, Mayor Brad Cabana's town council has voted not to collect or pay the GST, come what may. ``It's another example of government not listening to the people,'' he said. ``It's not a fair tax and it's quite inflationary.''

DOC.HEAD: Olympia and York Attracts Tenants Using Aggressive Inducements, Sources Say
DOC.TEXT: Developer Olympia and York has attracted tenants to its Canary Wharf center using such aggressive inducements as buying a tenant's current building and assuming others' leases, sources said. Questions about how Canary Wharf is faring were raised by the recent decision of Olympia and York's owners, the Reichmann family of Toronto, to sell a 20 percent stake in their vast U.S. properties. Canary Wharf, expected to cost 4 billion pounds ($7.5 billion), is Olympia and York's biggest project ever. It is Europe's largest office development and boasts Britain's tallest building. Outside real estate agents are divided about whether the project will prove successful. They agreed that it is a risky one because of its huge size and its untried, hard-to-reach location. The 71-acre project is 2.5 miles east of the City of London, or financial district. It is part of the sprawling Docklands development on the River Thames. It's not being helped by a real estate market depressed by 15 percent interest rates and a slowing economy, the agents say. The aggressive marketing of assuming leases reflects a desire by Olympia and York to create momentum and prove that the first phase of Canary Wharf will succeed, they say. ``It's basically musical chairs. It's all right as long as the music doesn't stop,'' said John Phillips, a property agent with the firm Gooch and Wagstaff. Olympia and York used such selling techniques in New York in the past, a Canary Wharf spokeswoman confirmed. The developer took over the project three years ago, when an original consortium including the investment firms Morgan Stanley and First Boston pulled out because of lack of expertise and funding for such a large project, she said. The Reichmanns' decision to sell interest in some of its holdings, reported last week, ``has nothing to do with Canary Wharf,'' said the Canary Wharf spokeswoman who spoke on condition of anonymity. The developer is pleased with the progress in signing up clients, she said. Olympia and York said last week that a 500 million-pound ($935 million) financing package for Canary Wharf will be completed soon. The project so far has been funded with developer's own resources and Canadian bank credit lines. Olympia and York views Canary Wharf as a long-term investment, the spokeswoman said. The company has never failed to complete a project, she said. ``I think it will be successful eventually,'' said Robert Foster, a partner with the real estate firm Weatherall Green and Smith. But Phillips said: ``I think the whole project is very much at a stage where it's questionable in viability terms. Even Olympia & York, with their financial assets, it's beginning to test even their resources, it's such a big expensive project.'' Thirteen tenants, including Morgan Stanley, American Express, and Manufacturers Hanover, have signed up to fill 2.5 million square feet of the 4.3 million square feet available in the first phase. The first buildings open in 1991. Olympia and York plans to build 10 million square feet of office space in five phases over as long as 10 years. ``They've been succeeding in attracting tenants to a greater extent than the market expected,'' said Peter Rose, another agent with Gooch and Wagstaff. ``However, other players in the market haven't been used to the aggressive tactics that they've used.'' Although the Canary Wharf spokeswoman said the company doesn't discuss the details of its tenancy agreements, she confirmed that the developer has bought the Daily Telegraph's nearby building in exchange for the newspaper taking space in Canary Wharf. Olympia and York has offered to assume prospective clients' leases, said a source at a company which has negotiated with the developer. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Another such source said: ``One of the things they have done which is very smart is to offer to take over people's leases and I know they have done that in a couple of cases.'' He said his company was offered low rent, an outfitting allowance, and a long fixed term without a rent review, which he called ``usual inducements'' for a new development. Foster said Canary Wharf is offering space at ``a very good rent'' of 30 pounds ($56) a square foot compared with 50 pounds ($94) in the City.

DOC.HEAD: Many Oil Companies Playing it Safe Despite Price Hikes
DOC.TEXT: Some oil and gas companies are rushing to take advantage of higher oil prices to increase drilling, but many say they've learned the hard way that it's better to wait out the latest Persian Gulf crisis. Two companies, Arkla Exploration of Shreveport, La., and Houston-based Conoco, a DuPont subsidiary, announced this month they were boosting their domestic exploration budgets. But independent producers and other oil and gas companies said in interviews Wednesday they don't believe prices are going to stay high enough long enough for them to risk millions of dollars in new drilling. ``A lack of trust in the pricing situation keeps us in place until we stop staring at each other across the Kuwait border,'' said Julian Martin, executive vice president of the Texas Independent Producers and Royalty Owners Association in Austin. Oil prices have been rising since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, with light sweet crude nearly double pre-invasion prices at almost $40 per barrel. Conoco announced earlier this month it was boosting its domestic exploration budget by $10 million, the first major energy company to respond to the recent price increases with more spending. Officials said the money would cover the cost of five new wells in the Gulf of Mexico. ``With the literal dismantling of the exploration infrastructure in the U.S. during recent years, this country can't expect to see a significant increase in exploratory activity right away,'' said Max Pitcher, Conoco's executive vice president for worldwide exploration. ``But while this single effort will not lessen U.S. dependence on overseas oil right away, it is a step in the right direction,'' he said. Arkla, which drills primarily for natural gas, announced last week it has increased its capital budget for the remainder of 1990 from $55 million to $70 million, a nearly 30 percent jump over what it originally planned to spend this year. ``We are doing something aggressive,'' company spokesman Louis Resweber said. ``The industry has to step up to the plate and assist in finding a domestic energy source when we're being threatened by the Middle East.'' But Martin and independent producers said it was too risky to increase drilling with expectations of $40-per-barrel oil and suddenly be stuck holding $10-per-barrel oil. ``Even if a real war breaks out and oil goes up to $60 a barrel, it would be risky to (increase drilling),'' said Houston oilman Michel Halbouty. ``Nobody's going to spend a lot of money then watch the price plummet.'' ``Most independents were burned in 1985 and 1986,'' TIPRO's Martin said. ``They fear the same phenomenon will occur again if they start projecting higher prices for a long time.'' Martin added, however, that some independents are using the increase in internal cash flows to rework existing wells and are increasing production in developed leases. Others, he said, are saving the money to increase drilling budgets in the next few months if it becomes clear that oil prices will stay up for a relatively long time. But for now, ``your friendly bank and traditional investors are unwilling to get into such an uncertain venture,'' Martin said. Other natural gas companies, including Mesa Ltd. Partnerships in Amarillo and Mitchell Energy and Development Corp. in Houston, said they also were waiting to see how the Persian Gulf crisis shapes up before increasing drilling. ``The more ominous it gets, the more people are tempted to stick their necks out,'' said Tony Lentini of Mitchell Energy. ``But they're taking the risk that without a price floor, the Saudis could flood the market.'' Lentini also said the company was beginning to turn ``just a little bit'' toward oil production because of demands for domestic oil.

DOC.HEAD: Portions of Government's Presentencing Documents Released
With PM-Milken, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from a prosecution memorandum to U.S. District Judge Kimba M. Wood, outlining the government's full case against Michael Milken and urging the judge to severely sentence him. The documents were made public Wednesday, by order of the judge, a day after the defense released its own presentencing memorandum urging leniency. The documents were edited to conceal identities of Milken associates, who are labeled as ``John Doe.''
DOC.HEAD: A PATTERN OF FRAUD
DOC.TEXT: Milken's crimes formed a pattern of calculated fraud, deceit and corruption of the highest magnitude. In a highly sophisticated and systematic way, Milken endeavored to enhance his power and enlarge his wealth by willingly cheating clients, manipulating the markets,and evading the laws and rules designed to safeguard the investing public. . . . Milken developed and nurtured corrupt relationships with numerous clients and customers, including Ivan F. Boesky, the prominent Wall Street arbitrageur, and (John Doe), an institutional money manager. Together with these criminal associates, Milken harnessed the vast economic power of Drexel Burnham Lambert's High-Yield Department and directed it to enhance his power and increase his wealth. The High-Yield Department became the means through which Milken rewarded his friends, defeated his rivals, and committed his crimes. . . . Contrary to Milken's persistent efforts to minimize the nature and scope of his criminal conduct, the six charges to which Milken pleaded guilty provide but a sampling of the larger pattern of criminal activity that permeated Milken's operation of the High-Yield Department.
DOC.HEAD: SEVERE PUNISHMENT REQUIRED
DOC.TEXT: In our view, three primary reasons mandate that Milken be severely punished for his crimes. First, Milken's criminal conduct, as reflected by his guilty plea, was sweeping. It warrants the imposition of a substantial term of imprisonment. Second, notwithstanding his entry of a guilty pea, Milken has scarcely accepted responsibility for his crimes. He has done little to mitigate his punishment. Finally, Milken's sentence will be used in criminal courts throughout this country as the model for how our justice system should treat white-collar criminals. This court's message must be a clarion call to the community that financial crime cannot be countenanced and will not be tolerated. . . . Put simply, Milken's crimes were crimes of greed, arrogance and betrayal.
DOC.HEAD: CALCULATED AND SYSTEMATIC
DOC.TEXT: Poised atop the Drexel financial colossus, Milken routinely possessed more power and better information than his clients, customers and the market. . . . On certain occasions, Milken engendered the loyalty of his customers by abetting their crimes and violations. On other occasions, Milken unlawfully provided gratuities - often in the form of valuable investment opportunities available only to those designated by him - to personally enrich institutional fiduciaries in order to influence them to direct their institutional business to Drexel. The net result of these corrupt practices was the creation of a marketplace rife with conflicts of interest and manipulative conduct. . . . Contrary to his efforts to characterize the crimes he committed as petty, Milken's crimes were neither technical nor victimless. They included the fraudulent misappropriation of funds from unsophisticated investors who entrusted their funds to the management of others; the deception of market participants who acted in reliance on the integrity of the marketplace; and contempt for the legal framework designed to protect such investors and ensure the integrity of the market. . . . Milken's criminal conduct was calculated and systematic, rather than gratuitous and aberrational, and Milken's criminal activity was a significant and necessary component of the growth of his power in the high-yield market.
DOC.HEAD: MILKEN UNREPENTANT
DOC.TEXT: Milken merits scant credit for accepting responsibility and no credit for cooperation. . . . Milken's decision reflects surrender not contrition. Further, Milken has not accepted responsibility for all of his crimes; indeed his self-serving rationalizations to the Probation Department undercut any serious claim that he has truly accepted responsiblity for even the crimes to which he has now pleaded. Finally, in spite of his many post-investigation social and charitable good works, Milken has not taken - and has indicated that he will not take - affirmative steps to clean up the industry he dirtied. . . . Milken should be punished as the unreconstructed and unapologetic man that he is.
DOC.HEAD: HASTENED DREXEL'S DEMISE
DOC.TEXT: Having been responsible for Drexel's rise to prominence, Drexel might have been Milken's to destroy. But there is no question that the excesses in Drexel's corporate culture that Milken fathered hastened the collapse of the company, corrupted many young professionals and occasioned the loss of thousands of jobs. Were it not for the lawlessness of Milken's High-Yield Department, there would not have been grand jury and SEC (Securities and Exchange Commission) investigations. Even after the investigations, moreover, the greedy habits of the Milken years led to the payment of tens of millions of dollars in 1989 bonuses and compensation as Drexel spiraled towards bankruptcy. Had more money been kept in Drexel rather than paid out to Milken and other members of the High-Yeild Department, Drexel undoubtedly would have had a greater chance to survive.
DOC.HEAD: HIS COMPENSATION
DOC.TEXT: The absurdity of Milken's claimed disinterest in wealth is demonstrated by his direct compensation from Drexel and his indirect compensation through Drexel. Milken's compensation from Drexel represented an enormous percentage of Drexel's bottom line. (A footnote showed the escalation of his compensation to $550 million in 1986, or 45.8 percent of Drexel's operating profit. His compensation of $316 million in 1987 was estimated at 81.7 percent of the company's operating profit, according to the government.) . . . As one former employee put it, ``Milken never let go of a nickel except to get a better grip.''
DOC.HEAD: RELATIONSHIP WITH BOESKY
DOC.TEXT: Between 1983 and March 1986, Drexel raised over $800 million for the Boesky Organization through the sale of high-yield securities. These financings culminated in March 1986 when Drexel and Milken raised $660 million for the Boesky Organization. This mutually beneficial relationship between Boesky and Milken evolved over time into a corrupt one in which each engaged in unlawful conduct to benefit the other . . . The secret Boesky relationship also allowed Milken to invest in lucrative trading opportunities which he was legally barred from because of Drexel's involvement in certain corporate finance transactions. . . . In May 1986, Dennis Levine, a prominent merger and acquisition specialist then employed by Drexel, was arrested for insider trading. The Levine arrest struck a weighty blow in the investment community. More particularly, it was an ominous event for Boesky (because of his own illegal dealings with Levine) and for Milken (because the arrest signaled a greater law enforcement vigilance in the investment banking area . . .) Following the Levine arrest, unlawful trading in the High-Yield Department slowed. More particularly, the Levine arrest affected the course of the unlawful Milken-Boesky relationship. In July 1986, Boesky visited Milken for the purpose of discussing a range of business items, both lawful and unlawful. During the course of a poolside discussion between Milken and Boesky at Milken's home, the two discussed the effect of Levine's arrest on their unlawful dealings . . . Boesky and Milken did not meet again until October 1986 . . . Shortly after the announcement of Boesky's plea and settlement with the government, (John Doe) asked Milken if he had been ``careful'' in his October 1986 meeting with Boesky. Milken answered that he thought he had been careful but that he was not entirely sure that he had been ``careful enough.'' (John Doe)'s fears were justified. The government tape-recorded Milken's meeting with Boesky in a room at the Beverly Hills Hotel.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: . . . Hills Hotel.
ON INSIDER TRADING
DOC.TEXT: During the period form 1984 through 1986, Drexel was at the center of Wall Street's takeover boom. Clients came to Drexel, for the most part, because of Drexel's unmatched ability to raise capital through the sale of high-yield securities. . . . there is substantial evidence that Milken caused Drexel to buy and sell securities based upon material, non-public information misappropriated from certain Drexel clients. In one of these instances, Milken traded on insider information for his own account.
DOC.HEAD: ON THE DEFENSE
DOC.TEXT: Milken's submission dramatically exposes the gulf between his crimes and his conviction, on the one hand, and his continuing agitprop on the other. Milken has been convicted of serious and sweeping crimes. His good works, however commendable, should not shield him from incarceration. He should be sentenced to a substantial term of imprisonment. . . . Milken is selling an old and threadbare story. By focusing the court's attention on the five specific crimes he had admitted - and by wholly ignoring his conviction on a broad conspiracy charge - Milken is attempting to minimize his criminal conduct. Were Milken to address the true range of his crimes, however, even he would have to acknowledge a different conclusion. Milken's crimes were serious and extensive.
DOC.HEAD: LIKE HELL'S ANGEL CASE
DOC.TEXT: Milken has been convicted of enormously serious crimes: conspiracy to violate the laws of the United States, securities fraud, mail fraud, wire fraud, tax fraud, and recordkeeping and reporting violations. . . . Although he has limited his allocution to five separate acts in furtherance of that conspiracy, this court can and should sentence Milken for all of his crimes. . . . In United States v. Kittel . . . Kittel, a member of the New York Chapter of the Hell's Angels Motorcycle Club, was charged with conspiracy to manufacture and distribute large quantities of methamphetamine and with 11 substantive counts relating to the unlawful distribution of methamphetamine. He was convicted on his plea of guilty to the conspiracy charge and to one of the distribution charges. In . . . Kittel's sentencing, however, the government alleged that Kittel had participated in the murder and dismemberment of another Hells Angels club member and the unlawful manufacture of an explosive device among other acts of violence. Judge (Pierre) Leval sentenced Kittel to a 14-year term of imprisonment stating that the sentence was based not only the particular offenses to which Kittel had pleaded guilty but on the government's evidence of Kittel's unadmitted crimes - persistent drug dealing and acts of violence.
DOC.HEAD: CONTRAST TO FREEMAN
DOC.TEXT: Moreover, although the government is asking the court to sentence Milken on crimes more numerous than he has specifically admitted, these additional charges are similar to the crimes that Milken has admitted: manipulating stocks, unlawfully influencing corporate events through the concealed ownership of securities, unlawfully providing benefits to clients and client representatives in order to cultivate their business, and fraudulently misappropriating funds from clients. . . . Indeed, Milken's agreement to pay $200 million in criminal penalities and $400 million in restitution dramatically belies both his contention that he committed only the five enumerated crimes and his argument that even these crimes were aberrational and technical violations. These fines, penalties, and restitution fix the scope of Milken's criminal conduct. Milken's agreement to pay these monies stands out as the most reliable measure of his criminal conduct. For all these reasons, this case is sharply different from United States v. Freeman . . . In Freeman (where the judge refused to admit a sentencing report on additional crimes), the defendant pleaded guilty to one narrow insider trading charge, not to multiple offenses and a broad conspiracy charge. Unlike Milken, Robert Freeman did not acknowledge the government's right to put before the court his ``unadmitted'' offenses. Unlike Milken, Freeman, in his allocution, did not admit that he committed crimes additional to the crimes to which he specifically pleaded guilty. Finally, Freeman did not agree to pay criminal fines and restitution penalties of $600 million.
DOC.HEAD: PUSH FOR PRISON TIME
DOC.TEXT: Milken should be sentenced to a substantial period of incarceration commensurate with his crimes. Those crimes were pervasive and systemic. They were committed for venal reasons - to enhance Milken's personal power and increase his wealth. No good works undertaken by Milken mitigate the imperative of a substantial prison term. Milken's proposal that he be sentenced to a probationary term and community service is absurd. Such a sentence would eviscerate law enforcement's efforts to police and deter financial crime. . . . Milken's crimes have had nationwide impact and his sentence will become the touchstone for every sentence for financial crime in the country. . . . other sentences demonstrate a consensus among judges that absent significant actual cooperation, a major securities law violator such as Milken will receive a substantial term of incarceration. Boesky's three-year term of incarceration provides a useful point of departure. As an initial, symbolic matter, Milken stands convicted of six times as many felony charges as Boesky and has agreed to pay six times Boesky's criminal fine and civil penalty. While the government does not suggest that simple arithmetic should determine Milken's sentence, Milken's suggestion that - facing almost six times Boesky's penalty - he merits a fraction of his punishment is preposterous.
DOC.HEAD: MILKEN'S COOPERATION
DOC.TEXT: Like Boesky and Levine, Milken committed very serious crimes. Unike Boesky and Levine, however, Milken has not cooperated. On the urging of the government, Boesky and Levine each received reduced sentences because of their extraordinary assistance in the successful prosecutions of others. . . . Boesky's cooperation resulted, directly and indirectly, in the successful prosecution of numerous prominent securities industry professionals in addition to Milken. In sharp contrast, during the four years of Boesky's cooperation, Milken has vigorously contested the government's charges and allowed the statute of limitations to preclude prosecution of others based on any information he could provide. . . . (The) sentence of Paul Bilzerian (to four years in prison) for repeated securities fraud crimes should also inform this court's exercise of its sentencing discretion. Bilzerian's sentence was based on multiple criminal acts over an extended period of time. His violations were similar in type to Milken's admitted crimes though fewer in number . . . Milken's conduct is, of course, far more widespread and systemic than Bilzerian's.
DOC.HEAD: RECOMMENDATION
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken stands before this court having been convicted of six felonies carrying a maximum sentence of 28 years. He has committed a range of serious white-collar crimes unmatched in the 1980s. The government respectfully submits that this court should impose a sentence that reflects the full magnitude of Milken's unlawful conduct and that unmistakably deters others . . . The court's sentence must demonstrate that persons who possess great wealth and prominence cannot expect that their privilege or their money will insulate them from certain and serious punishment. For these reasons, the government respectfully urges that . . . Michael Milken be sentenced to a substantial term of imprisonment.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Study: Two Market Watchdogs May be Too Many
DOC.TEXT: Two separate regulators for securities and futures markets may be too many as the links between Wall Street and Chicago bind the markets together, a congressional study has concluded. A study of financial market technology by the Congress's Office of Technology Assessment suggested creating one regulatory agency with responsibility over securities, including futures and options. The report found that ``dual regulatory agencies may no longer be appropriate, for what is now one marketplace.'' The study, scheduled to be made public today, could heat up the simmering dispute between the rival regulators - the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Both agencies have engaged in a war of words over which should regulate stock index futures and their margins. Stock index futures are futures contracts that allow investors to bet on the movement of a whole series of stocks without having to buy the underlying securities. Margins are the downpayments paid by investors buying securities on credit. Securities margins are about 50 percent of the stock's value, while futures margins are usually just 5 percent of the market value. The 220-page report, ``Electronic Bulls and Bears: U.S. Securities Markets and Inforamtion Technology,'' was an outgrowth of the 1987 stock market crash. The study ``looks at the regulatory structure and says `Hey, these are now one market and having two agencies that fight each doesn't make any sense,'' said Vary T. Coates, project director of the study. The study also is critical of the specialist system of trading at the New York and American stock exchanges. The OTA does not make recommendations to Congress but provides various policy options, officials stressed. The options included clearer definitions of jurisdiction by Congress and setting up a multi-agency panel with binding decision-making authority. ``And the one that looks best is to integrate, having one regulatory agency and this should be reexamined by the Congress,'' said Ms. Coates. Commodities trading would be left in the hands of a separate regulator. The report noted that the biggest stumbling block to a merger is different congressional committees have jurisdiction over the agencies ``and may not be willing or able to agree to consolidation of jurisdiction.'' Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee that oversees the SEC, said the panel would look at reforming the U.S. regulatory structure which he called ``fragmented and uncoordinated'' and ``out of step with the way these new electronic bulls and bears run.'' The report's finding bolstered a bill proposed earlier this year by Reps. Dan Glickman, D-Kan. and Dennis Eckart, D-Ohio, for merging the SEC and CFTC into a unified ``super regulatory agency.'' ``It is gratifying to know that an unbiased and careful analysis by an arm of Congress has reached the same conclusion that the SEC has been urging for some time,'' said Mary McCue, an SEC spokeswoman. ``They have their own opinion it's just not what we subscribe to,'' said CFTC spokesman David Gary. ``We feel the markets are linked but there is no need for one regulator - in fact we remain firmly in the camp of functional regulation.'' The report also said the SEC and CFTC ``often take radically different positions on issues'' and those differences ``raise doubts about the reliability of their coordination and cooperation during market emergencies.'' Earlier this year, the heads of both agencies trashed each other's study of the causes of the 1987 stock market crash, accusing one another of self-serving interpretation of the same data. In January, a draft version of the report drew fire from a blue-ribbon advisory panel that included representatives from exchanges in New York and Chicago, for criticizing the specialist system as ``faltering'' and possibly ``irredeemably obsolete.'' Under the specialist system, stock can only be traded through certain designated exchange members charged with maintaining an orderly market in that security - even if it means buying or selling the stock because no other takers can be found. Critics claim specialists are unable to keep up with the massive volume that occurs in a market crisis like the 1987 crash. But supporters say specialists stayed at their posts, taking orders, when other traders weren't answering their phones during the crash. While stock exchanges have sophisticated support systems on their trading floors, ``they have resisted the use of electronic systems for after-hours and remote-site trading,'' said the study which found recently announced plans for after-hours trading ``belated, cautious and tighly limited.'' The report also said the futures markets have ``resisted bringing technology into their domestic trading pits.'' Most futures exchanges still utilize the boisterous system of shouts and hand signals known as ``open outcry,'' which makes it difficult to prevent fraud and assure investors they are getting the best price, said the OTA.

DOC.HEAD: Laura Ashley to Close Seven Factories, Cut 1,500 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Laura Ashley Holdings PLC, the British clothing and home furnishings retailer, said Thursday it would close seven factories and cut 1,500 jobs, or nearly a fifth of its work force. The company said the moves were part of an ongoing cost-cutting program it began last year. It attributed the closures and cuts to a need to counter the effects of a strong British pound and high inflation. The company said it would be left with 6,650 workers and two manufacturing facilities. It said 1,000 of the job cuts would result from the factory closures, while the other 500 cuts would come from its worldwide retail operations. ``If Laura Ashley is to survive in today's highly competitive environment, it is no longer viable to source the current level of garments worldwide from our U.K. factories when products of similar quality can be obtained at a significantly lower cost from other supplies in other countries,'' Chairman Bernard Ashley said. The company said it would maintain enough in-house garment-making capacity to respond to quick changes in market needs. It said it would continue to print its own fabrics and wallpaper and operate its own curtain factory. The company lost 9.8 million pounds, or $18.3 million, in the year ended Jan. 27 in contrast to a net profit of 8.4 million pounds, or $15.7 million, in the previous year.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Study Aims For Fewer Crashes Despite More Crowded Skies
DOC.TEXT: Flying is getting safer, but more planes in the sky will mean more crashes unless the airline industry takes action, a Boeing Co. study says. The study also indicates a few simple changes in operations plus some relatively inexpensive equipment might help reduce serious accidents, Earl Weener, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group's chief engineer for safety, said Wednesday. The airplane manufacturer has kept statistics on all free world commercial jets for the past 30 years. The company predicts the worldwide accident rate for jetliners should decline to about 1 per million flights in 2005, compared with an average of about 1.5 per million in the past 10 years. But the number of jets is expected to double in the next 15 years to about 13,000. Weener said actual aircraft losses can be expected to grow to 20 per year by 2005, up from a yearly average of 15 during the past decade. That means a major air crash every 2{ weeks or so, something that won't sit well with the traveling public no matter how low the accident rate is, Weener said. ``If the general public understood rates, there wouldn't be a state lottery in existence,'' Weener said. Boeing, which has 60 percent of the world's commercial jet market, has been pushing its study among air carriers, industry groups and government regulators for the past year, Weener said. Weener, who briefed a group of reporters on the study Wednesday, plans to make presentations to carriers and regulators next month in Europe and Southeast Asia. So far, Boeing has seen ``a great deal of understanding and interest'' on the part of airlines, but it's been difficult to determine what the results have been, Weener said. This year there have been nine ``hull loss'' accidents - wrecks in which the aircraft was destroyed or too badly damaged to fix - which statistically would make 1990 one of the better years, he said. Dave Duff, spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration in Seattle, said the agency is looking at the study but hasn't made any decisions on it. The study says investigating agencies found that of the 121 hull-loss accidents in the past 10 years, the flight crew was the primary cause in 88 accidents or 72.5 percent. Weener said Boeing isn't holding pilots entirely to blame. In most cases, he said, the flight crew was only ``the last party who could have prevented the accident'' in a chain of events. Boeing has used the data to help design aircraft that are more ``mistake tolerant,'' he said. A spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association was not immediately available for comment Wednesday but ALPA officials previously have said they support Boeing's study. The study focuses on what might be done to avoid crew error, especially on takeoffs and landings, where nearly 70 percent of hull-loss accidents occur. Among its recommendations: -Install ``ground proximity warning systems'' in all jets and make sure crews pay attention to them. The systems, which warn pilots to pull up when the ground gets too near, have been required in U.S. jetliners since 1975 but not in all foreign commercial jets. -Install instrument landing systems for all runways and encourage pilots to use them, even in good weather. Virtually all U.S. airports have instrument landing systems, but many have them on only one runway. Many foreign airports lack them altogether, Weener said. -Make better use of flight data recorders, the ``black boxes'' that monitor flights. Currently, 12 carriers, none of them in this country, use the monitors to review flights and let pilots learn what they might have done better, Weener said. Airline managers have to see the monitors as teaching tools, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Suspends Dividend, Postpones Aircraft Purchase
DOC.TEXT: USAir Group Inc., the parent of USAir, has suspended indefinitely its common stock dividend and postponed buying new aircraft. The company had been paying an annual dividend of 12 cents a sharte. Analysts said the carrier is facing losses as high as $350 million for the year. It had an operating loss of $101 million in the first half of this year in contrast to an operating proifit of $258 million in the same period in 1989. Raymond E. Neidl, an analyst for Dillon Read & Co., said the dividend suspension was a prudent way to conserve cash. USAir Chairman and President Edwin I. Colodny said Wednesday the board voted to suspend the stock dividend ``in light of the company's recent financial performance and the poor outlook for the nation's economy and its effect on air travel.'' The airline industry has also been battered in recent weeks by sharply rising fuel costs in the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The dividend suspension will save about $3.5 million annually, the company said. The airline, however, remains liable for $33 million in annual dividend payments to Berkshire Hathaway Inc., headed by investor Warren Buffett, whose company put $358 million into USAir preferred stock last year. The company also delayed delivery of 16 new Boeing aircraft for a year. Earlier this year, USAir put off taking delivery of 12 Boeing 737 jets from 1991 and 1992 to 1995.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan Lifts Restrictions on Hiring Foreign Workers
DOC.TEXT: The Taiwan government lifted restrictions Thursday on the employment of foreign workers in government construction projects. Under the new rule approved by the Cabinet, contractors can apply for the importation of foreign workers for major government and special public projects. Currently, they can only import up to one-third of the work force needed for such construction projects. Officials also said that all foreign workers should be protected by Taiwan's labor laws, which stipulate that every worker receive a minimum monthly wage of 9,750 Taiwan dollars, or about $357 (U.S.), and be covered by health insurance. ``The new move would help boost our economic development,'' said Chen Chung-sheng, director general of Occupational Training Bureau, an agency under the Labor Council. In 1985, the government announced 14 projects to be completed in the early 1990s, including highway expansions, a major rail line and rapid transit system for Taipei. Chen said many of them have lagged behind schedule mainly because of the shortage of construction workers. ``Our workers don't like the non-skilled jobs that offer lower wages,'' he explained. Earlier this month, Foreign Minister Fredrick Chien urged the government to employ more workers from the Philippines, Indonesia and Thailand, saying the three nations have showed strong interest in meeting Taiwan's labor regulations. Officials said at least 20,000 foreigners, mostly from southeast Asia, are working illegally in Taiwan factories and construction sites because of a labor shortage.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Signals Extra Measures May Be Needed
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: In a new indication of the escalating economic fallout from the Persian Gulf turmoil, the head of the World Bank said today that he may be forced to call upon rich nations to boost their support for the international lending institution by early next year. World Bank President Barber Conable said that if oil prices remain at current high levels over the next three months, his institution would not have enough in existing resources to cushion the shock on the world economy. Conable's comments represented a change from his position just a few days ago. At that time, he and officials of the bank's sister lending organization, the International Monetary Fund, insisted that they could handle the economic impact of the Persian Gulf crisis with available resources without tapping rich countries for additional funds. However, as delegates from 154 member countries of the two institutions were holding their annual meeting this week, the price of oil jumped at one point to close to $40. Conable told reporters today that if oil prices stayed at high levels into 1991, he believed it would be necessary to ask for voluntary contributions from major industrial countries and oil producing nations. That money would be used to make no-interest loans to countries especially hard hit by the rise in oil prices and other economic fallouts from the Persian Gulf turmoil. ``If the price of oil stays up and there continues to be turmoil and uncertainty and an impact on the global economy, clearly it will have a major impact on significant parts of the developing world,'' Conable said. Other officials of the World Bank suggested that the proposed new lending facility would be available to work with the Gulf Crisis Financial Coordination Group, the steering committee of donor countries unveiled by President Bush in his speech to the IMF-World Bank opening session on Tuesday. Officials said that donations raised by the crisis group, which is headed by Treasury Secretary Nicholast Brady, might be funneled to this new lending facility for distribution to needy countries. However, they stressed that discussions on this matter remained at a preliminary stage. Both the IMF and World Bank had signaled earlier this week that they were ready to provide significant economic support to hardhit countries, endorsing a request made by the Bush administration. But that approval involved the use of existing programs. The crisis group, with officials representing more than 20 nations, held an organizational session Wednesday at the U.S. Treasury. The United States had hoped to amass commitments this week for between $13 billion and $15 billion in aid to Turkey, Jordan and Egypt. Those ``frontline'' nations have been hard hit by the U.N. economic sanctions placed on Iraq after its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But some European nations objected that the figure was too high and that a more realistic amount was $9 billion, with $6 billion of that support coming from oil-rich Mideast nations and $3 billion from the rest of the world. Following two hours of closed-door discussions at the U.S. Treasury, officials reported no resolution of the funding question. Also left unresolved were objections voiced to including Jordan in the assistance package. Saudi Arabia and Kuwait have complained that Jordan is showing reluctance to support the U.N. trade embargo and therefore should not get aid. And some nations raised the question of including other especially hard-hit nations in the frontline category in addition to Turkey, Jordan and Egypt. Proponents of a longer list pointed to a new World Bank study that identified Bangladesh, India, Pakistan, the Philippines, Sri Lanka and Sudan as seriously hurt by the Persian Gulf crisis. U.S. officials said they would not oppose expanding the list of most needy nations as long as the list did not grow too long. One senior Treasury official, briefing reporters on condition of anonymity, said many of the unresolved matters should be cleared up in discussions by lower-level working groups before the full crisis coordinating panel meets again on Oct. 12. The nations participating with the United States in Wednesday's meeting included Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada, Italy, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and South Korea. In addition, representatives of Belgium, the Netherlands, Sweden and Switzerland were added at the last minute after West Germany and others argued that the list of potential donor countries needed to be expanded. The U.S. official said, however, that not all of the participating countries had made a commitment to provide financial assistance. Representatives from the 12-nation European Community and the Gulf Cooperation Council of Persian Gulf countries also attended the meeting.

The stock market fell into negative territory today as an early surge fizzled. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which spurted more than 20 points higher at the opening, was off 9.40 at 2,450.25 in the first hour and a half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gaining issues by about 7 to 5 with 671 declining, 505 advancing and 546 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 55.90 million shares as of 11 a.m. on Wall Street. The near-term crude contract opened nearly $1 a barrel lower. But as investors digested the news, their enthusiasm waned. In addition to the fact that no other country has followed Bush's lead in tapping their own oil reserves, the amount he plans to release is ``very small, very minor compared to what U.S. oil needs are,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at IDEA. Market watchers were immediately skeptical that the morning's bounce could be maintained. Given the decline in stock prices, no one was surprised by the advance, but a bearish sentiment hung over the market. DOC.HEAD: Maxwell Buys Minority Stake in Hungarian Daily
DOC.TEXT: Robert Maxwell's Mirror Group has bought a 40 percent stake in Budapest's evening daily Esti Hirlap, the British media baron's second such investment in Hungary, the newspaper reported Thursday. The Mirror Group bought a 40 percent stake in the paper for $750,000, Esti Hirlap said. The Hungarian News Publishing Co. also holds 40 percent while the paper's editorial board controls the remaining 20 percent. Maxwell's purchase follows five months of negotiations since an initial letter of intent was signed. Esti Hirlap, formerly controlled by the Budapest Communist Party, has a circulation of about 80,000. Previously, Maxwell bought a 49 percent stake in Magyar Hirlap, the former government daily. On Wednesday, Maxwell announced that he was in a partnership with the investment bank Merrill Lynch that would set up a $250 million Central and East European investment fund in the Hungarian capital, the national news agency MTI reported. The fund will finance projects in energy, tourism, consumer-goods manufacture and telecommunications, MTI said.
