DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Rise Despite Bush's Decision to Sell Reserves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs with prices briefly passing $40 a barrel, picks up 7th graf, ``We have ...
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices advanced today, moving briefly past the $40-a-barrel mark for the first time, as another round of antagonistic statements from Iraq overshadowed President Bush's decision to sell a small part of the government's oil reserves. The November contract for light, sweet crude was up 68 cents at $39.35 a 42-gallon barrel at midday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Earlier in the session, the contract rose to $40.10, the first time the price of oil has traded above $40. Analysts said Bush's decision to release 5 million of America's 590 million barrels of strategic reserves was intended to calm the market, where prices have doubled since early August. ``He's recognized correctly that the battle is taking place in the psychological arena,'' said Peter Beutel, an energy market analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. Psychology was at work in the market again today. An Iraqi threat to execute U.S. and other diplomats unless they hand over Westerners they're sheltering revived trader fears that a possible military conflict could disrupt oil supplies from Saudi Arabia. The threat punctured the brief stability Bush's announcement had given the market. The November contract for crude fell to $37.67 in early trading before reversing course. ``We have not lost any Saudi production, but the threat of losing it is making people constantly nervous,'' Beutel said. In earlier London trading, North Sea Brent Blend for November delivery was trading at $36.75 a barrel, down $1.20 from Wednesday's close of $37.95 a barrel. Bush said the country has ``sufficient oil to meet current needs,'' and added that ``there is no justification for the intensive and unwarranted speculation in oil futures.'' One London broker said the announcement ``has reminded people that there are a number of large strategic reserves in the West which could be released if this is deemed to be necessary, so it may calm matters slightly.'' Paul Spedding, an oil analyst at the London investment firm Kleinwort Benson Ltd., said, ``People were beginning to despair that the U.S. government would never use its stocks. ``It has now been demonstrated there is a restraint mechanism on oil prices. It is a small but symbolic move,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Renault, Volvo Deal Approved by Swedish Authorities
DOC.TEXT: The government gave its final approval Thursday to a deal between Swedish car maker Volvo and Renault, the French state-owned automotive concern. Volvo and Renault will swap 45 percent of shares in their truck and bus operations and exchange 25 percent of stock in their car divisions, a press release from Volvo said. Renault's acquisition would make it the largest ever foreign investment in Sweden, Volvo said. The deal makes the two auto makers ``the world's largest industrial group for heavy trucks, Europe's largest bus manufacturer and one of the world's largest car makers,'' Volvo said. It will also reinforce Volvo's presence in the European Community, where Sweden is not a member. Volvo received approval to use 3 billion kronor, or $5.2 million, of its investment reserves through 1993 in Sweden. The deal must win the approval of the French government before it can be concluded formally in January 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Gold Rises
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites thruout to UPDATE with closing European rates, midday New York rates. An AMs version planned by 5:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell slightly against other major currencies in European trading Thursday. Gold prices were higher. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar traded in a narrow range in the absence of any market-moving news. But they said that general perceptions of fundamental weakness in the U.S. economy continues to depress the dollar. Some profit-taking from previous gains and a drop on Wall Street also helped keep the dollar on the defensive, dealers said. In London, the British pound rose to $1.8690 from $1.8635 late Wednesday. By midday in New York, the dollar traded at $1.8725. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.5685 German marks, down from 1.5715; 1.3055 Swiss francs, down from 1.3110; 5.2555 French francs, down from 5.2615; 1.7695 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7725; 1,175.50 Italian lire, down from 1,176.00; and 1.1573 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1535. Selected midday dollar rates in New York: 1.5660 German marks, 1.2980 Swiss francs, 1,170.00 Italian lire, and 1.15475 Canadian dollars. In Tokyo, the dollar closed up 137.50 Japanese yen from 137.40 yen Wednesday. It traded at 138.45 yen in London, and 138.04 by midday in New York. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $405.75 a troy ounce from $404.85 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold closed at $406 an ounce, up from $402.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $3.12 to close at $403.29 an ounce. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $4.80 a troy ounce from $4.81 bid late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: State Gas, Electric, Subway Companies Up For Sale
DOC.TEXT: The government plans to sell the state-owned gas, electric and water companies and the Buenos Aires subway system, President Carlos Menem said Wednesday. The privatization decree ``has already been drawn up'' and will be signed next week when he returns from trips to Venezuela and the United States, the president told reporters at Ezeiza International Airport. The sale of loss-ridden public companies has been a centerpiece of Menem's 14-month-old government. On Oct. 8, the state telephone company and airline are scheduled to be transferred to private owners. Many other state companies are in the process of being sold, leased or deregulated, including the railroad, defense industries, chemical plants and the oil company that is the country's biggest in terms of annual sales.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Appeals State Supreme Court for Lower Bail
DOC.TEXT: Jailed savings and loan executive Charles H. Keating Jr. has appealed to the state Supreme Court for a reduction in his $5 million bail. In his Wednesday appeal, the former chairman of American Continental Corp. said the high bail constitutes cruel and unusual punishment. He also has claimed he cannot legally defend himself properly from a jail cell. Keating filed the petition after the state's 2nd District Court of Appeal on Tuesday rejected his request to reduce the bail Superior Judge Gary Klausner set for him Sept. 18. Klausner last week refused to lower the bail, saying the charges against Keating were so serious he might flee. Keating has been charged along with three co-defendants in the selling of more than $200 million in risky junk bonds to more than 17,000 investors through branches of Lincoln Savings & Loan. The bonds became nearly worthless in April 1989 when Lincoln was seized by federal regulators and American Continental, its parent company, filed for bankruptcy. The co-defendants, officers of American Continental or Lincoln, originally were held on $1 million bail each. Their individual bails were later reduced to $100,000 or $200,000 and they were freed after posting bail. Keating's latest appeal claims the case against him should receive the same consideration as those of his co-defendants. Keating has declared he is bankrupt and cannot pay the bail. His attorneys say he is about $5 million in debt, and even if his children offer their houses as collateral, they could only pay about $500,000 of the bail. According to court testimony last week, Keating was worth nearly $40 million three years ago. Keating's attorneys have said he is not a flight risk, arguing he has not fled any of more than two dozen civil cases filed against him since his firm went to bankruptcy court.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Tumble Again, Dollar Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, The 225-issue . . . to CORRECT close to 21,771.91 sted as sent. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, On WEdnesday . . .
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices sank to 33-month lows today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, weighed down by pessimism about the Middle East and other negative factors. The dollar edged higher against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 478.71 points, or 2.15 percent, to close at 21,771.91 points, its lowest finish since Jan. 4, 1988. Volume on the first section was an estimated 430 million shares. On Wednesday, the index shed 1,108.70 points, or 4.75 percent, the ninth largest single-day decline as measured by points in the index's history. The Tokyo Stock Price Index, which lists all shares on the exchange's First Section, has been an even better guide to recent market activity, said Yoshio Miyauchi, an equities trader for Shearson Lehman Hutton Asia. The TOPIX index weighs shares according to the company size and other factors, so a fall in the stock value of a large company has a greater impact than an equal decline in the value of a smaller company. Today, the TOPIX index fell 31.18 points, or 1.89 percent, to 1,620.26, the lowest level since Jan. 1, 1988. The Nikkei has lost a total of 44.05 percent since the beginning of the year, the second largest cumulative percentage loss after World War II. In 1965, the index fell 44.2 percent. News that the Baghdad had notified the United States embassy that it would apply the death penalty to anyone hiding foreigners in diplomatic embassies sent the stock market plummeting in the morning, analysts said. The market recovered during the day but ended down. ``I am afraid to say that Japanese investors just lost all confidence,'' especially after the Nikkei index fell below the psychological barrier of 23,000 points on Wednesday, said Amy Yip, manager of sales at Baring Securities. Individual investors had been propping up the market for a couple of months after institutional investors retreated to the sidelines. But higher interest rates and inflation fears linked to higher oil prices are starting to extract a toll, Yip said. North Sea Brent crude oil prices came down sharply today on word that the United States would be selling 5 million barrels of oil from its strategic petroleum reserves to stem rising prices. At about 3 a.m. EDT in Tokyo, Brent crude for November delivery was notionally valued at about $36.60 a barrel, down from $38.10 a barrel in New York late Wednesday.

The New York market moved from an initial strong start to a sizeable decline while the London market was in session, and traders said all eyes were watching the U.S. market. DOC.HEAD: Italian Auto Giant Reports Lower Pre-tax Profit In First Half
DOC.TEXT: The automotive giant Fiat said Thursday its profit before taxes fell 12.6 percent in the first half of 1990 despite an 11.8 percent rise in revenue. The Turin-based company, which is owned by the Agnelli family, blamed the earnings drop on increased competition in its key markets and the sharp losses of its Brazilian subdiaries. In a statement, Fiat called the first-half results ``satisfactory'' but said the outlook for the second half was cause for concern because some of its sectors are likely to suffer from the impact of the Gulf crisis on the world economy. Fiat said that the January-June period this year its pre-tax profit dropped to 2.45 trillion lire, or $2.22 billion, from 2.80 trillion lire, or $2.54 billion, a year earlier. In the same period consolidated revenue rose to 30.3 trillion lire, or $27.5 billion, from 27.1 trillion lire, or $24.6 billion. Fiat's Brazilian units lost more than 300 billion lire, or $272 million, in the first half, in part because the Brazilian government's tough economic measures penalized exports.

DOC.HEAD: Italy Passes Its First Antitrust Law
DOC.TEXT: Italy's first anti-monopoly law cleared its last hurdle Thursday. The Industry Commission of the Italian Senate voted unanimously to approve the legislation, which will bring Italy into line with regulations laid down recently by the European Community. ``This decision has enabled us to provide an essential instrument to regulate the domestic market in harmony with the (European) Community orms,'' said Senator Robert Cassola, president of the Senate's Industry Commission. The Senate approved the law in a brief morning session, adding no changes to the version already approved by the Chamber of Deputies. Italy was among the last of its European counterparts to pass an antitrust law. The measure is designed to ensure free competition principles and prohibit the formation of monopolies or agreements among firms that would create dominant market positions. The legislation isn't likely to have any immediate impact on the current concentration of Italian industry, however. ``Other than the state monopolies that have formed over the years, there are very few monopolies in Italy,'' said Paolo Filippo Lardera, Italy analyst with UBS Phillips and Drew in London. ``This measure must be viewed in a wider European context, because Italian industry is already disadvantaged with respect to the rest of Europe in terms of dimension and the fragmentation of many sectors,'' Lardera said. Under the law, an anti-monopoly commission will be established to enforce the new norms. The commission will have authority to review cases on its own or on request by the Industry Ministry. The most controversial portion of the new law regulates the relationship between banks and industry, limiting the degree of control industrial companies can acquire over the financial sector. As a result of the new law, an industrialist won't be allowed to acquire direct or indirect shareholdings of more than 15 percent in a bank. Furthermore, a company must inform the Bank of Italy if it takes up more than 5 percent of a bank. Companies will be permitted to participate in shareholder syndicates of banks provided they don't gain a majority position in the syndicate. These provisions evolved in an effort, championed by the Bank of Italy, to safeguard the financial sector from manipulation by industrial companies. Although Italy's 1936 Banking Law prevents commercial banks from taking permanent shareholdings in industry, until now there was no legislation to prevent companies from acquiring stakes in banks.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Plunge in Profits
DOC.TEXT: Ing. C. Olivetti & C. Spa, the office equipment manufacturer, reported Thursday a 41 percent drop in its profit before taxes for the first half of 1990. Olivetti's chairman and controlling shareholder, Carlo De Benedetti, blamed the earnings drop on tough market conditions, a continuing squeeze in profit margins and an unfavorable exchange rate for the lira. The company posted consolidated pre-tax profit of 60.9 billion lire, or $52.1 million, in the first six months of the year, down from 102.6 billion lire, or $87.7 million, a year earlier. Revenue rose 5.8 percent to 4.167 trillion lire, or $3.56 billion. Stagnation in the U.S. computer market, a continued slowdown of the European market and growing competition by U.S. and Japanese computer manufacturers all increased pressure on margins, the company said. The lira's strength against the dollar and European currencies hurt Olivetti because the bulk of its production costs are in lire while 60 percent of its sales are in foreign currency, De Benedetti said. In fact, adjusted for exchange rate fluctuations, revenue rose 8.8 percent in the first semester, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Contributes to TV Ads Promoting State Tourism
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Corp. is giving $7 million to the Alaska Visitors Association for a national television advertising campaign to bring back visitors who may have been scared away by last year's oil spill. Starting Thursday, half of the nation's television viewers will be exposed to the three 30-second commercials, said Karen Cowart, the association's director. The commercials dovetail with Exxon's message about the effects of the spill on Prince William Sound. ``See its pristine shoreline, nearly restored after last year's spill,'' an announcer says. Exxon's contribution to the ads ``is consistent with our performance here to help industries in this state that may have suffered some damage as a result of the spill,'' said Karsten Rodvik, a company spokesman. Exxon last summer contributed to a print and broadcast ad campaign that was responsible for convincing 11,000 people to visit Alaska last summer despite an initial reticence, Cowart said. She said this summer's tourist season has been strong, although some fishing lodges report lingering effects from anglers' attitudes about the spill. Studies have suggested the spill may have cost Alaska nearly $20 million in lost tourist spending last year.

DOC.HEAD: Isuzu May Join GM in Czechslovakian Project
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. and Isuzu Motors Ltd. may participate in a truck manufacturing project in Czechoslovakia, a GM spokesman said Thursday. ``We are having discussions in Czechoslovakia about possible activity with commercial vehicles,'' GM spokesman Jack Harned said. ``Participation does not mean it will necessarily be a joint venture company. Specifics of the project have not been determined.'' GM owns 40.2 percent of Isuzu, Japan's second largest truck maker. GM has been working with the manufacturer Bratislava in Czechoslovakia, he said, and Isuzu would likely be involved in some capacity if an agreement is reached. ``It could be their product or their technology. Some form of participation by Isuzu could be likely,'' he said. GM currently has agreements with subsidiaries in Czechoslovakia to manufacture transmissions. The Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading economic newspaper, said the commercial vehicle plan was recently disclosed by John Smith, vice chairman of GM. Smith was quoted as saying Isuzu might cooperate in producing commercial vehicles in Hungary. Harned, however, denied the report and said GM had no plans to make commercial vehicles in Hungary. Earlier this year, GM and RABA, Hungary's state-owned manufacturer of trucks, diesel engines and axles, announced a plan to invest in a plant under construction in the city of Szentgotthard. The deal made GM the first U.S. automaker to invest in Eastern Europe, which has experienced political and economic liberalization in recent months. Chrysler Corp. sells cars in Europe but doesn't run independent manufacturing plants there. Ford Motor Co. spokesmen have said the No. 2 automaker was closely watching the Eastern Europe market.

NEW YORK (AP - Stock prices were sharply depressed today as an early surge fizzled along with a hike in oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which surged more than 20 points higher at the opening, was off 31.93 at 2,427.72 an hour before the closing bell. Losers outnumbered gaining issues by nearly 4 to 1 with 1,197 declining, 343 advancing and 429 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 154.68 million shares as of 3 p.m. on Wall Street. The market was jolted upward by lower energy prices and higher bond prices, which were triggered by President Bush's announcement Wednesday that he will sell 5 million barrels from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The near-term crude contract opened nearly $1 a barrel lower. But investors quickly realized that not only had no other country acted similarly, the amount of oil the president plans to release is ``very small, very minor compared to what U.S. oil needs are,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at IDEA. Crude prices spiked up above $40 to a new record before receding, and the stock market's decline accelerated. At one point the Dow was off 50 points, triggering the New York Stock Exchange's ``uptick rule,'' which restricts computer-driven program sell orders. The financial sector continued to take a severe beating and served as a drag on the rest of the market. Several big bank issues hit 52-week lows in the previous session and tumbled even further today. Among them, Citicorp was down 1\ at 13\; NCNB plunged 3{ to 19}; Chase Manhattan was down } at 10] and Continental Bank was off { at 7{. Among other actively traded issues on the Big Board, Union Carbide, which announced a restructuring plan that includes a stock buyback, was up } at 15; Philip Morris was down \ at 44], and IBM was down { at 104~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 2.16 to 165.36. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index stood at 305.51, off 4.55.

DOC.HEAD: American Continental Liquidation Plan on Way to Creditors
DOC.TEXT: A liquidation plan for American Continental Corp., formerly led by Charles H. Keating Jr., is headed toward a creditors' committee after a nod from a federal judge. The plan's provisions include a $21 million payment by the government to creditors, disposal of American Continental's assets and agreement by the government to join lawsuits filed by creditors against Keating and others. During a hearing Wednesday, District Judge Richard Bilby indicated he intends to approve the plan with some modifications, law clerk Linda McNulty said Thursday. The plan now goes to a creditors' committee, which will revise it before returning it to the judge. Bilby could either approve it or order more changes as early as next week, Ms. McNulty said. The plan would then be sent to all of the approximately 25,000 creditors. Both a majority of individual creditors and those holding the majority of the $365 million debt must approve the plan. Phoenix-based American Continental filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April 1989. The next day its primary subsidiary, Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., was seized by federal regulators. In a related ruling Wednesday, Bilby approved the settlement of two lawsuits filed by American Continental investors. Both were against law firms accused of helping Keating deceive investors and government regulatory agencies as to the stability of his financial empire. The settlements, for a total $24.3 million, will return 10 percent of what investors are believed to have lost when American Continental collapsed. Keating and three other former executives of American Continental or Lincoln were indicted in Los Angeles last week on state charges of securities fraud stemming from the sales of junk bonds. Keating remained jailed Thursday in lieu of $5 million bond pending an Oct. 5 arraignment, although he has appealed to the state Supreme Court to reduce his bail. The liquidation plan was agreed to by American Continental, its creditors and the Resolution Trust Corp., the federal agency that took over Lincoln after it was seized by regulators. Under the plan, American Continental's remaining assets, last valued at $16 million, would be disposed of over a three-year period. The RTC would provide creditors with $21 million immediately upon approval of the plan, providing creditors with compensation ranging up to 21 cents on the dollar. In return, the creditors would drop all claims against Lincoln Savings' 11 subsidiaries. The plan also calls for the RTC to become a party in a series of lawsuits against more than 50 defendants, including Keating, other former American Continental and Lincoln officials and numerous business associates.

DOC.HEAD: Laura Ashley to Close or Sell Most Factories, Cut Jobs By One-Fifth
DOC.TEXT: Laura Ashley, hailed as a great British retailing success story until falling on hard times, said Thursday it will sell or close most of its factories and cut its work force by one-fifth in an effort to survive. The retailer of English country-style women's clothing and home furnishings operates nearly 500 stores worldwide, 185 of them in the United States. Its shops are recognizable by their dark green fronts and blackberry sprig motif and are best-known for their flower-print, Victorian-style dresses. In a drastic switch, the company said it decided to largely abandon manufacturing its own apparel because it can be bought much more cheaply from outside suppliers. The slimdown is part of a year-old cost-cutting program, it said. It blamed the strong British pound and high inflation for its woes. Seven of its nine factories in Britain and Ireland will be closed or sold, and 1,500 of its 8,150 jobs will go, the company said. Stock of Laura Ashley Holdings has suffered along with the company's fortunes. It traded at the equivalent of $1.12 a share on London's Stock Exchange Thursday, unchanged from Wednesday, and less than half the price at which investors snapped up the shares when the company went public in 1985. Money-losing Laura Ashley is not the only troubled British retailer. Many operators have suffered from 15 percent interest rates, engineered by the government to curb inflation by slowing consumer spending. The annual inflation rate is running at 10.6 percent. Another of Britain's one-time retailing stars, the sock chain Sock Shop International PLC, fell into the hands of administrators earlier this year. Laura Ashley said it will retain enough in-house manufacturing to respond to changes in market needs. It said it would continue printing its own fabrics and wallpaper, and making its own curtains. Chairman Bernard Ashley issued a statement saying, ``If Laura Ashley is to survive in today's highly competitive environment,'' it could no longer supply its stores worldwide with garments made in its British factories. For years, the company had pursued a strategy of being a fully integrated retailer by making what it sold. In late August, Laura Ashley moved to raise cash and inspire confidence by selling a 15 percent stake to the Japanese retailer Jusco Co. for $56 million. The Ashley family, with the Ashley Foundation, retained a 59 percent stake. Joan d'Olier, a retail analyst with the London investment firm County Natwest Woodmac, said about the latest moves: ``It's good they have bitten the bullet. Long-term, they had to bring down the cost base in order to have a viable continuing business.'' Brian Corris, an analyst with Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. said: ``I think it's got a long way to go but this (abandoning manufacturing) is obviously a step in the right direction.'' Mrs. d'Olier blamed the company's difficulties on mismanagement. ``It hasn't been a sale problem. It's been a cost problem,'' she said. The Laura Ashley look still has appeal, Mrs. d'Olier said. ``The biggest asset the company has is the Laura Ashley brand. There is still a lot of goodwill attached to that.'' The company, which had been expected to report its half-year results this week, said they would be released in mid-October. It lost the equivalent of about $18.3 million in the year ended Jan. 27, compared with a profit of $15.7 million the previous year. Sales grew to $555 million from $472 million. The late Laura Ashley and her husband Bernard began the clothier as a small cottage industry in a London apartment 37 years ago. They printed fabrics on their kitchen table. The couple expanded into garments, accessories, wallpaper and soft furnishings. They opened their first store in 1968. The Welsh-born Mrs. Ashley died of head injuries in September 1985 at the age of 60 after falling down steep stairs at her daughter's West England home.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Corp. Bondholders Approve Brewery Sale
DOC.TEXT: Bondholders in Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. on Thursday approved the sale of the company's brewery operations to Bell Resources Ltd. Bell, which is 58 percent owned by Bond Corp., plans to sell a 50 percent stake in the breweries to Lion Nathan Ltd., a New Zealand-based brewer, and operate them as a joint venture. The European bondholder approval came a day after Alan Bond resigned as chairman and a director of Bond Corp. to pave a way for the financially troubled concern's restructuring. The brewery sale still could collapse if a group of investors who hold certain debentures issued by Bond Brewing Holdings Ltd. in the United States fails to agree to sell the securities back to the company at a discount. That buy-back offer has been extended until Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Grains Mixed, Beans Higher on BOT
DOC.TEXT: Wheat and soybean futures were mostly higher, while corn was mostly lower at the close of an unremarkable day of trading Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat futures prices extended Wednesday's gains after the Agriculture Department confirmed reports that it has offered to sell subsidized flour to the Soviet Union, Morocco and other West African countries. None of the countries have made a firm commitment to buy. ``There is the expectation that at some point the Soviets will come in and be a buyer,'' said Walter Spilka, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York. ``Right now, everybody's waiting for that. It takes some of the pressure off the market.'' Soybean futures prices followed wheat's lead after the USDA also reported the Soviet Union might be interested in buying soybean meal, Spilka said. Speculation that the deal may be soon came after several major commercial firms bought good quantities of soybean meal contracts, he said. Corn futures prices were mostly lower in thin, quiet trading after morning weather reports predicted near-ideal harvest weather over the next week. Such good weather hold prices lower because there is no fear of shortages. The USDA grain stocks report also was a factor in the thin trading, some analysts said. But Spilka said after the report's release at the close of trading that it should have little effect on Friday's market. ``In the past, the numbers have been all ver the map,'' he said. ``I wouldn't place great emphasis on the report having much influence.'' Soybeans, which analysts estimated would average 249 million bushels, came in at 239 million; corn, estimated at 1.34 billion bushels, came in at 1.34 billion; and wheat, estimated at 2.469 billion bushels, came in the low end of trade expectations at 2.402 billion bushels. The numbers represent the government's estimate on the stockpile of grains as of Sept. 1. At the close, wheat was { cent to 1{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.77{ a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to 1 cent higher with December at $2.27\ a bushel; oats were 1 cent lower to 1{ cents higher with December at $1.15} a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 4} cents higher with November at $6.19\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Rose $361.6 Million in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 524 money market mutual funds edged up $361.6 million in the latest week to a record total of $409.12 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise in the seven-day period ended Wednesday followed a $1.72 billion increase in the funds' assets the previous week that had lifted the funds' assets to the previous all-time high of $408.76 billion, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 256 general purpose funds rose $681.3 million to $145.53 billion and assets of 163 institutional funds rose $185.8 million to $98.48 billion while assets of 105 broker-dealer funds fell $505.5 million to $165.10 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds edged up in the week ended Tuesday to 7.47 percent from 7.46 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield held steady at 7.47 percent, unchanged from the previous week, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was also unchanged at 46 days, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nati n's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts held steady at 6.05 percent as of Wednesday, the same as a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, were also steady at 5.02 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.69 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, unchanged from the previous week. Yields were 7.83 percent on 1-year CDs, unchanged; 7.94 percent on 2{-year CDs, up from 7.92 percent; and 8.06 percent on 5-year CDs, up from 8.05 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Sentencing Put Off For Milken, Hearing Planned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES pvs; CORRECTS day to Wednesday, sted Thursday in 5th graf; EDITS to tighten; ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today put off the Monday sentencing of Michael Milken and ordered an extraordinary hearing to consider the unadmitted crimes alleged by the government against the junk-bond financier. U.S. District Judge Kimba M. Wood said she would hold a hearing in early October for approximately two weeks and give each side 20 hours to present arguments before pronouncing sentence. Milken pleaded guilty in April to six felonies and faces a maximum 28 years in prison for his role in Wall Street's worst financial scandal. The government had urged the judge to give Milken a stiff sentence in a pre-sentencing memorandum that outlined a broader array of crimes than those Milken admitted in his plea bargain. More than 200 pages of documents detailing those accusations were released Wednesday by order of the judge. The defense also had released a mountain of documents refuting the government's arguments and suggesting community service as an alternative sentence for the fallen billionaire. Federal law allows a judge to consider such evidence before passing sentence but must give the defense an opportunity to respond. Wood's ruling shocked defense attorneys, who have wanted to proceed wih the sentencing for months. Lead attorney Arthur Liman said, ``I was hoping we could dispense with this.'' He said such a hearing would ``prolong the extraordinary anguish and agony for my client's family.'' Wood tentatively scheduled a conference between the prosecutors and Milken's lawyers Tuesday to further define the extent of the extraordinary hearing. It was unclear when Milken would be ultimately sentenced. Milken was not in court. ``Your purpose should be to shed light on the defendant's character,'' Wood told the opposing lawyers. Wood's ruling made it almost certain that Milken's chief accuser Ivan Boesky would be called to testify about the extent of his relationship with Milken. But lawyers said it was unclear whether Milken would be present in the courtroom for such proceedings. In their pre-sentencing memorandum, the prosecutors did not prescribe a specific sentence for Milken, but drew a comparison to his co-conspirator Boesky. The convicted speculator and informant paid $100 million to settle insider trading charges, pleaded guilty to a felony and was sentenced to a three-year term now completed. ``Milken stands convicted of six times as many felony charges as Boesky and has agreed to pay six times Boesky's criminal fine and civil penalty,'' the prosecution said. ``While the government does not suggest that simple arithmetic should determine Milken's sentence, Milken's suggestion that - facing almost six times Boesky's penalty - he merits a fraction of his punishment is preposterous.'' Milken, one of the nation's richest men, paid a record $600 million in penalties as part of his plea agreement. The government's memo, which urged a substantial prison term for Milken, was riddled with allegations of insider trading, manipulation, bribery and hiding evidence by Milken, going far beyond the felonies to which he pleaded guilty. But the document offered little in the way of new evidence to support the claims. It also suggsted Milken's alleged greed hastened the demise of his former employer, the now-defunct junk-bond powerhouse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., another victim of the scandal which collapsed earlier this year. Contrary to Milken's claims of a modest, humble life in which money was secondary, the prosecution said he was obsessed with wealth and that his enormous compensation devoured much of Drexel's bottom line.

DOC.HEAD: Eli Lilly Gets FDA Approval for Coronary Artery Catheter
DOC.TEXT: Eli Lilly & Co. said it won approval for a new device for treating heart patients with clogged arteries - a catheter that removes rather than flattens the damaging plaque. The Simpson Coronary AtherCath is the first device that cuts, captures and removes plaque to gain approval by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, Lilly officials said. The catheter is manufactured by Devices for Vascular Intervention Inc., a California company Lilly purchased for $50 million last year. ``It's an important device. It has specific uses and it will add to the tools we have available, but it's not going to sweep everything else off the table,'' said Bruce F. Waller, a cardiac pathologist with the Indiana Heart Institute, where doctors helped test the device. Clogged arteries currently are treated with a balloon catheter, which doctors insert into a blood vessel and snake to the obstructed site. The balloon is expanded, flattening the plaque against the artery wall and allowing more blood to flow through the vessel. Researchers have been working on alternatives to balloon catheters in part because about one-third of the patients treated that way have partial blockage later. However, Waller said some studies indicate blockage recurs in up to 40 percent of patients treated with the atherectomy catheter. Because of that, Waller said the new device often will be used just before or as a follow-up treatment with the balloon catheters. More than 225,000 balloon catheter procedures are performed each year. Craig P. Baskin, an analyst with Duff and Phelps Inc. in Chicago, estimates the new device could account for about 10 percent of the operations.

Stock prices declined broadly today but managed to close off their worst levels as the rising price of oil drove investors to the sidelines. The decline, the sixth in seven trading days, underscored the market's inability to seize any kind of upward momentum. Prices surged at the opening bell, supported by a decline in oil prices following President Bush's announcement Wednesday that he would sell 5 million barrels from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. But traders soon realized the amount is insignificant compared with the nation's energy needs, and with tensions escalating in the Persian Gulf, oil prices spiked higher - briefly over a record $40 a barrel - and sent equities plunging. At one point the Dow Jones was industrial average was off 50 points, triggering the New York Stock Exchange's ``uptick rule,'' which restricts computer-driven program sell orders. The financial sector continued to take a severe beating and served as a drag on the rest of the market. Several big bank issues hit 52-week lows in the previous session and tumbled even further today.
