DOC.HEAD: Bank Customers Could End Up Paying More To Cover Deposit Insurance Hike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `If banks ...,' to CLARIFY that customers would lose $7.50 in interest, not savings.
DOC.TEXT: Bank customers could pay higher fees or receive lower interest on their savings to help make up for the 60 percent increase in bank insurance premiums mandated by regulators, industry analysts said Thursday. The insurance increase also could reduce profits in an already-troubled industry, the analysts said. But they added that the higher premiums for 1991 announced Thursday were necessary to ensure the health of the banking system. ``The FDIC (Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.) needs the money,'' said Christopher Mahoney, an analyst at Moody's Investors Service. ``The soundness of the FDIC is important.'' Analysts believe many banks will try to pass on to customers some of the premium increase in the form of higher fees for checking accounts, bounced checks and other services. Banks also may try to lower the interest they pay on savings accounts, certificates of deposit and other investments. Under the increase, banks will pay the FDIC 19.5 cents in insurance for each $100 in deposits starting next year. Currently, they pay 12 cents per $100 in deposits. If banks were to pass on to customers the full 7.5 cent increase, a customer with $10,000 in his savings account would lose $7.50 in interest over a year, disregarding compounding. But such moves could be met with resistance and loss of customers, analysts said. ``It's pretty hard to gouge the customer when the customer has other alternatives,'' said Eric Hemel of the investment firm First Boston Corp. He said savers could put their money in mutual funds or other investments, or switch banks. That means banks may be forced to absorb some or all of the insurance increase, which could affect their earnings and be especially troubling to weaker institutions. ``Revenues at banks are not growing robustly, so any increase in expenses is going to hurt,'' said Cheryl Swaim of the investment firm Oppenheimer & Co. She estimated the higher premiums could lower overall bank profits by 2 percent to 3 percent. Ms. Swaim said most banks do not disclose the percentage of their expenses composed of FDIC fees, but one that does, First Wachovia Corp. of Winston-Salem, N.C., said its FDIC cost was 3 percent of its expenses. ``It's not a huge chunk,'' she said. But ``for the banks that aren't earning much money it's going to be a higher percentage of their earnings.'' The insurance increase could push barely profitable banks into the red. In fact, the FDIC calculated that if the 1991 rate had been in effect last year, 69 banks would have recorded losses instead of profits and four additional banks would have failed. The American Bankers Association believes the increase also could lower the amount of money banks have available to make loans, said spokeswoman Ginnie Dean. She said the trade association supports the increase as a necessary step, but believes changes in the FDIC insurance program are needed. Insurance increases could be counterproductive in the long run because of their potential to make more banks unprofitable, she added. First Boston's Hemel said concern about the latest FDIC insurance increase overlooks the bigger picture of what future increases may be needed to bail out troubled banks as the economy weakens. He thinks future hikes could be much larger than the 1991 increase. The prices of many bank stocks tumbled Thursday, but analysts said it was due mostly to trouble reported by several major banks in recent days, not to the insurance increase. On Thursday, Bank of Boston said it expected to report a loss this quarter and would reduce its quarterly dividend by two-thirds. On Wednesday, NCNB Corp., a bank based in Charlotte, N.C., said it would report sharply lower earnings this quarter and would increase its reserves for potentially bad loans. And last week, Chase Manhattan Corp., the nation's second-largest bank, said it expects a loss this quarter and would cut its dividend in half.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador and Italian Minister Sign Air Accord
DOC.TEXT: After 20 years of negotiations, Italy and the United States signed a memorandum Thursday that will allow Italy's flagship airline to land in four additional U.S. cities. The government-owned Alitalia will offer year-round service to Boston, Miami, Chicago, Washington and Philadelphia with the option to add four more destinations in the near future. It currently has regular flights to New York, Los Angeles and Chicago, and flies seasonally to Boston. The accord takes effect on October 29th, when Alitalia begins its service to Miami. The memorandum of understanding also permits three U.S. carriers to fly to Italian cities. Until now, only two U.S. carriers - Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines - have had U.S.-Italy flights. American Airlines has already been approved for Italian flights and will begin flying from Chicago to Milan or Rome in 1991. The other two, to begin their flights in 1992 and 1994, will be chosen by the U.S. Department of Transportation from among Delta, Northwestern, United and Continental.

DOC.HEAD: GM to Repair Flaking Paint on Some Vehicles
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. dealers will offer free paint jobs to approximately 324,000 vehicles that may have had their coats damaged by ultraviolet light, the automaker said Thursday. Paint on some of the vehicles has flaked because ultraviolet light penetrates the topcoat of paint, damages the base primer and causes a loss of adhesion between the surfaces, the automaker said in a written statement. GM will inspect and repair about 230,000 1987-90 Chevrolet Berettas or Corsicas painted sapphire blue, medium sapphire blue, silver or gunmetal gray at no charge to the owner, the release said. Also to be repaired are about 93,500 1988-89 Chevrolet S-10 Blazers, S-10 pickups, GMC S-15 Jimmys and S-15 pickups painted bright blue, dark blue or gray metallic, the company said. The repair polcies are valid for three years from the date the vehicle was placed in service. For owners of the cars or light trucks that have passed that date, the refinishing offer will be extended another 12 months to Sept. 30, 1991, the release said. If vehicle owners already have paid for paint repairs, the company will reimburse them, the No. 1 automaker said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Merger Activity Edges Up in 3rd Quarter
DOC.TEXT: U.S. merger activity picked up slightly during the third quarter from the previous three months but continued to fall back sharply from 1989 levels, according to statistics released Thursday. The value of domestic mergers rose 7 percent from July through September when compared with the second quarter, said Securities Data Corp., a business research firm. During the third quarter, there were 941 deals worth a total of $58.6 billion announced, against 1,284 deals worth $47.8 billion announced in the second quarter, the company said. The pace was sharply lower from the 1,231 transactions worth $139.4 billion announced in the third quarter of 1989. The year-earlier levels were already down sharply from 1988, when the takeover boom hit its peak. The mergers business began to slow in early 1989 and then changed dramatically after last fall's collapse of the junk bond market made financing for deals harder to come by. In compiling its statistics, Securities Data considered transactions including mergers, acquisitions, repurchases, spin-offs, self-tenders of stock, minority stake purchases and leveraged recapitalizations. The number of stock repurchases increased during the third quarter as some companies took advantage of lower prices on Wall Street and began to buy back their shares. The Dow Jones industrial average reached a high of 2,999.75 on July 16 and 17, but has fallen more than 570 points since then as concerns about the economy and tensions in the Persian Gulf sent stock prices tumbling. Over the first three quarters of 1990, domestic merger activity fell 52 percent from a year earlier, with 3,306 deals valued at $151.2 billion announced, down from 3,734 deals worth $333 billion, Securities Data said. Securities Data said global merger activity also declined, but the value of British transactions increased 75 percent in the third quarter from the second quarter. There were 318 deals worth $24.1 billion involving British firms from July through September, up from 319 deals worth $13.7 billion the previous quarter, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Allied Bondholders Press for Right to Sue
DOC.TEXT: A committee representing bondholders of Allied Stores Corp. asked a bankruptcy judge Thursday for permission to sue Allied's owners and banks, alleging they fraudulently took money out of the company. Bondholders' lawyers argued that the threat of a lawsuit - which would seek damages of at least $700 million and possibly $1 billion - might prod the targets to settle the claims. ``I suggest that it's very important these issues be resolved,'' said Jonathan Jacobson, a lawyer on the bondholders' committee representing investors in Allied. ``It is critical that the defendants face the prospect of judicial reckoning.'' U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. took the case under review. He did not say when he would rule. His permission is needed for the litigation to proceed because Aug is overseeing the Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization of Allied and its sister retailer, Cincinnati-based Federated Department Stores Inc. In a Sept. 6 letter, the bondholders' lawyers said the prospective defendants in the lawsuit could include: Toronto-based Campeau Corp., which bought Allied in 1986; Federated Stores Inc., which is Campeau's U.S. retailing subsidiary; Bank of Montreal; Banque Paribas; Citibank, Edward J. DeBartolo Corp., First Boston Corp., and former officers and directors of Allied. Bondholders contend that up to $1 billion in proceeds from Allied's 1989 sale of the Ann Taylor store division and 1988 sale of Brooks Brothers were fraudulently conveyed to buy worthless stock or to pay off bank debt. The transactions stripped assets from Allied to the detriment of its investors, the bondholders allege. The lawyers gave advance notice of the lawsuit to meet a requirement by Aug. Lawyers for Allied and several targets of the threatened lawsuit asked Aug to prevent its filing, saying it could slow the reorganization. They also argued that it could become a tangled litigation involving multiple parties and said it should be up to Allied, not the bondholders, to resolve the claims since Allied has primary responsibility for charting its reorganization. Allied lawyer John Newman said the proposed lawsuit could become a ``wide-screen cinema production.'' Jacobson asked Aug to permit the bondholders to sue on or after Feb. 28, 1991, the deadline which ends the period in which Allied and Federated have the exclusive right to file their reorganization plans. After that, creditors may file their own suggested reorganization plans. In another matter, Aug approved a request from Federated and Allied to appoint a committee to represent the interests of retired non-union employees of the companies in the reorganization. The judge also approved Allied's sale of a company jet, a Gulfstream III, to the Deluxe Corp. of St. Paul, Minn., for $11.9 million. Federated and Allied filed reorganization petitions Jan. 15, listing more than $7.7 billion in debts. Most of those debts were acquired because of borrowings by Campeau Corp. to buy Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Off
DOC.TEXT: The dollar weakened Thursday against all major currencies except the Japanese yen, which remained pressured by rising oil prices and another sharp decline on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Gold prices retreated after rising overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $405 a troy ounce, down $2 from late Wednesday. Republic National Bank in New York also quoted a late bid for gold at $405 an ounce, down $1.70. Currency dealers said trading was slow and in a broad range in the absence of any fundamental news. ``The market has no clear direction and it probably won't until the budget situation is resolved and something happens in the Middle East,'' said Earl I. Johnson, a vice president and dealer at Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago. ``(The market) is being constantly buffeted by rumors.'' Johnson said the dollar was hurt by speculation of a budget compromise in Washington but supported by rumors of escalating tensions between the United States and Iraq in the Persian Gulf. The confrontation between the two countries, following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last month, has brought a sharp rise in oil price throughout the world. Particularly hard hit has been Japan, which imports about 95 percent of its petroleum. On Thursday, stock prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange sank to 33-month lows as oil prices continued to advance. The dollar gained ground against the yen everywhere. In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar closed up 137.50 Japanese yen from 137.40 yen Wednesday. It traded at 138.45 yen in London, and at 137.98 yen in New York, up from 136.855. But the dollar weakened against the British pound. Sterling rose to $1.8690 from $1.8635 in London, and to $1.8780 from $1.8718 in New York. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.5610 German marks, down from 1.5660; 1.2925 Swiss francs, down from 1.3025; 5.2250 French fracs, down from 5.2410; 1,169.25 Italian lire, down from 1,172.00; and 1.15495 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15635. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Wednesday: 1.5685 German marks, down from 1.5715; 1.3055 Swiss francs, down from 1.3110; 5.2555 French francs, down from 5.2615; 1.7695 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7725; 1,175.50 Italian lire, down from 1,176.00; and 1.1573 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1535. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $405.75 an ounce fro $404.85 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold closed at $406 an ounce, up from $402.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $3.12 to close at $403.29 an ounce. Silver prices retreated. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.771 a troy ounce, down 2.7 cents from late Wednesday. Silver fell in London to $4.80 an ounce from $4.81.

DOC.HEAD: USX Corp. Fined $4.1 Million in Labor Scheme
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge fined USX Corp. $4.1 million Thursday and ordered two union officials to prison for their role in a scheme to get inflated pensions in exchange for approving a major labor pact. The fine was the maximum the company could have received after being convicted in July of conspiracy, mail fraud and violating federal labor laws. In addition to the fine, U.S. District Judge E.B. Haltom also ordered USX to pay restitution of $289,995 to two pension funds that prosecutors claimed were depleted as part of the 1983 plan. Haltom sentenced United Steelworkers Union officials E.B. Rich and Thermon Phillips to 36 months and 30 months in prison, respectively. The men, who faced as long as 37 months in prison, also were fined $6,000 each. Phillips released a statement saying the sentence was unjust, but representatives of the company and Rich declined comment. The judge said he was tougher on Rich, a regional subdirector, than Phillips, the regional union director, because evidence showed Rich was behind the plot. Both men were allowed to remain free on their original $500 bonds until Nov. 27, when Haltom ordered them to report to an unspecified minimum-security federal prison. During a 4{-month trial, prosecutors alleged Phillips and Rich illegally negotiated inflated pensions for themselves and four other union officials during talks that led to the reopening of USX's Fairfield Works in Birmingham. Both men denied any collusion, as did USX. Both the company and the men plan to appeal. Federal prosecutors said Rich received a USX pension based on about 31 years of work, although he actually was employed for 13 years. Phillips' pension was based on about 38 years of work, but he had only worked for the company from 1946 to 1951, when it was known as U.S. Steel.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Fell in Week
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply declined in the week ended Sept. 17, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,316.1 billion from $3,317.7 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,093.7 billion from $4,097.6 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, held at a seasonally adjusted $820.7 billion, the same as the prior week's revised level. The previous week's M1 total was originally reported as $820.5 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is five percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 1.8 percent, which is at the low end of the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,296.1 billion, a 2.6 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,081.8 billion, up 1.2 percent, while M1 rose 3.9 percent to an average of $814.2 billion. In another report: - The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $513 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $974 million the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down Sharply As Oil Prices Rise
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT advance-decline figures
DOC.TEXT: The stock market declined broadly again Thursday as higher oil prices spooked investors. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 32.17 points to 2,427.48. The key index lost nearly 26 points on Wednesday. Losing issues outnumbered gaining ones by about 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,182 down, 395 up and 422 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 182.69 million shares, up from 155.57 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 222.55 million shares. Stocks started the day on a strong note, with the Dow surging more than 20 points at the opening bell as traders drew encouragement from lower oil prices. But the enthusiasm was short-lived. The markets soon realized President Bush's move to sell 5 million barrels from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve would do little to satisfy the nation's energy needs. Oil prices climbed higher, with the near-term crude contract briefly topping $40 a barrel. The rise in oil prices quickly convinced investors to dump equities. At one point the Dow was off 50 points, triggering the New York Stock Exchange's ``uptick rule,'' which restricts computer-driven program sell orders. The financial sector continued to take a severe beating, which served as a drag on the rest of the market. Regulators voted Thursday to raise banks' deposit insurance premiums by more than 60 percent in 1991, a move analysts said could cut profits in an already troubled industry. ``The bank stocks are the hate group for the moment,'' said Alfred E. Goldman, a senior vice president at A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis. He said stories were being conjured up ``by the minute about money-center banks going belly up.'' The Bank of Boston, which fell ] to a 52-week low of 7[, announced it will cut its dividend, post a $250 million quarterly loss and seek 1,500 job cuts. NCNB fell 3[ to 20[; it announced late Wednesday that it was increasing its reserves to cover problem debt. Among other heavily traded bank issues, Citicorp lost } to 13}; Continental Bank was down | at 7]; Manfuacturers Hanover was down 1 at 20\; BankAmerica lost } to 19\, and Chase Manhattan fell [ to 11. Among other actively traded Big Board issues, General Electric was down 3] at 51|; Unisys lost 1| to 5]; MCA was down 2\ at 59; IBM was down 1 at 104], and Philip Morris was down | at 44. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $40.06 billion, or 1.42 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost 2.16 to 165.36. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 4.89 to 355.10, and S&P's 500-stock composite index lost 4.09 to 300.97. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 8.84 to 341.19. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 305.43, down 4.63.

DOC.HEAD: Banking Committee Approves SEC Nominee
DOC.TEXT: The nomination of Richard Y. Roberts to the Securities and Exchange Commission was cleared by the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee on Thursday. The nomination now goes to the full Senate for approval. No date for a vote has been set. Roberts, a former top aide to Sen. Richard Shelby, D-Ala., was nominated by President Bush last month to fill the last vacant seat on the five-member commission. The independent commission oversees the stock and bond markets as well as related exchanges, brokerages and investment companies. Roberts, 39, a native of Birmingham, Ala., told the committee at his confirmation hearing last week that rooting out insider trading and penalizing fraudulent investment advisers would be among his top priorities as a commissioner.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman of American Express Travel Unit to Retire
DOC.TEXT: Aldo Papone, chairman of American Express Travel Related Services Co. Inc., will retire Jan. 1, the American Express Co. unit announced Thursday. Papone will be succeeded by two co-chairmen, Edwin M. Cooperman, president of the unit's North American division, and G. Richard Thoman, president of American Express International, the company said. The two men also will serve as co-chief executive officers of the unit. Papone, who has held his post since April 1989, will become a senior adviser to American Express Co., reporting to Chairman James D. Robinson III. Papone also will continue as a member of the parent company's board of directors. ``This completes a management evolution that began almost 18 months ago when Aldo advised me that he would need to be less active in TRS (Travel Related Services) management activities for medical reasons,'' Robinson said in a statement. Cooperman, an 18-year American Express veteran, is credited with increasing the growth of the American Express card. Thoman, an Amex executive since 1979, is in charge of the company's traveler's check business and its travel services operations outside North America, among other duties.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS in 5th graf to show 38 percent decline sted 38 percent loss
DOC.HEAD: Union Carbide Announces Major Restructuring Plan
DOC.TEXT: Union Carbide Corp. announced Thursday it would sell some assets and reorganize one of its principle subsidiaries under a restructuring plan expected to produce $600 million in after-tax proceeds. The plan calls for the Danbury-based company to sell up to half the equity in one subsidiary, while selling off its interest in two businesses and restructuring its industrial gases business. It also includes buying back up to 14 percent of its common stock. About half of the $600 million in proceeds will be used to reduce the company's staggering debt, which totaled $3.25 billion at the end of the second quarter, said Thomas F. Sprick, spokesman for Union Carbide. In trading Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange, Union Carbide stock closed up 62{ cents at $14.87{. One analyst said the plan was a step in the right direction, but wouldn't change the fortunes of Union Carbide, which suffered a 38 percent decline in second-quarter earnings. ``This is good, but it could have been better. It could have been a lot better,'' said Harvey S. Stober, a chemical analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York. ``They should joint venture their industrial gas corporation with a strong industrial gas producer in Europe. ... That is the jewel in this company.'' Under the plan, Union Carbide would sell up to 50 percent of the equity in its UCAR Carbon Company Inc. subsidiary, a major supplier of carbon and graphite electrodes to the steel industry. The sale is expected to result in a one-time after-tax book loss of up to $90 million, said Robert D. Kennedy, Carbide's chairman and chief executive officer. UCAR's sales last year totaled $802 million. The book loss from the UCAR sale will be offset by an expected $40 million profit from the sale of Union Carbide's interest in two companies, he said. Plans call for Union Carbide to sell off its 50 percent interest in KEMET Electronics Corp., which supplies capacitors, and Lincare Inc., a home oxygen and respiratory care supplier. The company did not disclose the expected selling prices. The restructuring also calls for Union Carbide to form five independent regional companies within its packaged gases subsidiary, Union Carbide Industrial Gas Company Inc. The companies will be formed after certain assets and businesses valued at approximately $55 million are divested, Kennedy said. Other businesses will also be added, he said. Domestic sales of packaged gases last year totaled $300 million. Union Carbide will also repurchase 20 million shares of common stock, about 14 percent of its total common outstanding, through a tender offer, Kennedy said. An employee stock ownership plan is also part of the restructuring, allowing workers to become majority owners of the new industrial gases companies, Kennedy said. The employee stock ownership plan will be funded through an independently managed trust that will borrow $325 million to purchase shares of a new issue of convertible preferred stock from Union Carbide. Kennedy said the restructuring plan is designed to establish Union Carbide as a leading global chemical company, focused on being the low-cost preferred supplier for its industries.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Tumbles With Silver and Platinum
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices reversed a three-day trend and tumbled Thursday despite modest gains in crude oil prices as speculators began to re-establish gold's traditional role in the market. On other commodity markets, silver and platinum extended their losses; energy futures rose slightly; wheat and soybean futures were mostly higher; meat futures were higher; and corn was lower. Gold continued to rise this week despite the fact that silver and platinum - which the gold market usually follows - plummeted to their lowest levels in years. Gold settled $1.90 to $2.20 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in September at $405.00 a troy ounce. Silver and platinum extended their losses following weak economic activity in the United States, analysts said. Platinum settled on the New York Mercantile Exchange $10.70 to $11.60 lower with October at $437.30 a troy ounce. Silver fell 3 cents to 2.7 cents on the Commodity Exchange with October at $4.771 an ounce. Gold's downturn Thursday could signal that speculators are getting over fears of war in the Middle East and are looking more toward inflation and a possible recession, where they would be more inclined to hoard their money, analysts said. ``Gold has been trading on the emotion of the market and has always been an emotional safe haven for people in times of distress,'' said Nina Lipton, vice president of Platinum Guild International in New York. ``I think the market is acting on impressions, not reality.'' On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat, soybean and corn futures had an unremarkable day of trading. Wheat futures prices extended Wednesday's gains after the Agriculture Department confirmed reports that it has offered to sell subsidized flour to the Soviet Union, Morocco and other West African countries. Soybean futures prices followed wheat's lead after the USDA also reported the Soviet Union might be interested in buying soybean meal, said Walter Spilka, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York. Corn futures prices were mostly lower in thin, quiet trading after morning weather reports predicted near-ideal harvest weather over the next week. Such good weather hold prices lower because there is no fear of shortages. The USDA grain stocks report also was a factor in the thin trading, some analysts said. But Spilka said after the report's release at the close of trading that it should have little effect on Friday's market. ``In the past, the numbers have been all over the map,'' he said. ``I wouldn't place great emphasis on the report having much influence.'' Soybeans, which analysts estimated would average 249 million bushels, came in at 239 million; corn, estimated at 1.34 billion bushels, came in at 1.34 billion; and wheat, estimated at 2.469 billion bushels, came in the low end of trade expectations at 2.402 billion bushels. The numbers represent the government's estimate on the stockpile of grains as of Sept. 1. Wheat settled { cent to 1{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.77{ a bushel; corn was } cent lower to 1\ cents higher with December at $2.27{ a bushel; oats were 1 cent lower to 1} cents higher with December at $1.16 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 5 cents higher with November at $6.19\ a bushel. Meat futures rebounded after three days of losses amid optimism that a federal budget agreement could be reached by Monday. House Speaker Thomas Foley made that announcement early in the day, which relieved fears that a budget impasse would trigger spending cuts and shut down the U.S. packing industry. Live cattle were .08 cent to .55 cent higher with October at 79 cents a pound; feeder cattle was .05 cent lower to .73 cent higher with September at 89.35 cents a pound; hogs were .40 cent lower to .13 cent higher with October at 53.85 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .55 cent to 1.50 cents higher with February at 57.37 cents a pound. Energy futures continued to rise despite President Bush's announcement that 5 million gallons of the nation's oil reserves would be sold. Light sweet crude oil settled 36 cents to $1.05 higher with November at $39.54 a barrel; heating oil was 1.26 cents to 1.80 cents higher with October at $1.0437 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.85 cents to 2.59 cents higher with October at $1.0269 a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Rubber Workers Oust Union Chief
DOC.TEXT: Milan Stone, president of the United Rubber Workers, was ousted from control of the 110,000-member union Thursday in an election upset that also will cost him his job as a vice president of the parent AFL-CIO. Stone, who had headed the Akron, Ohio-based union since 1981, was rebuffed by a nearly 2-to-1 margin. Delegates meeting for a convention in Florida instead favored Ken Coss, who had been Stone's No. 2 man as the union's secretary-treasurer. Stone's loss means he eventually will have to relinquish his influential post as one of 34 vice presidents of the 14.2 million-member AFL-CIO. He does not have to step down from the labor federation's executive council until his current term expires in November 1991, but other vice presidents who have been evicted from power by their own union often resign sooner. Coss had run on a pledge to make the union more active and progressive, while Stone's backers had pushed him as an experienced leader who had kept the union together during plant closings. Since 1975, union membership has fallen by about 60,000.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Was `Go-Between' on Silverado Credit Line
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th, ``The Smith ...' to CLARIFY explanation; also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's son Neil testified Thursday he was a ``go-between'' for a controversial line of credit extended by the failed thrift where he was a director. But he insisted his actions involved no conflict. Bush was testy at times as he testified on the third day of a hearing on the government's conflict-of-interest allegations against him. Bush, 35, was a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, which collapsed in 1988 at an estimated cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. The Office of Thrift Supervision brought the action against Bush, which could lead to his being barred from the banking industry. The OTS alleges that Bush failed to adequately inform fellow Silverado directors of his business ties with developers Kenneth Good and Bill Walters, who eventually defaulted on more than $132 million in Silverado loans. Last week, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. sued Bush and other former Silverado directors for $200 million, alleging that gross negligence on their part contributed to the S&L's collapse. Bush told Administrative Law Judge Daniel J. Davidson he ``had absolutely no doubt'' his dealings with Good and Walters did not conflict with his role as a Silverado director. Consequently, Bush said, he did not consult with Silverado's management about the question of a potential conflict. Bush insisted several times that, although Good and Walters invested in his oil company, JNB Exploration, he had no financial interest in the projects for which they got loans from Silverado. Previous testimony, however, showed that Silverado extended a $900,000 line of credit to a partnership formed by Bush and Good to explore for oil and gas in Argentina. The line of credit, intended to convince Argentine officials that the venture had strong financial resources, never was used. Under questioning from a government attorney, Bush said lawyers for Good's company suggested that Bush present the credit line proposal to Silverado's board. ``I was a go-between,'' Bush said. Bush maintained there was no conflict in his role because he didn't stand to gain any financial benefit from the credit line, which he described as a sort of ``letter of referral,'' and because he abstained from voting on the proposal. Pressed by OTS attorney Stephen Hershkowitz, however, Bush later admitted he had hoped the partnership would eventually benefit from the credit line, since it would persuade the Argentine government to permit the venture to drill wells in that country. ``I didn't know if we would (benefit); I hoped that we would,'' he said. Bush also said he couldn't remember if it was his own idea to abstain from voting on the line of credit or if someone suggested it to him. The judge will examine testimony from the hearing and recommend what sanctions, if any, should be taken against the president's son. Bush also said he used what he obliquely called ``the Smith smell test'' to evaluate a $150,000 investment by Walters in Bush's oil company. ``If it smelled - if my name was Mr. Smith, would they be coming to me for an investment? And, you know, that would be the test,'' he said. The company used the money to help finance an oil-drilling venture in Wyoming in the mid-1980s that never made a profit. Bush told Davidson that under his ``test,'' he would automatically reject any proposal that he deemed politically motivated. ``I gave him a very good deal,'' Bush said of Walters. ``It was a very strong economic deal for him, and had we been successful, he would have made a lot of money.'' Bush said several times he could not recall whether he had discussions with fellow Silverado directors about the specifics of his dealings with Good and Walters. ``That was five years ago,'' Bush said. ``I don't recall the specific discussions, but the discussions took place or there wouldn't have been a general awareness.'' At several points, Davidson warned Bush to answer questions directly and not to interrupt Hershkowitz. ``I'm sorry,'' Bush told the judge. ``My lawyer advised me that I should listen. I'm sorry.'' The judge told Bush to be patient. ``You're not going to be fooled or tricked by anyone as far as I'm concerned,'' Davidson said. Also testifying was Florian Barth, another former Silverado director who on Tuesday had refused to do so. Barth said Thursday he was not aware of Bush's specific business ties with Good and Walters, although he knew about the relationships. ``There might have been more discussion taking place if we had known certain things,'' Barth said. ``Knowing more about the facts might have made a difference.''

DOC.HEAD: Bank Of Boston Says It Will Cut Dividend, Report Loss
DOC.TEXT: Bank of Boston Corp. said Thursday it expects to report a loss of at least $200 million this quarter as it announced plans to slash its quarterly dividend by two-thirds and cut its staff by 1,500 employees. Bank of Boston joined a growing list of banks that are reducing payments to stockholders and curtailing expenses in the wake of a declining economy and troubles with real estate loans. Ira Stepanian, Bank of Boston's chairman and chief executive officer, said the moves are necessary to conserve the institution's capital base. ``We are taking decisive and admittedly painful actions,'' Stepanian said. He said the bank expects to show a loss after taxes of $200 to $250 million this quarter, which ends Sunday, resulting in red ink of up to $200 million for the first nine months of the year. The dividend cut, to 10 cents a share from 31 cents, is expected to conserve about $43 million yearly. The bank said the expected loss stems from several factors, including additions to loan loss reserves of $150 million to $200 million; an expected writeoff of bad loans totaling $175 million, chiefly on real estate; and $50 million in charges related to the staff reductions and other cutbacks. Bank of Boston is a regional bank holding company with assets of $37 billion. It owns banks in Massachusetts, Maine, Connecticut, Rhode Island and Vermont. Stepanian said the staff reduction will begin immediately with a voluntary plan that offers benefits for employees wishing to leave. Stepanian said the bank is still expanding its retail operations and increasing its marketing efforts. James E. Moynihan Jr., an analyst with the investment firm Advest Inc. in Boston, said the announcement was expected. ``The market place had discounted this news long ago. This stock value has been cut in half for the last six weeks,'' he said. But, Moynihan added, ``The news really isn't quite as bad as it had been thought.'' Bank of Boston's stock fell 37{ cents a share to close at $7.12{ in consolidated New York Stock Exchange trading Thursday. Also Thursday, Bank of New England-West, based in Springfield, laid off 201 of its 1,125 employees as part of a plan to cut its work force by about 30 percent before the end of the year. The bank also announced plans to sell four branches and consolidate 11 branch offices. The moves are part of a recovery plan by the bank's troubled parent, Bank of New England Corp. of Boston Stock prices of other banks also fell Thursday. Industry analysts attributed it to a spate of bad news recently by a number of banks. On Wednesday, NCNB Corp., based in Charlotte, N.C., said it would report sharply lower earnings this quarter and increase its reserves for potentially bad loans. Last week, Chase Manhattan Corp., the nation's second-largest bank, said it also expected a quarterly loss and would cut its dividend in half.

DOC.HEAD: California Investor Makes New Offer for United's Employee Buyout Plan
DOC.TEXT: A year after failing to takeover UAL Corp., California billionaire Marvin Davis suggested he should buy the parent of United Airlines and give employees an opportunity to buy him out in two years, officials said Thursday. ``We propose to effectively bridge the acquisition of UAL for its labor and employee groups for a period of two years,'' Davis said in a letter to the United Employee Acquisition Corp. The employee group, which faces an Oct. 9 deadline for financing its own buyout plan, said it doesn't expect to need the help. In a letter dated Wednesday, Davis proposed negotiating a merger with UAL in which employees would receive 20 percent ownership of the company and agree to union contract concessions amounting to comparable value. The employees would have the option to buy Davis' controlling position in UAL after two years, Davis said. ``We believe we have found a solution which both facilitates labor's acquisition of UAL and provides stockholders fair value for their investment,'' he said in the letter to Gerald Greenwald, chief executive officer of the employee-led buyout group. Davis did not suggest a purchase price in the letter. The pilots, flight attendants and machinists unions have offered $201 a share, or $4.38 billion, for UAL. The company directors accepted the offer, but the employee group has had trouble coming up with the financing. The employee group failed to meet a deadline in August and was given a two-month extension by the directors. The board said then that if the financing was not in place by Oct. 9 the deal would be off. Greenwald said in a statement released Thursday in New York that the employees expected to be able to pull off their acquisition without Davis. ``UEAC is optimistic that it will be able to finance and complete a proposal of its own,'' Greenwald said. ``... Accordingly, we do not expect any action will be taken on the proposal contained in Mr. Davis' letter.'' In August 1989 Davis offered $5.4 billion, or $240 a share, for UAL and later upped the bid to $6.19 billion or $275 a share. A month later, the corporation's directors accepted a bid of 6.75 billion, or $300 a share - plus employee concessions - in a deal with United's pilots, management and British Airways PLC. The next day Davis offered to match that bid with no demand for concessions. A month after that, the employee takeover planned collapsed for lack of financing, and Davis withdrew his matching bid. The latest employee offer was devised in the spring and accepted by the board April 6.

DOC.HEAD: Unisys Suspends Dividend
DOC.TEXT: Unisys Corp. on Thursday decided to suspend its common stock dividend, choosing to pay off debt with the $40 million normally paid to shareholders each quarter. The announcement sent Unisys stock to a new low for the year of $5.37{ a share, down 23 percent, on the New York Stock Exchange. Company officials said suspending the dividend would ultimately benefit shareholders by helping improve the overall financial structure of the company. ``This was the best way to accelerate our progress in improving the capital structure,'' company spokesman Peter Hynes said after the board of directors meeting in Detroit. Unisys, based in nearby Blue Bell, owed $3.6 billion on June 30, down from a peak $4.1 billion in the middle of 1989, Hynes said. The computer company reported a $639 million loss last year. Hynes said debt was cut $325 million in the first six months of this year, and the company's goal was to reduce it by $600 million to $800 million in 1990. The company showed meager profits for the first part of the year, but they were not enough to cover payment of preferred dividends. The poor performance prompted Standard & Poor's Corp. to drop its rating on Unisys' debt and preferred stock to just one notch above junk-bond status. The second-quarter profit of $11.8 million became a $15.1 million loss after dividends on preferred stock were paid. These dividends were not affected by Thursday's decision. The third quarter ends Sunday, and the projections are not good. ``All we can say is we project a loss and a profit in fourth,'' Hynes said. James A. Unruh, Unisys president and chief executive officer, said a poor economic climate influenced the board's decision. ``The conclusion was that this is simply not an appropriate point in the company's history to pay high dividends,'' Unruh said in a prepared statement. Unisys has made no decision about when the annual $1 common stock dividend will be restored, Hynes said. The company will wait for ``better profitability, a lower debt'' and an upturn in the sluggish economy, he said. Hynes said the quarterly dividend has been 25 cents a share at a cost of $40 million. Other steps toward debt reduction include the sales of real estate and ``non-strategic'' businesses, Hynes said. Last week, Unisys unveiled a computer line aimed at upgrading mini-computers made by its stiffest competition, IBM Corp. Mini-computers fall midway between personal computers and large mainframes and can support several users at one time. The announcement was unusual in that IBM and Unisys make computers that are not designed to be mixed and matched with the equipment of other companies.

DOC.HEAD: State Air Board Considers Sweeping Fuel-Vehicle Rules to Clean Air
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 5th graf, `It would...' to UPDATE with New York adopting California standards. Picks up 7th graf, `With filthy...'; also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A state board heard last-minute support and objections Thursday to a sweeping anti-smog plan that would force production of low-emission vehicles and distribution of cleaner fuels. The core of the plan is: A vehicle and its fuel are one system in regard to exhaust emissions. Therefore, reducing emissions demands changes in both. The California Air Resources Board will vote on the plan Friday. The plan seeks to overcome the Catch-22 of building alternative-fuel cars when the fuel is unavailable, or marketing cleaner-burning fuels when there are no cars to use those fuels. It would also require fuel companies to distribute a certain amount of alternative fuel to ensure availability. Meanwhile Thursday, New York's Environmental Board adopted auto emission and durability standards equal to California's, the nation's strictest. The new regulations, which take effect in the 1993 model year, are expected to be adopted by 1995 in seven other northeastern states. They require mandatory inspection of exhaust emissions and assembly-line testing and prohibit the sale of replacement parts that do not meet emission standards. Among the cleaner-burning fuels being considered in the even stricter California proposal are methanol, ethanol, liquefied natural gas and compressed natural gas. Cars powered by electricity are also a possibility. With filthy air hanging over California cities and roads jammed with 22 million cars, opponents are careful not to criticize the entire proposal but to target certain points. Oil companies want the state board to abandon mandatory distribution volume quotas for the new fuels because there is no way to force consumers to buy them. Automakers say they are concerned about the timetable for designing, testing and introducing new vehicles, as well as uncertainty of the technology and the need for marketing incentives. George Babikian, president of Atlantic Richfield Co., urged the board to eliminate mandatory distribution in favor of mandatory ``availability.'' The plan anticipates introduction of flexible-fuel vehicles which run on either gasoline or methnol blends. Given the choice, Babikian contends, a driver will choose gasoline because it is 30 to 40 cents cheaper per gallon. If distribution were mandatory, oil companies would lower the price of methanol to sell it and subsidize the alternative fuel by raising the price of gasoline, he said. The plan would, between 1994 and 2003, require the use of cars that are 50 percent to 84 percent less polluting than those which meet the current strictest standards. The state agency would test the cars' emissions before licensing them. In the first year about 200,000 ``ultra clean'' cars would be required, about 10 percent of annual new car sales in California. By 2003, the regulation would cover all 2 million cars sold annually. The board also would mandate production of so-called zero-emission electric cars starting in 1998. Up to 200,000 electric cars could be in the state by the year 2003, the ARB contends. The board says the plan is expected to reduce emissions of hydrocarbons by 28 percent, or 185 tons per day; nitrogen oxide by 18 percent, or 248 tons per day; and carbon monoxide by 8 percent, or 3.17 tons per day. The plan would take effect in the South Coast Air Basin, which encompasses smoggy Los Angeles, before going statewide. The regulations could be challenged in court. ``Certainly a nation that has the capability of building an airplane that you can't see, a submarine that you can't hear, can get electric cars built to get us to work and back,'' David Friedman, general manager of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, an electrical power utility, said at the hearing. ``If the government can put one on the moon, surely Detroit can put one on the road.'' James Lents, executive officer of the local South Coast Air Quality Management District, hailed the plan as essential to the district. ``We must continually remind ourselves that our 13 million residents breathe the most polluted air in the nation, and it impairs their lifestyle and health,'' Lents told board members.

DOC.HEAD: Bush May Take Compromise on Capital Gains, Republicans Say
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 1 graf for 4th graf, The White, with talks ending for evening; should stand
DOC.TEXT: President Bush may be willing to drop his insistence for a cut in the capital gains tax, Republican congressmen said Wednesday, a demand that has been the major obstacle to a budget deal. But the apparent softening of Bush's position was revealed on a day when Bush and congressional Democrats had their most withering public flare-up over the talks in weeks. The two sides accused each other of endangering their stalled bargaining, just five days before disruptive cuts in government services will be imposed if the negotiations fail. The White House signalled a willingess to consider keeping the current capital gains tax rate - the same as ordinary income - but exempting gains due to inflation. Democrats brushed aside the idea, and after nearly six hours negotiators broke off discussions for the evening at nearly 11:30 p.m. Bush said nothing about his reported change in his capital gains stance as he campaigned for Republican candidates in Ohio. ``The hang-up is with the Democrats,'' he said, accusing them of refusing to do their part to cut the deficit. ``If and when the ax falls, the Democratic Congress knows that it will be held accountable,'' he said. ``And I will take that message to every state in the union. It is their fault.'' He also told reporters while flying to Ohio that Democrats ``have not come forward with a package'' at the talks, a remark that touched off a Democratic uproar. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said Democrats have made several offers in recent bargaining sessions. ``To begin a series of charges or countercharges ... at this stage is not helpful,'' Foley said. ``It is damaging to the talks, though we're determined it not be critically damaging.'' Mitchell said the president must have been ``badly misinformed'' to have made the comment, and called it ``highly misleading and damaging.'' The Foley-Mitchell complaints led Bush to apologize at a later speech in Chicago: ``Earlier today, I said the Democrats have not come forward with a package. They say they have put a package, or at least a series of proposals, on the table in private negotiations. I accept the fact that in private negotiations there have been such proposals. I apologize for misspeaking on that point.'' However, he said, ``We have yet to see a comprehensive plan'' that encmpasses the goals of serious spending cuts, budget process change and incentives for economic growth. Hundreds of unionized federal workers rallied outside the Capitol at noon to demand a quick solution to the budget crisis. They carried signs reading, ``Your furlough begins Nov. 6, Election Day,'' and ``Congress, you do your jobs so we can do ours.'' The rally was organized by the American Federation of Government Employees, which represents 700,000 federal workers. Inside the building, the Senate voted overwhelmingly to apply the spending cuts to the salaries of members of Congress and top executive branch officials, including Vice President Quayle and members of the Cabinet - items now exempt under the Gramm-Rudman budget-cutting law. After a morning meeting at the White House, GOP lawmakers said Bush was signalling compromise. Instead of lowered capital gains tax rates, Bush might accept other items he believes would spur the economy, they said. ``He might be willing to look at other alternatives in the growth area,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the No. 2 House Republican, said the alternatives could include corporate tax breaks designed to encourage research and to prod businesses to operate in ailing urban and rural areas. The developments occurred as negotiators for the White House and Congress were resuming their search for a package of tax increases and spending cuts that could reduce the deficit by $500 billion over five years. Republican bargainers continued to present various offers involving a reduced capital gains tax, which is imposed on profits from the sale of property, said officials who asked to not be identified. One version would tax only the increased value of an asset that exceeds inflation, but Democrats said they wanted ``absolutely nothing to do with capital gains,'' said one official. Hanging over the bargainers was the prospect of $85 billion in potentially disruptive cuts scheduled to take place automatically Monday - reductions that could result in furloughs for as many as 2.1 million federal workers and curtail government programs as diverse as air traffic control to food inspections. If the cuts take effect, affected domestic programs would be slashed by 32.4 percent and defense programs by 35.3 percent. Social Security, the military payroll and many benefits for veterans and low-income people are exempt from the cuts. With no spending legislation in place for the new fiscal year, which starts Monday, the House prepared to decide whether to provide temporary financing for the government. Democratic leaders were ready to delay the vote until Friday or later in hopes of reaching a budget compromise. A vote was also planned on whether to postpone the approaching spending cuts, with Bush vowing to block any delay. ``It is the law of the land, and I took an oath to the Constitution to the land,'' Bush said about the pending cuts. ``We've tried to do our part.'' Participants in the budget talks reported progress in a late night session Tuesday, particularly over the size of cuts in the military and Medicare, which provides health care for the elderly. The talks on a deficit deal have been bogged down for weeks, and participants on both sides have said the president's insistence on a cut in the tax in profits from investments has been a major stumbling block. Democrats have called for an increase in income tax rates for the wealthy to offset any benefits from the cut that Bush wants. The president has been insisting on a capital gains tax cut out of the belief that it would stimulate the economy at a time of economcc slowdown. Many economists believe the country is headed for a recession, if not already in one.

DOC.BYLINE: JUDGMENT DAY: Junk Bond Whiz Nears Sentencing In Wall Street Scandal Case
DOC.TEXT:
NEW YORK - After nearly four years of intense federal inquiries, relentless public scrutiny, a shattered career and a humiliating guilty plea to six felonies for his role in Wall Street's worst scandal, Michael Milken, the prince of junk-bond financing, has neared his judgment day. The fate of the 44-year-old billionaire financier rests with a rookie federal judge only two years older than he, who's under enormous pressure to give him at least some time in prison. Slug BC-Milken. By Business Writer Rick Gladstone. Moving Friday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday Sept. 30.
With BC-Milken-Sentences and BC-Milken-Chronology.
DOC.BYLINE: MIRACLE ON 34TH STREET: Legendary Retailer Ready To Withstand Slump
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - The way skeptics tell it, the modern day R. H. Macy & Co. story wouldn't be fit for a feel-good Hollywood film. The retailer, they say, may need something like divine intervention, if not another miracle on 34th Street, to shoulder a heavy debt burden while losing support from retail revenue. Not so, say executives of the department store chain. They acknowledge that Christmas 1990 won't go down as one of the merrier holidays in history for the industry. But Macy's can survive a consumer spending slump and will prosper again, they say. Slug BC-Macy. By Business Writer Marybeth Nibley. Moved Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 30. With LaserPhoto.
With BC-Macy-Thumbnail.
DOC.BYLINE: THE PIT AND THE PENDULUM: Commodities Trader Fights Federal Charges
DOC.TEXT: CHICAGO - From the boxing ring to the football field to the fray of a commodities trading pit, Ray Pace never has been one to back down. But in the federal courtroom, where he and 13 other traders face charges of fraud and racketeering, Pace fights the feeling that he is already whipped. It's not because he has no hope of winning his case but because he says the cost of his defense has nearly wiped him out. Slug BC-Personal File-Pace. By Business Writer David Dishneau. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 30. With LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: BANKING BULLIES OR BUDDIES?: Foreign Bankers Find Bonanza On U.S. Shores
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - Foreign banks have been setting up shop on U.S. soil in droves, lending money to corporations, investing in government securities, buying loans from other financial institutions, even accepting deposits. In many cases, they've been competing head-on with American-owned banks. Now, as U.S. banks retrench abroad and struggle with a slumping real estate market at home, some critics charge foreign institutions are bullying their U.S. counterparts in a financial free-for-all and should be bound by new controls. Slug BC-Banking Invasion. By Jeff Donn. Moved Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 30. Graphic in AP Access under FEDRESERVE.
DOC.BYLINE: HAVE YOU ANY WOOL?: Farmer Sees Pot of Gold In Cashmere Goats
DOC.TEXT: LEBANON, Conn. - When Peter Sellew told his friends he planned to breed Australian cashmere goats, they thought he was crazy. No one in the state and only a handful of farmers on the East Coast had ever tried to raise cashmere goats. ``Now they call up and say, `How can we get some of those goats?' '' says the former publishing executive-turned farmer. In 18 months, Sellew has built his stock from five imported goats to a herd of nearly 100. This spring, he expects to sell their precious cashmere fleece for up to $45 a pound, compared to about 85 cents a pound for sheep's wool. Slug BC-Cashmere Goats. By Denise Lavoie. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 1. With LaserPhoto HF1 of Sept. 25.
DOC.BYLINE: BUMPER-TO-BUMPER BUSINESS: Upstart Company Offers Products For Commuters
DOC.TEXT: EMERYVILLE, Calif. - Mabel Yee was just another frustrated commuter, stuck in the middle of her stop-and-go crawl to work, when an idea hit her like an antsy driver following too close. ``I thought, `Gosh, there must be some option to just sitting here . . . There must be something to do,' '' she said. More than a year later, Yee has found lots for commuters to do through her company, Commuter Products Corp., which sells everything from massaging car seats to travel desks. Slug BC-Commuter Products. By Catalina Ortiz. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 1. With LaserPhoto FX2 of Sept. 25.
DOC.BYLINE: TANKED UP: Gulf Crisis Revives Brazil's Alcohol Fuel Program
DOC.TEXT: RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil - The Persian Gulf crisis has given new life to Brazil's program to run its vehicles on pure sugar-cane alcohol instead of gasoline. Shortages of the sugar-cane fuel, which has high production costs, and an abundance of inexpensive foreign oil had turned Brazilians off to alcohol. But as oil prices have risen beyond $34 a barrel as a result of Iraq's takeover of Kuwait, critics are taking another look one of the world's leading alternative fuel programs, called Pro-Alcohol here. Slug PM-Brazil-Alternative Fuel. By Peter Muello. Moved Monday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct 1. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: MIDEAST TOURISM:
Saddam Hussein's Shadow Of Fear Hits Egypt Tourism Hard
DOC.TEXT: CAIRO, Egypt - As July ended, Egypt was celebrating a tourism boom with no end in sight. Almost 3 million visitors last year, and officials foresaw visions of at least 5 million by 1995. Egypt finally was returning as an international tourist mecca after years of Middle East uncertainty that had devastated an industry as old as the pyramids. Then, on Aug. 2, Iraq invaded Kuwait. Slug PM-Egypt-Tourism Blues. By Mimi Mann. Moved Monday on FFF-level news wires for Thursday PMs, Sept. 27. With LaserPhoto. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: . . .And Cripples Tourism To Holy Land
DOC.TEXT: JERUSALEM - Most days, Abdel Raouf Abu Assab sits at the door of his souvenir shop in Jerusalem's Old City, smoking his water pipe and waiting for tourists. These days he waits in vain. Although Israel is hundreds of miles from the Persian Gulf, the headlines created by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait have scared away travelers from the Holy Land, government and industry officials say. Slug PM-Israel-Tourism. By Eileen Alt Powell. Moved Monday on FFF-level news wires for Thursday PMs, Sept. 27. With LaserPhoto. Also moved on general news wires.
